Q: What is the mission of the Office of Community Health and Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: To serve marginalized communities, address the needs of vulnerable residents, and make the city safer and more just.


Q: What programs are part of the continuum of support offered by the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: Co-response, People in Need of Support (PINS), and the Trauma Survivor’s Assistance Program (TSAP).


Q: What is the goal of the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program?
A: To reduce criminal-legal system engagement and provide care and support through person-centered social services.


Q: What does the Post Overdose Support Team (POST) do?
A: Responds to overdoses with peer recovery specialists and case managers to provide service connections for long-term recovery.


Q: What is the purpose of the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program?
A: To reduce homelessness and increase access to services by addressing social determinants of health.


Q: Who should be contacted for general inquiries about the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: Devlin Iaquinta at devlin.iaquinta@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: What is the primary mission of the Office of Community Health and Safety (OCH&S) in Pittsburgh?
A: The primary mission of OCH&S is to serve marginalized communities that have been systematically isolated and victimized by an unjust system, aiming to address the needs of those living in poverty, experiencing homelessness, substance use disorder, and mental or behavioral health challenges.


Q: When was the Office of Community Health and Safety announced?
A: The Office of Community Health and Safety was announced in 2020.


Q: What are some of the programs piloted by the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: Programs piloted include co-response, law enforcement assisted diversion, trauma survivor’s assistance, people in need of support, post overdose support team, and reaching out on the streets.


Q: What is the goal of the co-response program?
A: The goal of the co-response program is to provide the “right responders” to individuals experiencing a mental health or behavioral crisis, aiming to reduce violent behavior and involvement in the criminal justice system.


Q: How does the People in Need of Support (PINS) program assist individuals?
A: The PINS program connects city residents who frequently use 9-1-1 services to long-term services and supports, relieving pressure on emergency response systems.


Q: What is the focus of the Trauma Survivors Assistance Program (TSAP)?
A: TSAP focuses on providing emotional support and linking victims of crime and survivors of trauma to appropriate services to stabilize and begin healing.


Q: What does the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program aim to achieve?
A: LEAD aims to provide individuals with substance use disorder and mental health challenges with person-centered social services and intense case management, reducing criminal-legal system engagement.


Q: What is the purpose of the Post Overdose Support Team (POST)?
A: The purpose of POST is to respond to overdoses with peer recovery specialists and case managers to connect individuals to services that can lead to long-term recovery.


Q: What are the components of the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program?
A: ROOTS includes street outreach and drop-in sites to reduce homelessness and increase access to services.


Q: How does the Office of Community Health and Safety plan to engage with the community?
A: The office plans to engage with the community through collaboration, transparency, accountability, and the creation of advisory collaboratives focused on neighborhoods harmed by systemic racism.

Q: What is the purpose of the Co-Response program?
A: The Co-Response program aims to provide the "right responders" to individuals experiencing a mental health or behavioral crisis, reducing violent behavior and criminal justice involvement while increasing safety.


Q: Who are the team members involved in the Co-Response program?
A: The teams consist of a community social worker and a dedicated Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officer.


Q: What is the primary goal of the People in Need of Support (PINS) program?
A: The PINS program aims to identify and refer city residents who frequently utilize 9-1-1 services to meet their basic needs and connect them to long-term services and supports.


Q: What does the Trauma Survivors Assistance Program (TSAP) provide?
A: TSAP provides emotional support and links victims of crime and trauma survivors to appropriate trauma and crisis response services.


Q: What is the focus of the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program?
A: LEAD focuses on providing individuals with substance use disorder and mental and behavioral health challenges with person-centered social services and intense case management, aiming to reduce criminalization.


Q: What is the mission of the Office of Community Health & Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: The mission is to serve marginalized communities and address the needs of those living in poverty, experiencing homelessness, or facing mental and behavioral health challenges.


Q: How does the Post Overdose Support Team (POST) assist individuals?
A: POST responds to overdoses with certified peer recovery specialists and case managers to connect individuals to service connections for long-term recovery.


Q: What are the two components of the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program?
A: ROOTS includes street outreach and drop-in sites to reduce homelessness and increase access to services.


Q: What is the role of community engagement in the Office of Community Health & Safety's efforts?
A: Community engagement is critical for building trust, facilitating change, and ensuring programs serve those in need, especially in historically marginalized communities.

Q: What is the mission of the LEAD program in Pittsburgh?
A: The mission of LEAD in Pittsburgh is to reduce criminal-legal system engagement, promote individual agency, and provide care and support to people who use drugs, people with mental and behavioral health challenges, and people experiencing homelessness through person-centered social services.


Q: What are the primary goals of the Post Overdose Support Team (POST)?
A: The primary goals of POST are to support safety, recovery, and provide service connections to treat substance use and/or co-occurring mental health disorders.


Q: What is the primary focus of the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program?
A: The primary focus of ROOTS is to reduce homelessness by addressing social determinants of health, increasing access to services, and reducing fatal overdoses.


Q: Who should be contacted for general inquiries about the programs mentioned in the text?
A: For general inquiries, contact Devlin Iaquinta at devlin.iaquinta@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the role of the community engagement team in the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: The community engagement team seeks to build relationships and trust between the office and diverse communities in Pittsburgh while leveraging best practices in community outreach and engagement.


Q: What is the purpose of the Co-Response program?
A: The Co-Response program aims to provide the "right responders" to individuals experiencing mental health or behavioral crises, reducing the propensity for violent behavior and criminal justice involvement.


Q: What does the People in Need of Support (PINS) program do?
A: The PINS program identifies and refers residents who frequently use 9-1-1 services to meet basic needs, connecting them to services to relieve pressure on emergency response systems.


Q: What is the Trauma Survivors Assistance Program (TSAP)?
A: TSAP is a program that provides emotional support and links victims of crime and trauma survivors to appropriate services to stabilize and begin healing.


Q: How does the Office of Community Health and Safety aim to address community needs?
A: The office aims to address community needs through collaboration with first responders, service gap analysis, and developing partnerships to improve the continuum of resources and responses.

Q: What is the main focus of the Office of Community Health and Safety's initial efforts?
A: The initial efforts focus on creating multiple advisory collaboratives focused on Black neighborhoods most harmed by the war on drugs and systemic racism.


Q: What is the mission of the Office of Community Health and Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: The mission is to serve marginalized communities that have been systematically isolated from society and victimized by an unjust system, addressing the needs of those living in poverty, experiencing homelessness, substance use disorder, and mental or behavioral health challenges.


Q: What are some of the programs piloted by the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: The programs include co-response, law enforcement assisted diversion, trauma survivor’s assistance, people in need of support, post overdose support team, and reaching out on the streets.


Q: When was the Office of Community Health and Safety announced?
A: The office was announced in 2020.


Q: What is the purpose of the co-response program?
A: The co-response program aims to provide the right responders to individuals experiencing a mental health or behavioral crisis, reducing the propensity for violent behavior and involvement in the criminal justice system.


Q: How does the People in Need of Support (PINS) program operate?
A: The PINS program involves first responders identifying and referring city residents who frequently utilize 9-1-1 services to meet basic needs, with community social workers and public safety liaisons conducting home visits to assess health and social needs.


Q: What is the goal of the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program?
A: The goal of LEAD is to provide individuals with intense case management focused on harm reduction and compassion in lieu of criminalization, addressing needs related to poverty, homelessness, substance use disorder, and mental and behavioral health challenges.


Q: What does the Post Overdose Support Team (POST) do?
A: The POST responds to overdoses with teams of certified peer recovery specialists and case managers to provide service connections and support for long-term recovery.


Q: What is the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program's aim?
A: ROOTS aims to reduce the prevalence of homelessness by addressing social determinants of health and increasing access to services through street outreach and drop-in sites.


Q: How does the Trauma Survivors Assistance Program (TSAP) support individuals?
A: TSAP provides emotional support and links victims of crime and trauma survivors to appropriate services, offering community trauma response following instances of violence.


Q: Who can be contacted for general inquiries about the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: General inquiries can be directed to Devlin Iaquinta at devlin.iaquinta@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: What is the primary goal of the Office of Community Health & Safety (OCH&S) in Pittsburgh?
A: The primary goal of OCH&S is to make Pittsburgh a safer, healthier, and more equitable city by addressing community unmet social service needs and supporting marginalized communities.


Q: What is the Co-Response program?
A: The Co-Response program involves teams of a community social worker and a Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officer responding to individuals in mental health or behavioral crisis to reduce violent behavior and criminal justice involvement.


Q: What does the People in Need of Support (PINS) program do?
A: The PINS program identifies and refers city residents who frequently use 911 services for basic needs, and connects them to long-term services and resources to relieve pressure on emergency response systems.


Q: What is the purpose of the Trauma Survivors Assistance Program (TSAP)?
A: TSAP provides emotional support and links victims of crime and trauma survivors to appropriate services to stabilize them and begin the healing process.


Q: What is the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program's mission in Pittsburgh?
A: LEAD aims to reduce criminal-legal system engagement, promote individual agency, and provide care and support through person-centered social services, combating racial and ethnic disparities in the criminal-legal system.


Q: What does the Post Overdose Support Team (POST) do?
A: POST responds to overdoses with peer recovery specialists and case managers to connect individuals to long-term recovery services and support after an overdose.


Q: What is the focus of the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program?
A: ROOTS aims to reduce homelessness by addressing social determinants of health, increasing access to services, and reducing fatal overdoses through street outreach and drop-in sites.


Q: How does the Office of Community Health & Safety plan to improve the continuum of support?
A: By collaborating with first responders and community members, analyzing service calls, mapping existing services, developing new partnerships, and evaluating models to address unmet social service needs.


Q: What is the role of community engagement in OCH&S's mission?
A: Community engagement is critical for building trust, facilitating change, and ensuring transparency and accountability to the community and first responders.


Q: How does the Office of Community Health & Safety support individuals experiencing homelessness or substance use disorder?
A: Through programs like LEAD, POST, and ROOTS, which provide person-centered social services, harm reduction, and connections to long-term support and resources.

Q: What is the purpose of the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program in Pittsburgh?
A: LEAD aims to reduce criminal-legal system engagement, promote individual agency, and provide care and support to people with substance use disorders, mental and behavioral health challenges, and homelessness through person-centered social services.


Q: What are the primary goals of the Post Overdose Support Team (POST)?
A: The primary goals of POST are to support safety, recovery, and provide service connections that aim to treat substance use and/or co-occurring mental health disorders.


Q: What is the mission of the Office of Community Health and Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: The mission is to serve marginalized communities that have been systematically isolated and victimized by an unjust system, addressing needs related to poverty, homelessness, substance use disorder, and mental or behavioral health challenges.


Q: How does the Co-Response program operate in Pittsburgh?
A: The Co-Response program involves teams of a community social worker and a dedicated police officer dispatched to co-respond to individuals in mental health or behavioral crises, aiming to reduce violent behavior and criminal justice involvement.


Q: What is the focus of the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program?
A: ROOTS focuses on reducing homelessness by addressing social determinants of health, increasing access to services, reducing criminal legal interactions, and reducing fatal overdoses.


Q: What does the Trauma Survivors Assistance Program (TSAP) provide?
A: TSAP provides emotional support and links victims of crime and trauma survivors to appropriate trauma and crisis response services to stabilize them and begin the healing process.

A: Devlin Iaquinta can be contacted for general inquiries at devlin.iaquinta@pittsburghpa.gov.

A: PINS aims to connect frequent 9-1-1 service users to long-term services and supports, relieving pressure on emergency response systems.


Q: How does the Office of Community Health and Safety plan to improve the continuum of support?
A: By collaborating with first responders and community members, analyzing service calls, mapping existing services, developing new partnerships, and evaluating existing models.

A: The two components are street outreach and drop-in sites.

Q: What is the function of interdisciplinary zone teams in the ROOTS program?
A: To coordinate participant care and adapt to complex needs like human services, drug and alcohol treatment, and more.


Q: What is the goal of the Co-Response program?
A: To provide the "right responders" for individuals experiencing a mental health or behavioral crisis, reducing the use of force and increasing safety.


Q: Who should be contacted for general inquiries about the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: Devlin Iaquinta at devlin.iaquinta@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is a key focus of OCH&S in terms of community engagement?
A: Partnering with existing community organizations and prioritizing community members harmed by systemic issues.

Q: What is the primary mission of the Office of Community Health & Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: The primary mission is to serve marginalized communities that have been systematically isolated from society and victimized by an unjust system, addressing needs related to poverty, homelessness, substance use disorder, and mental or behavioral health challenges.


Q: When was the Office of Community Health & Safety announced?
A: The Office of Community Health & Safety was announced in 2020.


Q: What programs have been piloted by the Office of Community Health & Safety?
A: Programs include Co-response, Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion, Trauma Survivor’s Assistance, People in Need of Support, Post Overdose Support Team, and Reaching Out on the Streets.


Q: How does the Co-response program operate?
A: The Co-response program involves teams of a community social worker and a Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officer co-responding to individuals experiencing mental health or behavioral crises.


Q: What is the goal of the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program?
A: LEAD aims to reduce criminal-legal system engagement, promote individual agency, and provide care and support through person-centered social services, focusing on harm reduction and compassion instead of criminalization.


Q: What is the purpose of the Post Overdose Support Team (POST)?
A: The purpose is to respond to overdoses with certified peer recovery specialists and case managers to connect individuals to services that can lead to long-term recovery.


Q: Who are the partners of the Office of Community Health & Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: Partners include the Pittsburgh Bureaus of Police, Fire, and Emergency Medical Services.


Q: What is the focus of the Trauma Survivors Assistance Program (TSAP)?
A: TSAP focuses on providing emotional support and linking victims of crime and survivors of trauma to appropriate trauma and crisis response services.


Q: How does the People in Need of Support (PINS) program assist residents?
A: PINS assists by identifying and referring residents who frequently use 911 services, conducting home visits, and linking them to services and resources.


Q: What is the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program's aim?
A: ROOTS aims to reduce homelessness by addressing social determinants of health and increasing access to services, reducing fatal overdoses and criminal legal interactions.


Q: How does the Office of Community Health & Safety fund its programs?
A: The office funds its programs through state and federal grants, including federal funding mechanisms for specific programs like the Post Overdose Support Team and Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion.

Q: What is the goal of the co-response program?
A: The goal of the co-response program is to provide the "right responders" to individuals experiencing a mental health or behavioral crisis, reduce violent behavior, and increase safety for both officers and community members.


Q: What training supports the co-response program?
A: The co-response program is supported by training co-response officers on Crisis Response Intervention Training (CRIT), a national best-practice model by the Department of Justice.


Q: What is the purpose of the People in Need of Support (PINS) program?
A: The PINS program aims to identify and refer city residents who frequently utilize 9-1-1 services, assess their needs, and connect them to long-term services to relieve pressure on emergency response systems.


Q: How does the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program aim to address criminal justice reform?
A: LEAD aims to reduce criminal-legal system engagement, promote individual agency, and provide care through person-centered social services, focusing on harm reduction and compassion instead of criminalization.


Q: What is the Trauma Survivors Assistance Program (TSAP)?
A: TSAP is a partnership providing emotional support and linking crime victims and trauma survivors to appropriate services, including community trauma response after violent incidents.


Q: What is the role of the Post Overdose Support Team (POST)?
A: POST responds to overdoses with peer recovery specialists and case managers to provide service connections for long-term recovery and support safety and recovery after overdoses.


Q: What is the objective of the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program?
A: ROOTS aims to reduce homelessness by addressing social determinants of health, opening opportunities for personal agency, and reducing criminal legal interactions and overdoses.


Q: How does the Office of Community Health & Safety (OCH&S) plan to improve the continuum of support?
A: OCH&S plans to improve the continuum of support through collaboration with first responders, service mapping, partnership development, and evaluating existing models to address unmet social service needs.

Q: What is the Trauma Survivors Assistance Program (TSAP)?
A: TSAP is a partnership between the Office of Community Health & Safety (OCHS) and the three bureaus of public safety, providing emotional support and linking trauma survivors to crisis response services.


Q: What does the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program aim to achieve?
A: LEAD aims to reduce criminal-legal system engagement, promote individual agency, and provide care and support through person-centered social services, focusing on harm reduction and compassion.


Q: Where is the LEAD program currently operating?
A: The LEAD program is currently operating in zones 1 and 2 and plans to expand to other zones.


Q: What is the primary goal of the Post Overdose Support Team (POST)?
A: The primary goal of POST is to support safety and recovery, providing service connections to treat substance use and co-occurring mental health disorders.


Q: What are the two components of the Reaching Out on the Streets (ROOTS) program?
A: The two components of ROOTS are street outreach and drop-in sites.


Q: Who should be contacted for more information about the LEAD program?
A: Stephen Gress, the LEAD program manager, at stephen.gress@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the mission of the Office of Community Health and Safety's community engagement team?
A: Their mission is to build relationships and trust between the office and diverse communities in Pittsburgh, enhancing quality of life, safety, and security through partnership.


Q: What is the focus of the Office of Community Health & Safety in terms of community engagement?
A: The focus is on building trust, facilitating change, and addressing the needs of communities most harmed by systemic issues, like the war on drugs and systemic racism.

Q: What is the focus of the initial efforts by the Office of Community Health and Safety (OCH&S)?
A: The initial efforts focus on creating multiple advisory collaboratives focused on Black neighborhoods most harmed by the war on drugs and systemic racism.


Q: Who should be contacted for community partnership inquiries at OCH&S?
A: Malaysia Smith, the Community Partnership Specialist, should be contacted at malaysia.smith@pittsburghpa.gov.

A: The mission is to build relationships and trust between the office and diverse communities in Pittsburgh, enhancing the quality of life, safety, and security through community partnerships.


Q: What resources does the Urban Redevelopment Authority of Pittsburgh provide during COVID-19?
A: The URA partners with the city and the Urban League of Greater Pittsburgh to provide short-term rent/mortgage/utility financial assistance to city residents.


Q: What hotline is available for 24-hour mental health crisis support?
A: The Resolve Crisis Network provides 24-hour help at 1-888-7-YOU-CAN (796-8226).


Q: What organization provides crisis intervention and suicide prevention for LGBTQ youth under 25?
A: The Trevor Project provides crisis intervention and suicide prevention services to LGBTQ youth under 25.


Q: How can veterans access food resources in Pittsburgh?
A: Veterans can connect with food resources by calling the Veteran Leadership Project at 412-481-8200.


Q: What is the purpose of the BigBurgh mobile app?
A: The BigBurgh mobile app helps neighbors without homes by providing resources and support.


Q: Where can individuals find free financial counseling in Pittsburgh?
A: The Pittsburgh Financial Empowerment Center offers free one-on-one financial counseling for area residents over 18.

A: The agency provides assistance for homeowners and renters to access assistance through the CARES Act.

A: The Persad Center aims to improve the well-being of LGBTQ communities and the HIV/AIDS communities.

A: The American Foundation for Suicide Prevention hotline is 1-800-273-8255.

A: Naloxone is available at local pharmacies per state order and can be mailed from the PA Harm Reduction Coalition.

A: The current Roots sites are located in the Northside, Downtown, and East Liberty, respectively in police zones 1, 2, and 5.


Q: What is the role of the Community Social Worker?
A: The Community Social Worker works with a team to identify and support individuals whose needs are not met by the traditional public safety response paradigm, focusing on addressing barriers to consistent care, resources, and treatment.


Q: What is the purpose of the Post Overdose Support Team (POST)?
A: The POST is designed to provide supports to individuals who have experienced an overdose and refused medical care, focusing on harm reduction and compassion to reduce the likelihood of another overdose and improve quality of life.


Q: What services does the Victim Assistance Specialist provide?
A: The Victim Assistance Specialist provides direct support to community members who are victims of intimate partner violence, other categories of violent crime, and instances of trauma and grief.


Q: What is the goal of the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) initiative?
A: The goal of the LEAD initiative is to provide people with substance use disorder and mental and behavioral health challenges with person-centered social services and intense case management to reduce legal recidivism and improve quality of life.


Q: What is the responsibility of the LEAD Team Lead?
A: The LEAD Team Lead is responsible for the daily supervision of LEAD case managers, facilitating the review of referrals from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, and collaborating with the LEAD Program Manager and other Office of Community Health and Safety leadership in project development.


Q: What is the role of the Co-Response Clinician?
A: The Co-Response Clinician is a master's-level position that works alongside Pittsburgh Bureau of Police personnel to provide crisis intervention and support during emergent calls for service, bridging public health and public safety.

A: Camila Alarcon-Chelecki, Assistant Director, Department of Public Safety, Office of Community Health and Safety, can be contacted at ochspgh@pittsburghpa.gov.

A: To build relationships and trust with diverse communities and enhance the quality of life, safety, and security through community outreach and engagement initiatives.

A: The team seeks to build relationships and trust between the office and diverse communities in Pittsburgh by developing programs and initiatives in partnership with the community to enhance quality of life, safety, and security.


Q: How many Narcan kits has the Office of Community Health & Safety distributed?
A: Over 150 Narcan kits have been distributed.


Q: How can someone obtain Narcan from the Office of Community Health & Safety?
A: Interested individuals can reach out to ochspgh@pittsburghpa.gov to obtain Narcan.


Q: What items have been distributed by the Office of Community Health & Safety to contribute to community safety?
A: Over 150 Narcan kits, 300 fentanyl test strips, and 100-gun safety locks have been distributed.


Q: How can community members invite the Office of Community Health & Safety to a meeting or event?
A: They can send staff meeting invites or questions to ochspgh@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the purpose of the health and safety resource fairs hosted by the Office of Community Health & Safety?
A: The fairs are meant to engage with community members, local businesses, and frontline workers to provide education about harm reduction.


Q: What is the email address to contact the Office of Community Health & Safety for community engagement inquiries?
A: The email address is ochspgh@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: What is the mission of the engagement team in Pittsburgh?
A: The mission is to build relationships and trust between the office and diverse communities in Pittsburgh, leveraging best practices in community outreach and engagement.


Q: What initiatives does the community engagement team participate in?
A: The team attends harm reduction resource pop-ups and collaborates with council members to host health and safety resource fairs.


Q: How many Narcan kits, fentanyl test strips, and gun safety locks have been distributed?
A: Over 150 Narcan kits, 300 fentanyl test strips, and 100-gun safety locks have been distributed.


Q: How can someone obtain Narcan in Pittsburgh?
A: Narcan can be obtained by reaching out to ochspgh@pittsburghpa.gov or from Prevention Point Pittsburgh free of charge.


Q: What is the purpose of fentanyl test strips?
A: Fentanyl test strips are used to detect the presence of fentanyl in substances to prevent opioid overdoses.


Q: What is the Never Use Alone hotline?
A: It is a hotline where an operator stays on the line with someone using drugs alone to ensure their safety and notify emergency services if needed.


Q: What legal protection does Pennsylvania Act 139 provide?
A: It provides legal protection for the person experiencing an overdose and the caller, provided they stay with the victim.


Q: How can someone contact the Office of Community Health and Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: They can be contacted at ochspgh@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the main risk associated with fentanyl?
A: Fentanyl is an extremely potent opioid that can quickly stop breathing and cause an opioid overdose, leading to death.


Q: What are some safe practices when using drugs to reduce overdose risk?
A: Safe practices include calling 9-1-1, having Narcan on hand, using fentanyl test strips, not using drugs alone, and starting with a small amount.


Q: Where can sterile syringes be obtained in Pittsburgh?
A: Sterile syringes are provided by Prevention Point Pittsburgh at no cost.

Q: What is fentanyl and why is it dangerous?
A: Fentanyl is an extremely potent opioid that can quickly stop breathing and cause an opioid overdose, which can lead to death.


Q: What can fentanyl test strips detect?
A: Fentanyl test strips can detect the presence of fentanyl in drugs.


Q: Where can you obtain fentanyl test strips at no cost in Pittsburgh?
A: Fentanyl test strips are provided by Prevention Point Pittsburgh at no cost.


Q: What should you do if you are using drugs alone?
A: Call the Never Use Alone hotline at (800) 484-3731, where an operator will stay on the line with you while you use.


Q: What is Narcan and what is its purpose?
A: Narcan (naloxone) is a safe and legal medication that can reverse an opioid overdose and enable breathing.


Q: Where can Narcan be obtained for free in Pittsburgh?
A: Narcan can be obtained free of charge from Prevention Point Pittsburgh.


Q: What are the risks of using drugs alone?
A: Using drugs alone is dangerous because there is no one around to help in case of an overdose.


Q: What is the purpose of taking turns or staggering drug use?
A: Taking turns ensures that everyone does not overdose at the same time and someone is always available to help.


Q: What should you do if experiencing or witnessing an overdose?
A: Call 9-1-1 immediately as overdoses can be fatal within a very brief period of time.


Q: What legal protection does Pennsylvania Act 139 provide?
A: Pennsylvania Act 139 provides legal protection for the person experiencing the overdose and the caller, provided they stay with the victim.


Q: What is the hotline number for accessing treatment for drug use in Pennsylvania?
A: The hotline number is 1-800-662-HELP (4357).


Q: How can using sterile syringes benefit individuals who inject drugs?
A: Using sterile syringes can decrease the risk of infection and contracting conditions such as HIV and hepatitis C.


Q: What should be done if using drugs for the first time or after a period of abstinence?
A: Start slow and use a very small amount due to the unpredictability of drug strength.


Q: What is the contact email for the Office of Community Health and Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: The contact email is ochspgh@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: What is fentanyl?
A: Fentanyl is an extremely potent opioid that can quickly stop your breathing and cause an opioid overdose, which can lead to death.


Q: What types of substances might contain fentanyl?
A: Substances that might contain fentanyl include heroin, cocaine, crack, methamphetamine, benzodiazepines, ecstasy, and counterfeit pills such as Percocet and Xanax.


Q: What legal protection does Pennsylvania Act 139 provide?
A: Pennsylvania Act 139 provides legal protection for the person experiencing an overdose and the caller, provided they stay with the victim. This protection is for a drug overdose only.


Q: What is Narcan and what does it do?
A: Narcan (naloxone) is a safe and legal medication that can reverse an opioid overdose and enable breathing.


Q: Where can Narcan be obtained?
A: Narcan can be purchased at any pharmacy and is covered by most insurance plans. It can also be obtained free of charge from Prevention Point Pittsburgh.


Q: What are fentanyl test strips used for?
A: Fentanyl test strips are used to detect the presence of fentanyl in substances, which can help prevent an opioid overdose.


Q: Why is it dangerous to use drugs alone?
A: Using drugs alone is dangerous because there is no one to help in case of an overdose. Having someone present can ensure help is given, such as administering Narcan or calling an ambulance.


Q: What is the purpose of the "Never Use Alone" hotline?
A: The "Never Use Alone" hotline provides support by having an operator stay on the line while a person uses drugs alone, and they will notify emergency services if the person becomes unresponsive.


Q: What is a recommended strategy for safer drug use?
A: A recommended strategy is to take turns using drugs, ensuring that not everyone overdoses at the same time and someone is always available to help.


Q: What should be done to reduce the risk of infection when injecting drugs?
A: To reduce the risk of infection, use sterile syringes, which are provided by Prevention Point Pittsburgh at no cost.


Q: How can someone access treatment for drug use?
A: Treatment can be accessed through resources such as PA Get Help Now, UPMC Recovery Engagement Program, AHN Addiction Medicine Center of Excellence, and Pathway to Care and Recovery.


Q: Can fentanyl be absorbed through the skin?
A: Nearly all forms of fentanyl do not absorb through the skin and cannot cause an overdose through direct skin contact.


Q: What is the contact information for the Office of Community Health and Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: The contact email for the Office of Community Health and Safety is ochspgh@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: What is the purpose of Prevention Point Pittsburgh?
A: Prevention Point Pittsburgh provides sterile syringes and other safe drug use supplies at no cost to reduce the risk of contracting conditions such as HIV and hepatitis C.


Q: What is the primary risk associated with fentanyl in the drug supply?
A: The increased presence of fentanyl in the drug supply heightens the risk of overdose, which can be fatal.


Q: Can fentanyl cause an overdose through skin contact?
A: No, nearly all forms of fentanyl do not absorb through the skin and cannot cause an overdose through direct skin contact.


Q: What should you do if someone is experiencing a drug overdose?
A: Call 9-1-1 immediately, as overdoses can be fatal within a very brief period of time.


Q: What legal protection does Pennsylvania Act 139 provide?
A: Pennsylvania Act 139 provides legal protection for the person experiencing the overdose and the caller, provided they stay with the victim, for a drug overdose only.


Q: What is Narcan and how can it be obtained?
A: Narcan (naloxone) is a medication that can reverse an opioid overdose and is available at pharmacies and Prevention Point Pittsburgh, often without a prescription and covered by most insurance plans.


Q: What are fentanyl test strips used for?
A: Fentanyl test strips are used to detect the presence of fentanyl in drugs, helping to prevent overdoses.


Q: Why is it dangerous to use drugs alone?
A: Using drugs alone is dangerous because there is no one to help in case of an overdose.


Q: What should you do if you are using drugs alone?
A: Call the Never Use Alone hotline at (800) 484-3731, where an operator will stay on the line with you and notify emergency services if necessary.


Q: What are some strategies to reduce overdose risk when using drugs?
A: Strategies include calling 9-1-1, having Narcan on hand, using fentanyl test strips, not using drugs alone, taking turns, and starting slow with small amounts.


Q: Where can individuals seek treatment for drug use in Pittsburgh?
A: Resources include PA Get Help Now, UPMC Recovery Engagement Program, AHN Addiction Medicine Center of Excellence, and Pathway to Care and Recovery.


Q: How can sterile syringes help individuals who inject drugs?
A: Using sterile syringes can decrease the risk of infection and contracting conditions like HIV and hepatitis C.

Q: Where can Narcan be purchased and is it covered by insurance?
A: Narcan can be purchased at any pharmacy and is covered by most insurance plans.


Q: Where can Narcan be obtained for free?
A: Narcan can be obtained free of charge from Prevention Point Pittsburgh.


Q: What do fentanyl test strips detect?
A: Fentanyl test strips detect the presence of fentanyl in substances.


Q: Where can fentanyl test strips be obtained at no cost?
A: Fentanyl test strips are provided by Prevention Point Pittsburgh at no cost.


Q: What is the phone number for the Never Use Alone hotline?
A: The phone number for the Never Use Alone hotline is (800) 484-3731.


Q: What legal protection does Pennsylvania Act 139 provide?
A: Pennsylvania Act 139 provides legal protection for the person experiencing an overdose and the caller, provided they stay with the victim, but only for a drug overdose.


Q: What is the recommended action if using drugs alone?
A: If using drugs alone, call the Never Use Alone hotline.


Q: What is a safer practice when using drugs?
A: Using drugs with another person present is safer because they can administer Narcan or call for help in case of an overdose.


Q: What are some of the drugs that might be contaminated with fentanyl?
A: Drugs that might be contaminated with fentanyl include heroin, cocaine, crack, methamphetamine, benzodiazepines, ecstasy, and counterfeit pills like Percocet and Xanax.


Q: What is the contact email for the Office of Community Health and Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: The contact email is ochspgh@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the risk of fentanyl in the air or through skin contact?
A: Nearly all forms of fentanyl do not absorb through the skin and cannot cause an overdose through direct skin contact or by being in the vicinity of powdered fentanyl in the air.


Q: What is a key strategy to prevent overdose when using drugs?
A: Start slow and use a very small amount, especially if using drugs for the first time, after a break, or when mixing drugs and alcohol.


Q: What resources are available for drug use treatment in Pittsburgh?
A: Resources include PA Get Help Now, UPMC Recovery Engagement Program, AHN Addiction Medicine Center of Excellence, and Pathway to Care and Recovery.

Q: What is Narcan and what is its purpose?
A: Narcan (naloxone) is a safe and legal medication that can reverse an opioid overdose and enable breathing.


Q: Where can Narcan be obtained without a prescription?
A: Narcan can be purchased at any pharmacy and is covered by most insurance plans. It can also be obtained for free from Prevention Point Pittsburgh.


Q: What is the purpose of fentanyl test strips?
A: Fentanyl test strips are used to detect the presence of fentanyl in substances, which can quickly stop breathing and cause an opioid overdose.


Q: What hotline should you call if you are using drugs alone?
A: If using drugs alone, call the Never Use Alone hotline at (800) 484-3731.


Q: What should you do to decrease the risk of overdose when using drugs?
A: Start slow by using a very small amount, especially if using drugs for the first time, after a period of not using, or when mixing drugs and alcohol.


Q: What are the legal protections under Pennsylvania Act 139?
A: Pennsylvania Act 139 provides legal protection for the person experiencing the overdose and the caller, provided they stay with the victim, for a drug overdose only.


Q: What resources are available for drug use treatment in Pittsburgh?
A: Resources include PA Get Help Now (1-800-662-HELP), UPMC Recovery Engagement Program, AHN Addiction Medicine Center of Excellence, and Pathway to Care and Recovery.


Q: How can using sterile syringes benefit individuals who inject drugs?
A: Using sterile syringes can decrease the risk of infection and contracting conditions such as HIV and hepatitis C.


Q: What is the risk associated with fentanyl in the drug supply?
A: Fentanyl is an extremely potent opioid that can quickly stop breathing and cause an opioid overdose, leading to death.


Q: How does the presence of fentanyl in non-opioid drugs affect drug safety?
A: The presence of fentanyl in non-opioid drugs like cocaine, methamphetamine, and counterfeit pills increases the risk of overdose due to its potency.

Q: What precautions are advised against tragedy scammers after the Tree of Life synagogue shooting?
A: The FBI advises verifying the legitimacy of organizations before donating and avoiding giving personal information to unsolicited requests.

Q: What should individuals avoid doing with unsolicited emails to prevent computer viruses?
A: Do not respond to unsolicited emails or click on links within them.


Q: How can people verify the legitimacy of non-profit organizations?
A: Use internet-based resources to verify the existence and legitimacy of non-profit organizations.


Q: What is advised against when making donations?
A: Do not be pressured into making contributions and avoid giving personal or financial information to solicitors.


Q: How should donations be made to ensure they reach intended purposes?
A: Make donations directly to known organizations and avoid cash donations if possible.


Q: How can suspicious email solicitations or fraudulent websites be reported?
A: Report them to the FBI’s internet crime complaint center at www.ic3.gov.

Q: What technology is Pittsburgh employing to enhance public safety regarding gunfire incidents?

Q: What is the purpose of the ShotSpotter service?
A: It detects gunfire, pinpoints the location, and notifies police and 911 dispatchers quickly to save lives.

A: As ethnic intimidation.

A: Sexual orientation.


Q: How many ethnic intimidation incidents does Pittsburgh average per year over a ten-year period?
A: 19 incidents per year.


Q: What percentage of ethnic intimidation incidents involved race according to the data from 2008 to 2018?
A: 76%.

A: The importance of residents reporting potential crimes involving ethnic intimidation.


Q: What is the average arrest rate for ethnic intimidation incidents in Pittsburgh?
A: 40%, with nearly 60% for violent incidents.

A: ShotSpotter.

A: Sergeant John Fisher was promoted to commander.

A: John Fisher has worked at the training academy, within the traffic division, as a patrol supervisor, a member of the SWAT unit, and with the narcotics and vice division.


Q: What incident involving a Duquesne University student occurred on October 4, 2018?
A: Duquesne University student Marquis Jaylen Brown jumped from the 16th floor of Brottier Hall and was pronounced dead at the hospital.


Q: What were the findings of the investigation into Marquis Jaylen Brown's death?
A: Brown acted erratically, broke a window, and then jumped out. Drug testing showed marijuana in his system, and there was no physical contact with police.

A: Skeletal remains were found buried under a slab of concrete and assorted brick.

A: The remains were identified as Mary Arcuri through DNA analysis.

Q: Who was Glenn M. Cannon, and what was his contribution to Pittsburgh?
A: Glenn M. Cannon was a former director of public safety in Pittsburgh and the creator and first leader of the city's EMS department.


Q: When did Glenn M. Cannon begin his public service career in Pittsburgh?
A: In 1975.


Q: What significant roles did Glenn M. Cannon hold during his career?
A: He was the first leader of Pittsburgh's EMS, established the city's first river rescue unit, specialized rescue units, and hazardous materials response team, and served as public safety director from 1986 to 1992.

A: The firefighter recovered from the virus and returned to work.


Q: What actions were taken after a Pittsburgh police officer tested positive for COVID-19?
A: Identifying and notifying everyone who had contact with the officer, placing them in self-quarantine, and suspending a 28-person recruit class.


Q: What was the purpose of issuing masks to all City of Pittsburgh staff working in the field?
A: To help stop the spread of COVID-19 by reducing the amount of potentially infectious droplets expelled by the wearer.


Q: What measures were taken by Pittsburgh Public Safety for St. Patrick's Day celebrations amid COVID-19 concerns?
A: Maintaining a zero tolerance policy for illegal behavior, deploying DUI patrols, and urging businesses to lower occupancy rates.


Q: How did Pittsburgh's Public Safety Department respond to the first firefighter testing positive for COVID-19?
A: The firefighter was placed in self-isolation, and seven firefighters who had contact were instructed to self-quarantine.


Q: What was the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's response to a police officer testing positive for COVID-19?
A: Temporarily suspended a recruit class, identified potential contacts for self-quarantine, and ensured thorough cleaning of equipment.

A: Two additional officials tested positive.

A: The use of fireworks, even those that are legal, is prohibited within 150 feet of any structure.

A: Sparklers burn at 1,200 degrees, making them unsafe, especially for children.

A: Nine officers.

A: A second specialized EMS unit with enhanced decontamination capabilities and advanced PPE.

Q: How were the New Year's Eve celebrations in Pittsburgh affected by the pandemic in 2020?
A: The celebrations were transformed into a made-for-TV-only event, with venues closed, large gatherings prohibited, and fireworks canceled.


Q: What safety message did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich issue for New Year's Eve?
A: He urged people to celebrate responsibly, ideally at home, and warned against dangerous activities like celebratory gunfire.


Q: What incidents did Pittsburgh police respond to on January 4, 2021?
A: Police responded to two separate incidents involving explosives, one involving an improvised explosive device and the other believed to be caused by an aerial firework.


Q: What preparations did Pittsburgh's Public Safety Department make ahead of the presidential inauguration?
A: They prepared with law enforcement partners at local, state, and federal levels for potential protests and monitored the situation closely.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police do on Super Bowl weekend in 2021?
A: They conducted sobriety checkpoints and roving DUI patrols as part of Penndot’s impaired driving enforcement campaign.


Q: Who were Tanikka Pinnix and Layla Gooden, and why were they honored?
A: They were honored for saving a woman in distress on the Homestead Grays Bridge, preventing a potential tragedy.


Q: What issue did Pittsburgh police address regarding off-road vehicles in 2021?
A: They addressed the problem of unlawful off-road vehicles like ATVs and dirt bikes riding recklessly on city streets.


Q: What promotions were held by the Pittsburgh Department of Public Safety in March 2021?
A: Swearing-in and promotions ceremonies for EMS and fire personnel were held, including the promotion of Kari Burnham to lieutenant, making her the highest-ranking female in the bureau.


Q: What initiative did Pittsburgh announce to address opioid use in March 2021?
A: The creation of the opioid overdose dashboard to address unsafe opioid use.

Q: What is the purpose of the new public dashboard in Pittsburgh?
A: The dashboard is a public tool to help form and guide policies and programs to address unsafe opioid use by compiling data on monthly opioid overdose calls and public safety responses.


Q: What type of information will the Pittsburgh opioid dashboard include?
A: The dashboard will include the number of people who overdose, neighborhood-level mapping, demographic information, and statistics on care provided by on-scene first responders.


Q: Who announced the creation of the Pittsburgh public dashboard for opioid data?
A: Mayor William Peduto announced the creation of the dashboard.


Q: What is the role of the Office of Community Health and Safety in Pittsburgh's opioid crisis response?
A: The office will issue weekly reports to city staff and partner organizations to coordinate an equitable public health-informed response to the overdose crisis.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's new resource for addressing animal welfare concerns?
A: The bureau has created a central email address, animal.law@pittsburghpa.gov, for citizens and officers to send information or ask questions regarding animal welfare.


Q: How did COVID-19 affect the St. Patrick's Day celebrations in Pittsburgh in 2021?
A: Celebrations were muted due to ongoing COVID-19 safety measures, including restrictions on large crowds and bar and restaurant occupancy.


Q: What was the size of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire recruit class that graduated in March 2021?
A: The class started with 24 recruits and graduated 23.


Q: What new service has Pittsburgh launched to assist victims of crime?
A: Pittsburgh launched a new victim assistance website to connect victims to services like crisis intervention, referrals, information, and advocacy.


Q: Who was promoted to the rank of sergeant in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police in March 2021?
A: Detectives James Sherer and Joseph Simunovic were promoted to sergeant.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's policy on public intoxication and open container laws during St. Patrick's Day?
A: The police enforce a zero-tolerance policy for public intoxication and open container laws, citing anyone caught with an open container.

Q: What has been the increase in homicides and non-fatal shootings in Pittsburgh in 2021 compared to the previous year?
A: There has been an 80% increase in homicides and a 90% increase in non-fatal shootings compared to the previous year.


Q: What proactive measures are Pittsburgh police taking to address the surge in violent crime?
A: Pittsburgh police are using community resource officers (CROs) and neighborhood resource officers (NROs) to engage with residents and business owners, and group violence intervention (GVI) outreach workers are increasing their presence.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Police Chief, Scott Schubert, say about the verdict in Derek Chauvin's trial?
A: Scott Schubert stated that police have a duty to care for those in custody, which did not occur in George Floyd's case, leading to a loss of life and trust in law enforcement.


Q: What does the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's 2020 annual report include?
A: The report includes statistics on personnel distribution by rank, gender, and race, information on arrests and citations, and crime statistics by neighborhood.


Q: What new equipment has been added to Pittsburgh's River Rescue unit?
A: A new paramedic and police rescue boat equipped with advanced technology for emergency response on the rivers.


Q: What are some features of the new River Rescue boat?
A: The boat has increased fire suppression capabilities, improved lighting, a windless anchor, docking assist, built-in sonar, and forward-looking infrared for night vision.


Q: What was the purpose of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's promotions ceremony?
A: To promote Michael Fuerst to battalion chief, three firefighters to captain, and several others to lieutenant.


Q: What are the requirements for obtaining a block party permit in Pittsburgh?
A: Block party permits cost $25, are for residentially zoned streets, must be applied for by a resident of the block, and are valid for weekends or holidays from 10 am to 10 pm.


Q: How much does a special event permit cost in Pittsburgh, and what does it cover?
A: A special event permit costs $200 plus any contracted city services and covers outdoor community and civic events on public property.

Q: What types of permits can businesses in Pittsburgh apply for to create outdoor spaces?
A: Businesses can apply for sidewalk cafe, parking lane cafe, full street closure, and curbside pick-up zone permits.


Q: Until when are the temporary outdoor space permits free in Pittsburgh?
A: The permits are free through the end of 2021.


Q: What is the purpose of the Stop the Violence Community Investment Grant Program in Pittsburgh?
A: The program funds community projects intended to reduce violence in the city.


Q: Who is leading the Stop the Violence Community Investment Grant Program?
A: Public Safety Assistant Director of Community Affairs, Shatara Murphy, will lead the project.

A: An initial investment of $1,000,000 will be made.

Q: What is the leading cause of unintentional injury death among children ages 1-14, according to the CDC?
A: Drowning is the second leading cause of unintentional injury death among children ages 1-14, after motor vehicle crashes.


Q: What disparity exists in drowning rates among children?
A: Black children ages 10-14 years drown at rates 7.6 times higher than other children.


Q: What is the purpose of Pittsburgh's Fireworks Task Force?
A: The Fireworks Task Force aims to enforce fireworks regulations and ensure safety, responding to fireworks-related complaints and issuing citations for illegal use.


Q: What are the legal restrictions on fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: It is illegal to discharge fireworks within 150 feet of a structure and on any city park, ball field, or city-owned property.


Q: What is the focus of the Pittsburgh Police's abandoned vehicle blitz on June 23?
A: The blitz will focus on citizen complaints about abandoned vehicles in the Homewood neighborhood.


Q: How many homicides have occurred in Pittsburgh year-to-date compared to last year?
A: There have been 31 homicides compared to 20 homicides at the same time in 2020.

A: The ATF is creating a firearms trafficking unit, assigning two agents to work with Pittsburgh police to reduce illegal guns and gun violence.

A: Events included distributing bicycle helmets, a chess event, food distribution, and community walks in various neighborhoods.

A: Pittsburgh police are increasing lighting, deploying mounted units, and ensuring crowd movement for safety during the Independence Day celebration.


Q: What heat-related safety advice does Dr. Donald Yealy provide for the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: Dr. Yealy advises staying hydrated, avoiding alcohol, and being mindful of medications that may affect heat response to prevent heat-related ailments.


Q: What is a key safety reminder from Pittsburgh's Public Safety Director regarding hot weather?
A: The director reminds people not to leave children or pets in hot vehicles, as temperatures can rise rapidly, posing a risk of heat stroke or death.

A: Pittsburgh police will issue warnings and citations for obstructing public passageways, enforce parking regulations, and tow vehicles in violation.

A: The celebration is scheduled for Sunday, July 4, 2021, at Point State Park.

A: The penalty can be up to $300, plus court costs.

A: Increased police presence, mobile light towers for visibility, and bag screenings at park entrances are among the precautions.


Q: What advice does Dr. Donald Yealy give regarding heat-related ailments?
A: Dr. Yealy advises staying hydrated with the right fluids and being cautious of medications that affect heat response.

A: The use of any fireworks, even legal ones, is prohibited.

A: The task force aims to ensure the safe usage of legally purchased fireworks and respond to fireworks-related calls and complaints.


Q: What are some restrictions on fireworks use within the city of Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be discharged within 150 feet of a building or vehicle, are prohibited in city parks, and cannot be used under the influence of alcohol or drugs.

Q: Who was Therese Rocco, and what was her significance in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Therese Rocco was Pittsburgh's first female assistant chief.

Q: When did Therese Rocco become an officer and what notable achievements did she have in her law enforcement career?
A: Therese Rocco became an officer in 1952, rose to the rank of assistant chief of police in 1989, and was the first woman in the department and the country to reach such a high-ranking position.


Q: What was Therese Rocco known for in the field of law enforcement?
A: Therese Rocco was a nationally renowned expert in the field of missing persons, particularly children.


Q: When and where will Therese Rocco's viewing and prayer service be held?
A: The viewing and prayer service for Therese Rocco will be held on Monday, December 18, at Frank F. DeBor Funeral Home, located at 1065 Brookline Blvd, from 09:30-10:30 a.m.


Q: What event is the Department of Public Safety preparing for in Pittsburgh, and when will it occur?
A: The Department of Public Safety is preparing for Highmark First Night 2024 in Pittsburgh, occurring on December 31, 2023.


Q: What specific measures will the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police take during the First Night 2024 event?
A: Pittsburgh police officers will be stationed at key intersections, and the department will erect close to 60 barricades and place "no parking" signs 48 hours in advance.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's recent announcement regarding recruit class 133-23?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire held a graduation ceremony for recruit class 133-23, welcoming 29 new firefighters.


Q: What recent operational changes has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police announced for its personnel?
A: Starting February 26, 2024, police personnel will transition to four 10-hour shifts each week with three consecutive days off to enhance officer wellness.


Q: What policy improvements has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police made following the death of Jim Rogers?
A: Improvements include assigning an officer to monitor prisoners during hospital transfers, summoning EMS after taser deployment, retraining on single officer tactics, and reviewing body camera footage after use of force.


Q: What recent decision has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Animal Care and Control made regarding its spay and neuter program?
A: The Bureau has paused the spay and neuter program due to inappropriate uses and is evaluating potential applicant criteria to develop a more sustainable program.


Q: Who were promoted to the position of assistant chief in the recent Pittsburgh Bureau of Police promotion ceremony?
A: Christopher Ragland, Martin Devine, and Richard Ford were promoted to the position of assistant chief.

Q: What is the purpose of the centralized deployment for the night shift in Pittsburgh?
A: The centralized deployment for the night shift involves strategically placing police units throughout zones, overseen by multiple supervisors and a night watch commander, to allocate resources where needed.


Q: What is the goal of the newly formed violent crime division in Pittsburgh?
A: The goal of the violent crime division is to reduce violent crime and gun violence.


Q: What are the operating hours for the enhanced telephone reporting unit (TRU) in Pittsburgh?
A: The TRU operates from 7 a.m. to 3 a.m. daily, including weekends.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Police Cares Portal designed for?
A: The Pittsburgh Police Cares Portal is designed for police/community engagement events, safety alerts, monthly crime statistics, and zone/neighborhood-centered news.


Q: What was the purpose of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's promotion ceremony?
A: The ceremony was to advance five members of the bureau to the next stage in their careers and to highlight the service of Maxine Anthony.


Q: What is the function of the new police substation on Mary Street in Pittsburgh?
A: The substation allows officers to attend roll call, complete paperwork, or take breaks while remaining close to the action, but it is not open to the public or used for detaining arrestees.


Q: What is the purpose of the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program in Pittsburgh?
A: The LEAD program aims to improve public safety and order by providing case management and social services to individuals with substance use disorders and mental health challenges, reducing unnecessary justice system involvement.


Q: When will the LEAD program launch in Pittsburgh, and where will it be focused?
A: The LEAD program will launch in spring 2024 in police zones 1 and 2.


Q: What change is being made to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's response protocol for burglar alarms?
A: Adjustments are being made to how officers are dispatched to burglar alarm activations to improve efficiency, as most alarms are false.

Q: How many calls for service for burglar alarms were there in 2023?
A: There were 9,097 calls for service for burglar alarms in 2023.


Q: What percentage of the burglar alarm calls in 2023 generated police reports?
A: 0.43% of the burglar alarm calls generated police reports.


Q: How many of the incidents with police reports involved a verified alarm and a break-in?
A: 6 incidents involved a verified alarm and a break-in.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarms resulted in vandalism or objects being thrown through windows?
A: 0.27% of burglar alarms resulted in vandalism or objects being thrown through windows.


Q: How many police staff hours were spent on burglar alarm responses in 2023?
A: 4,166 police staff hours were spent on burglar alarm responses.


Q: What is the average time spent per unit on burglar alarm responses?
A: The average time spent per unit on burglar alarm responses is 13.5 minutes.


Q: What types of alarms will receive priority response under the new model?
A: Hold-up alarms, panic alarms, medical alert alarms, and verified burglar alarms will receive priority response.


Q: What will happen to unverified burglar alarms under the new model?
A: Unverified burglar alarms will be dispatched with the same level of response given to other non-priority calls and placed in a queue.


Q: What ordinance pertains to penalties for false burglar alarms in Pittsburgh?
A: The ordinance is City of Pittsburgh Ordinance 611.07.


Q: How many false alarm responses are permit holders allowed before being charged a fee?
A: Permit holders are allowed two false alarm responses before being charged a fee.


Q: What happens after the fifth documented false alarm activation in a calendar year?
A: Pittsburgh police supervisors are permitted to disregard the call.


Q: When will the updated burglar alarm response model go into effect?
A: The updated response model will go into effect on April 15, 2024.


Q: How many repeat addresses generated burglar alarms in 2023?
A: Nearly 1,500 repeat addresses generated burglar alarms.

A: The contact number is 412-255-2860.

Q: What is bigburgh.com?
A: Bigburgh.com is a City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Safety web-app listing free services for people experiencing homelessness or anyone in dire need.


Q: Who can use bigburgh.com?
A: Anyone, including first responders, service providers, and the general public, can use bigburgh.com.


Q: What types of services does bigburgh.com list?
A: Bigburgh.com lists services for meals, shelter, clinics, showers, laundry, clothing, diapers, financial, legal, and employment matters, and emergency hotlines.


Q: When did bigburgh.com join the list of city web-apps?
A: Bigburgh.com joined the list of city web-apps in 2018.


Q: What is the Citiparks Summer Food Service Program?
A: It is a program operated by Citiparks in partnership with Pittsburgh Public Schools to provide food for the city's youth.


Q: Who is eligible for the Citiparks food programs?
A: All children up to 18 years old and individuals with any type of disability/handicap up to 21 years old are eligible.


Q: What funding supports the Citiparks Summer Food Service Program?
A: It is funded by the US Department of Agriculture through the Pennsylvania Department of Education.

A: No charges were filed as it was deemed an unfortunate accident.

A: The collision occurred between a Port Authority bus and an SUV, resulting in six people being transported to hospitals.

A: Zone 3 can be reached at 412-488-8326, Zone 5 at 412-665-3605, and Zone 1 at 412-323-7201.

A: The meeting focused on "the state of human trafficking: the Pittsburgh region."

A: He reportedly jumped from a 16th-floor window and later died from his injuries.

A: The Pittsburgh Police Crash Investigation Unit is assisting the Port Authority in the investigation.

A: Six students were injured when struck by a vehicle driven by a teenage student.

A: Human trafficking.

A: An outpouring of support, including food and messages, was shown to first responders and victims.


Q: What did the FBI warn the public about following the Tree of Life Synagogue shooting?
A: Potential scammers soliciting fraudulent donations for the victims.


Q: What are some guidelines provided by the FBI to avoid donation scams?
A: Verify the legitimacy of organizations, avoid unsolicited emails, and do not give personal information to solicitors.

A: Ronald Romano has been with Pittsburgh EMS since 1978.

A: There was a 19 percent reduction in non-fatal shootings and a 5 percent reduction in homicides.


Q: What was the clearance rate for homicide cases in Pittsburgh in 2018?

A: Camerin Caldwell, 18, was charged.


Q: What is the status of Pittsburgh police officer Calvin Hall after the shooting incident on Monticello Street?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was in critical condition after being shot.

Q: Who was Officer Calvin Hall and what was his role at the Northview Heights Public Safety Center?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was a Pittsburgh police officer known for his dedication to community outreach. He was hand-picked to work at the Northview Heights Public Safety Center due to his positive attitude and ability to connect with people from all walks of life.


Q: What happened to Officer Calvin Hall on July 14, 2019?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was shot three times in the back on July 14, 2019, on the 7300 block of Monticello Street.


Q: When did Officer Calvin Hall pass away, and where?
A: Officer Calvin Hall passed away on July 17, 2019, at UPMC Presbyterian.


Q: What charges were filed against Camerin Caldwell in connection with the July 4, 2019, shooting?
A: Camerin Caldwell was charged with criminal attempt homicide (two counts), aggravated assault (two counts), reckless endangerment (two counts), and firearms violations.


Q: How did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police honor Officer Calvin Hall after his passing?
A: They conducted an end of watch ceremony for Officer Hall and organized a public blood drive in his honor.


Q: What precautions did Pittsburgh officials advise residents to take during the heat wave in July 2019?
A: Officials advised residents to drink plenty of fluids, stay indoors if possible, check on elderly neighbors, and avoid leaving pets or children in vehicles. They also suggested using public pools, spray parks, and cooling centers.


Q: What was Officer Calvin Hall's signature motto?
A: Officer Calvin Hall's signature motto was, “Gotta go. Time for me to make a difference.”


Q: What is the purpose of the blood drive organized by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police in July 2019?
A: The blood drive was organized to honor Officer Calvin Hall and to highlight the importance of blood donation, as Officer Hall received several units of blood in an effort to save his life.

Q: When can the public donate blood in honor of Calvin Hall?
A: From August 1 through August 31.


Q: What is the special group code to use when donating blood in honor of Calvin Hall?
A: Z0021100.

A: By calling (412) 209-7000 or visiting vitalant.org/officerhall.

A: Six police officers.

Q: How much expired, unused, and unwanted prescription drugs were collected in Pittsburgh in April?
A: Nearly 420 pounds were collected.


Q: How many law enforcement partners participated nationally in the April drug take-back initiative?
A: Nearly 5,000 law enforcement partners participated.


Q: What is the main goal of the National Prescription Drug Take Back Day?
A: To diminish devastating drug abuse in communities.


Q: Where can expired, unused, and unwanted prescription drugs be dropped off in Pittsburgh?
A: At various locations including all six Pittsburgh police zone stations, police headquarters, and the Phillips Rec Center in Carrick.


Q: What safety and health hazards are associated with improper disposal of unused medicines?
A: Flushing them down the toilet or throwing them in the trash poses potential safety and health hazards.

A: The one-year anniversary of the tragic events at the Tree of Life Synagogue.

A: Awards were given to one civilian and six EMS workers who went above and beyond the call of duty.

A: Ensure costumes are reflective, light in color, and masks provide full visibility; add clip-on lights; and dress warmly due to weather.
