A: The 19 crossing guards were recognized for 582 years of service.


Q: What was unique about the recruit class 129-19 of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: The class included 16 U.S. military veterans and was taught by Captain James Petruzzi, who will retire next summer.


Q: What is the policy regarding fireworks during the First Night 2020 events in Pittsburgh?
A: City law prohibits the use of any fireworks, even those that are legal, within 150 feet of a structure.


Q: What did Glenn M. Cannon establish during his time with the Pittsburgh EMS department?
A: Glenn M. Cannon established the city’s first river rescue unit, first specialized rescue units, and the city’s first hazardous materials response team.

Q: What law firm was Glenn Cannon associated with?
A: Glenn Cannon was associated with the Pittsburgh law firm of Kennedy, Cannon & Devinney.


Q: What role did Glenn Cannon have at the University of Pittsburgh?
A: Glenn Cannon was an adjunct faculty member and visiting senior lecturer at the University of Pittsburgh.


Q: Who expressed condolences on behalf of public safety for Glenn Cannon?
A: Director Wendell Hissrich offered condolences on behalf of all in public safety.


Q: How many new K9 officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police K9 Training Academy in January 2020?
A: Five new regional K9s graduated.


Q: Which police departments had members graduate from the K9 academy?
A: Members from Pittsburgh Police, Butler City Police, and the Lawrence County Sheriff's Department graduated.


Q: What significant change in crime rates occurred in Pittsburgh in 2019?
A: Homicides dropped by 36 percent from 2018 to 2019.


Q: What system was expanded to help reduce crime in Pittsburgh?
A: The ShotSpotter system was expanded from three square miles to 18 square miles of coverage.


Q: What did Allegheny Health Network donate to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Allegheny Health Network donated 1,000 packages of NuStat hemostatic gauze.


Q: What preparations did the Pittsburgh Public Safety Department take for a possible coronavirus outbreak?
A: They updated the 2014 pandemic operational plan, trained first responders, and coordinated with local hospitals and officials.


Q: How many new paramedics were sworn in by the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS in March 2020?
A: Six new paramedics were sworn in.


Q: What positions were Fred Caprio II and Christy Zalewski promoted to within the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS?
A: They were promoted to the position of crew chief.

Q: What role do the women of Pittsburgh EMS play in EMS evolution?
A: They are leaders at the forefront of a new evolution in EMS, recognizing its role at the intersection of public safety, public health, and healthcare.


Q: What advice did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich give to new paramedics and crew chiefs?
A: He reminded them to represent the city well, treat patients like family, and take time for themselves and their families.


Q: Who was recently promoted within the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Four sergeants were promoted to lieutenant, and three officers were promoted to sergeant.


Q: What did Mayor William Peduto emphasize to the newly promoted police sergeants and lieutenants?
A: He emphasized the importance of their knowledge and experience in guiding officers during challenging times, such as the COVID-19 pandemic.


Q: How did Pittsburgh plan to handle St. Patrick's Day celebrations amid COVID-19 concerns?
A: By maintaining a zero-tolerance policy for disruptive behavior, targeting underage drinking and DUI, and deploying various police units to ensure safety.


Q: What measures were taken after a Pittsburgh firefighter tested positive for COVID-19?
A: The firefighter self-isolated, and seven others who had contact with them were instructed to self-quarantine.


Q: What actions were taken after a Pittsburgh police officer tested positive for COVID-19?
A: The officer self-isolated, and officials began identifying and notifying contacts for self-quarantine.


Q: What precautionary measure did the City of Pittsburgh implement for staff amid COVID-19?
A: Issued protective masks to all city staff working in the field and having contact with the public.


Q: What recognition did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive during National EMS Week?
A: They were recognized by the Pennsylvania Emergency Health Services Council for achieving expert-level pediatric emergency care.


Q: Who is the Pediatric Emergency Care Coordinator for the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS?
A: EMS District Chief Jeffrey Meyer.


Q: How did Mayor William Peduto describe the Pittsburgh EMS Bureau's reputation?
A: He stated that it is viewed on a global basis, with people traveling from around the world to be trained by Pittsburgh EMS.

Q: What was the response of Pittsburgh Bureau of Police Chief Scott Schubert to the death of George Floyd?
A: Chief Scott Schubert expressed that he was deeply disturbed and saddened by the video of George Floyd's death and emphasized that the actions of the officers involved were inexcusable and did not represent the values of law enforcement.


Q: What initiative did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police take in response to the protests in the city?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police formed the Damage Assessment & Accountability Task Force (DAAT) to investigate crimes such as property damage and violence during the protests.


Q: What significant statistic was highlighted in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police 2019 annual report?
A: The report noted a 36% drop in homicides.


Q: Who was Officer Calvin Hall, and what happened to him in 2019?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was a member of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police who died in the line of duty on July 17, 2019.


Q: What was the purpose of the Fireworks Taskforce formed in Pittsburgh in June 2020?
A: The taskforce was created to address the illegal use of fireworks in city neighborhoods, especially due to the increase in fireworks complaints.


Q: What restrictions were placed on fireworks in Pittsburgh for the Fourth of July 2020?
A: Fireworks were prohibited within 150 feet of any structure, in all parks, public spaces, and on private property without consent.


Q: What safety measures were emphasized by public safety officials for the Fourth of July 2020 in Pittsburgh?
A: Officials advised against the illegal use of fireworks, firing guns in the air, and emphasized water safety due to closed city pools.

Q: What is the risk associated with swimming in the city's rivers during the Fourth of July?
A: There is typically not a qualified lifeguard on duty, making it risky.


Q: What measures are being taken on the city's rivers during the Fourth of July?
A: River rescue, the fire boat, and the coast guard will enforce boating laws and teach water safety.


Q: What guidelines should people follow to prevent the spread of COVID-19 according to the text?
A: Maintain physical distancing, wear a mask, wash hands for at least 20 seconds, avoid large crowds, and stay home if unwell.


Q: What is the forecast for the Fourth of July weather?
A: Temperatures are forecast to be above 90 degrees for many days in a row.


Q: What is the public safety policy on drinking and driving during the Fourth of July?
A: There is a zero-tolerance policy, and patrols will be searching for impaired drivers.


Q: What should pet owners be aware of during the Fourth of July?
A: Many dogs are panicked by fireworks and may run away, leading to an increase in lost pets.


Q: How many fireworks complaint calls were received across all six police zones on the night before the Fourth of July?
A: There were a total of 85 fireworks complaint calls.


Q: What damage resulted from fireworks incidents at the Horace Mann School?
A: A 2-alarm blaze caused an estimated $50,000 to $60,000 damage.


Q: What is the legal restriction on the use of fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be used within 150 feet of any structure and are prohibited in parks and public spaces without landowner consent.


Q: What recognition did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive from the American Heart Association in 2020?
A: They received the Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.


Q: What changes are being implemented by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police during protests?
A: Changes to incident command to keep citizens safe and improve police-community relations.


Q: How many free masks were distributed through the “Need a Mask, Take a Mask” initiative in Pittsburgh?
A: More than 100,000 free masks were distributed.


Q: What new capability has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire achieved?
A: They are recognized as a Type-3A Swift Water and Flood Response Team.


Q: What notable event occurred for Officer Timothy Matson nearly two years after the Tree of Life shooting?
A: Officer Matson returned to work on modified duty.


Q: What ceremony did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS hold on October 14, 2020?
A: An awards, swearing-in, and promotions ceremony.

Q: What did Dr. Roth emphasize as a way of keeping people safe?
A: Dr. Roth emphasized that public safety measures are a way of keeping individuals, their families, and patients safe.


Q: What key service did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich highlight for Pittsburgh EMS personnel?
A: Wendell Hissrich highlighted compassion as one of the most important services Pittsburgh EMS personnel can provide.


Q: Who administered the oath of office for the new and newly-promoted members of Pittsburgh EMS?
A: Mayor William Peduto administered the oath of office.


Q: What award did Paramedics Romayne Bendig and Taylor Mahoney receive?
A: They received the District Chief’s Award for rescuing a woman struck by a vehicle and trapped underneath.


Q: What precautionary measures did Pittsburgh Public Safety implement during the COVID-19 pandemic?
A: They suspended all in-person training programs and inter-unit rotations for police, fire, and EMS until after the election period.


Q: How did Pittsburgh Public Safety plan to prepare for the federal election on November 3, 2020?
A: They prepared by working closely with Allegheny County and local, state, and federal partners, and the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police moved to 12-hour shifts with all pass days, personal days, and holidays cancelled during that time.


Q: What was the outcome of the Nuisance Bar Task Force's operation at Bridgez on October 23, 2020?
A: Officers seized beer, liquor, gambling devices, and cash proceeds, and charged three individuals for illegal alcohol sales and gambling.


Q: What new signage was installed in Frick Park, and why?
A: 'No Hunting' signs were installed to ensure the safety of visitors due to the high visibility of deer and other wildlife.


Q: What is prohibited in Pittsburgh city parks according to the municipal code of ordinances?
A: Hunting, trapping, feeding, and harvesting wildlife are prohibited.


Q: How many Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officers tested positive for COVID-19 as of the statement?
A: Nine officers tested positive for COVID-19.


Q: What adjustments were made to Pittsburgh's New Year's Eve celebrations due to the pandemic?
A: Venues were closed, large gatherings prohibited, fireworks cancelled, and the event was transformed into a made-for-TV-only celebration.


Q: What incidents did Pittsburgh Police, FBI, and ATF investigate on January 4, 2021?
A: They investigated two separate explosives incidents involving an IED and an aerial firework.


Q: What was the response to possible protests in Pittsburgh leading up to the presidential inauguration?
A: Public Safety prepared with law enforcement partners to address any potential actions or protests.

Q: What measures did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police take in preparation for President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration following the January 6 Capitol riot?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police utilized all intelligence-gathering methods to protect residents and infrastructure, remained vigilant, and ensured information flow with law enforcement partners.


Q: What action will be taken if Pittsburgh city employees are found to have participated in the January 6 insurrection?
A: Appropriate disciplinary action will be taken.


Q: When did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police recruit class BR20-01 graduate?
A: The class graduated on January 22, 2021.


Q: How did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police plan to address impaired driving on Super Bowl weekend?
A: They participated in PennDOT’s Western Alliance/Team DUI program to set up sobriety checkpoints and conduct roving DUI patrols.


Q: How were Tanikka Pinnix and Layla Gooden recognized for their actions on January 28, 2021?
A: They were honored in council chambers and had a day proclaimed in their name for saving a stranger on the Homestead Grays Bridge.


Q: What issue regarding off-road vehicle use is Pittsburgh facing, and how are they addressing it?
A: Pittsburgh is facing unlawful off-road vehicle use on city streets, and they are addressing it with a three-pronged response: education, law enforcement collaboration, and investigation.


Q: What new tool did Pittsburgh introduce to address opioid overdoses?
A: The Opioid Overdose Dashboard, which compiles EMS data to map overdose calls and responses.


Q: Who is leading the work on opioid overdose prevention strategies within the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: The Overdose Prevention Program Coordinator, in partnership with Pittsburgh EMS and the Allegheny County Health Department.


Q: How has the COVID-19 pandemic affected St. Patrick's Day celebrations in Pittsburgh for the second year in a row?
A: Celebrations are muted with restrictions on large crowds, and bar and restaurant occupancy is reduced.

Q: What is the Pittsburgh Public Safety's stance on pandemic restrictions as of fall 2021?
A: Pittsburgh Public Safety urges continued vigilance and promises a focus on safety and catching law-breakers.


Q: What policy did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich announce regarding illegal behavior?
A: Director Hissrich announced a zero-tolerance policy for disruptive and illegal behavior, including underage drinking, public intoxication, and drinking and driving.


Q: What activities will Pittsburgh police and partner law enforcement agencies monitor?
A: They will monitor crowds for illegal activity and actively seek anyone driving under the influence.


Q: What is illegal regarding cocktails-to-go in Pittsburgh during the pandemic?
A: It is illegal for cocktails-to-go to be consumed in public spaces.


Q: What will Pittsburgh fire officials do to ensure safety during the pandemic?
A: They will conduct occupancy checks and close any establishment that exceeds occupancy limits.


Q: How should the public report illegal off-road vehicle driving in Pittsburgh?
A: The public should send tips to 412_tips@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is encouraged for those who choose to go out during the pandemic in Pittsburgh?
A: Public Safety encourages wearing a mask, washing hands, and maintaining social distancing.


Q: When were new firefighters sworn in at the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: New firefighters were sworn in on March 19, 2021.

A: 23 recruits graduated.

A: The smaller class size was to comply with the governor’s COVID-19 measures banning gatherings larger than 25 people.

A: Detective James Sherer and Detective Joseph Simunovic were promoted.

A: They created a central email address: animal.law@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What was the increase in homicides and non-fatal shootings in Pittsburgh as of April 2021 compared to the previous year?
A: There was an 80% increase in homicides and a 90% increase in non-fatal shootings.

A: They released their 2020 annual report.

A: Scott Schubert.

A: Relational policing.


Q: What is the primary purpose of the new paramedic and police rescue boat launched by Pittsburgh Public Safety?
A: To expand River Rescue's life-saving capabilities on the region's rivers.


Q: Where was the new rescue boat for Pittsburgh's River Rescue manufactured?
A: Lake Assault in Superior, Wisconsin.


Q: What are some features of the new rescue boat for Pittsburgh's River Rescue?
A: Increased fire suppression capabilities, improved lighting, a windless anchor, docking assist, built-in sonar, and forward-looking infrared for night vision.

A: 17 vehicles were towed.


Q: Who addressed the spike in gun violence in Pittsburgh?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, ATF, community partners, and families of victims.


Q: How many homicides were reported in Pittsburgh year-to-date compared to the previous year?
A: 31 homicides in 2021 compared to 20 in 2020.

A: There have been 76 non-fatal shootings.

A: Approximately 75% of firearms were purchased in Pennsylvania.

A: A firearms trafficking unit.

A: It hampered face-to-face contact, custom notifications, hospital visits, and support from coaches and teachers.

A: By calling 311, 412-255-2621, or filing an online 311 request form.

A: The Fourth of July celebrations.

A: To protect residents and visitors so they can safely enjoy Independence Day.

Q: What advice is given regarding heat-related safety during the Fourth of July?
A: Avoid dehydration by drinking enough fluids and be cautious of heat-related ailments.


Q: What measures will Pittsburgh police take to manage crowds during the Fourth of July?
A: Increased lighting, mounted units, and ensuring clear ingress and egress points.


Q: What will happen to vehicles violating parking measures on the South Side?
A: They will be towed.

Q: What measures will the Pittsburgh police take to ensure safety during the July 4th celebrations?
A: Pittsburgh police will conduct light bag screenings at park entrances, use mobile light towers for visibility, and activate mounted units to manage crowds.


Q: What time are the fireworks scheduled to end on July 4th in Pittsburgh?
A: The fireworks are scheduled to end at 10 p.m.


Q: What are attendees of the July 4th celebrations in Pittsburgh encouraged to check in advance?
A: Attendees are encouraged to check bus and rail schedules in advance.


Q: What will the Pennsylvania State Police use to monitor traffic during the July 4th fireworks?
A: A Pennsylvania State Police helicopter will monitor traffic to ensure it keeps flowing on bridge decks.


Q: What safety concerns does Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich highlight regarding fireworks?
A: Fireworks are not allowed in Point State Park or any city park and are prohibited within 150 feet of any structure.


Q: What advice does Dr. Donald Yealy give regarding heat-related ailments during the July 4th celebrations?
A: Dr. Yealy advises staying hydrated, avoiding alcohol, and being cautious with medications that can cause dehydration or heat stress.


Q: What is the role of the Fireworks Task Force in Pittsburgh during the July 4th weekend?
A: The Fireworks Task Force will enforce regulations to curb the illegal use of fireworks until July 5.


Q: What does the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS plan to do on July 4th to handle emergencies in crowded areas?
A: Motorcycle medic units will operate near viewing points, and traditional medic units will stage near key fireworks viewing areas.

A: Unvaccinated individuals are strongly encouraged to wear a mask.


Q: What activities are the Pittsburgh Police Community Engagement Office involved in during the week of July 5 to July 11?
A: Activities include visiting schools, hosting "Chess with Cops," reading at Summer Storytime, and engaging with summer camps.


Q: Who was promoted during the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire promotions ceremony on July 22, 2021?
A: Joshua Kuzma was promoted to Battalion Chief, and John Gallagher and Eric Smith were promoted to Fire Lieutenant.

Q: What issues have arisen on East Carson Street as pandemic restrictions eased?
A: Increased gun violence, overcrowded sidewalks and streets, traffic safety obstacles, and noise complaints.


Q: What changes are being implemented on East Carson Street to address these issues?
A: Vehicle traffic will be allowed outbound only on East Carson Street between S.10th and S.18th streets on Fridays and Saturdays from 7 p.m. to 4 a.m., side streets from S.11th to S.17th will be closed to traffic, and ride-sharing services will not be permitted on East Carson Street between S.10th and S.18th streets.


Q: Who will be allowed to travel in both directions on East Carson Street?
A: Only emergency vehicles and Port Authority buses.


Q: What restrictions are placed on ride-sharing services on East Carson Street?
A: Ride-sharing services like Uber and Lyft will not be permitted between S.10th and S.18th streets; passengers must arrange pick-up and drop-off on open side streets.


Q: What is prohibited on East Carson Street between 7 p.m. and 4 a.m.?
A: Parking and deliveries are prohibited.


Q: Why has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police partnered with Books Bridge Hope?
A: To assist unsheltered communities by distributing "Boxes of Goodness" filled with items like books, socks, toiletries, and non-perishable food.


Q: What modifications were made to the South Side vehicle traffic pilot project?
A: The start time for converting East Carson Street to one-way traffic was changed from 7 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.


Q: Why was the South Side traffic pilot project temporarily paused?
A: Due to a partial building collapse on East Carson Street.


Q: When did East Carson Street fully reopen to vehicle traffic following the building collapse?
A: August 19, 2021, after successful stabilization and demolition of the affected structure.

Q: When was the traffic pilot project initially implemented and when was it modified?
A: The traffic pilot project was implemented on July 30 and modified on August 12.


Q: What event did the Pittsburgh Police Community Engagement Office participate in with Pittsburgh Public Schools?
A: They participated in a backpack, supplies, and mask giveaway for students near Heinz Field.


Q: How many masks were distributed during the Pittsburgh Police Community Engagement Office event?
A: More than 600 masks were distributed.


Q: What topic did Sergeant Tiffany Kline-Costa and CEO officers discuss with children at Homewood YMCA?
A: They discussed how to prepare and protect themselves in the event of an active shooter incident in their school.


Q: When will the modified traffic pilot project on the South Side be reinstated?
A: It will be reinstated on the weekend of August 27 – August 29.


Q: What change was made to the traffic flow on East Carson Street during the pilot project?
A: East Carson Street will convert from two-way to one-way traffic traveling eastbound between S. 10th and S. 18th starting at 9:30 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.


Q: What award has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Emergency Medical Services received from the American Heart Association?
A: They received the Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Achievement Award.

A: They have received it for four consecutive years.

Q: What is the city of Pittsburgh's response to illegal dumping?

A: Increased police presence and resources will be deployed in anticipation of large crowds for watch parties and celebrations.


Q: What incident led to policy and procedural changes in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: The incident involving Jim Rogers, who died after being in police custody, led to policy and procedural changes.

Q: How many Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officers are facing discipline due to procedural failures?
A: Eight officers, including two supervisors, are facing discipline.


Q: What training measures has Pittsburgh implemented to ensure police accountability?
A: Pittsburgh implemented mandatory de-escalation and implicit bias training for officers and participates in the National Initiative for Building Community Trust & Justice.


Q: What new requirements were recommended for use of force incidents involving a Taser?
A: Incidents involving a Taser will require emergency medical services personnel to assess the patient.


Q: What additional certification will Pittsburgh police officers be required to obtain?
A: Officers will be required to become fully certified emergency medical responders.


Q: Who was promoted to the rank of Assistant Chief in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Phillip Carey was promoted to Assistant Chief.

A: Police encourage using public transportation or ride services and will be looking for impaired drivers.

A: Eric Holmes oversees dignitary protection for national and international leaders visiting Pittsburgh.


Q: What happened to the Forbes Avenue bridge in Frick Park on January 28, 2022?
A: The bridge collapsed, involving five vehicles and one bus, resulting in minor injuries.

A: A mass casualty plan was activated, and PA USAR Strike Team 1 was deployed to check for victims.

A: Paramedic Edward Parker received a promotion.


Q: What is the historical significance of the Freedom House Ambulance Service mentioned by Dr. Ronald Roth?
A: It was the first emergency medical service to provide training beyond basic first aid and set the standard for emergency care.


Q: What specific initiative is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police participating in to strengthen community ties?
A: The OneCOP (One Congregation, One Precinct) program.


Q: What is the main focus of the OneCOP initiative?
A: To facilitate positive partnerships between law enforcement and diverse congregations for crime and violence prevention.

Q: What is the purpose of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's 2021 annual report?
A: The report provides a comprehensive overview of the bureau’s work, including statistical analysis of calls for service, homicide analysis, arrests, and disciplinary action.


Q: When did Chief Scott Schubert announce his retirement from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Chief Scott Schubert announced his retirement on May 27, 2022.


Q: What notable initiative did Chief Schubert implement during his tenure?
A: Chief Schubert implemented the pillars of former President Obama's task force report on 21st-century policing.


Q: What is the Group Violence Intervention (GVI) program?
A: GVI is a partnership between law enforcement, social services, and the faith community to mediate and interrupt violence.


Q: What technology did Chief Schubert promote to increase safety?
A: Chief Schubert promoted the creation of a Real Time Crime Center (RTCC).


Q: What did Chief Schubert do to enhance transparency and accountability within the police force?
A: He fully adopted the use of body-worn cameras for all officers.


Q: What is the function of the Office of Strategy, Accountability, and Resiliency (OSAR)?
A: OSAR is responsible for incubating, fostering, and implementing Pittsburgh police initiatives and advancing the strategic mission of the chief of police.


Q: When will Deputy Chief Tom Stangrecki serve as acting chief?
A: Tom Stangrecki will serve as acting chief starting July 1, 2022.


Q: What event is the Pittsburgh Department of Public Safety preparing for on July 4, 2022?
A: The city is preparing for the Independence Day celebration and fireworks.


Q: What are the restrictions regarding fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks are prohibited in Point State Park or any city park and within 150 feet of any occupied structure.

Q: When will the fireworks task force be active in Pittsburgh?
A: The fireworks task force will be active each night from June 27 to July 6.


Q: Who is part of the Pittsburgh fireworks task force?
A: The task force is comprised of members from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire and the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police.


Q: What is Scott Schubert's new position after retiring as Pittsburgh Police Chief?
A: Scott Schubert will become the section chief overseeing the global law enforcement support section at the FBI's Criminal Justice Information Services Division in Clarksburg, West Virginia.


Q: How long did Captain Jim Ellis serve with the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: Captain Jim Ellis served for 23 years.


Q: What is the purpose of Pittsburgh's first "Girls Fire Camp"?
A: The camp aims to empower girls aged 15-18 by providing a real-life look at becoming a firefighter and addressing gender stereotypes in the fire service.

A: They received a $1.7 million FEMA Assistance to Firefighters Grant to upgrade self-contained breathing apparatus.


Q: What significant event is happening at Acrisure Stadium on September 1, 2022?
A: The "Backyard Brawl" football game between the Pittsburgh Panthers and the West Virginia Mountaineers.

A: Anthony Horne was promoted to the rank of captain.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police held a promotions ceremony.

A: Timothy Novosel and William Watts were promoted to the rank of lieutenant.

A: Thirteen officers were promoted to the rank of sergeant.

A: He reminded them about the importance of leading the next generation of officers.


Q: What incident prompted an internal investigation by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: The lack of police presence during a funeral at the Destiny of Faith Church after a tragic shooting incident.


Q: What was the primary focus of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's graduation ceremony for recruit class 132-22?
A: The ceremony focused on the 31 recruits who completed 32 weeks of training.


Q: Who delivered the oath of office at the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's graduation ceremony?
A: Public Safety Director Lee Schmidt administered the oath of office.

A: It is internationally known for its academic excellence and offers advanced training for law enforcement officers.

Q: When will the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police Zone 3 roll out the Axon My90 pilot engagement program?
A: The program will start on Monday, December 19, 2022.


Q: What is the purpose of the Axon My90 program in Pittsburgh?
A: The program aims to bridge the gap between officers and the neighborhoods they serve by utilizing brief surveys to provide feedback on police interactions.


Q: How will residents participate in the Axon My90 surveys?
A: Residents will receive a text link for a survey following designated police interactions.


Q: Is the Axon My90 survey mandatory or optional?
A: The survey is optional and completely anonymous.


Q: When will the Axon My90 program be active in all Pittsburgh police zones?
A: The program became active city-wide on February 16, 2023.


Q: What is the new office created by the Pittsburgh Department of Public Safety in 2023?
A: The Office of Film & Event Management (OFEM).


Q: What is the role of the Office of Film & Event Management in Pittsburgh?
A: It is responsible for receiving and vetting applications for events and film productions, ensuring compliance with industry standards, safety regulations, and city policies.

A: Brian Katze as Film & Events Manager and Anna Boekenhauer as Film & Event Permit Coordinator.

A: The annual St. Patrick's Day Parade.

A: They are encouraged to use designated drivers, taxis, or rideshare services like Uber or Lyft.

Q: Who were the two paramedics sworn-in at the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS ceremony?
A: Alex Cappellini and Adam Croci.


Q: What historical EMS development did Director Schmidt remind the new paramedics about?
A: Pittsburgh EMS grew out of the creation of Freedom House in 1967.

Q: What is the purpose of the community paramedicine program launched by Pittsburgh EMS and the Office of Community Health & Safety?
A: The program is designed to address the needs of the most vulnerable in the community, providing ongoing support and connecting patients with proper health services to avoid future hospitalization.


Q: Who are the leaders of the community paramedicine program in Pittsburgh?
A: EMS Community Paramedic Crew Chief John Mooney and OCH&S Manager Laura Drogowski.


Q: What chronic health conditions are commonly seen in patients frequently calling EMS in Pittsburgh?
A: Obstructive lung diseases (asthma and COPD), diabetes, seizure disorders, and heart disease.


Q: What did EMS Chief Ronald Romano achieve during the COVID-19 pandemic?
A: Under his leadership, Pittsburgh EMS did not have any employees hospitalized or pass away due to COVID-19, and they continued to operate without interruption.


Q: How long did Ronald Romano serve in the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS before retiring?
A: 45 years.

A: A promotions ceremony for new sergeants and a lieutenant.

A: There were no major safety or security incidents, and 25 patients were transported by EMS mainly for hyperthermia and orthopedic injuries.

A: The parade starts on Liberty Avenue at 11th Street, proceeds westbound on Liberty, turns onto Seventh Street, crosses the Andy Warhol Bridge onto Sandusky Street, turns left onto South Commons, and ends in Allegheny Commons Park West.

A: The 50th anniversary of Pride in Pittsburgh and a three-game series between the Pittsburgh Pirates and the St. Louis Cardinals.

A: Fort Duquesne Boulevard will be closed from Stanwix Street to Ninth Street for the entirety of the festival, June 2-11.

A: Larry Scirotto was sworn in as the 55th chief.

Q: What major events are happening in Pittsburgh from June 16-19, 2023?
A: Juneteenth celebrations and two Taylor Swift concerts.


Q: What are the parking and entry guidelines for the Taylor Swift concerts at Acrisure Stadium?
A: Parking lots open at 1:30 p.m., VIP gates open at 3:30 p.m., all gates open at 4:30 p.m., and only mobile tickets are accepted.


Q: What is prohibited in Point State Park during the Juneteenth fireworks display?
A: Alcohol, narcotics, laser pointers, weapons, explosives, ammunition, and grills are prohibited.


Q: What is the role of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire during the Juneteenth and Taylor Swift events?
A: Fire marshals will ensure safety guidelines are followed for the fireworks and pyrotechnics.


Q: What is the purpose of the Fire Investigation Unit's annual fireworks task force?
A: To respond to fireworks-related calls and complaints from June 29 to July 6, 2023.


Q: What restrictions are there on fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be ignited on property without permission, within 150 feet of a building or vehicle, or in city parks.

Q: What restrictions apply to the use of consumer-grade fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Municipalities may restrict the use of consumer-grade fireworks between 10 p.m. and 10 a.m., except for July 2, 3, and 4, where they can be displayed until 1 a.m.


Q: What is the role of the Fireworks Task Force in Pittsburgh?
A: The Fireworks Task Force enforces safe usage of legally purchased fireworks, issues warnings, citations, arrests, and confiscates fireworks if misused or used illegally.


Q: What are the scheduled times for fireworks at Point State Park on July 4th?
A: Fireworks are scheduled from 9:35 - 10:00 p.m. at Point State Park on July 4th.


Q: What road closures are in place for the July 4th celebrations in Pittsburgh?
A: Liberty Avenue from Stanwix to Commonwealth Place, 376E exit 70A to Liberty Avenue, and Commonwealth Place will be closed at various times on July 4th.


Q: Who was Earl Buford Jr., and when did he serve as Pittsburgh's police chief?
A: Earl Buford Jr. was the Pittsburgh police chief from 1992 until 1995 and was the second minority to hold the position.


Q: What is the purpose of the planned exercise by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire on August 22, 2023?
A: The exercise simulates a real-world rescue and involves the use of Blackhawk helicopters to prepare teams for potential disaster situations.


Q: What happened during the active shooter incident in Pittsburgh's Garfield neighborhood on August 23, 2023?
A: Pittsburgh police and SWAT responded to shots fired during an eviction notice, resulting in a standoff where the subject was pronounced deceased.


Q: What was Lieutenant Randolph "Randy" Meyer, II known for in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: He was known for his courage, dedication, and mentorship, and he passed away after battling appendiceal cancer.


Q: What actions are being taken following the use of force encounter in Pittsburgh on August 25, 2023?
A: An independent use of force review is commissioned to ensure adherence to policy and national best practices.

A: The Department of Public Safety is preparing for road closures and increased public safety presence due to expected large crowds.

A: Officers will transition to four 10-hour shifts each week with three consecutive days off.

A: The Violent Crime Division, including homicide, narcotics, intelligence, and the violence prevention unit.


Q: What is the purpose of the Pittsburgh Police CARES portal?
A: It is a one-stop shop for police/community engagement events, safety alerts, monthly crime statistics, and zone/neighborhood-centered news.


Q: Why is the City of Pittsburgh pausing the spay and neuter program?
A: Due to inappropriate use of the program by individuals using city addresses of friends and family to bring in animals from outside city limits.


Q: Who received a proclamation for forty-three years of service at the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire ceremony?
A: Maxine Anthony.


Q: What policy changes have the Pittsburgh Police made following the death of Jim Rogers?
A: Assigning an officer to monitor prisoners during hospital transfers, summoning EMS after taser use, retraining on avoiding single officer tactics, training on the "duty to intervene," and reviewing all body worn camera footage after use of force incidents.

A: The graduation ceremony was held on March 6, 2024.

Q: What percentage of burglar alarm calls in Pittsburgh in 2023 resulted in verified incidents?
A: 0.43% of calls resulted in verified incidents.


Q: How many police staff hours were spent responding to burglar alarms in Pittsburgh in 2023?
A: 4,166 police staff hours were spent.


Q: What changes are being made to the Pittsburgh police response protocol for burglar alarms?
A: Verified alarms will be dispatched as high priority, while unverified alarms will be treated as non-priority.


Q: What will happen after the fifth false alarm response in a calendar year in Pittsburgh?
A: Pittsburgh police supervisors are permitted to disregard the call.

Q: When does the updated response model for police response to false alarms go into effect in Pittsburgh?
A: April 15, 2024.

A: Applicants must be at least 18 years old, possess a valid Class C Pennsylvania driver’s license, pass a background check, and be Pittsburgh residents.

A: The camps are held at Allegheny County Community College, Duquesne University, University of Pittsburgh, and Chatham University.

A: Fifty city youths are invited to attend each session.

Q: What measures are being taken by the city of Pittsburgh to ensure the safety of protesters?
A: The city of Pittsburgh will protect protesters' First Amendment rights and ensure safety by having police officers work 12-hour shifts indefinitely.


Q: What advice is given to Pittsburgh residents to avoid falling victim to scammers posing as utility workers?
A: Residents are advised to use caution when opening doors to strangers, check the identification of workers, verify with the company, and call the police if in doubt.

A: The suspect was found deceased with an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, and no officers or residents were injured.


Q: What restrictions are in place for pet owners in Pittsburgh during hot weather?
A: Pet owners cannot leave dogs outside for more than 30 minutes when temperatures exceed 90 degrees, and pets cannot be left in hot vehicles.


Q: How many arrests and medical incidents were reported during the Luke Bryan concert?
A: There was one arrest and 88 patients treated by EMS, with 30 transported to hospitals.

A: There were no evacuations, no hazmat concerns, and no injuries, but West Carson Street and the Smithfield Street Bridge were closed.

A: Early warning signs include "not feeling quite right," upset stomach, or feeling a little sweaty.

A: Officer Hall's motto, “Gotta go. Time for me to make a difference,” reflects his dedication to making a positive impact, which his fellow officers honored through a blood drive.

A: There will be temporary road closures and rolling closures to accommodate the funeral procession.

A: They began a two-week enforcement campaign in school zones, strictly enforcing traffic laws.

A: A $250 fine, $117.50 in court costs and state fees, 5 points on the driver's license, and a 60-day suspension.

Police Department, Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, and the Drug Enforcement Administration.

A: They received more than $1 million in federal and civic funding.

A: Three new EMTs and ten paramedics were sworn in.

A: Pittsburgh Public Safety is anticipating a more robust turnout with larger-than-usual crowds for the St. Patrick's Day parade and gatherings.

Q: What safety measures will be enforced during St. Patrick's Day celebrations in Pittsburgh?
A: Pittsburgh police will monitor for underage drinking, public intoxication, and drinking and driving. Open container laws will be strictly enforced, and temporary light towers will be used for security.


Q: What is the OneCOP program in Pittsburgh?
A: The OneCOP program is a partnership between Pittsburgh police and local faith-based organizations to strengthen community ties and improve police-citizen relationships.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire held a promotions ceremony where Jeffrey Morris was promoted to battalion chief, and several others were promoted to captain and lieutenant.

A: The Pittsburgh Marathon returns on May 1, 2022, and residents should be aware of road closures and parking restrictions starting from April 30, 2022.

A: The report provides a comprehensive overview of the bureau's work, including statistical analyses and community engagement efforts, to promote transparency and improvement.

A: Chief Scott Schubert announced his retirement on May 27, 2022, after 29 years with the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police.

A: Chief Schubert implemented the pillars of President Obama's task force report, focusing on building trust and legitimacy in the community.

A: Schubert established the Pittsburgh Police Community Engagement Office.

A: GVI is a partnership between law enforcement, social services, and the faith community to mediate and interrupt violence.

A: Schubert led the creation of a Real Time Crime Center (RTCC).

A: OSAR was responsible for incubating, fostering, and implementing Pittsburgh police initiatives and advancing the strategic mission of the chief of police.

A: Schubert established a High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (HIDTA) unit.

A: The Civil Affairs Unit serves as liaisons with activists and stakeholders during First Amendment-protected activities.

Q: What is the time frame for Halloween block party permits in Pittsburgh?

Q: What are the requirements for obtaining a block party permit in Pittsburgh?
A: The applicant must live on the block being closed, permits can only be issued for streets in residentially-zoned areas, closures are limited to one block in length, and all residents of the requested block must be informed of the permit request.

Q: What is the fee for a block party permit in Pittsburgh?
A: The fee for a block party permit is $25.

A: Questions can be directed to the Office of Film & Event Management at ofem@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: When did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police transition to the National Incident-Based Reporting System (NIBRS)?
A: The transition began on November 14, 2023.


Q: What is a key difference between NIBRS and the Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) method?
A: NIBRS documents "crimes against society" and allows reporting of multiple offenses in one incident, unlike UCR which reports only the most serious offense.


Q: What new categories of crime does NIBRS document that UCR did not?
A: NIBRS documents crimes such as animal cruelty, extortion, and identity theft.


Q: When is the 62nd annual Highmark Light Up Night in Pittsburgh scheduled?
A: It is scheduled for Saturday, November 18.

A: Therese Rocco was Pittsburgh's first female assistant chief of police and a nationally renowned expert in missing persons.

A: The viewing and prayer service is on Monday, December 18, from 09:30-10:30 a.m.

A: Highmark First Night 2024 marks the start of the New Year celebrations.

A: The training lasted thirty-two weeks.


Q: Who received the academic achievement and physical fitness awards in the recruit class 133-23 of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: Richard Fashion received the academic achievement award, and Hunter Reed earned the physical fitness award.

Q: What did Mr. Todd Hollis, attorney for the family of Jim Rogers, release publicly?
A: Mr. Todd Hollis released the body worn and dash camera footage of the Pittsburgh police interaction with Jim Rogers on October 13, 2021.


Q: What improvements did Pittsburgh police make after the incident involving Jim Rogers?
A: Pittsburgh police made several policy and procedural improvements, including assigning an officer to monitor prisoners during hospital transfer, summoning EMS after Taser deployment, retraining on avoiding single officer tactics, training on "duty to intervene," and reviewing body camera footage after use of force.


Q: Why has the City of Pittsburgh paused its spay and neuter program?
A: The program was paused due to abuses, such as individuals using city addresses of friends to bring in animals from outside city limits.


Q: What is the goal of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's transition to four 10-hour shifts?
A: The goal is to enhance officer wellness by providing an additional day away from work each week.


Q: What new division is being formed by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police to address crime?
A: The Violent Crime Division, which includes homicide, narcotics, intelligence, and the violence prevention unit.


Q: How are Pittsburgh police officers being supported in terms of wellness under the new operational changes?
A: Officers will have one hour of wellness time each week while on shift.


Q: How many new officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Police Academy in March 2024?
A: Twenty-four new officers graduated.

A: It is an online resource for police/community engagement events, safety alerts, crime statistics, and neighborhood-centered news.

Q: What is the purpose of the new Pittsburgh police substation on Mary Street?
A: It allows officers to attend roll call, complete paperwork, or take breaks while remaining close to E. Carson.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh LEAD program designed to address?
A: It addresses the root causes of criminal justice involvement by providing diversion methods for individuals with substance use disorder and mental and behavioral health challenges.


Q: When will the LEAD program launch in Pittsburgh?
A: The program will launch in Spring 2024.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarm calls in 2023 generated police reports in Pittsburgh?
A: 0.43% of burglar alarm calls generated police reports.


Q: What is the new response protocol for unverified burglar alarms in Pittsburgh?
A: Unverified burglar alarms will be dispatched with the same level of response given to other non-priority calls for service.


Q: What is the penalty for false burglar alarms under Pittsburgh's ordinance 611.07?
A: After two false alarm responses, the permit holder must pay a fee, and calls may be disregarded after the fifth false alarm in a calendar year.


Q: What requirements must applicants meet to become a school crossing guard in Pittsburgh?
A: Applicants must be at least 18 years old, possess a valid class C Pennsylvania driver's license, pass a background check, and be city residents.

Q: What is the philosophy of the group regarding peaceful protests?
A: The group protects all parties involved and facilitates the event without arresting protesters exercising their constitutional rights, unless the protest turns violent or destructive.

A: Camerin Caldwell faces charges of criminal attempt homicide (two counts), aggravated assault (two counts), reckless endangerment (two counts), and firearms violations.


Q: What was Officer Calvin Hall's role in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was a 2-year veteran assigned to the Northview Heights Public Safety Center, known for his dedication to community outreach.


Q: How did Officer Calvin Hall die?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was shot three times in the back and passed away after fighting for more than three days.


Q: What did the family of Officer Calvin Hall express gratitude for in their statement?
A: The family expressed gratitude for the care from UPMC Presbyterian staff, support from the police force, and the community's love and support.


Q: What heat advisory was issued for Pittsburgh in July 2019?
A: A heat advisory was issued from noon on Friday until 8 p.m. Saturday, predicting a heat index between 100 and 105 degrees.

Q: Who held a news conference to provide information on safely dealing with extreme heat conditions in Pittsburgh?
A: Pittsburgh Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich, Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS Chief Ron Romano, Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire Chief Darryl Jones, Parks and Recreation Director Ross Chapman, and Dr. Donald Yealy from UPMC.


Q: What actions will be taken against those who leave animals or children in vehicles during the heat event?
A: They will be aggressively prosecuted.


Q: What are some early warning signs of heat stress mentioned by Dr. Donald Yealy?
A: Not feeling quite right, upset stomach, or feeling a little sweaty.


Q: What does EMS Chief Ron Romano advise residents to do during extreme heat conditions?
A: Drink plenty of fluids and stay indoors, especially those with underlying medical conditions.


Q: What warning did Fire Chief Darryl Jones give regarding cooling down during extreme heat?
A: Opening neighborhood fire hydrants is potentially dangerous and could lead to a water shortage.


Q: What facilities did Parks and Recreation Director Ross Chapman suggest as alternatives for cooling down?
A: The city's 18 public pools, eight spray parks, and three cooling centers.


Q: When and where will the end of watch ceremony for Officer Calvin Hall take place?
A: On July 20, at 8 p.m. in the 1500 block of Brighton Road, directly in front of Zone 1.


Q: What arrangements have been made for Officer Calvin Hall's funeral and viewing?
A: The viewing is on July 22 at Soldiers & Sailors Memorial Hall, and the funeral is on July 23 at the same location.


Q: What temporary road closures will occur for Officer Hall's funeral?
A: Fifth Avenue will be closed temporarily, and there will be rolling closures for the funeral procession.


Q: What initiative did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police launch in honor of Officer Calvin Hall?
A: A month-long blood drive in partnership with Vitalant.


Q: Who was arrested in connection with a double stabbing in downtown Pittsburgh?
A: James Wyatt, 23, of McKeesport.


Q: What precautions are Pittsburgh police taking for the new school year?
A: A two-week enforcement campaign in school zones, ensuring operational school zone signs, and meeting with crossing guards.


Q: What penalties are mentioned for traffic violations in school zones?
A: Fines for passing a school bus with red lights activated and speeding in school zones, along with points on a driver's license and possible suspension.


Q: What temporary changes are happening at Fire Station 8 in East Liberty?
A: The station will close for repairs, and personnel and equipment will be moved to other stations.

Q: What will happen to the service provided by Fire Station 8 during repairs?
A: Residents currently served by Fire Station 8 will have uninterrupted service during repairs.


Q: Who was promoted to the rank of captain at the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire promotion ceremony?
A: Michael Schanck was promoted to the rank of captain.


Q: When will the Department of Defense conduct training in the greater Pittsburgh area?
A: The Department of Defense will conduct training from September 16 through September 22.


Q: How have Part 1 property crimes changed in the first eight months of 2019 compared to the five-year average?
A: Part 1 property crimes show a 4% decrease compared to the five-year average.


Q: What is the primary responsibility of officers assigned to the downtown substation in Pittsburgh?
A: Their primary responsibility is to perform foot patrols in the downtown core.


Q: What event will take place at the convention center on September 16, 2019?
A: A public safety drill involving an active threat scenario will occur.


Q: What task force arrested a man in connection with South Side overdose deaths?
A: A task force of Pittsburgh Bureau of Police detectives and federal law enforcement officials arrested the man.


Q: How much funding did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire receive to serve the deaf and hard of hearing?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire received more than $1 million in funding.


Q: What is the goal of the "Scentsational" tracking program launched by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: The goal is to create a safety net for those who might get lost and have trouble finding their way home using the scent of a loved one.

Q: What is the purpose of the scentsational tracking program launched by the Pittsburgh Bureau?
A: The program is designed to help find missing people, particularly those with cognitive disabilities, using bloodhounds.


Q: Who can benefit from the bloodhound tracking services offered by Pittsburgh's public safety department?
A: The service is available to anyone who wants it, including other communities in Western Pennsylvania.


Q: What accolade did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive in 2019?
A: They received the American Heart Association’s 2019 Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.


Q: What achievement was highlighted by Assistant Chief Mark Pinchalk regarding STEMI patient care?
A: The goal of getting a patient from the scene to having their vessels opened in a cardiac catheterization lab in under 90 minutes was achieved in about 80% of cases in 2018, with an average time of 80 minutes.


Q: What event is causing street closures in Pittsburgh on October 23, 2019?
A: President Donald Trump’s visit to the David L. Lawrence Convention Center for the Shale Insight Conference.


Q: What is National Prescription Drug Take Back Day, and when is it scheduled in 2019?
A: It is an event for safely disposing of unused prescription drugs, scheduled for October 26, 2019.


Q: What is the significance of October 27, 2019, for the Tree of Life synagogue?
A: It marks one year since the tragic shooting at the synagogue.


Q: What challenges do the Pittsburgh police officers injured in the Tree of Life shooting face?
A: Officers continue to recover from serious injuries, with some still off the job.


Q: How does the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS contribute to public safety during high-profile events?
A: They work with partner law enforcement agencies to address safety concerns and manage traffic.


Q: What is the public advised to do with unused prescription drugs?
A: They are advised to drop them off at designated locations for safe disposal instead of flushing them down the toilet or throwing them in the trash.

Q: What is the purpose of the Group Violence Intervention (GVI) program in Pittsburgh?
A: The GVI program aims to help individuals most likely to commit or become victims of violent crime escape a dangerous lifestyle.


Q: What type of relationships does the Pittsburgh Police maintain with other agencies?
A: The Pittsburgh Police maintain great working relationships with the district attorney’s office, US attorney’s office, FBI Pittsburgh, university police departments, county law enforcement agencies, and neighboring regional agencies.


Q: By how much did violent crime downtown Pittsburgh increase from 2018 to 2019?
A: Violent crime downtown increased from 119 cases in 2018 to 136 cases in 2019.


Q: What increase was observed in ethnic intimidation cases in Pittsburgh from 2018 to 2019?
A: Ethnic intimidation cases increased from 17 total incidents (6 involving violence) in 2018 to 22 total incidents (11 involving violence) in 2019.


Q: What life-saving tool has Allegheny Health Network donated to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Allegheny Health Network donated 1,000 packages of NuStat hemostatic gauze to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police.


Q: What is the purpose of the NuStat hemostatic gauze provided to Pittsburgh police officers?
A: The NuStat gauze is used to control bleeding and prevent infection in trauma wounds until a patient can be transported to the hospital.


Q: What preparations has the Pittsburgh Public Safety Department made for a potential coronavirus outbreak?
A: Preparations include updating the pandemic operational plan, training first responders, and providing enhanced personal protection kits.

A: Seven firefighters were instructed to self-quarantine.

A: The officer tested positive on April 4, 2020.

A: Individuals who had contact are being identified, notified, and placed in self-quarantine.

A: The potential exposure occurred at the outdoor police firing range in Zone 5.

A: The DAAT taskforce investigates looting, vandalism, assaults on journalists, and analyzes digital evidence related to protests.

A: By sharing videos, photographs, or information via email to daat@pittsburghpa.gov or calling (412) 323-7800.


Q: What significant increase in fireworks complaint calls did Pittsburgh police experience in June 2020?
A: A 389 percent increase over the same period last year.


Q: What are the restrictions on fireworks usage in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be used within 150 feet of any structure, in parks, public spaces, or on private property without consent.


Q: What was the purpose of the fireworks taskforce formed in Pittsburgh?
A: To patrol neighborhoods and respond to illegal fireworks usage.

A: Hunting, trapping, feeding, and harvesting wildlife are prohibited.

A: Mandatory masks, social distancing, daily screenings, and strict quarantine/isolation procedures.

A: Venues are closed, large gatherings are prohibited, fireworks are canceled, and First Night is a made-for-TV event.

A: The use of fireworks within 150 feet of a structure is prohibited.

A: Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich administered the oaths.


Q: What new tool has been created to address opioid use in Pittsburgh?
A: The Opioid Overdose Dashboard has been created to help form and guide policies and programs to address opioid use.


Q: What data will the Opioid Overdose Dashboard compile?
A: It will compile EMS data to map monthly opioid overdose calls, including demographic information and statistics on care provided by first responders.


Q: What is the purpose of the newly launched victim assistance website in Pittsburgh?
A: It connects crime victims to services such as crisis intervention, referrals, information, and advocacy.


Q: What is the role of the Office of Community Health and Safety in Pittsburgh?
A: It coordinates an equitable public health-informed response to the overdose crisis and provides weekly reports to city staff and partner organizations.

A: They will enforce pandemic protocols, occupancy restrictions, and laws against underage drinking, public intoxication, and open container violations.

Q: What are the potential health risks mentioned by Dr. Donald Yealy related to heat during the celebrations?
A: Heat exhaustion and heat stroke.


Q: What advice does Dr. Donald Yealy give regarding hydration?
A: Avoid alcohol as it dehydrates, and be cautious with certain medications that can impair the body's response to heat.


Q: What safety concern does Wendell Hissrich highlight regarding children and vehicles?
A: The danger of leaving children in hot vehicles, as temperatures can rise quickly, leading to heat stroke or death.


Q: What is the purpose of the fireworks taskforce mentioned in the text?
A: To patrol city neighborhoods and respond to complaints about illegal fireworks use.


Q: What is the warning given about consumer-grade fireworks?
A: They are fire hazards and can cause injuries, particularly when used in celebratory settings with alcohol.


Q: What is the recommendation for those not vaccinated against COVID-19 during the celebrations?
A: To wear a mask, as the virus still poses a risk.


Q: How will the Pittsburgh police manage crowd movement after the fireworks display?
A: By working with Port Authority personnel to move people out of the downtown core quickly.


Q: What is the penalty for obstructing public passageways on East Carson Street?
A: Citations carrying penalties of up to $300 plus court costs, and potential physical arrests for non-compliance.


Q: What specific safety measures are being implemented in the South Side business district?
A: Issuing warnings and citations for obstructing passageways, and enforcing parking regulations with motorcycle and bicycle units.


Q: What are the forecasted weather conditions for Independence Day in Pittsburgh?
A: Temperatures in the 80s with mostly sunny skies.

Q: What danger does Wendell Hissrich warn about regarding hot weather?
A: Wendell Hissrich warns about the danger of forgetting children in hot vehicles, which can lead to heat stroke and even death.


Q: How much can the temperature inside a vehicle rise within 10 minutes, even with a window open?
A: The temperature inside a vehicle can rise by 20 degrees within 10 minutes, even with a window open.


Q: What does Yealy recommend for those who are not vaccinated against COVID-19?
A: Yealy recommends that those who are not vaccinated should wear a mask, even at outdoor activities.

Q: What traffic adjustments were announced for East Carson Street on weekends?
A: Vehicle traffic will be outbound only between S.10th and S.18th streets, side streets will be closed, and ride-sharing services will not be permitted on East Carson Street.

A: CEO officers participated in community walks, summer camps, sports practices, and events like "pizza with the police" and community picnics.

A: The ceremony was to swear in four new EMTs and two paramedics to the city of Pittsburgh.


Q: What ongoing adjustments are being enforced on East Carson Street during weekends?
A: Adjustments include converting traffic to one-way, prohibiting parking and deliveries, and restricting ride-sharing services.

A: The goal is to mitigate gridlock, ensure emergency vehicle access, and create a safer experience for residents and visitors.

A: Changed the start time for traffic conversion to 9:30 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.

Q: How many people lost their lives in the September 11, 2001, attacks?
A: Close to 3,000 people.

A: They are working with the FBI to investigate the threats and have increased patrols to safeguard churches.

A: They attended the Steelers home opener at Heinz Field.

A: 21 years.

A: Complications from COVID-19.

A: It will convert back to two-way traffic between S.10th and S.18th streets in the evenings.

A: 12 arrests, including one firearms-related arrest.

A: They announced policy and procedural changes including mandatory supervisor presence at use of force incidents and retraining of officers.

A: All officers were required to complete a Taser refresher course and become fully certified emergency medical responders.

A: Phillip Carey was promoted to the rank of assistant chief.

A: A proper fitting, three-layer surgical-type mask is recommended over a cloth mask.

A: Residents should expect temporary traffic disruptions and parking restrictions along 2nd Avenue between the Glenwood Bridge and Hazelwood Avenue.

A: The bridge collapsed on January 28, 2022, at 6:39 a.m.

A: Ten people were evaluated and treated for minor injuries, with three transported to local hospitals with non-life-threatening injuries.


Q: What special plan was activated due to the Forbes Avenue bridge collapse?
A: The mass casualty plan was activated.

A: Fire Chief Darryl Jones was named the emergency management coordinator.

A: He is a PA certified municipal emergency management professional and holds a doctorate in public safety with a specialty in emergency management.

A: The OneCOP inaugural luncheon is on Thursday, March 24, at the IBEW Local Union 5.

A: Chief Scott Schubert implemented the pillars of former President Obama's task force report on 21st century policing.


Q: What is the Group Violence Intervention (GVI) program?
A: The GVI program is a partnership between law enforcement, social services, and the faith community to mediate and interrupt violence.

A: Chief Schubert led efforts to create a Real Time Crime Center (RTCC) to promote safety using crime-solving technology.


Q: What is the purpose of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's Civil Affairs Unit?
A: The Civil Affairs Unit ensures well-trained officers serve as liaisons during First Amendment-protected activities to increase communication and community trust.

A: The city of Pittsburgh publishes an extensive annual report with detailed crime statistics, arrest information, and a demographic breakdown of the bureau of police.

A: Scott Schubert's final day as police chief is Friday, July 1, 2022.

Q: What is unique about Pittsburgh's emergency medical services (EMS) system?
A: Physicians work side-by-side with paramedics and EMTs in the field on emergency calls and during training and protocol development.

Q: What recent change did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police make in crime data reporting?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police switched from the Uniform Crime Reporting method to the National Incident Based Reporting System (NIBRS).


Q: What is the significance of NIBRS in crime reporting?
A: NIBRS provides more specific crime data and includes "crimes against society," which were not documented under the previous UCR method.


Q: What recent event did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS hold?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS held a swearing-in and promotions ceremony for nine members.

A: Brian Havaran was promoted to the rank of district chief.

A: Highmark First Night 2024.


Q: How many recruits graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's recruit class 133-23?
A: Twenty-nine recruits.


Q: What awards were given during the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's graduation ceremony, and to whom?
A: Richard Fashion received the Academic Achievement Award and Hunter Reed earned the Physical Fitness Award.


Q: What changes have the Pittsburgh Police made following the death of Jim Rogers?
A: Assigning officers to monitor prisoners during transfers, summoning EMS after taser use, retraining on single officer tactics, training on "duty to intervene," and reviewing body camera footage after use of force.


Q: Why is the City of Pittsburgh pausing its spay and neuter program?
A: Due to inappropriate use of services and increased associated costs.

Q: What changes are being made to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's work schedule starting February 26, 2024?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police will transition to four 10-hour shifts each week, with three consecutive days off.


Q: How many personnel were promoted in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police promotion ceremony?
A: Thirteen personnel were promoted.


Q: What is the purpose of the new work schedule for Pittsburgh police officers?
A: The new schedule is designed to enhance officer wellness and contribute to recruiting and retaining officers.


Q: What new division is being formed to address violent crime in Pittsburgh?
A: The Violent Crime Division, which includes homicide, narcotics, intelligence, and the Violence Prevention Unit.


Q: Who were promoted to the position of assistant chief in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Christopher Ragland, Martin Devine, and Richard Ford.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Police Cares Portal?
A: An online portal for police/community engagement events, safety alerts, monthly crime statistics, and zone/neighborhood-centered news.


Q: How many new officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police on March 6, 2024?
A: Twenty-four new officers graduated.


Q: What event is expected to attract 200,000 spectators in Pittsburgh?
A: The annual St. Patrick's Day parade.


Q: What will the Pittsburgh police substation on Mary Street be used for?
A: It will be used for officers to attend roll call, complete paperwork, or take breaks, but not for holding or detaining arrestees.


Q: What is the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program launched by the City of Pittsburgh?
A: A diversion method aimed at addressing the root causes of criminal justice involvement.

Q: What program did Mayor Ed Gainey and others celebrate the launch of in Pittsburgh?
A: The Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program.


Q: What is the main goal of the LEAD program in Pittsburgh?
A: To improve public safety and public order and reduce unnecessary justice system involvement for participants.


Q: When is the LEAD program expected to launch in Pittsburgh?
A: Spring 2024.


Q: In which Pittsburgh police zones will the LEAD program initially launch?
A: Police zones 1 and 2.


Q: What types of offenses is the LEAD program focusing on?
A: Low-level offenses associated with unmet behavioral health needs, trauma, and/or extreme poverty.


Q: What is the expected benefit of the LEAD program according to Chief of Police Larry Scirotto?
A: Reduction in recidivism, homelessness, overdoses, and high utilization of 911 services.


Q: How many calls for service for burglar alarms were there in Pittsburgh in 2023?
A: 9,097 calls.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarm calls in Pittsburgh in 2023 resulted in police reports?
A: 0.43%.


Q: What new protocol will the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police implement for burglar alarms starting April 15, 2024?
A: Verified burglar alarms will be dispatched as high priority calls, while unverified alarms will be treated as non-priority.


Q: How many police staff hours were spent on burglar alarm responses in Pittsburgh in 2023?
A: 4,166 police staff hours.


Q: What penalty will be enforced for false burglar alarms in Pittsburgh?
A: Permit holders will be required to pay a fee after two false alarms, and calls may be disregarded after the fifth false alarm in a calendar year.


Q: What are the requirements to apply for a school crossing guard position in Pittsburgh?
A: Must be at least 18 years old, possess a valid Class C Pennsylvania driver's license, pass a background check, and be a Pittsburgh resident.


Q: Who was charged with 19 counts of criminal mischief for graffiti in Pittsburgh?
A: Tylor O'Connell.


Q: What is the estimated damage caused by Tylor O'Connell's graffiti tags?
A: Approximately $26,450.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Police's approach to peaceful protests?
A: They protect all parties involved, facilitate the event, and do not arrest protesters exercising their constitutional rights unless the protest turns violent or destructive.


Q: What type of alarms will still receive priority response under Pittsburgh's new burglar alarm protocol?
A: Human-activated hold-up and panic alarms, medical alert alarms, and verified alarms with reliable information of a crime.


Q: Who was arrested for the non-fatal shooting of a 72-year-old woman in Sheraden?
A: Tyler Sherrell.

Q: Where was a male victim found with multiple gunshot wounds on August 18, 2017?
A: The 2400 block of Colorado Street.


Q: Who was arrested in connection with the shooting on Colorado Street?
A: 41-year-old Brett Thomas Beecher.


Q: What charges were filed against Brett Thomas Beecher?
A: Criminal attempt homicide, aggravated assault, reckless endangerment of another person, and firearms violations.


Q: What was the condition of the 25-year-old male victim after being transported to the hospital?
A: He was reported to be in stable condition.


Q: Where did the shooting involving Brett Thomas Beecher and the victim occur?
A: In Beecher's living room on the second floor of the residence.


Q: What happened on August 18, 2017, in Homewood?
A: An adult female was grazed by a bullet in the head and foot.


Q: What was the condition of the female victim grazed by a bullet in Homewood?
A: She was in stable condition.


Q: What information is available about the shooter in the Homewood incident?
A: No information is available concerning the shooter/shooters or circumstances.


Q: What crime occurred at Dollar Bank on August 21, 2017?
A: A bank robbery involving a white male displaying a knife.


Q: How was the suspect in the Dollar Bank robbery described?

A: Use internet-based resources to verify the existence and legitimacy of non-profit organizations.

A: Make donations directly to known organizations rather than relying on others to donate on your behalf.

A: Pay by debit or credit card or write a check directly to the charity, and avoid cash donations if possible.

A: Do not make checks payable to individuals.

Q: How many incidents of ethnic intimidation did Pittsburgh average per year over a ten-year period?
A: Pittsburgh averaged 19 incidents per year.

A: 76% of the incidents involved race.


Q: What is the arrest rate for ethnic intimidation incidents in Pittsburgh?
A: The arrest rates for ethnic intimidation incidents average 40%.


Q: Which type of bias is the most common contributor to ethnic intimidation charges in Pittsburgh?
A: Racial animus is the most common contributor.


Q: What does the Pennsylvania ethnic intimidation crimes code not cover that the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police tracks?
A: Sexual orientation is not covered by the Pennsylvania ethnic intimidation crimes code, but the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police tracks it.

A: He emphasized the importance of residents reporting potential crimes involving ethnic intimidation.

Q: What has been formed to address the illegal use of fireworks in Pittsburgh neighborhoods?
A: A fireworks taskforce made up of Pittsburgh police and fire investigators has been formed.


Q: What is prohibited by city law regarding fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: The use of fireworks, even those that are legal, is prohibited within 150 feet of any structure, in all parks, any public space, and on private property without the landowner's consent.


Q: What is the penalty for violating fireworks law in Pittsburgh?
A: Anyone caught violating fireworks law is subject to a $100 fine and the possible seizure of their fireworks.


Q: What did Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire’s fire prevention officer Lisa Epps-Cuda say about sparklers?
A: Lisa Epps-Cuda stated that sparklers are not safe and burn at 1,200 degrees, which is why they should not be put in the hands of a child.


Q: What changes will Pittsburgh police make during the Fourth of July due to the pandemic?
A: Police will counsel people not adhering to physical distancing or mask-wearing, instruct large groups to disperse, and enforce laws.


Q: What specific safety tips were provided for the Fourth of July holiday weekend in Pittsburgh?
A: Safety tips include not using fireworks illegally, not firing guns in the air, practicing water safety, following pandemic guidelines, preparing for heat, not drinking and driving, and remembering pet safety.


Q: What incidents underscored the dangers of fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Incidents included a fire at Horace Mann School causing $50,000 to $60,000 damage, a minor burn injury at McNaugher School, and a brush fire on Rose Street.

Q: What issue did Pittsburgh face regarding off-road vehicles in 2020?
A: Large numbers of unlawful off-road vehicles were riding recklessly on city streets.


Q: What was the purpose of the opioid overdose dashboard announced by Pittsburgh officials in March 2021?
A: To address unsafe opioid use.

Q: What is the purpose of the new public dashboard in Pittsburgh?
A: The dashboard is designed to help form and guide policies and programs to more effectively address unsafe opioid use in Pittsburgh by compiling EMS data on opioid overdose calls and public safety responses.


Q: What kind of data will the Pittsburgh opioid dashboard include?
A: The dashboard will include the number of people who overdose, neighborhood-level mapping, demographic information, and other statistics regarding care provided by on-scene first responders.


Q: Who will issue weekly reports to coordinate a response to the overdose crisis in Pittsburgh?
A: The Office of Community Health and Safety will issue weekly reports to city staff and partner organizations.


Q: What is the goal of the Office of Community Health and Safety's weekly reports?
A: The goal is to coordinate an equitable public health-informed response to the overdose crisis.


Q: What approach does the Office of Community Health and Safety aim to employ for opioid overdose prevention?
A: They aim to utilize a person-first approach and address social determinants of health.


Q: What event did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire hold on March 19, 2021?
A: They held a swearing-in ceremony for the latest recruit class of firefighters.


Q: How many recruits graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire recruit class in March 2021?
A: 23 recruits graduated.


Q: What was unique about the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire recruit class during the pandemic?
A: The class size was smaller, with 24 starting and 23 graduating, to comply with COVID-19 measures.


Q: What new resource did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police create for public assistance?
A: They created a central email address for animal welfare complaints and concerns.

A: animal.law@pittsburghpa.gov
