A: Detective James Sherer and Detective Joseph Simunovic were promoted to the rank of sergeant.


Q: What is the focus of the newly-launched victim assistance website by Pittsburgh's Public Safety Department?
A: The website connects victims to services like crisis intervention, referrals, information, and advocacy.

Q: How many homicides have occurred in Pittsburgh so far in 2021?
A: There have been 20 homicides in Pittsburgh so far in 2021.


Q: What percentage increase do the 2021 homicides and non-fatal shootings represent compared to the previous year?
A: The homicides represent an 80% increase, and non-fatal shootings represent a 90% increase compared to the previous year.


Q: What approach are Pittsburgh police taking to address the surge in violent crime?
A: Pittsburgh police are taking a proactive approach by having community resource officers and neighborhood resource officers engage with residents and business owners in affected neighborhoods.


Q: What is the role of Group Violence Intervention (GVI) in Pittsburgh's crime reduction strategy?
A: GVI is a partnership that involves law enforcement, outreach, social services, and the faith community to mediate and interrupt violence.


Q: What was the outcome of the Derek Chauvin trial mentioned in the text?
A: Derek Chauvin was found guilty of second-degree murder, third-degree murder, and manslaughter.


Q: What did Police Chief Scott Schubert emphasize about law enforcement in his statement on the Chauvin trial verdict?
A: Chief Schubert emphasized the importance of mutual trust and respect between police and the communities they serve.


Q: What notable feature does the new Pittsburgh river rescue boat have?
A: The new river rescue boat includes features such as increased fire suppression capabilities, improved lighting, and built-in sonar for accurate search capability.


Q: Who was promoted to battalion chief in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire promotions ceremony?
A: Michael Fuerst was promoted to battalion chief.


Q: What are the requirements for obtaining a block party permit in Pittsburgh?
A: Block party permits are $25, available online, limited to residentially zoned streets, and must be applied for at least seven business days before the event.


Q: How much does a special event permit cost in Pittsburgh, and what is the application deadline?
A: A special event permit costs $200 plus any contracted city services, and applications must be submitted at least 14 business days in advance.

Q: What types of permits can businesses in Pittsburgh apply for to promote outdoor space and social distancing?
A: Businesses can apply for temporary sidewalk cafe, parking lane cafe, full street closure, and curbside pick-up zone permits.


Q: Until when are the outdoor space permits free in Pittsburgh?
A: The permits are free through the end of 2021.


Q: How can park shelters and picnic groves in Pittsburgh be rented?
A: They can be rented online at https://registerparks.pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the purpose of the Stop the Violence Community Investment Grant Program in Pittsburgh?
A: The program funds community projects intended to reduce violence in the city.


Q: Who will lead the Stop the Violence Community Investment Grant Program project?
A: Public Safety Assistant Director of Community Affairs, Shatara Murphy, will lead the project.

A: An initial investment of $1,000,000 will be made.

A: Duquesne Light Company provides hydraulic service trucks and mechanics to assist with hazardous materials safety training.

A: Drowning.


Q: How much higher is the drowning rate for Black children ages 10-14 compared to other children?
A: 7.6 times higher.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Fireworks Task Force's enforcement timeframe?
A: From 7 p.m. until 2 a.m. every night until July 5.


Q: Is it legal to discharge fireworks within 150 feet of a structure in Pittsburgh?
A: No, it is not legal.


Q: What will happen if there are subsequent calls to the same address for fireworks complaints in Pittsburgh?
A: It could result in a $100 citation and confiscation of the fireworks.

A: To focus on citizen complaints regarding abandoned vehicles.

A: On Wednesday, June 23, starting at 10 a.m.

A: 31 homicides in 2021 compared to 20 in 2020.

A: Approximately 75%.

A: Creating a firearms trafficking unit and assigning two agents to work with Pittsburgh police.

Q: What safety measures are Pittsburgh police implementing for the July 4th celebrations?
A: Increased lighting, mounted units to ensure crowd movement, and motorcycle medics for quick response.


Q: What are the potential risks of using consumer-grade fireworks according to Dr. Yealy?
A: Risks include blast injuries, heat injuries, and ocular injuries.


Q: What is a key safety reminder from Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich regarding hot weather?
A: To remember not to leave children or pets in hot vehicles, as temperatures can rise quickly.


Q: How will the Pittsburgh Fireworks Task Force address illegal fireworks use?
A: By continuing nightly enforcement efforts until July 5.

Q: What is the main focus of Pittsburgh's public safety director for the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: The primary focus is to protect residents and visitors so they can safely enjoy Independence Day with their families and friends.


Q: What specific safety measures are being implemented by Pittsburgh police for the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: Pittsburgh police, along with other law enforcement agencies, will use mobile light towers, mounted units, and enforce parking regulations to ensure safety and manage crowds.


Q: What are the penalties for obstructing public passageways on East Carson Street in Pittsburgh?
A: Violators may receive citations with penalties up to $300, plus court costs, and may face physical arrests if they fail to comply.


Q: What is the role of the Pennsylvania State Police helicopter during the Fourth of July celebrations in Pittsburgh?
A: It will monitor from overhead to ensure traffic keeps flowing on bridge decks, reducing congestion and the possibility of collisions.


Q: What precautions are being taken regarding fireworks during the Pittsburgh Independence Day celebration?
A: Fireworks are prohibited in Point State Park or any city park, and their use is banned within 150 feet of any structure.


Q: What is Dr. Donald Yealy's advice for those attending outdoor events during the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: He advises staying hydrated with the right fluids, as alcohol and certain medications can increase the risk of heat-related ailments.


Q: What will Pittsburgh police do to ensure safety on the South Side business district during busy weekends?
A: They will issue warnings and citations for obstructing public passageways and enforce parking regulations, with potential towing of vehicles.


Q: What are the public safety measures for pets during the Fourth of July fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Public safety director Wendell Hissrich advises remembering that fireworks can startle pets, causing them to run away or hide.


Q: How are Pittsburgh police ensuring the safety of children during hot weather?
A: They remind people not to leave children in hot vehicles, as temperatures inside can rise quickly, posing a risk of heat stroke or death.

A: They are strongly encouraged to wear a mask, as the COVID-19 virus still poses a risk.

A: 'No parking' measures will be strictly enforced starting at 8 p.m., including towing of vehicles.

Q: What is the fee for a Halloween block party permit in Pittsburgh?
A: The fee for a Halloween block party permit is $25.


Q: What reporting system did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police switch to on November 14, 2023?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police switched to the National Incident Based Reporting System (NIBRS).

A: The 62nd annual Highmark Light Up Night.


Q: What was Therese Rocco's role in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Therese Rocco was Pittsburgh's first female assistant chief.

A: 1952

A: Assistant Chief of Police

A: Missing persons, particularly children

A: To enhance officer wellness

A: Due to inappropriate use of the program

A: Assistant Chief


Q: What specific improvements have Pittsburgh Police made following the death of Jim Rogers?
A: Assigning an officer to monitor prisoners during transfer and summoning EMS when a taser is deployed

Q: What is the purpose of the centralized deployment for the night shift in Pittsburgh?
A: To strategically place police units throughout zones with multiple supervisors and a night watch commander overseeing operations and resource allocation.


Q: What new division was formed with the goal of reducing violent crime and gun violence?
A: The Violent Crime Division, which includes homicide, narcotics, intelligence, and the violence prevention unit.


Q: What is the function of the blue phones installed in Pittsburgh?
A: They provide a direct line to 9-1-1 between 3 a.m. and 7 a.m. when officers are deployed in the field.


Q: When does the enhanced Telephone Reporting Unit (TRU) operate?
A: From 7 a.m. to 3 a.m. daily, including weekends.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Police Cares Portal?
A: An online portal for police/community engagement events, safety alerts, monthly crime statistics, and zone/neighborhood-centered news.

A: A promotions ceremony for five members advancing in their careers.

A: As many as 200,000 spectators.

A: A new substation on Mary Street open from 7 p.m. to 5 a.m. Wednesdays through Sundays.


Q: What program did the City of Pittsburgh launch to address the root causes of criminal justice involvement?
A: The Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program.


Q: What changes are being made to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's response to burglar alarms?
A: Adjustments to dispatch protocols to reduce responses to false alarms.

Q: How many calls for service for burglar alarms were there in 2023?
A: There were 9,097 calls for service for burglar alarms in 2023.


Q: What percentage of the burglar alarm calls in 2023 generated police reports?
A: 0.43% of the burglar alarm calls generated police reports.


Q: How many incidents involved a verified alarm with a break-in occurring?
A: 6 incidents involved a verified alarm with a break-in occurring.


Q: What was the most common cause of burglar alarms with police reports?
A: The most common cause was vandalism or objects being thrown through windows.


Q: How much police staff time was spent on burglar alarm responses in 2023?
A: 4,166 police staff hours, or 174 days, were spent on burglar alarm responses.


Q: What is the average time spent per unit on burglar alarm responses?
A: The average time spent per unit on burglar alarm responses is 13.5 minutes.


Q: What types of alarms will be prioritized under the new response model?
A: Hold-up alarms, panic alarms, medical alert alarms, alarms at priority locations, verified burglar alarms, and multiple progressive alarm activations will be prioritized.


Q: What happens to unverified burglar alarms under the new model?
A: Unverified burglar alarms will be dispatched with the same level of response given to other non-priority calls and placed in a queue.


Q: What is the policy for documenting and enforcing false burglar alarms?
A: The Pittsburgh police will document officer responses to false alarms and enforce penalties according to city ordinance 611.07.


Q: When will the updated burglar alarm response model go into effect?
A: The updated response model goes into effect on April 15, 2024.


Q: Who was charged with 19 counts of criminal mischief for graffiti tags in Pittsburgh?
A: Tylor O’Connell was charged with 19 counts of criminal mischief.


Q: What are the requirements for applying to be a school crossing guard in Pittsburgh?
A: Applicants must be at least 18 years old, possess a valid class C Pennsylvania driver’s license, pass a background check, and be city residents during employment.

A: Approximately 9:45 a.m. on Wednesday, August 23.

Q: What is BigBurgh.com doing in partnership with Citiparks?
A: BigBurgh.com is featuring the City of Pittsburgh Summer Food Service Program sites in its listings of free meal locations.

Q: What is bigburgh.com?
A: Bigburgh.com is a City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Safety web-app listing free services for people experiencing homelessness or anyone in dire need.


Q: Who can use bigburgh.com?
A: Anyone, including first responders, service providers, and the general public, can use bigburgh.com.


Q: What services does bigburgh.com list?
A: Bigburgh.com lists services such as meals, shelter, clinics, showers, laundry, clothing, diapers, and expert help with financial, legal, and employment matters.


Q: When did bigburgh.com join the list of city web-apps?
A: Bigburgh.com joined the list of city web-apps in 2018.


Q: Who were among the first users of bigburgh.com?
A: City of Pittsburgh police officers were among the first users of bigburgh.com during its pilot phase in 2016.


Q: What is the Citiparks Summer Food Service Program?
A: The Citiparks Summer Food Service Program provides food for children up to 18 years old and individuals with disabilities up to 21 years old.


Q: Who funds the Citiparks Summer Food Service Program?
A: The program is funded by the US Department of Agriculture through the Pennsylvania Department of Education.


Q: How many monthly users does bigburgh.com have on average since its adoption by the city?
A: Bigburgh.com has an average of over 4,800 monthly users since its adoption by the city.


Q: Who should be contacted for more information about bigburgh.com?
A: For more information, contact Sally Stadelman, the City of Pittsburgh manager of bigburgh.com.

Q: What scam are Pittsburgh residents being warned about in December 2018?
A: Pittsburgh residents are being warned about a telephone scam where callers impersonate Duquesne Light Company representatives, threatening immediate service termination unless payment is made with gift cards or pre-paid cards.


Q: What does Duquesne Light Company not ask customers to do?
A: Duquesne Light Company does not ask customers to purchase any type of pre-paid cards.


Q: What should residents do if they suspect a scam call from Duquesne Light?
A: Residents should call Duquesne Light at 412-393-7100 to verify the call, and contact Pittsburgh police at 412-323-7800 if they suspect a scam.

A: Pittsburgh Public Safety will have a significant police presence, including uniformed and plainclothes officers, and will work with law enforcement agencies to maintain safety.


Q: What technology does Pittsburgh use to detect and locate gunfire incidents?
A: Pittsburgh uses ShotSpotter, a wide-area network of acoustic sensors, to detect and locate gunfire incidents.


Q: What were the homicide numbers in Pittsburgh from 2014 to 2018?
A: There were 71 homicides in 2014, 60 in 2015, 59 in 2016, 58 in 2017, and 55 in 2018.

A: A one-alarm fire occurred at a two-story duplex on Lowrie Street, but all residents and pets were safely evacuated.

Q: What legacy did Glenn M. Cannon leave in Pittsburgh's public safety?
A: Glenn M. Cannon was the creator and first leader of Pittsburgh's EMS department and established several specialized rescue units.

A: Glenn M. Cannon served as Pittsburgh's Public Safety Director from 1986 to 1992.

A: Kennedy, Cannon & Devinney.

A: Adjunct faculty member and visiting senior lecturer.

A: Five.

A: Homicides dropped 36 percent from 58 in 2018 to 37 in 2019.

A: The ShotSpotter system.

A: 18 square miles.

A: NuStat Tactical hemostatic gauze.

A: Six.

A: From reactive policing to evidence-based and intelligence-led policing.

A: 18.8 percent.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police attribute the drop in crime rates to?

A: Their knowledge and experience will be indispensable, and they should ensure the safety and guidance of the officers they lead.


Q: What specific public safety measures were emphasized for St. Patrick's Day 2020 in Pittsburgh?
A: Zero tolerance for drinking and driving, underage drinking, and maintaining social distancing due to COVID-19 concerns.


Q: What happened on April 1, 2020, concerning a Pittsburgh firefighter?
A: A Pittsburgh firefighter tested positive for COVID-19 and was in self-isolation at home.


Q: How did Pittsburgh respond to the first police officer testing positive for COVID-19?
A: The officer was sent home, tested, and placed in self-isolation, while those in contact were identified and instructed to self-quarantine.


Q: What preventive measure was taken for City of Pittsburgh staff in response to COVID-19?
A: Staff working in the field and having contact with the public were issued protective masks.

A: They received state recognition for achieving expert-level pediatric care from the Pennsylvania Emergency Health Services Council.

A: EMS District Chief Jeffrey Meyer.

A: Pittsburgh Bureau of Police Chief Scott Schubert.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police release online on July 3, 2019?
A: The 2019 annual report.


Q: What significant statistic was included in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's 2019 annual report?
A: A 36% drop in homicides.


Q: What task force was created in response to the protests in Pittsburgh?
A: The Damage Assessment & Accountability Task Force (DAAT).


Q: What was the purpose of the Damage Assessment & Accountability Task Force?
A: To investigate individuals causing destruction during protests and assess property damage.


Q: Who was arrested in connection with the protests for placing a backpack with homemade explosives?
A: Matthew Michanowicz.


Q: What event led to the formation of a fireworks task force in Pittsburgh?
A: A significant increase in fireworks complaints due to canceled public shows amid COVID-19.


Q: What is prohibited regarding fireworks usage in Pittsburgh city limits?
A: Using fireworks within 150 feet of any structure and in all parks or public spaces.


Q: What was the approach of Pittsburgh's public safety for the Fourth of July during the pandemic?
A: To counsel people on physical distancing and mask-wearing, and enforce laws against large gatherings.


Q: What safety concern is associated with celebratory gunfire during the Fourth of July?
A: Bullets fired into the air can come down and cause deadly results.


Q: What was the role of the newly formed fireworks task force?
A: To patrol neighborhoods and respond to 911 calls for illegal fireworks usage.

Q: What significant risk is associated with swimming in the city's rivers?
A: There is typically not a qualified lifeguard on duty.


Q: What safety measures are being enforced on Pittsburgh's rivers?
A: River rescue, the fire boat, and the coast guard will enforce boating laws and teach water safety.


Q: What health guidelines are recommended to combat the spike in COVID-19 cases in Allegheny County?
A: Maintain proper physical distancing, wear a mask, wash hands for at least 20 seconds often, avoid large crowds, and stay home if unwell.


Q: What is the forecast for the Fourth of July in terms of weather?
A: Temperatures are forecast to be above 90 degrees for many days in a row.


Q: What is the policy on drinking and driving during the Fourth of July?
A: Public safety has a zero-tolerance policy, and patrols will be out actively searching for and arresting impaired drivers.


Q: Why are pets a concern during the Fourth of July?
A: Many dogs are panicked by fireworks and may run away when they hear them.


Q: What was the result of a fireworks-related incident at Horace Mann School?
A: The roof of the abandoned school caught fire, causing an estimated $50,000 to $60,000 in damage.


Q: What does state law prohibit regarding the use of fireworks?
A: The use of fireworks is prohibited within 150 feet of any structure, in all parks, public spaces, and on private property without consent.


Q: What award did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive for the third year in a row?
A: The American Heart Association’s 2020 Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.


Q: What is the purpose of the "Need a Mask, Take a Mask" initiative?
A: To distribute free masks to Pittsburgh residents during the COVID-19 pandemic.


Q: What new capability has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire achieved?
A: Recognition as a Type-3A Swift Water and Flood Response Team.


Q: What significant event occurred for Pittsburgh Police Officer Timothy Matson in October 2020?
A: He returned to work on modified duty nearly two years after being injured in the Tree of Life shooting.


Q: What event did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS hold on October 14, 2020?
A: An outdoor awards, swearing-in, and promotions ceremony.

Q: Who congratulated the Pittsburgh EMS personnel and emphasized the importance of compassion in their service?
A: Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich.


Q: What did Mayor William Peduto remind the new and newly-promoted members of the Pittsburgh EMS during their oath of office?
A: He reminded them that they are part of an organization of leaders and a team that will support them as they serve the people of Pittsburgh.


Q: Which award was presented to paramedics Romayne Bendig and Taylor Mahoney, and for what action?
A: The District Chief’s Award for rescuing a woman struck by a vehicle and trapped underneath.


Q: What action did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich take in response to the COVID-19 pandemic?
A: He suspended all in-person training programs and inter-unit rotations for police, fire, and EMS until after the election period.


Q: How did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police adjust their operations around the federal election on November 3, 2020?
A: They moved to 12-hour shifts from November 2 until November 8, and canceled all pass days, personal days, and holidays.


Q: What was the result of the nuisance bar task force's investigation at Bridgez on Arlington Avenue?
A: Beer, liquor, gambling devices, and cash proceeds were seized, and three individuals were charged for sales of alcohol without a license and illegal gambling.


Q: What measures have been enforced in Frick Park to ensure visitor safety?
A: 'No hunting' signs have been erected, and hunting, trapping, feeding, and/or harvesting wildlife is strictly prohibited.


Q: How many Pittsburgh public safety personnel tested positive for COVID-19 as of the latest report?
A: Nine police officers, nine firefighters, and three EMS members.


Q: What changes were made to Pittsburgh’s New Year’s Eve celebrations in 2020 due to the pandemic?
A: Venues were closed, large gatherings were prohibited, fireworks were canceled, and the event was transformed into a made-for-TV-only event.


Q: What were the two separate incidents involving explosives in Pittsburgh on January 4, 2021?
A: An improvised explosive device damaged a parked vehicle on Penn Avenue, and an aerial firework caused an explosion on Dinwiddie Street.

Q: Who is the public safety director mentioned in the text?
A: Wendell Hissrich.

A: The inauguration of President-elect Joe Biden on January 20, 2021.

A: 32 recruits.

A: Setting up sobriety checkpoints and conducting roving DUI patrols.

A: Tanikka Pinnix and Layla Gooden.

A: Unlawful use of ATVs and dirt bikes on city streets.

A: The opioid overdose dashboard.

A: Lt. Kari Burnham.

A: To guide policies and programs to address unsafe opioid use in Pittsburgh.

A: They were muted due to COVID-19 safety measures and restrictions.

Q: What is the policy of Pittsburgh Public Safety regarding disruptive and illegal behavior during the pandemic?
A: Pittsburgh Public Safety has a zero-tolerance policy for disruptive and illegal behavior, including underage drinking, public intoxication, and drinking and driving.


Q: What is the consequence for being caught with an open container in Pittsburgh?
A: Anyone caught with an open container will be cited.

A: The public can send tips to 412_tips@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: What increase in violent crime has Pittsburgh experienced in early 2021?
A: There have been 20 homicides and close to 50 non-fatal shootings, marking 80% and 90% increases respectively.

A: They are working directly with the community and using Group Violence Intervention (GVI) outreach workers.


Q: What was the outcome of the Derek Chauvin trial?
A: Derek Chauvin was found guilty of second-degree murder, third-degree murder, and manslaughter.

A: The bureau is committed to implementing fair, equitable, transparent, and procedurally just law enforcement services.

A: Relational policing.

A: To expand life-saving reach with state-of-the-art capabilities on the region’s rivers.

A: Lake Assault in Superior, Wisconsin.

A: Increased fire suppression capabilities, improved lighting, a windless anchor, docking assist, built-in sonar, and forward and backward-trained cameras.

A: A partnership with Duquesne Light Company for hazardous materials safety training.

A: To simulate a rollover of a tank or fuel trailer for hazmat training.

A: In 1986.

A: An abandoned vehicle blitz.

Q: How many complaints did the police investigate regarding abandoned vehicles?
A: The police investigated 124 complaints.


Q: How many vehicles were towed by the police?
A: The police towed 17 vehicles.


Q: How can residents report abandoned vehicles in Pittsburgh?
A: Residents can report abandoned vehicles by calling 311, 412-255-2621, or filing an online 311 request form.


Q: How many homicides have occurred in Pittsburgh year-to-date compared to the same time in 2020?
A: There have been 31 homicides, compared to 20 at the same time in 2020.


Q: How many non-fatal shootings have occurred in Pittsburgh since January?
A: There have been 76 non-fatal shootings.


Q: What is the ATF doing to help reduce gun violence in Pittsburgh?
A: The ATF is creating a firearms trafficking unit in Pittsburgh and assigning two agents to work with Pittsburgh police.


Q: What challenge did the COVID-19 pandemic pose to Pittsburgh's violence prevention strategy?
A: The pandemic hampered face-to-face contact with young people and restricted custom notifications, hospital visits, and support from coaches and teachers.


Q: What event is Pittsburgh planning for Independence Day?
A: Pittsburgh is planning a city-sponsored fireworks display at Point State Park on July 4.


Q: What safety measures are being implemented in Pittsburgh for the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: Increased lighting, police presence, and monitoring of bridges and traffic flow are being implemented.


Q: What are some potential risks associated with using fireworks, according to Dr. Yealy?
A: Risks include blast injuries, heat injuries, and ocular injuries from explosions or sediment.


Q: What advice does Dr. Yealy give regarding heat-related ailments during the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: He advises staying hydrated, avoiding alcohol, and being cautious with certain medications that may affect heat response.


Q: What is the potential penalty for obstructing public passageways on East Carson Street in Pittsburgh?
A: The penalty could be up to $300 plus court costs.


Q: How many mobile light towers will be used to increase visibility in downtown Pittsburgh during the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: More than a dozen mobile light towers will be used.

Q: What safety measures will the Pittsburgh police and Point State Park rangers implement during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: They will conduct light bag screenings at the park's entrances.


Q: What is prohibited within 150 feet of any structure in Pittsburgh parks during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: The use of any fireworks, even those that are legal.


Q: What precautions are being taken to manage traffic during the fireworks display in Pittsburgh?
A: A Pennsylvania State Police helicopter will monitor from overhead to ensure traffic keeps flowing on the bridge decks.


Q: What will the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS deploy to reach crowded areas during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: Motorcycle medic units and traditional medic units near key fireworks viewing points.


Q: What heat-related advice does Dr. Donald Yealy provide for the Independence Day celebrations?
A: Avoid dehydration by drinking enough fluids and avoid alcohol, which is the wrong fluid.


Q: What will the Pittsburgh police do to ensure the safety of the downtown area during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: They will work closely with Port Authority personnel to move people out of the downtown core quickly after the fireworks.


Q: What is the role of the Fireworks Task Force in Pittsburgh during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: To curb the illegal use of fireworks and continue enforcement efforts until July 5.


Q: What advice is given to those who are not vaccinated against COVID-19 during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: They are strongly encouraged to wear a mask, even though the activities are primarily outdoors.


Q: What event is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire celebrating with a promotions ceremony?
A: The promotion of Joshua Kuzma to Battalion Chief and John Gallagher and Eric Smith to Fire Lieutenants.


Q: What community engagement activities are Pittsburgh police officers involved in during the week of July 12 to July 18?
A: Activities include visiting summer camps, participating in Chess with Cops, reading at Summer Storytime in the Park, and addressing community concerns about drug use and overdoses.

Q: What are the main concerns caused by increased visitors to East Carson Street as pandemic restrictions eased?
A: Increased gun violence, overcrowded sidewalks and streets, traffic safety obstacles, and noise complaints.


Q: What changes are being implemented on East Carson Street as a pilot project?
A: Vehicle traffic will be outbound only between S.10th and S.18th streets from 7 p.m. to 4 a.m. on Fridays and Saturdays, side streets from S.11th to S.17th will be closed to traffic, only emergency vehicles and buses can travel both directions, ride-sharing services are restricted, and parking and deliveries are prohibited.


Q: Who is allowed to travel in both directions on East Carson Street during the pilot project?
A: Only emergency vehicles and Port Authority buses.


Q: What is the role of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officers during the pilot project?
A: They will be posted in key areas to ensure the safe flow of traffic.


Q: What is the purpose of the traffic adjustments on East Carson Street?
A: To mitigate gridlock, allow for a dedicated emergency vehicle corridor, and create a safer, more pleasant experience for residents and visitors.


Q: What is the "Box of Goodness" initiative?
A: A project by Books Bridge Hope that distributes boxes filled with books, magazines, writing supplies, socks, toiletries, and non-perishable food to the unsheltered community.


Q: Who founded Books Bridge Hope and what inspired its creation?
A: Lillie Leonardi, inspired by her own experiences with PTSD and the desire to help the unsheltered community.


Q: What happened to East Carson Street on August 12, 2021?
A: A partial building collapse occurred, leading to the temporary halting of the traffic pilot project.


Q: What adjustments were made to the South Side vehicle traffic pilot project after discussions with business owners?
A: The start time for one-way traffic was changed from 7:00 p.m. to 9:30 p.m., and side streets remained open until 9:30 p.m.


Q: When did East Carson Street reopen to vehicle traffic after the building collapse?
A: August 19, 2021.

Q: When was the traffic pilot project initially implemented and when was it modified?
A: The traffic pilot project was implemented on July 30 and modified on August 12.


Q: What event did the Pittsburgh Police Community Engagement Office participate in on August 20, 2021?
A: They participated in a backpack, supplies, and mask giveaway for students near Heinz Field in partnership with Pittsburgh Public Schools.


Q: How many masks were distributed during the backpack giveaway event?
A: More than 600 masks were distributed.


Q: What topic did Sergeant Tiffany Kline-Costa and CEO officers discuss with children at Homewood YMCA?
A: They spoke about how to prepare and protect themselves in the event of an active shooter incident in their school.


Q: What is the purpose of the modified traffic pilot project on the South Side of Pittsburgh?
A: The purpose is to stem the flow of vehicle traffic into the commercial corridor to alleviate density during the busiest evening hours on weekends.


Q: What changes were made to the traffic pilot project on the South Side regarding traffic direction and parking enforcement?
A: East Carson Street will convert from two-way to one-way traffic eastbound starting at 9:30 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays, and 'no parking' measures will be enforced starting at 8 p.m.


Q: What award did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive from the American Heart Association?
A: They received the Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Achievement Award.


Q: What is the significance of the Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Achievement Award?
A: It recognizes the implementation of quality care for severe heart attack and stroke patients.


Q: What ongoing investigation is the Pittsburgh task force involved in?
A: Investigating illegal "ride-outs" involving off-road vehicles like ATVs and dirt bikes on city streets.

A: Nicholas James Putnam and James B. Selester, among others.

A: Multiple law enforcement agencies will work together, light towers will be in place, and road closures will be marked.


Q: What is prohibited at Point State Park during the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: Fireworks are prohibited within 150 feet of any occupied structure, and consumer-grade fireworks are not allowed in the park.

A: The fireworks task force will be in place each night until July 6.


Q: Who comprises the fireworks task force in Pittsburgh?
A: The task force is comprised of members from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire and the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police.

Q: Which Pittsburgh police sergeant graduated from the FBI National Academy?
A: Sergeant Carla Kearns.


Q: What program did Sergeant Carla Kearns create following the death of FBI Special Agent Sam Hicks?
A: The Pittsburgh Members Assistance Program (PMAP), a peer-to-peer support program for police.

Q: When did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police Zone 3 launch the pilot engagement program with Axon My90?
A: The pilot program launched on December 19, 2022.


Q: What is the purpose of the Axon My90 program?
A: The purpose is to bridge the gap between officers and neighborhoods by using surveys to gather feedback on police interactions.


Q: How are the survey results from the Axon My90 program used?
A: They are used to identify areas of improvement and increase community engagement and relationships.


Q: Which types of police interactions trigger the Axon My90 survey?
A: Interactions include calls for prowler, hit-and-run, stolen vehicle, harassment, suspicious vehicle, theft, parking complaints, lost property, suspicious person, criminal mischief, loud music, landlord/tenant issues, crash (no injuries), burglary, fraud, and missing person.


Q: What event does the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust's Highmark First Night Pittsburgh celebrate?
A: It celebrates the New Year, drawing tens of thousands of people to the city.


Q: What is the role of the newly formed Office of Film & Event Management (OFEM) in Pittsburgh?
A: OFEM receives and vets applications for events and film productions, ensuring compliance with industry standards, safety regulations, and city policies.


Q: Who leads the new Office of Film & Event Management?
A: Brian Katze is the Film & Events Manager, with Anna Boekenhauer as the Film & Event Permit Coordinator.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire hold on March 6, 2023?
A: A promotion and swearing-in ceremony for an assistant chief, two captains, and four lieutenants.


Q: What is the significance of the St. Patrick's Day parade in Pittsburgh?
A: It is a popular tradition attracting large crowds, with extensive public safety preparations to ensure a safe event.


Q: What safety measures are in place for the St. Patrick's Day parade in Pittsburgh?
A: Extra police officers, fire inspectors, and EMS personnel are deployed, with no parking allowed in designated safety lanes.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS do on March 10, 2023?
A: They held a swearing-in ceremony for two paramedics who completed their probationary period.


Q: What historical significance does Pittsburgh EMS have?
A: It grew out of the creation of Freedom House in 1967, pioneering new protocols for prehospital care.

Q: What program did Pittsburgh EMS and the Office of Community Health & Safety launch?
A: They launched a community paramedicine program.


Q: Who are the leaders of the community paramedicine program in Pittsburgh?
A: EMS Community Paramedic Crew Chief John Mooney and OCH&S Manager Laura Drogowski.


Q: What is the main goal of the community paramedicine program in Pittsburgh?
A: To address the needs of the most vulnerable in the community and connect patients with proper health services.


Q: What chronic health conditions are common among patients frequently calling EMS in Pittsburgh?
A: Obstructive lung diseases (asthma and COPD), diabetes, seizure disorders, and heart disease.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police do on March 30, 2023?
A: They held a promotions ceremony for new sergeants and a lieutenant.


Q: Who was promoted to lieutenant during the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police promotions ceremony?
A: Sergeant Andrew Baker.

A: April 3, 2023.


Q: How long did Ronald Romano serve in the EMS field before retiring?
A: 45 years.

A: The Pittsburgh Marathon.

A: More than 30,000 people.

Q: What is the purpose of the Fire Investigation Unit's annual fireworks task force in Pittsburgh?
A: To respond to fireworks-related calls and complaints from June 29 to July 6, 2023.


Q: What are the rules regarding the use of consumer-grade fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be ignited on public or private property without permission, within 150 feet of a building or vehicle, and are prohibited in city parks.

Q: What restrictions are placed on the use of consumer-grade fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Municipalities may restrict the use of consumer-grade fireworks between 10 p.m. and 10 a.m., except for July 2, 3, 4, where they can be displayed until 1 a.m.


Q: What are the consequences of misusing or illegally using fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Misuse and/or illegal use of fireworks can result in warnings, citations, arrests, and confiscation by the fireworks task force.


Q: What should pet owners in Pittsburgh be mindful of during the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: Pet owners should be aware that some pets can be extremely sensitive to the loud noises and flashing lights caused by fireworks, prompting them to run away or hide.


Q: When will the main Independence Day events take place at Point State Park in Pittsburgh?
A: The events will take place from 4 p.m. to 10 p.m. on July 4th, with fireworks scheduled from 9:35 to 10:00 p.m.


Q: What road closures are planned in Pittsburgh for Independence Day?
A: Liberty Avenue from Stanwix to Commonwealth Place will be closed from noon to midnight, and additional closures include the 376E exit 70A to Liberty Avenue.


Q: Who was Earl Buford Jr., and what was his role in Pittsburgh?
A: Earl Buford Jr. was the second minority to serve as the chief of police for the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police from 1992 to 1995.

A: A planned exercise simulating a real-world rescue involving Blackhawk helicopters will take place at Point State Park and Brunot Island.

A: Pittsburgh police and SWAT responded to shots fired during an eviction notice, resulting in a six-and-a-half-hour standoff where the subject was pronounced deceased.

Q: What major change did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police implement on November 14, 2023?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police transitioned to the National Incident Based Reporting System (NIBRS).


Q: What is a key difference between NIBRS and the Uniform Crime Reporting method?
A: NIBRS includes "crimes against society" and allows reporting of multiple offenses per incident.


Q: How does NIBRS categorize offenses compared to the old UCR system?
A: NIBRS categorizes offenses into Group A and Group B, replacing Part I and Part II offenses.

Q: Where are the kids summer camps held?
A: The camps are held at Allegheny County Community College, Duquesne University, University of Pittsburgh, and Chatham University.


Q: What activities do the kids summer camps include?
A: The camps include hands-on interactions with police specialty units, medic and fire departments, the 911 mobile training unit, exploring a SWAT vehicle, robotic performance, and participating in a mock crime scene.


Q: Who expressed support for the Cops and Kids Camp and why?
A: Mayor Bill Peduto expressed support, stating it provides opportunities for youth to learn about public service and grow.


Q: What issues does the summer camp program address?
A: The program addresses issues like bullying, illegal drugs, violent gangs, and firearm safety.


Q: How many city youths can attend each camp session?
A: Fifty city youths are invited to attend each session.


Q: What are the dates and locations for the camp sessions?
A: Session 1: July 9-13 at Duquesne University, Session 2: July 23-27 at the University of Pittsburgh, Session 3: July 30-August 3 at CCAC/Northside Campus, Session 4: August 6-10 at Chatham University.


Q: What is provided to campers during the summer camps?
A: Two meals, snacks, uniforms, and transportation to and from the campsite are provided.


Q: How can parents sign up their children for the camp?
A: Parents can pick up a brochure at police headquarters, complete the registration form, and return it in person or by fax.

A: The ShotSpotter gunshot detection service is being tested.


Q: What does the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's ten-year analysis on ethnic intimidation incidents indicate about the most common contributor?
A: Racial animus is the most common contributor to ethnic intimidation charges, targeting African Americans.


Q: What percentage of ethnic intimidation incidents involved race according to the analysis?
A: 76% of the incidents involved race.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's stance on ethnic intimidation and hate crimes?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police is committed to thoroughly investigating and prosecuting anyone who violates the law regarding ethnic intimidation and hate crimes.

A: Residents are being warned about a telephone scam where callers impersonate Duquesne Light Company and threaten to terminate services.

A: Pittsburgh Public Safety is committed to a policy of zero tolerance of illegal gun use.

Q: What is ShotSpotter used for in Pittsburgh?
A: ShotSpotter is used to detect and locate gunfire incidents, gather gunfire intelligence and data, and help deter gun violence in Pittsburgh.


Q: How many cities use ShotSpotter technology?
A: ShotSpotter is used in more than 90 cities.

A: Four residents and eight pets were safely evacuated with no injuries, and the Red Cross was notified to help with temporary shelter.

A: The clearance rates improved due to increased community engagement, the use of technology like security cameras and ShotSpotter, and the hard work of police officers.

A: Homicides decreased from 71 in 2014 to 55 in 2018.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, in partnership with Vitalant, is organizing the blood drive.

A: Early warning signs include not feeling quite right, upset stomach, or feeling a little sweaty.

A: They will aggressively prosecute cases where animals or children are left in vehicles.

A: Pittsburgh police will conduct a two-week enforcement campaign in school zones, focusing on strict enforcement periods in the morning and when school lets out.


Q: What are the penalties for passing a school bus with red lights activated in Pittsburgh?
A: The penalties include a $250 fine plus $117.50 in court costs and state-mandated fees, 5 points on the driver's license, and a 60-day driver's license suspension.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire received more than $1 million in federal and civic funding.


Q: What is the purpose of the Scentsational Tracking Program launched by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: The program aims to create a safety net for those who might get lost and have trouble finding their way home by utilizing a police bloodhound to track a person using their scent.

A: The scent container can remain usable for seven years.

A: He warned against shooting guns into the air due to the dangers of celebratory gunfire.


Q: Who was Glenn M. Cannon and what was his contribution to Pittsburgh?
A: Glenn M. Cannon was the creator and first leader of the city's EMS department and contributed significantly to public safety in Pittsburgh.


Q: How many new K9 officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police K9 Training Academy in January 2020?
A: Five new K9 officers graduated.


Q: What significant trend did the city of Pittsburgh observe in crime rates in 2019?
A: There were significant reductions in several key crime categories, most notably in homicides.

Q: What was the percentage drop in homicides in the city from 2018 to 2019?
A: Homicides in the city dropped 36 percent from 58 in 2018 to 37 in 2019.


Q: What policing strategy did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police begin transitioning to in 2016?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police began transitioning to evidence-based and intelligence-led policing in 2016.


Q: What is the focus deterrents model, and who advocates it?
A: The focus deterrents model is a policing strategy that focuses on identifying and holding accountable small groups of individuals engaged in violence, advocated by David Kennedy.


Q: What role did the ShotSpotter system and security cameras play in crime reduction?
A: The ShotSpotter system and security cameras helped police respond immediately to gunfire, locate victims, and identify suspects, contributing to crime reduction.


Q: How much did the ShotSpotter coverage area expand in 2018?
A: The ShotSpotter coverage area expanded from three square miles to 18 square miles in 2018.


Q: What was the percentage drop in citywide violent crimes from the five-year average?
A: There was an 18.8 percent drop in citywide violent crimes from the five-year average.


Q: How did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police receive support for trauma responsiveness?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police received a donation from Allegheny Health Network to provide officers with life-saving hemostatic gauze.


Q: What are Pittsburgh police officers trained to use in response to traumatic injuries?
A: Pittsburgh police officers are trained to use tourniquets and hemostatic gauze in response to traumatic injuries.


Q: What increase in ethnic intimidation cases was noted from 2018 to 2019?
A: Ethnic intimidation cases increased from 17 total incidents in 2018 to 22 total incidents in 2019.


Q: What preparations did the City of Pittsburgh's Public Safety Department make for a possible coronavirus outbreak?
A: Preparations included updating the pandemic operational plan, training first responders, and coordinating with local hospitals and public safety officials.

A: Six new paramedics were sworn in by the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS.

A: Wendell Hissrich emphasized treating patients like family and being prepared for potential challenges, such as the coronavirus outbreak.

A: The ceremony was held to promote four sergeants to lieutenants and three officers to sergeants.

A: Mayor Peduto emphasized the importance of their knowledge and experience in guiding other officers during challenging times, including the COVID-19 pandemic.

A: A zero tolerance policy for disruptive and illegal behavior, including underage drinking and drinking and driving.

A: DUI patrols will actively seek anyone who drives under the influence.


Q: What additional safety measures are being emphasized in Pittsburgh due to COVID-19?
A: Personal hygiene, social distancing, washing hands regularly, not sharing drinks, and maintaining a personal space of at least six feet from others.

A: A Pittsburgh firefighter tested positive for COVID-19 and went into self-isolation.

A: They suspended a 28-person recruit class and are identifying and notifying everyone who had contact with the officer to self-quarantine.

A: Recognition from the Pennsylvania Emergency Health Services Council for achieving expert level pediatric care.

Q: What are some features of the new paramedic and police rescue boat launched by Pittsburgh Public Safety?
A: The new rescue boat features a bow gate for shoreline work, improved FLIR for night vision, a catamaran hull for stability, increased fire suppression capabilities, improved lighting, a windless anchor, docking assist, and built-in sonar.

Q: What does the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police 2021 Annual Report provide?
A: A comprehensive overview of the bureau’s work, including statistical analysis and community engagement efforts.


Q: When did Chief Scott Schubert announce his retirement from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: May 27, 2022.


Q: How long did Chief Scott Schubert serve with the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: 29 years.

Q: What was Chief Schubert's greatest passion and motivating force as chief of police?
A: Working with officers and the community to create a more equitable, safe, and inclusive city of Pittsburgh.


Q: Which report's pillars did Chief Schubert implement during his tenure?
A: Former President Obama's task force report on 21st century policing.


Q: What office did Chief Schubert establish to foster community engagement?
A: The Pittsburgh Police Community Engagement Office.


Q: Which sports teams did Chief Schubert partner with to build relationships with inner-city children and youth?
A: The Pittsburgh Steelers, Pirates, and Penguins.


Q: What commendation did the Pittsburgh police bureau receive in 2016?
A: A community policing commendation from the U.S. Justice Department.


Q: What is the Group Violence Intervention (GVI) program?
A: A partnership between law enforcement, social services, and the faith community to mediate and interrupt violence.


Q: What technological initiative did Chief Schubert lead to promote safety?
A: The creation of a Real Time Crime Center (RTCC).


Q: What unit was established in partnership with the U.S. Attorney’s Office to focus on strategic investigations?
A: The High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (HIDTA) unit.


Q: What is the purpose of the Civil Affairs Unit established by Chief Schubert?
A: To serve as liaisons with activists and other stakeholders during First Amendment-protected activities.


Q: When is Chief Schubert's final day as police chief?
A: Friday, July 1, 2022.

A: Section Chief overseeing the Global Law Enforcement Support Section at the FBI.

A: The Independence Day celebration and fireworks.

A: Light bag screenings at the park's entrances.

A: The use of any fireworks, even those that are legal.

A: The Fireworks Task Force.

A: To allow community members to provide feedback on police interactions through anonymous surveys.

A: Pittsburgh’s annual “First Night” celebration.

Q: What is the purpose of the Axon My90 survey program?

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police does not have a street unit like the Scorpion Unit.

Q: What events are taking place in Pittsburgh during the long weekend of June 16-19, 2023?
A: Juneteenth celebrations and two Taylor Swift concerts.


Q: What security measures are in place for the Juneteenth fireworks display at Point State Park?
A: Bag checks at the park's five entry points and prohibition of items like alcohol, narcotics, laser pointers, weapons, explosives, and grills.


Q: What is the entry policy for the Taylor Swift concerts at Acrisure Stadium?
A: Parking lots open at 1:30 p.m., VIP gates open at 3:30 p.m., all gates open at 4:30 p.m., and music starts at 6:30 p.m. Only mobile tickets are accepted, and the venue is cashless.


Q: What was the outcome of the trial against Robert Bowers related to the Tree of Life synagogue shooting?
A: Robert Bowers was found guilty on all 63 federal charges.


Q: What restrictions are in place for fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be discharged within 150 feet of a building or vehicle, are prohibited in city parks, and cannot be used while under the influence of substances.


Q: How is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police preparing for the Independence Day celebrations?
A: They are implementing road closures, parking restrictions, and light bag checks at Point State Park.


Q: Who was Sergeant Dawn Mercurio, and what was her role in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: A retired police sergeant who served as a patrol officer, detective, and adjunct instructor, and passed away in June 2023.

Q: When do the temporary road closures for the fireworks display begin?
A: The temporary road closures begin at 9 p.m.


Q: What roads will have detours due to the fireworks display?
A: Detours will be at North Shore Drive at Allegheny Avenue, Reedsdale Street at Allegheny Avenue, Reedsdale Street at Tony Dorsett Drive, Reedsdale Street at Mazeroski Way, and West General Robinson Street at Federal Street.


Q: When will the roads closed for the fireworks display reopen?
A: The roads will reopen immediately at the conclusion of the fireworks.


Q: When do road closures on Mount Washington begin for the fireworks display?
A: Road closures on Mount Washington begin at 6 p.m.


Q: What will be the restrictions on Grandview Avenue during the fireworks display?
A: Grandview Avenue will be barricaded at McArdle Roadway, allowing no entry into the 500 block of Grandview Avenue.


Q: What organization is tasked with responding to fireworks-related calls and complaints until July 6?
A: The Fireworks Task Force.


Q: What consequences can result from the misuse or illegal use of fireworks?
A: Misuse or illegal use of fireworks can result in warnings, citations, arrests, and confiscation by the Fireworks Task Force.

A: Earl Buford Jr. was a former police chief of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, who passed away on July 25, 2023.

A: A planned exercise with the Pennsylvania Helicopter Aquatic Rescue Team (PA-HART) will take place.

A: The subject was pronounced deceased after a nearly six-and-a-half-hour standoff.


Q: Who was Lieutenant Randolph "Randy" Meyer II and what did he pass away from?
A: Lieutenant Randolph "Randy" Meyer II was a member of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire who passed away from appendiceal cancer.


Q: What is the purpose of Pittsburgh Police's new crime data portal launched in October 2023?
A: The portal provides a general overview of criminal activity across the city and aims to drive accountability through transparency.

Q: What is the difference between police reports and "call for service" records?
A: Police reports are not the same as "call for service" records; not all calls result in a police report.


Q: Where can Pittsburgh residents find the police data portal?
A: On the City of Pittsburgh website at https://pittsburghpa.gov/police/data-portal.


Q: When is the nationwide emergency alert system test scheduled?
A: October 4, 2023, at approximately 2:20 PM Eastern Time, with a backup date of October 11.


Q: Who will conduct the nationwide emergency alert system test?
A: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and FEMA.


Q: What language options are available for the wireless emergency alert test message?
A: English or Spanish, depending on individual language settings.

A: He served as the Medical Director for over 21 years.

A: Physicians work side-by-side with paramedics and EMTs in the field and during training.

A: They can be issued on Halloween, even though typically they are only issued on weekends or federal holidays.

A: The fee for a block party permit is $25.

A: The application must be submitted by 5:00 p.m. on Monday, October 23.


Q: What reporting system did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police switch to on November 14, 2023?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police switched to the National Incident-Based Reporting System (NIBRS).


Q: What additional category of offenses does NIBRS document that UCR does not?
A: NIBRS documents "crimes against society," including offenses like drugs, gambling, pornography, prostitution, and weapons law violations.


Q: What major event is Pittsburgh preparing for on November 18, 2023?
A: Pittsburgh is preparing for the 62nd annual Highmark Light Up Night.


Q: Who was Therese Rocco, and what was her significance in the Pittsburgh Police?
A: Therese Rocco was Pittsburgh's first female assistant chief of police and a nationally renowned expert in missing persons cases.

A: A viewing and prayer service will be held at Frank F. DeBor Funeral Home, followed by a funeral mass at St. Teresa of Kolkata Parish, St. Pius X Church.

A: The Highmark First Night 2024 event is on December 31, 2023.

A: Twenty-nine recruits graduated.

A: Richard Fashion received the Academic Achievement Award, and Hunter Reed earned the Physical Fitness Award.

Q: Who released the body worn and dash camera footage of the Pittsburgh police interaction with Jim Rogers?
A: Mr. Todd Hollis, the attorney for the family of Jim Rogers, released the footage.


Q: What improvements have the Pittsburgh police made following the death of Jim Rogers?
A: Improvements include assigning an officer to monitor prisoners during transfer, summoning EMS after taser deployment, retraining on avoiding single officer tactics, training on "duty to intervene," and reviewing body worn camera footage after every use of force.


Q: Why is the spay and neuter program in Pittsburgh paused?
A: The program is paused due to inappropriate use, such as individuals using city addresses of friends and family to access services for animals from outside city limits.


Q: How many Pittsburgh police personnel were promoted during the ceremony in council chambers?
A: Thirteen personnel were promoted.


Q: What is one of the key priorities for the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police according to Chief Larry Scirotto?
A: Enhancing officer wellness is a key priority.


Q: What new organizational change will Pittsburgh police personnel undergo starting February 26, 2024?
A: They will transition to four 10-hour shifts each week with three consecutive days off.


Q: What is the purpose of the new violent crime division in Pittsburgh?
A: The division aims to reduce violent crime and gun violence.


Q: What event does the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's promotion ceremony highlight?
A: The ceremony highlighted the promotion of five members and recognized Maxine Anthony's 43 years of service.

A: Twenty-four new officers graduated.

A: Must be at least 18 years old, possess a valid Class C Pennsylvania driver's license, pass a background check, and be a city resident.

Q: What is the general philosophy on handling peaceful protests according to the text?
A: The philosophy is to protect all parties involved and facilitate the event without arresting protesters exercising their constitutional rights, unless the event turns violent or destructive.

Q: What is the ShotSpotter gunshot detection service in Pittsburgh?
A: ShotSpotter is a service that uses a wide-area network of acoustic sensors to detect gunfire and quickly notify police officers and 911 dispatchers of gunfire incidents.


Q: What is the purpose of the live-fire test for the ShotSpotter service?
A: The test is to verify that all systems are operating as expected and to guide any final adjustments before the service is activated.


Q: What did the ten-year analysis on ethnic intimidation incidents in Pittsburgh reveal?
A: The analysis revealed that Pittsburgh averaged 19 ethnic intimidation incidents per year, with 76% involving race and the vast majority targeting African Americans.


Q: How does the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police respond to ethnic intimidation incidents?
A: The police take these reports seriously, with an average arrest rate of 40% for all incidents and nearly 60% for violent incidents.


Q: What scam are Pittsburgh residents being warned about?
A: A scam where callers impersonate Duquesne Light Company representatives, threatening to terminate services unless payment is made via gift or pre-paid cards.


Q: What safety measures are in place for Pittsburgh's First Night events?
A: There will be a significant police presence, and public safety urges people not to drink and drive, with officers looking for impaired drivers.


Q: What happened during the Troy Hill fire in Pittsburgh?
A: A one-alarm fire occurred, but all four residents and eight pets were safely evacuated, with no injuries reported.


Q: What trend was discussed regarding Pittsburgh's 2018 crime statistics?
A: Homicides and shootings have trended downwards, continuing a trend of decreasing numbers since 2014.

Q: What factors contributed to the decrease in homicide numbers in Pittsburgh from 2014 to 2018?
A: Increased community engagement, use of technology like security cameras and ShotSpotter, and more police officers contributed to the decrease.


Q: What was the trend in Pittsburgh's homicide numbers from 2014 to 2018?
A: Homicides decreased from 71 in 2014 to 55 in 2018.


Q: What unit was created by Pittsburgh police to address community violence and when?
A: The Group Violence Intervention (GVI) unit was created in 2015.


Q: How did the clearance rate for crimes in Pittsburgh change by 2018?
A: The clearance rate improved to 71 percent in 2018.


Q: What was the status of non-fatal shootings in Pittsburgh from 2015 to 2018?
A: Non-fatal shootings decreased from 174 in 2015 to 114 in 2018.

Q: What was the response of public safety to the heat wave advisory in Pittsburgh?

A: Pittsburgh public safety director Wendell Hissrich, Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS Chief Ron Romano, Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire Chief Darryl Jones, Parks and Recreation Director Ross Chapman, and UPMC's Emergency Medicine Department Chairman Dr. Donald Yealy.


Q: What did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich say about animals and children left in vehicles during the heat event?
A: He said that they will aggressively prosecute cases where animals or children are left in vehicles.


Q: What are some early warning signs of heat stress mentioned by Dr. Donald Yealy?
A: Early warning signs include "not feeling quite right," upset stomach, or feeling a little sweaty.


Q: What did EMS Chief Ron Romano advise residents to do during the heat event?
A: He urged residents to drink plenty of fluids and stay indoors, especially those with underlying medical conditions.


Q: What did Fire Chief Darryl Jones warn against as a way to cool down?
A: He warned against opening neighborhood fire hydrants.


Q: What alternative cooling options did Parks and Recreation Director Ross Chapman suggest?
A: He suggested visiting the city's 18 public pools, eight spray parks, and three cooling centers.


Q: When and where will the end of watch ceremony for Officer Calvin Hall take place?
A: It will take place on Saturday, July 20, at 8 p.m. in the 1500 block of Brighton Road.


Q: What are the dates and locations for Officer Calvin Hall's viewing and funeral?
A: The viewing is on July 22 at Soldiers & Sailors Memorial Hall, and the funeral is on July 23 at the same location.


Q: What temporary road closures are planned for Officer Hall's funeral service?
A: Fifth Avenue will be closed temporarily before and after the service, with additional rolling closures for the funeral procession.


Q: What initiative did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police launch to honor Officer Calvin Hall?
A: They launched a month-long public blood drive in partnership with Vitalant.


Q: What are the penalties for passing a school bus with red lights activated in Pittsburgh?
A: A $250 fine, $117.50 in court costs and fees, 5 points on the license, and a 60-day license suspension.


Q: What temporary changes are being made at Fire Station 8 in Pittsburgh?
A: Fire Station 8 will be temporarily closed for repairs, and personnel and vehicles will be relocated to other stations.

Q: What will happen to the service provided by Fire Station 8 during repairs?
A: Residents currently served by Fire Station 8 will have uninterrupted service.


Q: What event took place on September 12, 2019, involving the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: A promotion ceremony where one lieutenant was promoted to captain and six firefighters to lieutenant.


Q: Who administered the oath of office during the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire promotion ceremony?
A: Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich.


Q: What training exercise will the Department of Defense conduct in Pittsburgh in September 2019?
A: A planned training exercise from September 16 through September 22 in cooperation with local authorities.


Q: What was the response to multiple stabbings in downtown Pittsburgh in August 2019?
A: Increased police patrols resulted in immediate arrests following each stabbing.


Q: When is the downtown Pittsburgh police substation open?
A: Daily from 11 a.m. until 11 p.m., often later during large events.


Q: What are the most common types of calls to police in downtown Pittsburgh from July to July?
A: 1) Disorderly person (824), 2) Burglary alarm (761), 3) Parking complaint (526), 4) Welfare check (469), 5) Trespass (362).


Q: What incident occurred on September 18, 2019, involving a bank robbery suspect?
A: The suspect was shot and killed by law enforcement after holding a woman at knifepoint in Wilkinsburg.


Q: What charges are being considered following a violent assault at a North Side gas station?
A: Assault charges against the gas station owners and employee.


Q: Who was arrested in connection with overdose deaths in the South Side of Pittsburgh?
A: Peter Rene Sanchez Montalvo, aka Carlos.


Q: What funding did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire receive for fire prevention safety for the deaf and hard of hearing?
A: More than $1 million, including over $950,000 from FEMA and close to $50,000 from the city of Pittsburgh.


Q: What is the purpose of the "Scentsational" tracking program launched by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: To create a safety net for those who might get lost by using collected scent samples for tracking with a police bloodhound.

Q: Who noted that the bloodhound will be available to other communities in western Pennsylvania?
A: Public safety director Wendell Hissrich.


Q: What is the purpose of the scentsational tracking program launched at Point State Park?
A: To help find missing individuals using bloodhounds trained for scent tracking.


Q: What organization donated containers and equipment for the scentsational tracking program?
A: Allegheny General Hospital.


Q: How can residents get involved in the scentsational tracking program?
A: By attending community outreach events or contacting their local police zone for more information.


Q: What award did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive from the American Heart Association in 2019?
A: The Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.


Q: How many patients per year does the Pittsburgh EMS see with a STEMI?
A: Approximately 60 patients per year.


Q: What is the goal time for Pittsburgh EMS from paramedic arrival to cardiac catheterization for STEMI patients?
A: Less than 90 minutes.


Q: What major event is Pittsburgh Public Safety preparing for on October 23, 2019?
A: President Donald Trump's visit to the David L. Lawrence Convention Center.


Q: What is the purpose of the National Prescription Drug Take Back Day?
A: To safely dispose of expired, unused, and unwanted prescription drugs to prevent misuse and abuse.


Q: How many pounds of prescription drugs were collected in Pittsburgh during the April initiative of the National Prescription Drug Take Back Day?
A: Nearly 420 pounds.

A: The use of any fireworks within 150 feet of a structure is prohibited by city law during First Night celebrations.


Q: Who was Glenn M. Cannon, and what was his contribution to Pittsburgh?
A: Glenn M. Cannon was the first leader of Pittsburgh's EMS department and contributed significantly to public safety in Pittsburgh.


Q: How many new K9 officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police K9 training academy?
A: Five new K9 officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police K9 training academy.


Q: By what percentage did homicides in Pittsburgh decrease from 2018 to 2019?
A: Homicides in Pittsburgh decreased by 36 percent from 2018 to 2019.


Q: What system was expanded in 2018 to help reduce crime in Pittsburgh?
A: The ShotSpotter system was expanded in 2018 to help reduce crime in Pittsburgh.


Q: What role did community engagement play in reducing crime in Pittsburgh?
A: Increased community engagement led to more people helping police investigations by passing on key information, contributing to crime reduction.

Q: What is the purpose of the GVI initiative mentioned in the text?
A: The GVI initiative aims to identify individuals most likely to commit or become victims of violent crime and help them escape a dangerous lifestyle.


Q: How are partner law enforcement agencies contributing to public safety in Pittsburgh?
A: They are teaming up to disrupt and dismantle criminal enterprises and maintain good working relationships with various agencies.


Q: What was the trend in overall crime rates downtown Pittsburgh from 2018 to 2019?
A: Overall crime rates downtown dropped by 6 percent.


Q: What increase in crime was noted in downtown Pittsburgh from 2018 to 2019?
A: Violent crime downtown increased from 119 cases in 2018 to 136 cases in 2019.


Q: How has ethnic intimidation crime changed from 2018 to 2019 in Pittsburgh?
A: Ethnic intimidation cases increased from 17 total incidents (6 involving violence) in 2018 to 22 total incidents (11 involving violence) in 2019.


Q: What donation did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police receive from Allegheny Health Network?
A: They received a donation of 1,000 NuStat hemostatic gauze packages.


Q: What purpose does the NuStat hemostatic gauze serve?
A: It is used to control bleeding and prevent infection in trauma wounds until a patient can be transported to the hospital.


Q: How is Pittsburgh's Public Safety Department preparing for a potential coronavirus outbreak?
A: By updating the city’s 2014 pandemic operational plan, training first responders, and coordinating with local hospitals and public safety officials.


Q: What was the role of the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS in the March 9, 2020, ceremony?
A: They held a swearing-in and promotions ceremony for new paramedics and crew chiefs.

A: It recognizes the role of EMS in public safety and healthcare and acknowledges the new challenges posed by the coronavirus.


Q: What action did Pittsburgh’s Public Safety Department take in anticipation of St. Patrick’s Day celebrations amid COVID-19 concerns?
A: They prepared for lighter crowds, maintained a zero-tolerance policy for illegal behavior, and enforced social distancing and occupancy limits.


Q: What happened to a Pittsburgh firefighter on April 1, 2020?
A: A Pittsburgh firefighter tested positive for COVID-19 and was instructed to self-isolate.


Q: What measures were taken after a Pittsburgh police officer tested positive for COVID-19?
A: The officer was sent home for self-isolation, and those in contact with the officer were identified for self-quarantine.

Q: Why was the 28-person recruit class temporarily suspended?
A: The recruit class was suspended to identify who might have been exposed to a firearms instructor who tested positive for COVID-19.


Q: Where did the potential exposure to COVID-19 occur for the recruit class?
A: The potential exposure occurred at the outdoor police firing range in Zone 5, not in the academy.


Q: What measures were taken for recruits who might have been exposed to COVID-19?
A: Recruits who might have been exposed were instructed to self-quarantine, and their health is being monitored daily.


Q: How many Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officials tested positive for COVID-19 over the past week?
A: Two additional officials tested positive, including a recruit and an officer.


Q: How many total positive COVID-19 tests have there been among Pittsburgh police officers?
A: There have been six total positive tests among Pittsburgh police officers.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS received state recognition for achieving expert level pediatric care.

A: They completed Pennsylvania's Pediatric Voluntary Recognition Program (PVRP).

A: Chief Schubert stated that the actions of the officers were inexcusable and emphasized the duty of police to care for and safeguard those in custody.

A: Its purpose is to investigate individuals causing destruction during protests and assess property damage.

A: Matthew Michanowicz was arrested after police recovered a backpack with homemade explosives.

A: An explosion near Mellon Square caused the officer to suffer concussion-like symptoms.


Q: What is the primary guiding principle of the Pittsburgh police regarding protests?
A: The belief that all people have a fundamental right to protest peacefully, as guaranteed by the First Amendment.


Q: What is the DAAT and what agencies does it comprise?
A: The DAAT is a multi-agency taskforce comprised of local, state, and federal law enforcement partners, including the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, Allegheny County District Attorney’s Office, and others.


Q: How many paramedics were sworn in by Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich?
A: Seven paramedics were sworn in.


Q: What measures will the fireworks taskforce take to address illegal fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: The taskforce will patrol neighborhoods and respond to 911 calls for illegal fireworks.


Q: What are the legal restrictions on the use of fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be used within 150 feet of any structure, in parks, public spaces, or on private property without consent.


Q: What is the penalty for violating fireworks laws in Pittsburgh?
A: A $100 fine and possible seizure of fireworks.


Q: What safety tips were provided for the Fourth of July weekend in Pittsburgh?
A: Do not use fireworks illegally, do not fire guns in the air, practice water safety, follow pandemic guidelines, prepare for heat, do not drink and drive, and remember pet safety.

A: A 2-alarm blaze caused an estimated $50,000 to $60,000 damage.

A: The 2020 Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.

Q: What is Dr. Donald Yealy's advice regarding heat-related ailments?
A: To avoid dehydration by drinking enough fluids and avoiding alcohol, which is not effective for hydration.


Q: What is a safety concern related to fireworks mentioned in the text?
A: Fireworks pose a risk of blast injuries and heat injuries, and their use is prohibited within 150 feet of any structure.


Q: What are the penalties for obstructing public passageways on East Carson Street in Pittsburgh?
A: Citations carrying penalties of up to $300, plus court costs, and possible physical arrests for non-compliance.


Q: What should people remember about children and pets in hot weather, according to Wendell Hissrich?
A: Never leave them in hot vehicles, as temperatures can rise rapidly even with a window open.

A: The pandemic is not over, and unvaccinated individuals are advised to wear masks during gatherings.


Q: When are the fireworks scheduled to end during the Pittsburgh Independence Day celebration?
A: At 10 p.m.


Q: What enforcement efforts are continuing until July 5 in Pittsburgh?
A: The fireworks task force's efforts to curb illegal use of fireworks.

Q: What is a common danger associated with leaving children in hot vehicles?
A: Forgetting children in hot vehicles can lead to heat stroke and even death, as temperatures inside can rise by 20 degrees within 10 minutes.


Q: What should unvaccinated individuals do during outdoor activities according to the text?
A: Unvaccinated individuals are strongly encouraged to wear a mask even during outdoor activities.

A: Intensive therapy, meditation, journaling, and reading books.

A: Passages & Prose, LLC and its non-profit subsidiary, Books Bridge Hope.


Q: What is the "Box of Goodness" initiative?
A: A project by Books Bridge Hope that distributes boxes filled with books, magazines, writing supplies, warm socks, toiletries, and non-perishable food to the unsheltered community.


Q: How many "Boxes of Goodness" have been distributed since the initiative's launch?
A: More than 50 boxes.

A: Pittsburgh Bureau of Police and its community engagement officers.


Q: What changes were made to the South Side traffic pilot project in Pittsburgh?
A: The start time for converting East Carson Street to one-way traffic was changed from 7:00 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.

A: Due to a partial building collapse on East Carson Street.

Q: What restrictions are in place for fireworks use within the City of Pittsburgh?

Q: What improvements have been made by Pittsburgh police following the in-custody death of Jim Rogers?
A: Assigning an officer to monitor prisoners during transfers, summoning EMS when a taser is deployed, retraining on avoiding single officer tactics, training on "duty to intervene," and reviewing body camera footage after every use of force.

Q: How many calls for service for burglar alarms were there in Pittsburgh in 2023?
A: 9,097 calls.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarm calls in 2023 resulted in police reports?
A: 0.43%.


Q: What new model will Pittsburgh Police implement regarding burglar alarm responses?
A: Officers will prioritize verified alarms and certain types of alarms like hold-up and panic alarms.


Q: What is the penalty for repeated false burglar alarms under Pittsburgh's ordinance 611.07?
A: A fee is required after the second false alarm, and calls may be disregarded after the fifth false alarm in a calendar year.


Q: What is the purpose of Pittsburgh's updated burglar alarm response model?
A: To minimize police response to false alarms and make better use of officers' time.

A: Ladder truck #14 will be stationed in Oakland, and ladder truck #30 will be stationed in Elliott.


Q: What is the purpose of the custom design of the new ladder trucks?
A: The custom design allows firefighters to navigate Pittsburgh's narrow and winding roadways more easily.

A: The design was a collaboration between Glick Fire Equipment Company, Inc. and a committee of Pittsburgh fire officials.


Q: What are some features that make the new ladder trucks slimmer than standard models?
A: The trucks have recessed grab rails, bar lights, and a recessed AC unit.

A: Each ladder truck costs $890,000.
