Q: Who hosted the discussion on ethnic intimidation in Pittsburgh?
A: The Bureau of Police hosted the discussion on ethnic intimidation.


Q: Who coordinated the discussion on ethnic intimidation with the FBI?
A: Pittsburgh Police Commander Eric Holmes and FBI Supervisory Special Agent Greg Heeb coordinated the discussion.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Police Crime Analysis Unit release during the meeting?
A: They released statistics and analysis on ethnic intimidation in the city of Pittsburgh.


Q: How does the Pennsylvania Crimes Code define ethnic intimidation?
A: The term ethnic intimidation is used synonymously with the term hate crime.


Q: What is not covered under the Pennsylvania ethnic intimidation crimes code?
A: Sexual orientation is not covered.


Q: What is the average number of ethnic intimidation incidents per year in Pittsburgh over the past ten years?
A: Pittsburgh averaged 19 incidents per year.


Q: What percentage of ethnic intimidation incidents involved race from 2008 to 2018?
A: 76% of the incidents involved race.


Q: What is the arrest rate for violent ethnic intimidation incidents in Pittsburgh?
A: The arrest rate for violent incidents is nearly 60%.


Q: What is a key strategy suggested to reduce ethnic intimidation incidents?
A: Educating law enforcement and the community on recognizing ethnic intimidation.


Q: What scam are Pittsburgh residents being warned about?
A: A telephone scam involving callers pretending to be from Duquesne Light Company.


Q: What should residents do if they suspect a scam call from Duquesne Light?
A: Contact Pittsburgh Police or Duquesne Light to verify the call.


Q: What event is the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust hosting on December 31?
A: First Night events at venues throughout the Golden Triangle.


Q: What technology does Pittsburgh use to detect gunfire incidents?
A: ShotSpotter gunfire alerts and analysis solution.


Q: What trend in crime statistics was discussed by Pittsburgh officials in January 2019?
A: A downward trend in homicides and shootings in Pittsburgh.


Q: Who was arrested in connection with a 2017 homicide in Pittsburgh?
A: Tremayne Wilmer and Nehlah Stubblefield were arrested.


Q: What charges were filed against Roy Johnson in January 2019?
A: Aggravated assault, attempted homicide, and reckless endangerment.

Q: When is the snowstorm expected to arrive and how long will it last?
A: The snowstorm is expected to arrive midday or early afternoon Saturday and last until Sunday morning.

A: Emergency medical services will have extra units, including four-wheel drive vehicles, in service.


Q: What type of vehicles do most Pittsburgh Bureau of Police use?
A: Most Pittsburgh Bureau of Police vehicles are all-wheel drive.


Q: What precaution has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire taken for the snowstorm?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire has ensured that all of their vehicles have chains installed.

A: Sergeant John Fisher was promoted to commander, assigned to the administrative branch.

A: Sergeant John Fisher is a 31-year veteran of the bureau.

A: The remains were identified as Mary Arcuri.

A: The mission is to develop and strengthen positive interactions between Pittsburgh area youth and police in a non-confrontational environment.

A: Road restrictions around the Allegheny County Courthouse will be implemented starting March 19.

A: The city increased patrols at mosques and other locales and expressed solidarity with Christchurch, New Zealand.

A: The primary goal is to keep the city safe.

A: On the 7300 block of Monticello Street.

A: He was a police officer known for his dedication to community outreach.

A: To eliminate violent crime.

Q: Why did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police increase patrols in downtown Pittsburgh?
A: In response to four stabbings, including one fatal, in August.

Q: How did part 1 property crimes in the first 8 months of 2019 compare to the 5-year average?
A: Part 1 property crimes showed a 4% decrease compared to the 5-year average.


Q: What was the percentage decrease in part 1 crimes in August 2019 compared to the average August over the last 5 years?
A: There was a 10% decrease in part 1 crimes in August 2019 compared to the average August over the last 5 years.


Q: How did the number of aggravated assaults in August 2019 compare to the 5-year average?
A: There were four aggravated assaults in August 2019, slightly higher than the 5-year average of 3.75.


Q: By what percentage did robberies decrease in 2019 compared to the average of the last 5 years?
A: Robberies were down 67% in 2019, with 3 robberies compared to the average of 9.


Q: During what hours have violent crimes been more likely to occur over the past 5 years?
A: Violent crimes have been more likely to occur between 4 p.m. and 10 p.m.


Q: What are the operating hours of the downtown substation?
A: The downtown substation is open daily from 11 a.m. until 11 p.m., and often stays open until midnight or later during large events.


Q: What was the most common type of call to police covering the downtown area over the past year?
A: The most common call was for a disorderly person, with 824 calls.


Q: What will Pittsburgh Public Safety conduct at the convention center on September 16, 2019?
A: Pittsburgh Public Safety will conduct a safety drill involving an active threat scenario.


Q: What happened during the arrest attempt of a bank robbery suspect on September 18, 2019?
A: The suspect held a female at knifepoint, and two law enforcement officials shot and killed the suspect.


Q: What charges are being considered in the North Side gas station assault incident?
A: Assault charges against the gas station owners and employee are being considered, with the possibility of rising to aggravated assault.


Q: Who was arrested in connection with the South Side overdose deaths, and what was distributed at the after-party?
A: Peter Rene Sanchez Montalvo, aka Carlos, was arrested, and he distributed a white powdered substance, believed to be cocaine.


Q: What funding did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire receive to assist the deaf and hard of hearing?
A: They received more than $1 million in federal and civic funding for smoke and fire detection devices.


Q: What is the purpose of the Scentsational Tracking Program launched by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: The program aims to create a safety net for those who might get lost by using bloodhounds to track people based on their scent.


Q: What award did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive from the American Heart Association in 2019?
A: They received the 2019 Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.

A: About 80 percent of cases achieved this metric.

Q: What advice is given to trick-or-treaters and drivers for Halloween safety in Pittsburgh?
A: Trick-or-treaters should wear reflective, light-colored costumes with full visibility, and drivers should slow down during trick-or-treat hours, especially in inclement weather.

Q: How many recruits graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire in December 2019?
A: 31 recruits graduated.

A: The class exuded intestinal fortitude, resiliency, and a can-do attitude.

Q: What warning did Wendell Hissrich give regarding New Year's Eve in Pittsburgh?
A: Hissrich warned against shooting guns into the air, stating that what goes up must come down, leading to tragic results when people are hit by celebratory gunfire.


Q: Which law enforcement agencies will Pittsburgh police work with during First Night celebrations?
A: Pittsburgh police will work with the Pennsylvania State Police, state park rangers, Port Authority Police, the Allegheny County Sheriff’s Office, and the Allegheny County Police.


Q: What did Wendell Hissrich say about former Public Safety Director Glenn M. Cannon?
A: Hissrich described Cannon as an extraordinary man who lived an exemplary life and contributed significantly to Pittsburgh and public safety.


Q: What roles did Glenn M. Cannon hold during his career in Pittsburgh?
A: Cannon was the creator and first leader of Pittsburgh's EMS department and served as Public Safety Director, overseeing police, fire, EMS, and more.


Q: What significant reduction in crime did Pittsburgh experience in 2019?
A: Homicides in Pittsburgh dropped 36% from 58 in 2018 to 37 in 2019.


Q: How did the ShotSpotter system contribute to crime reduction in Pittsburgh?
A: The ShotSpotter system expanded coverage, allowing police to respond immediately to gunfire and locate victims, contributing to crime reduction.


Q: What strategy has Pittsburgh police employed to reduce gun violence?
A: Pittsburgh police use evidence-based and intelligence-led policing, focusing on small groups of individuals actively engaged in violence.


Q: How did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police plan to address the increase in ethnic intimidation cases?
A: The Pittsburgh police prioritized building bridges with every community and will continue to combat hate crime in all forms.


Q: What grant did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police receive to support trauma responsiveness?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police received a donation of 1,000 NuStat gauze packages from Allegheny Health Network to help control bleeding in traumatic injuries.


Q: What new K9 officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police K9 Training Academy?
A: Graduates included Pittsburgh Police Officer Kevin Foley and K9 Shadow, Officer Matt Schwartzmiller and K9 Miky, Butler City Police Lt. Brian Grooms and K9 Chooch, Patrolman Andrew Niederlander and K9 Rico, and Lawrence County Sheriff’s Deputy John Baldelli and K9 Baki.

Q: What measures has the city of Pittsburgh's Public Safety Department taken to prepare for a possible coronavirus outbreak?
A: The department updated the city's 2014 pandemic operational plan, added contingency plans for additional EMS personnel, trained first responders to identify and isolate possible cases, and provided them with personal protection kits.


Q: When did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS hold a swearing-in and promotions ceremony?
A: The ceremony was held on March 9, 2020.


Q: Who were promoted to crew chief at the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS ceremony?
A: Fred Caprio II and Christy Zalewski were promoted to crew chief.


Q: What did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich emphasize during the EMS swearing-in ceremony?
A: He reminded the new paramedics and crew chiefs to treat patients like family and to take time for themselves and their families.


Q: What was the focus of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police promotions ceremony on March 12, 2020?
A: Four sergeants were promoted to lieutenant, and three officers were promoted to sergeant.


Q: What did Police Chief Scott Schubert highlight during the police promotions ceremony?
A: He emphasized the officers' dedication, the challenges of their job, and their role in guiding other officers.


Q: What preparations did the city of Pittsburgh's Public Safety Department make for St. Patrick's Day celebrations amid COVID-19 concerns?
A: They prepared to enforce a zero-tolerance policy for illegal behavior, including underage drinking and DUI, and urged social distancing and hygiene practices.


Q: What happened to a Pittsburgh firefighter on April 1, 2020?
A: The firefighter tested positive for COVID-19 and went into self-isolation at home.


Q: How did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police respond to an officer testing positive for COVID-19?
A: They temporarily suspended a recruit class to identify and quarantine those who might have been exposed to the officer.


Q: What new policy was implemented for Pittsburgh city staff on April 8, 2020, to help stop the spread of COVID-19?
A: All city staff working in the field and in contact with the public were issued protective masks.


Q: What was the outcome for the Pittsburgh firefighter who tested positive for COVID-19?
A: The firefighter recovered and returned to work.

Q: How many Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officials tested positive for the virus recently?
A: Two additional officials tested positive, including a recruit and an officer.


Q: What measures have been implemented to keep the virus numbers low among public safety personnel?
A: Measures include issuing personal protective equipment (PPE), wearing masks in public, screening first responders before entering facilities, and observing social distancing.


Q: What recognition did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive during National Emergency Medical Services Week?
A: They received recognition from the Pennsylvania Emergency Health Services Council for achieving expert level pediatric care.


Q: Who received the official certification for the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS's recognition?
A: EMS Chief Ron Romano received the official certification.


Q: What tragic event did Pittsburgh Police Chief Scott Schubert respond to in his message?
A: The tragic and senseless death of George Floyd.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's 2019 annual report highlight?
A: A 36% drop in homicides and ongoing efforts by group violence intervention.


Q: What task force was created by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police in response to protests?
A: The Damage Assessment & Accountability Task Force (DAAT).


Q: What incident led to the arrest of Matthew Michanowicz?
A: Police recovered a backpack with homemade explosives, and security footage showed Michanowicz placing the bag.


Q: How many new paramedics were sworn in by Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich?
A: Seven new paramedics were sworn in.


Q: Why did Pittsburgh see an increase in fireworks complaint calls in June 2020?
A: Due to the cancellation of public fireworks shows, many people conducted private shows, leading to a 389% increase in complaint calls.

Q: What is the purpose of the fireworks taskforce formed in Pittsburgh?
A: The fireworks taskforce, made up of Pittsburgh police and fire investigators, was formed to patrol city neighborhoods and respond to 911 calls for illegal fireworks.


Q: What are the restrictions on fireworks in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks are prohibited within 150 feet of any structure, in all parks, any public space, and on private property without the landowner's consent.


Q: What are the consequences for violating fireworks laws in Pittsburgh?
A: Violators are subject to a $100 fine and possible seizure of their fireworks.


Q: What safety concern does Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's Fire Prevention Officer highlight about sparklers?
A: Sparklers burn at 1,200 degrees, making them unsafe, especially for children.


Q: What will be different about Pittsburgh's Fourth of July celebrations due to the ongoing global pandemic?
A: There will be no city-sponsored fireworks show, no mass gatherings, and no alcohol consumption at bars.


Q: What is the role of Pittsburgh police during the Fourth of July amid the pandemic?
A: Pittsburgh police will counsel people not adhering to physical distancing or mask-wearing and instruct large groups to disperse.


Q: What safety tips are provided for the Fourth of July weekend in Pittsburgh?
A: Do not use fireworks illegally, do not fire guns in the air, practice water safety, follow pandemic guidelines, prepare for heat, and do not drink and drive.


Q: What incident occurred at Horace Mann School involving fireworks?
A: A group was warned about shooting off fireworks, which later led to a fire on the school's roof causing $50,000 to $60,000 in damage.


Q: What statement did the family of Officer Calvin Hall release on July 17, 2020?
A: The family expressed ongoing mourning for Officer Hall, who died from injuries on July 17, 2019, and thanked the community for their support.


Q: What award did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive in 2020?
A: The American Heart Association’s 2020 Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.


Q: What initiative did Pittsburgh Police and Global Links conclude in September 2020?
A: The "Need a Mask, Take a Mask" initiative, which distributed over 100,000 free masks to residents.


Q: What new capability has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire achieved as of October 2020?
A: Recognition as a Type-3A Swift Water and Flood Response Team by the Pennsylvania Department of Health.

Q: Who has headed up the training program for the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire over the past eight years?
A: Captain Patrick Shaw with engine truck 17.


Q: What certification makes the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's teams a regional asset for disaster response?
A: Type-3A certification.


Q: How many firefighters are trained and certified at the technician level in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: Thirty-eight firefighters.


Q: When did Pittsburgh Police Officer Timothy Matson return to work after the Tree of Life shooting?
A: October 6, 2020.


Q: What was Officer Timothy Matson's condition after the Tree of Life synagogue attack?
A: He was shot and seriously injured.


Q: Who was promoted to district chief during the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS ceremony on October 14, 2020?
A: Crew chief Anthony Shrader.


Q: What award did paramedics Romayne Bendig and Taylor Mahoney receive?
A: The district chief’s award.


Q: What precautionary measures did Pittsburgh Public Safety take in response to COVID-19?
A: Suspended all in-person training programs and inter-unit rotations.


Q: When did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police promote five officers to the rank of sergeant?
A: October 23, 2020.


Q: What illegal activities were discovered at the establishment Bridgez on Arlington Avenue?
A: Liquor sales without a license and illegal gambling.


Q: What action did Pittsburgh Public Safety take in Frick Park in November 2020?
A: Erected 'No Hunting' signs.


Q: How many Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officers tested positive for COVID-19 as of the latest report?
A: Nine officers.

Q: What changes were made to the Highmark First Night Pittsburgh celebrations due to the pandemic?
A: It transformed into a made-for-TV-only event with closed venues, prohibited large gatherings, and cancelled fireworks.


Q: What message did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich give for New Year’s Eve during the pandemic?
A: He urged people to celebrate responsibly, ideally at home, and not engage in dangerous or illegal activities like celebratory gunfire.


Q: What incidents did Pittsburgh police respond to on January 4, 2021?
A: They responded to two separate incidents involving explosives, one with an IED and another believed to be caused by an aerial firework.


Q: What preparations were being made by Pittsburgh's public safety department ahead of the presidential inauguration?
A: They were preparing with law enforcement partners at local, state, and federal levels for any possible events or protests.


Q: What was the outcome for the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police recruit class BR20-01?
A: The class graduated and will begin 13 weeks of field training starting January 25, 2021.


Q: What measures were Pittsburgh police taking on Super Bowl weekend?
A: They set up sobriety checkpoints and conducted roving DUI patrols as part of an impaired driving enforcement campaign.


Q: Who were Tanikka Pinnix and Layla Gooden, and what were they recognized for?
A: They were honored for saving a woman in distress on the Homestead Grays Bridge, preventing a potential tragedy.


Q: How did Pittsburgh police address the issue of unlawful off-road vehicle use in the city?
A: They devised a comprehensive operational plan focusing on education, law enforcement collaboration, and investigation/enforcement.


Q: What promotions and appointments took place in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Emergency Medical Services and Fire?
A: Several individuals were sworn in or promoted, including the first woman promoted to lieutenant since 1995, Kari Burnham.


Q: What tool was announced by the Office of Mayor William Peduto to address opioid use?
A: The creation of the opioid overdose dashboard.

Q: What is the purpose of the opioid overdose dashboard in Pittsburgh?
A: The dashboard compiles Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS data to map monthly opioid overdose calls and public safety’s response, including demographic information and statistics regarding care provided by first responders.


Q: Who is responsible for leading the overdose prevention efforts within the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: The overdose prevention program coordinator, in partnership with Pittsburgh EMS and the Allegheny County Health Department’s CDC-funded Overdose Data to Action program.


Q: What measures were taken for St. Patrick’s Day celebrations in Pittsburgh in 2021 due to COVID-19?
A: Celebrations were muted with restrictions on large crowds, mask-wearing, social distancing, and reduced bar and restaurant occupancy. The annual parade was moved to the fall.


Q: How many recruits graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire recruit class in March 2021?
A: 23 recruits graduated.


Q: What new resource has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police created to address animal welfare concerns?
A: A central email address (animal.law@pittsburghpa.gov) for citizens and officers to report animal welfare complaints and concerns.


Q: What is the goal of the newly-launched victim assistance website by Pittsburgh’s Public Safety Department?
A: To connect victims of crime to services such as crisis intervention, referrals, information, and advocacy.


Q: What does the Office of Community Health and Safety aim to do with the data from the opioid overdose dashboard?
A: To inform progressive opioid overdose prevention strategies and coordinate an equitable public health-informed response to the overdose crisis.


Q: What did Mayor William Peduto emphasize about the role of the Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: Redirecting city resources to better meet community needs by housing social services, public health, and social work experts to assist first responders.


Q: How did the COVID-19 pandemic affect the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire recruit class size?
A: The class started with 24 recruits instead of the typical 32 to comply with COVID-19 measures banning gatherings larger than 25 people.


Q: What is the focus of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's new animal welfare resource?
A: To ensure no concerns regarding the welfare and safety of the city’s animal population go unaddressed.

Q: What has caused concern among Pittsburgh residents and police in recent times?
A: The recent surge in violent crime, particularly affecting young people, has caused concern among Pittsburgh residents and police.


Q: How many homicides have occurred in Pittsburgh so far this year, and how does this compare to the previous year?
A: There have been 20 homicides, marking an 80% increase from the same time last year.


Q: What approach are Pittsburgh police taking to address the increase in violent crime?
A: Pittsburgh police are taking a proactive approach by working with community resource officers and neighborhood resource officers to engage with residents and business owners.


Q: What is the role of Group Violence Intervention (GVI) outreach workers in Pittsburgh?
A: GVI outreach workers mediate and interrupt violence as part of a partnership between law enforcement, outreach, social services, and the faith community.


Q: What did Pittsburgh Police Chief Scott Schubert say about the city's response to the national trend of increased violence?
A: Chief Schubert emphasized that the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police will not allow the senseless loss of life to continue and will work with the community to address the root causes of crime.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's 2020 annual report focus on?
A: The report includes crime statistics, personnel distribution, and highlights the bureau's commitment to community engagement and relational policing.


Q: What recent addition has been made to Pittsburgh's River Rescue unit?
A: A new paramedic and police rescue boat with state-of-the-art capabilities has been added to the River Rescue unit.


Q: What are some features of the new rescue boat launched by Pittsburgh's River Rescue unit?
A: The boat includes increased fire suppression capabilities, improved lighting, a windless anchor, docking assist, and built-in sonar.


Q: Who was promoted to battalion chief in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's recent promotions ceremony?
A: Michael Fuerst was promoted to battalion chief.


Q: What are the conditions for obtaining a block party permit in Pittsburgh?
A: Block party permits are limited to residentially zoned streets, cost $25, and are available for weekends or holidays from 10 am to 10 pm.


Q: How much does a special event permit cost in Pittsburgh, and what is its purpose?
A: A special event permit costs $200 plus any contracted city services and is for outdoor community and civic events on public property.

Q: What types of temporary permits can businesses in Pittsburgh apply for to promote outdoor space?
A: Businesses can apply for sidewalk cafe, parking lane cafe, full street closure, and curbside pick-up zone permits.


Q: Until when are the temporary permits for outdoor dining in Pittsburgh free?
A: The permits are free through the end of 2021.


Q: What is the purpose of the Stop the Violence Community Investment Fund in Pittsburgh?
A: To fund community projects intended to reduce violence in the city.


Q: How much initial investment is being made for the Stop the Violence Community Investment Fund?
A: An initial investment of $1,000,000.


Q: What organization is partnering with the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire for hazardous materials safety training?
A: Duquesne Light Company (DLC).


Q: When will the Department of Defense conduct training in and around Pittsburgh?
A: From June 13 to June 19, 2021.


Q: What is the purpose of the plaque dedicated by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: To honor firefighters who were lost in the line of duty.


Q: What event will Vice President Kamala Harris attend in Pittsburgh?
A: A visit to the city on June 21, 2021.


Q: What will the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS distribute to encourage safe swimming?
A: Youth life vests.

Q: What is the Safe Swim Initiative in Pittsburgh?
A: The Safe Swim Initiative aims to increase swimming and water safety throughout Pittsburgh by distributing youth-sized personal flotation devices and safe swimming information packets.


Q: When and where will the youth-sized personal flotation devices be distributed?
A: They will be distributed on Wednesday, June 23, at three summer lunch grab-and-go locations in Pittsburgh: Mellon, Beechview, and Troy Hill spray parks, from 9:30 a.m. to 1:00 p.m.


Q: What prompted the start of the Safe Swim Initiative?
A: The initiative began last summer due to the widespread closures of community pools during the COVID-19 pandemic, increasing the risk of children swimming in less-supervised settings.


Q: What is the second leading cause of unintentional injury death among children ages 1-14 according to the CDC?
A: Drowning is the second leading cause of unintentional injury death among children ages 1-14.


Q: What racial disparity exists in drowning rates among children?
A: Black children ages 10-14 years drown at rates 7.6 times higher than other children.


Q: What is the purpose of the Fireworks Task Force in Pittsburgh?
A: The Fireworks Task Force enforces regulations on the use of fireworks in Pittsburgh, including issuing citations and confiscating fireworks if laws are broken.


Q: What are the legal restrictions on fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be discharged within 150 feet of a structure or in any city park, ball field, or city-owned property.


Q: What enforcement actions will the Fireworks Task Force take for illegal fireworks use?
A: They will explain the laws on first complaints and may issue a $100 citation and confiscate fireworks on subsequent calls to the same address.


Q: What is the focus of Pittsburgh police's abandoned vehicle blitz on June 23?
A: The focus will be on addressing citizen complaints regarding abandoned vehicles in the Homewood neighborhood.


Q: How many homicides have occurred in Pittsburgh year-to-date compared to the same time in 2020?
A: There have been 31 homicides year-to-date compared to 20 at the same time in 2020.


Q: What is the role of the ATF in addressing gun violence in Pittsburgh?
A: The ATF is creating a firearms trafficking unit in Pittsburgh and assigning agents to work with local police to reduce gun violence.


Q: What activities are planned for Pittsburgh's Independence Day celebration?
A: The city-sponsored fireworks display will take place at Point State Park on July 4, with increased police presence and safety measures.


Q: What are the risks associated with consumer-grade fireworks?
A: Risks include blast injuries, heat injuries, and ocular injuries, especially when used in celebratory settings with impaired judgment.


Q: What is the primary focus of Pittsburgh Public Safety for the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: To ensure the safety of residents and visitors during the celebrations, with increased lighting and police presence in key locations.

Q: What safety measures are Pittsburgh police implementing in the South Side business district starting July 2, 2021?
A: Pittsburgh police will issue warnings and then citations to those obstructing public passageways, with potential penalties up to $300 plus court costs, and will enforce parking regulations with motorcycle and bicycle units.


Q: When and where is the city-sponsored fireworks display for Pittsburgh's 2021 Independence Day celebration scheduled?
A: The fireworks display is scheduled for July 4, 2021, at Point State Park.


Q: What is the role of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire boat during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire boat will be on the water with three firefighters to help ensure safety on the rivers.


Q: What are the potential risks of not managing heat during outdoor activities according to Dr. Donald Yealy?
A: Risks include heat exhaustion or heat stroke due to dehydration or inadequate heat dissipation.


Q: What is prohibited within 150 feet of any structure in Pittsburgh during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: The use of any fireworks, even legal ones, is prohibited within 150 feet of any structure.


Q: What reminders does Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich provide regarding children and pets in vehicles?
A: Hissrich warns against leaving children or pets in hot vehicles, as temperatures can rise rapidly, posing a risk of heat stroke or death.


Q: What is the advice given by Dr. Yealy for those not vaccinated against COVID-19 during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: Dr. Yealy advises those not vaccinated to wear a mask, as the COVID-19 virus is still present.


Q: What activities did the Pittsburgh Police Community Engagement Office participate in during the week of July 5 to July 11, 2021?
A: Activities included visiting a school, hosting "Chess with Cops," reading events in parks, engaging with summer camps, and participating in the Market Square Farmer’s Market.

A: The helicopter will monitor bridge traffic to ensure it keeps flowing and reduce congestion and collision risks.


Q: What is the function of the fireworks task force in Pittsburgh?
A: The task force enforces regulations related to fireworks use, continuing efforts until July 5.

A: Vladmir, a family member visiting from Russia, played an impromptu game with Officer Shifren.

A: Officers addressed concerns about ongoing drug use and overdoses.

A: Officer Payton deputized Andrew with a sticker recognizing him as a "junior police officer."

A: Vehicle traffic will be allowed outbound only between S.10th and S.18th streets, and side streets from S.11th to S.17th will be closed to traffic.

A: Officers spent time talking with youth and parents and participated in activities like reading and playing games.

A: To deliver essential items and hope to Pittsburgh's unsheltered community through the "Box of Goodness."


Q: What changes were made to the South Side vehicle traffic pattern on weekends?
A: East Carson Street was converted to one-way traffic eastbound between S.11th and S.17th, with parking and deliveries prohibited from 7 p.m. to 4 a.m.

Q: When will the traffic changes on East Carson Street begin on Fridays and Saturdays?
A: The traffic changes will begin at 9:30 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.


Q: What are the new 'no parking' enforcement hours on East Carson Street?
A: 'No parking' measures will be enforced starting at 8 p.m.


Q: Why was the traffic pilot project on East Carson Street temporarily halted?
A: The project was halted due to a partial building collapse in the 1600 block of East Carson Street.


Q: How were traffic and pedestrians affected by the building collapse on East Carson Street?
A: East Carson Street was closed to vehicle and pedestrian traffic between S. 16th and S. 17th streets.

A: They participated in a backpack, supplies, and mask giveaway for students.

A: He expressed being heartbroken and praised Tunch Ilkin's impact and legacy.

A: They honored the memory of those who lost their lives and the first responders who acted heroically.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police and FBI Pittsburgh are investigating threats to city churches.

A: Threats to harm congregants were received by telephone.


Q: What did parishioners observe at the church on the North Side?
A: A fellow congregant was carrying a gun during the service.

A: No, he provided a valid conceal carry permit and was allowed to leave.

A: They secured the scene and ensured no visible threat was present before escorting congregants to safety.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police and the FBI.

Q: How much prescription medication was collected by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police in April?
A: 34 boxes weighing a combined total of 672 pounds.


Q: How much expired or unused medication was collected nationally during the event?
A: 420 tons.


Q: What is the purpose of proper disposal of unused or expired prescription drugs?
A: To prevent them from getting into the wrong hands, reduce public safety hazards, and protect the environment.


Q: Where can expired, unused, and unwanted prescription drugs be dropped off in Pittsburgh?
A: At various police zones and headquarters, including Zone 1 at 1501 Brighton Rd, Zone 2 at 2000 Centre Ave, and others.

A: The enforcement of illegal dumping and littering.


Q: How much does illegal dumping cost Pennsylvania taxpayers annually?
A: Approximately $68 million in mitigation each year.

A: The city's goals on littering and dumping (GOLD) plan.

Q: What happened to Jim Rogers after being taken into Pittsburgh Bureau of Police custody on October 13, 2021?
A: He was transported to Mercy Hospital, where he passed away the following day.


Q: What did the internal critical incident review board (CIRB) find regarding the incident involving Jim Rogers?
A: A series of procedural failures contributed to the tragic outcome.


Q: What new requirement was implemented for Pittsburgh police officers following the incident with Jim Rogers?
A: Officers are required to complete a taser refresher course and become fully certified emergency medical responders.


Q: What significant change did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police announce following the critical incident review of Jim Rogers' case?
A: Policy and procedural changes, including mandatory presence of a supervisor at any use of force incident.


Q: What was the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's response to the bridge collapse in Frick Park on January 28, 2022?
A: Rescue crews responded, and a mass casualty plan was activated.


Q: What was the cause of the bridge collapse in Frick Park, Pittsburgh?
A: The cause of the collapse is under investigation.


Q: Who was appointed as the emergency management coordinator for the city of Pittsburgh in January 2022?
A: Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire Chief Darryl Jones.

Q: What position has Chief Jones held since 2007?
A: Chief Jones has held the position of Chief with the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire since 2007.


Q: What additional role will Chief Jones supervise?
A: Chief Jones will supervise the Office of Emergency Management and Homeland Security (OEHMS).


Q: What are some of Chief Jones' qualifications for the OEHMS role?
A: Chief Jones is a PA certified municipal emergency management professional, a member of the Pennsylvania All-Hazards Incident Management Team, and a U.S. Department of Homeland Security Type-3 Incident Commander and Planning Section Chief.


Q: What did the city of Pittsburgh do after the Fern Hollow Bridge collapse?
A: The city of Pittsburgh worked with PennDOT to secure a contractor for remediation and reconstruction, and to support the NTSB investigation.

A: There were 28 recruits in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's recruit class 131-21.

A: One recruit is a third-generation firefighter, and eight are second-generation firefighters.


Q: What was the main message from Public Safety Director Lee Schmidt during the EMS swearing-in ceremony?
A: Lee Schmidt encouraged new EMS members to continue Pittsburgh's legacy of innovative emergency care and to think of new ideas to improve EMS services.


Q: What is the significance of the Freedom House Ambulance Service mentioned by Dr. Ronald Roth?
A: It was the first emergency medical service to provide training beyond basic first aid and set the standard for emergency care.


Q: What is the OneCOP program?
A: OneCOP is a program that facilitates partnerships between local law enforcement agencies and diverse congregations to improve police-community relations.


Q: What is the aim of the OneCOP initiative in Pittsburgh?
A: To strengthen ties between police and communities, and to address grievances and perceptions civilians have about law enforcement.

A: Chief Scott Schubert announced his retirement from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police.


Q: What significant initiatives did Chief Scott Schubert implement during his tenure?
A: He implemented the pillars of former President Obama's task force report on 21st-century policing, created a real-time crime center, and established the Group Violence Intervention program.


Q: What is the purpose of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's annual report?
A: The report provides a comprehensive overview of the bureau’s work, statistical analysis, and highlights community engagement efforts.

A: The 50th anniversary of Pride in Pittsburgh was commemorated.


Q: What was announced by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police on June 22, 2023?
A: The passing of retired Police Sergeant Dawn Mercurio was announced.

Q: When did Sergeant Dawn Mercurio fall ill and what was her diagnosis?
A: Sergeant Dawn Mercurio fell ill in September 2020 and was diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma, a rare form of kidney cancer.


Q: What was Dawn Mercurio's career before joining the police force?
A: Before joining the police force, Dawn Mercurio was in the teaching field.


Q: At what age did Dawn Mercurio complete the police academy?
A: Dawn Mercurio completed the police academy at age 37.


Q: What roles did Dawn Mercurio serve in during her policing career?
A: Dawn Mercurio served as a uniformed patrol officer, plainclothes detective, sergeant, adjunct instructor at the Pittsburgh Police Training Academy, and SWAT negotiator.


Q: Who is Dawn Mercurio's husband and what is his role in the Pittsburgh SWAT?
A: Dawn Mercurio's husband is Sergeant Larry Mercurio, a long-time member of Pittsburgh SWAT.


Q: When did Dawn and Larry Mercurio get married, and what is their argued true anniversary date?
A: Dawn and Larry Mercurio got married on September 19, 1995, but Larry argues their true anniversary date is February 14, 1983.


Q: When were Dawn and Larry Mercurio's grandsons born?
A: Their grandsons, Colton and Ryder, were born on January 22 and January 24, 2023.


Q: What is the purpose of the Fire Investigation Unit's annual fireworks task force in Pittsburgh?
A: The purpose is to respond to fireworks-related calls and complaints, ensuring safe usage of legally purchased fireworks.


Q: What are some restrictions on fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be ignited on property without permission, discharged within 150 feet of buildings, or in city parks, and cannot be directed at people or used under the influence.


Q: When is Pittsburgh's Independence Day celebration scheduled and where will events be held?
A: Pittsburgh's Independence Day celebration is scheduled for July 4, 2023, with events at Point State Park, North Shore, Mount Washington, and West End Overlook.


Q: What are some road closures planned for Pittsburgh's Independence Day celebration?
A: Liberty Avenue, 376E exit 70A, and Commonwealth Place will have closures, with potential closures on Fort Duquesne Boulevard and others on the North Shore and Mount Washington.


Q: What significant event occurred in Pittsburgh on July 25, 2023?
A: Former Pittsburgh Police Chief Earl Buford Jr. passed away on July 25, 2023.


Q: What planned exercise did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire announce for August 22, 2023?
A: A planned exercise involving PA-HART and Blackhawk helicopters at Point State Park and Brunot Island.

A: An active shooter/critical incident occurred during an eviction notice, resulting in a standoff and the subject's death.

A: City social workers and trauma support teams will be available to provide support services.

A: Lieutenant Randolph "Randy" Meyer, II was a firefighter with the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire who passed away on August 19, 2023.

A: Lieutenant Meyer battled appendiceal cancer.

A: The purpose is to provide a general overview of criminal activity across the city, making comprehensive crime data publicly available and easily accessible.

A: Dr. Ronald Roth served as the medical director for the Department of Public Safety for over 21 years.

Q: What was Therese Rocco's role in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Therese Rocco was Pittsburgh's first female assistant chief.

Q: What was Therese Rocco known for in her law enforcement career?
A: Therese Rocco was known for becoming the first woman in the U.S. to be promoted to assistant chief of police and for being a nationally renowned expert in missing persons, particularly children.


Q: When did Therese Rocco retire from her law enforcement career?
A: Therese Rocco retired in 1994.

A: The Department of Public Safety is preparing for Highmark First Night 2024 in Pittsburgh.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's recruit class 133-23 completed their training and held a graduation ceremony.


Q: What new policy changes have been made by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police following the death of Jim Rogers?
A: The new policy changes include assigning an officer to monitor prisoners during transfer to hospitals, summoning EMS after Taser deployments, retraining on single officer tactics, training on "duty to intervene," and reviewing body camera footage after use of force.


Q: What operational change will the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police implement starting February 26, 2024?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police will transition to four 10-hour shifts each week with three consecutive days off.


Q: Why is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Animal Care and Control pausing its spay and neuter program?
A: The program is paused due to inappropriate use, such as individuals using city addresses to bring in animals from outside city limits.

A: Christopher Ragland, Martin Devine, and Richard Ford were promoted to assistant chief.


Q: What are the weather expectations for the First Night 2024 event in Pittsburgh?
A: The weather is expected to be seasonal with temperatures in the low to mid-30s and a chance of precipitation.

Q: What new division has been formed within the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: The Violent Crime Division, which includes homicide, narcotics, intelligence, and the violence prevention unit.


Q: What is the purpose of the blue phones installed outside all six police zones and the downtown public safety center?
A: They provide a direct line to 9-1-1 between 3 a.m. and 7 a.m.


Q: What is the function of the newly created Enhanced Telephone Reporting Unit (TRU) in Pittsburgh?
A: It operates from 7 a.m. to 3 a.m. daily to handle reports for calls not requiring an in-person officer response.

A: An online portal for police/community engagement events, safety alerts, monthly crime statistics, and zone/neighborhood-centered news.

Q: What changes are being made to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's response to burglar alarms?
A: Adjustments to how officers are dispatched to burglar alarm activations to improve efficiency.

Q: How many calls for service for burglar alarms were there in 2023?
A: There were 9,097 calls for service for burglar alarms in 2023.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarm calls generated police reports in 2023?
A: 0.43% of burglar alarm calls generated police reports.


Q: How many of the police-reported incidents involved a verified alarm with a break-in?
A: 6 incidents involved a verified alarm with a break-in.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarms with police reports resulted from vandalism or objects thrown through windows?
A: 64% of burglar alarms with police reports resulted from vandalism or objects thrown through windows.


Q: How many police staff hours were spent on burglar alarm responses in 2023?
A: 4,166 police staff hours were spent on burglar alarm responses.


Q: What is the average time spent per unit on burglar alarm responses?
A: The average time spent per unit on burglar alarm responses is 13.5 minutes.


Q: What types of alarms will be dispatched as a priority response under the new model?
A: Hold-up alarms, panic alarms, medical alert alarms, alarms at priority locations, verified burglar alarms, and multiple progressive alarm activations will be dispatched as a priority response.


Q: What is the consequence for having more than two false alarm responses in a calendar year?
A: The permit holder will be required to pay a fee for each false alarm after the second one.


Q: When will the updated response model for burglar alarms go into effect?
A: The updated response model will go into effect on April 15, 2024.


Q: What is the requirement for applicants to be school crossing guards in Pittsburgh?
A: Applicants must be at least 18 years old, possess a valid class C Pennsylvania driver’s license, pass a background check, and be city residents during employment.

Q: What is BigBurgh.com doing to support Citiparks' summer food program?
A: BigBurgh.com is listing the summer food service program sites and will have an information table at the kickoff event.

Q: What is bigburgh.com?
A: bigburgh.com is a City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Safety web-app listing free services for people experiencing homelessness or anyone in dire need.


Q: Who can use bigburgh.com?
A: Anyone, including first responders, service providers, and the general public, can use bigburgh.com to find free services throughout Pittsburgh and Allegheny County.


Q: What services does bigburgh.com list?
A: bigburgh.com lists essential everyday needs such as meals, shelter, clinics, showers, laundry, clothing, diapers, and help with financial, legal, and employment matters, as well as emergency hotlines.


Q: When did bigburgh.com join the list of city web-apps?
A: bigburgh.com joined the list of city web-apps in 2018.


Q: How many monthly users does bigburgh.com average since its adoption by the city?
A: The city has seen an average of over 4,800 monthly users.


Q: What is the Citiparks Summer Food Service Program?
A: It is a program operated by Citiparks in partnership with Pittsburgh Public Schools to provide food for the city’s youth during summer and after-school periods.


Q: Who funds the Citiparks Summer Food Service Program?
A: The program is funded by the US Department of Agriculture through the Pennsylvania Department of Education.


Q: Who should be contacted for more information about bigburgh.com?
A: Sally Stadelman, the manager of bigburgh.com, can be contacted at sally.stadelman@pittsburghpa.gov or 412-255-2239.

A: Pittsburgh police investigated a social media post by a city officer and referred the officer to OMI for a full investigation.

A: Pittsburgh officials commended participants for peaceful protests and have prioritized respecting protesters' First Amendment rights while ensuring public safety.

A: Gregory Clark Wagner was charged with three counts of reckless endangerment, one count of driving the wrong way, and one count of careless driving.

A: Misting stations and EMS units were deployed, and a "zero tolerance" warning for disorderly conduct was issued. The Coast Guard enforced regulations on the waterways.


Q: What are the pet safety regulations during hot weather in Pittsburgh?
A: Pets cannot be left outside for more than 30 minutes when temperatures exceed 90 degrees, and animals in distress inside hot cars will be removed by officers.

Q: How many ethnic intimidation incidents does the city of Pittsburgh average annually?
A: Pittsburgh averages 19 ethnic intimidation incidents per year.


Q: What percentage of ethnic intimidation incidents in Pittsburgh involve racial animus?
A: 76% of incidents involve race, with the vast majority targeting African Americans.


Q: What is the arrest rate for ethnic intimidation incidents in Pittsburgh?
A: The arrest rate averages 40%, with nearly 60% for violent incidents.

Q: What is the nature of the Duquesne Light scam mentioned in the text?
A: The scam involves callers pretending to be from Duquesne Light Company, threatening to terminate services unless the customer buys gift cards or pre-paid cards to pay off a supposed debt.


Q: What should residents do if they receive a suspicious call claiming to be from Duquesne Light?
A: Residents should not provide payment information and should verify the call by contacting Duquesne Light directly.

Q: What safety measures are in place for the First Night events in Pittsburgh?
A: There will be a significant police presence, and police will look for impaired drivers. Drones and illegal weapons are prohibited.


Q: What technology does Pittsburgh use to detect gunfire incidents?
A: Pittsburgh uses ShotSpotter, a wide-area network of acoustic sensors, to detect and locate gunfire incidents.


Q: How has the trend in homicides and shootings in Pittsburgh changed from 2014 to 2018?
A: Homicides and shootings have trended downwards, with homicides decreasing from 71 in 2014 to 55 in 2018, and non-fatal shootings decreasing from 188 in 2016 to 114 in 2018.

A: The clearance rate improved to 71 percent in 2018.

Q: What happened to Officer Hall on July 14, 2019?
A: Officer Hall was shot three times in the back on Monticello Street and remained in critical condition until he passed away on July 17, 2019.

A: Camerin Caldwell was charged with criminal attempt homicide (two counts), aggravated assault (two counts), reckless endangerment (two counts), and firearms violations.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police planned an end of watch ceremony and a public funeral and memorial service, with full burial honors for Officer Hall.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police launched a month-long public blood drive in partnership with Vitalant to honor Officer Hall.

A: Officer Hall's signature motto was, "Gotta go. Time for me to make a difference."

A: Temporary road closures were implemented, and a funeral procession was organized to accommodate the large number of attendees.

A: Officer Hall's family thanked the medical staff, fellow officers, city officials, and others for their support and care during the difficult time.

A: To investigate crimes such as property damage, looting, and assaults related to protests.


Q: How many paramedics were sworn in by Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich on June 5, 2020?
A: Seven new paramedics.


Q: Why was a Fireworks Taskforce formed in Pittsburgh in June 2020?
A: To address the illegal use of fireworks in city neighborhoods due to increased complaints.


Q: What are the legal restrictions on fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks are prohibited within 150 feet of any structure, in parks, public spaces, and on private property without the owner's consent.


Q: What safety concern is associated with celebratory gunfire during events like the Fourth of July?
A: Bullets fired into the air must come down and can be deadly.

Q: What organizations will be on Pittsburgh's three rivers to enforce boating laws and teach water safety?
A: River rescue, the fire boat, and the coast guard.


Q: What are the pandemic guidelines mentioned in the text?
A: Maintain proper physical distancing, wear a mask, wash hands for at least 20 seconds often, avoid large crowds, and stay home if not feeling well.


Q: What is Allegheny County experiencing according to the text?
A: A spike in new COVID-19 cases.


Q: What is the forecast for the Fourth of July weather in Pittsburgh?
A: Temperatures are forecast to be above 90 degrees for many days in a row.


Q: What is the policy on drinking and driving mentioned in the text?
A: Public safety has a zero-tolerance policy for drinking and driving.


Q: What should pet owners do during fireworks according to the text?
A: Keep pets in a safe place as many dogs panic and run away when they hear fireworks.


Q: How many fireworks complaint calls were received by the fireworks taskforce across all six police zones?
A: 85 fireworks complaint calls.


Q: What happened at the Horace Mann School due to fireworks?
A: The roof of the abandoned school was discovered to be on fire, causing an estimated $50,000 to $60,000 damage.


Q: What is prohibited by state law regarding the use of fireworks?
A: The use of fireworks within 150 feet of any structure, in all parks, public spaces, and on private property without the landowner's consent.

A: The Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.

A: Four years in a row.

A: The "Need a Mask, Take a Mask" initiative.

A: More than 100,000 free masks.

A: Recognition as a Type-3A Swift Water and Flood Response Team.

A: A severe rainstorm causing flash flooding along Washington Boulevard in August 2011.

A: Pittsburgh Bureau of Police Officer Timothy Matson returned to work on modified duty.

A: 11 people.

A: The District Chief’s Award.

A: For consistently demonstrating outstanding acts of service that reflect rare and exceptional character and an uncommon degree of concern for the well-being of others.


Q: What immediate action did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich take in response to COVID-19 exposures?
A: Suspended all in-person training programs and inter-unit rotations for police, fire, and EMS until after the election period.


Q: What shift changes were implemented for the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police around the federal election?
A: Police moved to 12-hour shifts from November 2 until November 8, with all pass days, personal days, and holidays canceled.

A: Seizure of beer, liquor, gambling devices, cash, and arrests for sales of alcohol without a license and illegal gambling.

A: Hunting.

A: Nine officers.

A: The COVID-19 pandemic led to the closure of venues, prohibition of large gatherings, and cancellation of fireworks.

A: Two separate incidents involving explosives, one with an IED and another with an aerial firework.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police utilized intelligence-gathering methods and maintained communication with local and federal law enforcement to protect residents and infrastructure.

A: The class of 32 recruits graduated and began 13 weeks of field training starting January 25, 2021.

A: They participated in PennDOT’s Western Alliance/Team DUI program to set up sobriety checkpoints and conduct roving DUI patrols.

A: Tanikka Pinnix and Layla Gooden were honored for their actions.


Q: What issues did Pittsburgh face with off-road vehicles in 2020?
A: Pittsburgh experienced large numbers of unlawful off-road vehicles, such as ATVs and dirt bikes, driving recklessly in the city.


Q: What is the purpose of the Opioid Overdose Dashboard announced by Pittsburgh Public Safety?
A: To guide policies and programs addressing unsafe opioid use by compiling EMS data to map overdose calls and responses.


Q: What changes were made to St. Patrick's Day celebrations in Pittsburgh in 2021?
A: Celebrations were muted due to COVID-19 safety measures, with the annual parade moved to the fall.

Q: What is the stance of Pittsburgh's Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich on maintaining vigilance during the pandemic?
A: Wendell Hissrich urges continued vigilance and discipline in fighting COVID-19, emphasizing a zero-tolerance policy for illegal behavior.


Q: What are the specific illegal behaviors Pittsburgh law enforcement is focusing on during the pandemic?
A: Underage drinking, public intoxication, drinking and driving, and violations of open container laws.


Q: How are Pittsburgh fire officials ensuring safety in establishments during the pandemic?
A: They conduct occupancy checks and will clear and close any establishment that exceeds occupancy limits.


Q: What new resource did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police create to address animal welfare concerns?
A: A central email address (animal.law@pittsburghpa.gov) for citizens to report animal welfare complaints and concerns.


Q: What was the outcome of the Derek Chauvin trial as mentioned by Pittsburgh Police Chief Scott Schubert?
A: Derek Chauvin was found guilty of second-degree murder, third-degree murder, and manslaughter.


Q: How did Pittsburgh Police Chief Scott Schubert describe the duty of police officers in relation to the Derek Chauvin trial?
A: He stated that police officers have a fundamental duty to care for and safeguard everyone in their custody, which did not occur in George Floyd's case.

A: To connect victims to services like crisis intervention, referrals, information, and advocacy.

A: An 80% increase in homicides and a 90% increase in non-fatal shootings compared to the previous year.

A: Engaging with community resource officers and neighborhood resource officers in affected neighborhoods and increasing presence of group violence intervention workers.

A: Scott Schubert

A: Establishing strong ties with each community in the city and implementing relational policing.

A: A new paramedic and police rescue boat.

A: Increased fire suppression capabilities, improved lighting, a windless anchor, docking assist, built-in sonar, forward and backward-trained cameras, a bow gate, and improved FLIR for night vision.

A: Lake Assault in Superior, Wisconsin.

A: The ATF is creating a firearms trafficking unit in Pittsburgh and assigning two agents to work with Pittsburgh police.

A: The pandemic restricted face-to-face contact, custom notifications, hospital visits, and support from coaches and teachers, while recreation centers were closed.

A: Violators may receive citations with penalties up to $300 plus court costs, and possibly face physical arrests.

A: The taskforce patrols neighborhoods and responds to complaints about illegal fireworks use.

A: Risks include blast injuries, heat injuries, and ocular injuries, especially when used with impaired judgment.

A: Fireworks are not allowed in Point State Park or any city park, and their use is prohibited within 150 feet of any structure.

A: They will be monitoring for heat-related ailments.


Q: What is the role of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire boat will be on the water with three firefighters.

A: People are advised to avoid alcohol as it leads to quick dehydration and to drink enough fluids to prevent heat-related issues.

A: Increased gun violence, overcrowded sidewalks and streets, traffic safety obstacles, and noise complaints.


Q: What traffic changes are being implemented on East Carson Street as part of the pilot project?
A: Vehicle traffic will be outbound only between S.10th and S.18th streets on Fridays and Saturdays from 7 p.m. to 4 a.m., and side streets from S.11th to S.17th will be closed to traffic.


Q: Who is allowed to travel in both directions on East Carson Street during the pilot project?
A: Only emergency vehicles and Port Authority buses.


Q: Are ride-sharing services allowed on East Carson Street between S.10th and S.18th streets?
A: No, ride-sharing services like Uber and Lyft are not permitted in this area during the specified hours.


Q: What are the parking and delivery restrictions on East Carson Street during the pilot project?
A: Parking and deliveries are prohibited on either side of East Carson Street between 7 p.m. and 4 a.m.


Q: What is the role of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police during the pilot project on East Carson Street?
A: Officers will be posted in key areas to ensure the safe flow of traffic.


Q: What adjustment was made to the traffic pilot project on East Carson Street on August 12, 2021?
A: The start time for converting East Carson Street to one-way traffic was changed from 7:00 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.

A: Due to a partial building collapse on the 1600 block of East Carson Street.

A: 237 law enforcement officers attended.


Q: What program did Sergeant Carla Kearns create following the death of FBI Special Agent Sam Hicks?
A: She created the Pittsburgh Members Assistance Program (PMAP), a peer-to-peer support program for police.

Q: When did the trial run of Axon My90 begin in Pittsburgh Police Zone 3?
A: The trial run of Axon My90 began on December 19, 2022.


Q: What is the purpose of the Axon My90 tool?
A: The Axon My90 tool aims to bridge the gap between officers and the neighborhoods they serve by using brief surveys to gather community feedback on police interactions.


Q: How are residents in Pittsburgh Police Zone 3 able to provide feedback on police interactions?
A: Residents receive a text link for a survey following designated calls for service or police interaction.


Q: Are the surveys used in the Axon My90 program anonymous?
A: Yes, the surveys are completely anonymous.


Q: When did the Axon My90 program become active in all Pittsburgh Bureau of Police zones?
A: The Axon My90 program became active city-wide on February 16, 2023.


Q: What is the Office of Film & Event Management (OFEM) responsible for?
A: OFEM is responsible for receiving and vetting applications for events and film productions, consulting with applicants, and ensuring industry standards, safety regulations, and city policies are followed.


Q: Who leads the new Office of Film & Event Management?
A: Brian Katze leads the new Office of Film & Event Management as the Film & Events Manager.

Q: What historical significance does Pittsburgh EMS have?
A: It grew out of the creation of Freedom House in 1967, where new and innovative protocols for prehospital care were developed.

A: EMS Community Paramedic Crew Chief John Mooney and OCH&S Manager Laura Drogowski


Q: What are some chronic health conditions mentioned that lead to frequent EMS calls in Pittsburgh?

A: To address the needs of the most vulnerable in the community and reduce reliance on the 9-1-1 system

Q: What is the purpose of the annual fireworks task force in Pittsburgh?
A: The task force responds to fireworks-related calls and complaints.


Q: What are the restrictions on fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be ignited on property without permission, within 150 feet of buildings or vehicles, or in city parks.

Q: When can municipalities restrict the use of consumer-grade fireworks?
A: Municipalities may restrict the use of consumer-grade fireworks between 10 p.m. and 10 a.m., except for July 2, 3, and 4, when they can be displayed until 1 a.m.


Q: What happens if fireworks are misused or used illegally in Pittsburgh?
A: Misuse or illegal use of fireworks can result in warnings, citations, arrests, and confiscation by the fireworks task force.


Q: What should pet owners be aware of during fireworks events?
A: Pet owners should be aware that some pets can be sensitive to loud noises and flashing lights, which may cause them to run away or hide.


Q: Where is the central location for Pittsburgh's Independence Day events?
A: Point State Park is the central location for Pittsburgh's Independence Day events.


Q: What are the scheduled times for the fireworks at Point State Park on July 4th?
A: The fireworks are scheduled from 9:35 to 10:00 p.m.


Q: What are the road closures in downtown Pittsburgh on July 4th?
A: Liberty Avenue from Stanwix to Commonwealth Place and 376E exit 70A to Liberty Avenue will be closed from noon to midnight.


Q: What new feature is added to the North Shore for this year's Independence Day celebration?
A: A stage set up for live music and a hot air balloon landing on the Great Lawn area near the Allegheny River.


Q: What is the role of the fireworks task force in Pittsburgh?
A: The task force allows for the safe usage of legally purchased fireworks in compliance with laws and ordinances.

A: Residents should call Animal Care and Control at (412) 255-2036, or for urgent situations after office hours, call (412) 255-2935.

A: A planned exercise with the Pennsylvania Helicopter Aquatic Rescue Team at Point State Park and Brunot Island.

A: The subject was pronounced deceased at the scene following a nearly six-and-a-half-hour standoff.

A: Earl Buford Jr. was a former police chief of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, serving from 1992 to 1995.

A: The Department of Public Safety is planning for road closures and increased monitoring by public safety bureaus and local law enforcement partners.

Q: What is the purpose of the new Pittsburgh police data portal?
A: The purpose is to provide a general overview of criminal activity across the city, making comprehensive crime data publicly available and easily accessible.


Q: What exclusions are there in the Pittsburgh police data portal?
A: Violent crimes of a sexual nature are excluded, and no personally identifying information is attached to the incidents.


Q: What will the nationwide emergency alert system test include?
A: The test will include alerts sent to all wireless and electronic devices, targeting consumer cell phones and displaying messages on radios and televisions.

A: Officers will transition to four 10-hour shifts each week with three consecutive days off.

A: The Violent Crime Division, which includes homicide, narcotics, intelligence, and the violence prevention unit.


Q: Why is the City of Pittsburgh pausing its spay and neuter program?
A: Due to inappropriate use of the program, such as using city addresses to bring in animals from outside city limits.

A: It serves as a one-stop shop for police/community engagement events, safety alerts, monthly crime statistics, and zone/neighborhood-centered news.

A: Improvements include monitoring prisoners during hospital transfers, summoning EMS after taser deployments, retraining on avoiding single officer tactics, and reviewing body camera footage after use of force incidents.

Q: What changes are being made to the Pittsburgh police response protocol for burglar alarms?
A: Officers will prioritize verified alarms and certain types of alarms, while unverified alarms will be treated as non-priority calls.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarm calls in 2023 resulted in verified incidents?
A: 0.43% of the calls resulted in verified incidents.


Q: What financial penalty is imposed for multiple false burglar alarms in Pittsburgh?
A: The permit holder must pay a fee after the second false alarm, and calls may be disregarded after the fifth false alarm in a calendar year.

A: April 15, 2024.

Q: What are the penalties for passing a school bus with red lights activated in Pittsburgh?
A: The penalty includes a $250 fine, $117.50 in court costs and state fees, 5 points on the driver's license, and a 60-day license suspension.

Q: Which law enforcement agencies are part of the team mentioned in the text?
A: The team includes law enforcement officers from the FBI, Port Authority Police of Allegheny County, Allegheny County Police Department, Allegheny County Sheriff’s Office, North Versailles Police Department, Stowe Township Police Department, Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, and the Drug Enforcement Administration.


Q: What funding has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire received for fire prevention for the deaf and hard of hearing?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire has been awarded more than $1 million in federal and civic funding, with FEMA providing over $950,000 and the City of Pittsburgh contributing close to $50,000.


Q: What is the purpose of the Scentsational Tracking Program launched by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: The program is designed to create a safety net for individuals who might get lost, using bloodhounds to track a loved one's scent.


Q: What award did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive from the American Heart Association in 2019?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS received the American Heart Association’s 2019 Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.


Q: When is the National Prescription Drug Take Back Day scheduled, and what is its purpose?
A: It is scheduled for October 26, 2019, and aims to safely dispose of expired, unused, and unwanted prescription drugs to prevent misuse and abuse.


Q: What preparations are being made for President Donald Trump's visit to Pittsburgh?
A: The City of Pittsburgh’s Department of Public Safety is preparing for street closures and traffic management around the David L. Lawrence Convention Center.


Q: How can residents participate in the Scentsational Tracking Program?
A: Residents can participate by attending community outreach events or contacting their local police zone for more information.


Q: What are the storage recommendations for scent containers in the Scentsational Tracking Program?
A: Scent containers should be stored in a refrigerator, or if not feasible, at a temperature below 76°F and humidity less than 60%.


Q: What significant event is Pittsburgh Public Safety preparing for on October 23, 2019?
A: They are preparing for President Donald Trump's visit to the Shale Insight Conference in downtown Pittsburgh.


Q: What is the status of the officers injured in the Tree of Life synagogue attack?
A: Officers Michael Smidga, John Persin, and Tyler Pashel have recovered and returned to work, while Officers Dan Mead, Anthony Burke, and Timothy Matson continue to recover and have not yet returned.

Q: Who suffered a gunshot wound to the hand and expressed gratitude for community support?
A: Officer Anthony Burke.


Q: Which officer suffered multiple gunshot wounds and thanked the community, UPMC staff, and SWAT teammates?
A: Officer Timothy Matson.

A: A swearing-in and awards ceremony for new paramedics and a promotion to paramedic.

A: Swearing in new paramedics and promoting an EMT to paramedic.

A: Late Pittsburgh Bureau of Police Officer Calvin Hall.

A: 34 new officers.


Q: What is the significance of Light Up Night in Pittsburgh?
A: It marks the start of the holiday season and involves large public festivities.


Q: What was Officer Phil Lerza promoted to within the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Sergeant.


Q: What safety advice did public safety give for Halloween trick-or-treaters in Pittsburgh?
A: Ensure costumes are reflective, light in color, and provide full visibility; add clip-on lights for visibility.

A: A significant police presence, collaboration with law enforcement agencies, and a zero-tolerance policy for disorderly conduct.


Q: What was the weather forecast for Halloween trick-or-treating hours in Pittsburgh?
A: Temperatures dropping to the low 50s with wind chill and significant rainfall expected.

Q: Who was Rocco and what happened to him?
A: Rocco was Officer Lerza's K-9 partner who was stabbed in the line of duty and later succumbed to his injuries.

A: Sergeant Lerza will be assigned to Zone 5 under the leadership of Commander Stephen Vinansky.

A: 93 officers and traffic guards were honored.

A: The class included 16 U.S. military veterans and four recruits following in the footsteps of family members.


Q: What did Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich remind people about during the First Night 2020 celebrations?
A: Hissrich reminded people to be safe and law-abiding and warned against shooting guns into the air.


Q: Who was Glenn M. Cannon, and what was his contribution to Pittsburgh?
A: Glenn M. Cannon was a former Public Safety Director who created and led Pittsburgh's EMS department and established the city's first river rescue and hazardous materials response teams.


Q: How many new K9 officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police K9 Training Academy in January 2020?
A: Five new K9 officers graduated.


Q: What were some factors credited for the reduction in Pittsburgh's crime rates in 2019?
A: Excellent police work, community outreach, the work of medics, firefighters, hospitals, and partner law enforcement agencies were credited for the reduction in crime rates.

Q: By what percentage did homicides in the city drop from 2018 to 2019?
A: Homicides in the city dropped by 36 percent from 2018 to 2019.


Q: What policing model did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police begin transitioning to in 2016?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police began transitioning to evidence-based and intelligence-led policing in 2016.


Q: What technology was expanded in 2018 to help reduce crime in Pittsburgh?
A: The ShotSpotter system was expanded from three square miles of coverage to 18 square miles of coverage in 2018.


Q: How many violent crimes were reported citywide in Pittsburgh in 2019?
A: There were 1,569 violent crimes reported citywide in Pittsburgh in 2019.


Q: What is the purpose of the Group Violence Intervention (GVI) strategy?
A: The purpose of GVI is to focus police efforts on the most violent individuals in communities to help them avoid a dangerous lifestyle.


Q: How did the number of ethnic intimidation cases change from 2018 to 2019 in Pittsburgh?
A: Ethnic intimidation cases increased from 17 total incidents in 2018 to 22 total incidents in 2019.


Q: What donation did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police receive from Allegheny Health Network (AHN)?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police received a donation of 1,000 NuStat gauze packages from Allegheny Health Network (AHN).


Q: What preparations has the Pittsburgh Public Safety Department made for a potential coronavirus outbreak?
A: The Pittsburgh Public Safety Department updated its pandemic operational plan, trained first responders, and coordinated with local hospitals and public safety officials for a potential coronavirus outbreak.

A: Six new paramedics were sworn in by the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS on March 9, 2020.

A: Four sergeants were promoted to lieutenant, and three officers were promoted to sergeant in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police.

A: Pittsburgh will maintain a zero tolerance policy for disruptive and illegal behavior.

A: Pittsburgh police are targeting underage drinking and drinking and driving.

A: Pittsburgh suggests using Lyft, Uber, and Z-trip.

A: Pittsburgh police will have undercover officers, uniformed officers, and mounted units deployed, and river rescue will be active.

A: Officials are urging businesses to lower occupancy rates and enforce social distancing.

A: A 28-person recruit class was temporarily suspended, and contact-tracing was conducted.

A: They received state recognition for achieving expert level pediatric care.
