A: He expressed being deeply disturbed and emphasized the duty to safeguard everyone in custody.


Q: What was noted in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's 2019 annual report?
A: The report noted a 36% drop in homicides and ongoing efforts in group violence intervention and homeless empathy training.

Q: Who was Officer Calvin Hall?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was a member of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police who died in the line of duty on July 17, 2019.


Q: What is the DAAT?
A: The DAAT, or Damage Assessment & Accountability Task Force, is a multi-agency team formed to investigate crimes related to protests in Pittsburgh.


Q: What was Matthew Michanowicz arrested for?
A: Matthew Michanowicz was arrested for placing a backpack with homemade explosives in Pittsburgh.


Q: What is the role of the Fireworks Taskforce in Pittsburgh?
A: The Fireworks Taskforce in Pittsburgh is responsible for patrolling neighborhoods and responding to 911 calls regarding illegal fireworks use.


Q: How has the COVID-19 pandemic affected Fourth of July celebrations in Pittsburgh?
A: Due to COVID-19, Pittsburgh cancelled public fireworks shows and large gatherings for the Fourth of July, and law enforcement focused on enforcing safety measures and preventing illegal fireworks use.


Q: What are the restrictions on fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be used within 150 feet of any structure, in parks, public spaces, or on private property without consent; violators face a $100 fine and seizure of fireworks.


Q: What safety tips were provided for the Fourth of July?
A: Safety tips included not using fireworks illegally, not firing guns in the air, practicing water safety, following pandemic guidelines, preparing for heat, and not drinking and driving.


Q: What incidents occurred due to fireworks leading up to the Fourth of July in Pittsburgh?
A: Incidents included a fire at Horace Mann School, a minor injury at McNaugher School, and a brush fire on Rose Street, all believed to be caused by fireworks.

Q: When was Pittsburgh Bureau of Police Officer Calvin Hall shot and when did he die from his injuries?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was shot in the early morning hours of July 14, 2019, and died from his injuries on July 17, 2019.


Q: What award did the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS receive in 2020, and for how many consecutive years have they received it?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS received the American Heart Association’s 2020 Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award, the highest level, for the third consecutive year.


Q: What initiative did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police and Global Links conclude in September 2020?
A: They concluded the "Need a Mask, Take a Mask" initiative, which distributed over 100,000 free masks to Pittsburgh residents.


Q: What new capability did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire achieve in October 2020?
A: They completed training to become recognized as a Type-3A Swift Water and Flood Response Team.


Q: Who returned to work in October 2020, nearly two years after the Tree of Life shooting?
A: Pittsburgh Bureau of Police Officer Timothy Matson returned to work on modified duty.


Q: What significant action did Pittsburgh Public Safety take in October 2020 due to COVID-19?
A: They suspended all in-person training programs and inter-unit rotations for police, fire, and EMS until after the election period.


Q: How did Pittsburgh Public Safety prepare for the federal election on November 3, 2020?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police moved to 12-hour shifts from November 2 until November 8, with all pass days, personal days, and holidays canceled during that time.

Q: Who were promoted to the rank of sergeant in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: William Friberger, Robert Monticelli, Kyle Nelson, and Peter Bechtold were promoted to the rank of sergeant.


Q: What did Police Chief Scott Schubert say about the new sergeants?
A: Chief Schubert expressed pride and mentioned that the new sergeants have proven themselves and now have the opportunity to mentor officers and model leadership.


Q: What is the Nuisance Bar Task Force (NBTF) responsible for?
A: The NBTF is responsible for ensuring establishments serve alcohol and conduct business legally, safely, and responsibly.


Q: What action did the Nuisance Bar Task Force take at Bridgez on October 23, 2020?
A: The NBTF executed a search warrant for illegal liquor sales and seized beer, liquor, gambling devices, and cash proceeds.


Q: What are the Pittsburgh Park Rangers responsible for in city parks?
A: Pittsburgh Park Rangers enforce city ordinances, including prohibitions on hunting, trapping, feeding, and harvesting wildlife.


Q: What preventative measures have Pittsburgh public safety bureaus implemented during the COVID-19 pandemic?
A: Measures include mandatory masks, social distancing, daily screenings, and strict quarantine/isolation procedures.


Q: What changes were made to Pittsburgh's New Year's Eve celebrations in 2020 due to the pandemic?
A: Venues were closed, large gatherings were prohibited, fireworks were canceled, and First Night became a TV-only event.

A: Police responded to an improvised explosive device on Penn Avenue and an aerial firework explosion on Dinwiddie Street.

Q: What new equipment did the Pittsburgh River Rescue Unit receive in May 2021?
A: A new paramedic and police rescue boat manufactured by Lake Assault.


Q: What features does the new river rescue boat have?
A: Two V8 Yamaha 425 outboard motors, increased fire suppression capabilities, improved lighting, a windless anchor, docking assist, and built-in sonar.

Q: What new addition did Pittsburgh Public Safety announce for its river rescue unit?
A: Pittsburgh Public Safety announced the launch of a new paramedic and police rescue boat.


Q: What are some key features of the new river rescue boat?
A: Key features of the new boat include a bow gate for accessible shoreline work, improved FLIR for night vision, a catamaran hull for stability, and built-in sonar.


Q: How many calls for service did the river rescue respond to in 2020?
A: The river rescue responded to 264 calls for service in 2020.


Q: Who manufactured the new river rescue boat?
A: The new river rescue boat was manufactured by Lake Assault in Superior, Wisconsin.


Q: What engines power the new river rescue boat?
A: The new river rescue boat is equipped with two V8 Yamaha 425 outboard motors.

A: Increased lighting, mounted units to ensure crowd movement, and motorcycle medics will be in place for safety.


Q: What is the role of the Fireworks Task Force in Pittsburgh?
A: The Fireworks Task Force patrols city neighborhoods to respond to complaints of illegal fireworks use.


Q: What is the main concern related to fireworks use according to public safety director Wendell Hissrich?
A: Fireworks pose a fire hazard and safety concern, and their use is prohibited within 150 feet of any structure.


Q: What advice does Dr. Donald Yealy give regarding heat-related ailments during the celebrations?
A: Dr. Yealy advises staying hydrated and avoiding alcohol, which can increase dehydration risk.


Q: What are the dangers of leaving children or pets in hot vehicles, according to public safety director Wendell Hissrich?
A: Temperatures inside a vehicle can rise quickly, putting children and pets at risk for heat stroke and even death.


Q: What should unvaccinated individuals do during outdoor Fourth of July activities, according to Dr. Yealy?
A: Unvaccinated individuals are encouraged to wear a mask as the virus still poses a risk.

Q: What is the main event for Pittsburgh's 2021 Independence Day celebration?
A: The main event is the city-sponsored fireworks display at Point State Park on Sunday, July 4.


Q: What are the safety measures being implemented for Pittsburgh's Independence Day celebrations?
A: Pittsburgh police will work with local law enforcement, use 15 mobile light towers, and activate mounted units to ensure safety during the event.


Q: What is the primary concern related to heat during the Independence Day celebrations according to Dr. Donald Yealy?
A: The primary concern is heat-related ailments such as heat exhaustion and heat stroke due to dehydration and the inability to dissipate heat.


Q: What are unvaccinated individuals encouraged to do during the Independence Day celebrations?
A: Unvaccinated individuals are strongly encouraged to wear a mask.


Q: What adjustments are being made to traffic patterns on Carson Street in Pittsburgh?
A: Vehicle traffic will be allowed outbound only on E. Carson Street between S.10th and S.18th streets, and side streets from S.11th to S.17th will be closed to traffic.


Q: What is the purpose of the traffic adjustments on Carson Street?
A: The adjustments aim to mitigate gridlock, allow for a dedicated emergency vehicle corridor, and create a safer experience for residents and visitors.

Q: What is a STEMI?
A: A STEMI is an ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction, the deadliest type of heart attack caused by a blockage of blood flow to the heart.


Q: How many people experience a STEMI heart attack each year?
A: More than 250,000 people experience a STEMI heart attack each year.


Q: Who expressed pride in the Pittsburgh EMS team for their quality care?
A: Ronald Romano, Chief of Pittsburgh EMS, expressed pride in the team.


Q: What event did the task force in Pittsburgh investigate?
A: The task force investigated illegal "ride-outs" involving off-road vehicles on city streets.


Q: What charges were filed against Nicholas James Putnam?
A: Nicholas James Putnam was charged with felony riot, felony conspiracy, recklessly endangering another person, and disorderly conduct.

A: Chief Scott Schubert expressed being heartbroken and considered Tunch Ilkin a friend and mentor.


Q: How many people lost their lives on September 11, 2001?
A: Close to 3,000 people lost their lives on September 11, 2001.

A: The program treats first responders for illnesses linked to their response on 9/11.

A: Mayor William Peduto administered the oath of office.

A: Chief Scott Schubert served for 29 years.

A: His main goal was to create a more equitable, safe, and inclusive city by building trust and legitimacy in the community.

A: Schubert implemented the pillars of the task force report on 21st-century policing.

A: They received a community policing commendation from the U.S. Justice Department.


Q: What is the Group Violence Intervention (GVI) program?
A: GVI is a partnership between law enforcement, social services, and the faith community to mediate and interrupt violence.

A: The creation of a Real Time Crime Center (RTCC).

A: The full adoption of body-worn cameras for all officers.

A: A High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (HIDTA) unit.

A: He became the section chief overseeing the Global Law Enforcement Support Section at the FBI.

A: To ensure well-trained officers serve as liaisons with activists and stakeholders during first amendment-protected activities.

A: By making all police policies and procedures available on the city website.

Q: What is the purpose of the Pittsburgh Police's new crime data portal?
A: The portal provides a general overview of criminal activity across the city, promoting transparency and accountability.


Q: What type of crimes are excluded from the Pittsburgh Police's crime data portal?
A: Violent crimes of a sexual nature are excluded from the data set.

Q: What is the difference between police reports and "call for service" records?
A: Police reports are not the same as "call for service" records. While reports may be filed as a result of a call for service, not all calls result in a police report.


Q: Where can residents find the police data portal for the city of Pittsburgh?
A: Residents can find the police data portal on the city of Pittsburgh website at https://pittsburghpa.gov/police/data-portal.


Q: When is the nationwide emergency alert system test scheduled?
A: The nationwide emergency alert system test is scheduled for October 4, 2023, at approximately 2:20 PM Eastern Time, with a back-up date of October 11, 2023.


Q: Who is conducting the nationwide emergency alert system test?
A: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and FEMA are conducting the nationwide emergency alert system test.


Q: What will the emergency alert system test message state?
A: The emergency alert system test message will state: 'This is a nationwide test of the emergency alert system, issued by the federal emergency management agency, covering the United States from 14:20 to 14:50 hours ET. This is only a test. No action is required by the public.'

Q: What time are Halloween block party permits valid in Pittsburgh?

Q: What are some requirements for obtaining a block party permit in Pittsburgh?
A: The applicant must live on the block being closed, permits can only be issued for streets in residentially-zoned areas, closures are limited to one block in length, and all residents of the requested block must be informed.

Q: What condition must be met for a permit to be issued for a street closure where there is a PRT route?
A: A PRT detour must be accommodated.


Q: Who is eligible to apply for block party permits?
A: Churches and other houses of worship located on the street being requested.


Q: What is the fee for a block party permit application?
A: The fee is $25.


Q: By what time and date must block party permit applications be submitted?
A: By 5:00 p.m. on Monday, October 23.


Q: Where can the block party permit application be found?
A: At https://pittsburghpa.gov/publicsafety/ofem-eventpermits.


Q: Who should questions regarding block party permits be directed to?
A: The Office of Film & Event Management at ofem@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What reporting system did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police transition to on November 14, 2023?
A: The National Incident Based Reporting System (NIBRS).


Q: What does NIBRS document that the UCR method did not?
A: Crimes against society, such as drugs, gambling, pornography, prostitution, and weapons law violations.


Q: How does NIBRS differ from UCR in terms of counting offenses?
A: NIBRS allows for the reporting of up to 10 criminal offenses within an incident, eliminating the "hierarchy" of offenses.


Q: What are the new categories for offenses under NIBRS?
A: Group A and Group B offenses.


Q: Who headed the team for building out the new records management and reporting system for the Pittsburgh Police?
A: Acting Commander of Administration, Patrick Fosnaught.


Q: When is the Highmark Light Up Night scheduled for in 2023?
A: Saturday, November 18.


Q: What will the Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS provide during the Highmark Light Up Night?
A: Extra medic units.

A: She was the first female assistant chief of police.

A: In 1994.


Q: What event is taking place on December 31, 2023, in Pittsburgh?
A: Highmark First Night 2024.


Q: How long did recruit class 133 train before their graduation from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: Thirty-two weeks.


Q: Who received the academic achievement award in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire recruit class 133?
A: Richard Fashion.


Q: What is the primary focus of the new NIBRS system compared to the UCR system?
A: Whether the crime was attempted or completed.

Q: When was the body-worn and dash camera footage of the Pittsburgh police interaction with Jim Rogers released?
A: The footage was released after October 13, 2021.


Q: What procedural improvements did the Pittsburgh police make following the death of Jim Rogers?
A: Improvements include assigning an officer to monitor prisoners during hospital transfers, summoning EMS when a taser is deployed, retraining on avoiding single officer tactics, training on "duty to intervene," and reviewing body camera footage after every use of force.


Q: Why did the City of Pittsburgh pause its spay and neuter program?
A: The program was paused due to inappropriate use, such as individuals using city addresses to bring in animals from outside city limits.


Q: What changes did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police implement to enhance officer wellness?
A: The bureau transitioned to four 10-hour shifts per week with three consecutive days off and provided one hour of wellness time each week for officers.


Q: What new division was formed within the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police to address violent crime?
A: The Violent Crime Division was formed, including homicide, narcotics, intelligence, and the violence prevention unit.


Q: What is the purpose of the Pittsburgh Police Cares Portal?
A: The portal is for police/community engagement events, safety alerts, monthly crime statistics, and zone/neighborhood-centered news.


Q: How many new officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Police Academy in March 2024?
A: Twenty-four new officers graduated.


Q: What was emphasized by Chief Larry Scirotto during the police promotion ceremony?
A: Chief Scirotto emphasized the importance of character in leadership roles.


Q: What is the role of the newly created Telephone Reporting Unit (TRU) within the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: The TRU handles reports that do not require an in-person response by officers, operating daily from 7-3 a.m.

A: Pittsburgh is preparing for the St. Patrick's Day parade and weekend celebrations.

Q: Where is the new Pittsburgh police substation located?
A: The new substation is located on Mary Street.

A: The substation operates from 7 p.m. to 5 a.m. Wednesdays through Sundays.


Q: What is the purpose of the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program?
A: The LEAD program aims to address the root causes of criminal justice involvement by providing individuals with substance use disorder and mental and behavioral health challenges with case management and social services.


Q: When is the LEAD program expected to launch in Pittsburgh?
A: The LEAD program is expected to launch in spring 2024.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarm calls in 2023 resulted in police reports?
A: 0.43% of burglar alarm calls resulted in police reports.


Q: What will happen after the fifth documented false alarm activation in a calendar year?
A: Pittsburgh police supervisors are permitted to disregard the call.


Q: What are the new priority responses for burglar alarms under the updated protocol?
A: Priority responses include hold-up alarms, panic alarms, medical alert alarms, and verified burglar alarms.


Q: What is the estimated damage cost caused by graffiti tagger Tylor O'Connell?
A: The estimated damage cost is approximately $26,450.


Q: What is required to apply for a school crossing guard position in Pittsburgh?
A: Applicants must be at least 18 years old, possess a valid Pennsylvania driver's license, pass a background check, and be city residents.

Q: What is the philosophy of the police department regarding peaceful protests?
A: The police department protects all parties involved in peaceful protests and facilitates the event without arresting protesters exercising their constitutional rights.


Q: Under what circumstances will the police make arrests during protests?
A: The police will make arrests if a protest turns violent or destructive, causing injury or property damage.


Q: Who was arrested for the non-fatal shooting in Sheraden?
A: 19-year-old Tyler Sherrell was arrested for the non-fatal shooting of a 72-year-old female in Sheraden.


Q: What charges were brought against Tyler Sherrell?
A: Tyler Sherrell was charged with criminal attempt homicide, conspiracy, aggravated assault, and firearms charges.


Q: What happened during the fatal shooting in Middle Hill?
A: An adult male was found with a gunshot wound to the face and was pronounced deceased at the scene.


Q: What is the description of the suspect in the bike theft outside Rivers Casino?
A: The suspect is a middle-aged black male with a goatee, approximately 6 feet tall, wearing a white t-shirt and blue pants.


Q: What was the outcome of the shooting incident involving Brett Thomas Beecher?
A: Brett Thomas Beecher was arrested and charged with criminal attempt homicide, aggravated assault, reckless endangerment, and firearms violations.


Q: What was the condition of the female victim grazed by a bullet in Homewood?
A: The female victim was in stable condition after being grazed in the head and foot.


Q: What details are known about the bank robbery on East Carson Street?
A: A white male approximately 6'2" with a thin build, wearing sunglasses and a brunette wig, displayed a knife and fled with cash.


Q: What happened during the business robbery in Brighton Heights?
A: A black male with long braids, wearing dark clothing and a scarf over his face, robbed a Metro PCS store at gunpoint.


Q: How was Terrell Lamar Lineburg apprehended after the shots fired call in the Hill District?
A: He was taken into custody with the assistance of a K-9 officer after running into an abandoned house.


Q: What was the condition of the male shot in Garfield?
A: The male was in guarded condition with a gunshot wound to the side of his chest.


Q: What occurred during the Carrick 3-alarm fire?
A: The fire originated in the basement, two people escaped unharmed, one firefighter was evaluated at a hospital, and a dog died inside.


Q: What happened during the carjacking in Marshall-Shadeland?
A: A female victim was threatened with a handgun and carjacked by two black males wearing dark clothing.

Q: Where did the vehicle recovery related to the carjacking take place?
A: Near the intersection of Arlington and E. Warrington Avenues.


Q: What was the date of the carjacking vehicle recovery incident?
A: Approximately 12:30 a.m. on Monday, August 29.

A: Davon Jones, 26.

A: A routine check of the flood gates was conducted.

A: A woman died in a train hopping incident.

A: 6 years old.

Q: What happened on September 11, 2017, in Stanton Heights?
A: A male was discovered deceased in a home.

A: She was arrested on charges including endangering the welfare of children and aggravated assault.


Q: Who is being sought for the armed robbery at Pizza Hut on September 12, 2017?
A: A white male with blonde hair and blue eyes, approximately 5'9" and 170 pounds.


Q: What was the cause of the fatal shooting on South Side Slopes?
A: An argument while drinking and playing cards led to the shooting.

Q: What incident occurred on September 16, 2017, involving a double shooting in Homewood South?
A: A 29-year-old male and a 28-year-old female were shot near the intersection of Frankstown Avenue and Tyson Street and were transported to UPMC Presbyterian in stable condition.


Q: What vehicle was involved in the Sheraden shooting on September 16, 2017?
A: A blue Chrysler minivan was involved and matched the description of the getaway vehicle.


Q: Who were the suspects arrested in connection with the Sheraden shooting?
A: Rico Green, Diontae Hollinger, and Tywan David were arrested and taken to Allegheny County Jail.


Q: What disguise did the suspect wear during the Huntington Bank robbery on September 15, 2017?
A: The suspect wore a long curly wig and a black trench coat.


Q: What alerted officers to a non-fatal shooting in Homewood South on September 17, 2017?
A: A ShotSpotter notification alerted officers to gunshots fired in the 800 block of Brushton Avenue.


Q: What happened in the fatal shooting on Hamilton Avenue on September 17, 2017?
A: A 21-year-old male was found unresponsive with multiple gunshot wounds and was pronounced deceased at UPMC Presbyterian.


Q: What was the outcome of the forcible arrest involving David Jones on September 19, 2017?

Q: What is the purpose of the ShotSpotter gunshot detection service test conducted by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: To verify that all systems are operating as expected and to guide any final adjustments before activating the service.


Q: How does the ShotSpotter service notify police officers and 911 dispatchers of gunfire incidents?
A: It uses acoustic sensors to detect gunfire and notifies officers and dispatchers in less than a minute.

A: Both homicides and shootings have trended downwards.

A: The staffing levels improved thanks to the mayor and city council, allowing more officers to be on the street.


Q: What was the trend in the number of homicides in Pittsburgh from 2014 to 2018?
A: The number of homicides decreased from 71 in 2014 to 55 in 2018.

A: The clearance rate improved to 71 percent in 2018.

A: The initiative aims to prevent drug addiction and overdoses by allowing safe disposal of unused or unwanted prescription drugs.


Q: How much drugs were collected nationally during the last fall's Drug Take Back event?
A: Nearly 914,236 pounds, or 457 tons, of unused or unwanted prescription drugs were collected.


Q: How many sergeants were promoted to lieutenant during the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police promotion ceremony?
A: Two sergeants were promoted to lieutenant.


Q: Who were the two sergeants promoted to lieutenant in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: William S. Hohos and Patrick L. Knepp were promoted to lieutenant.


Q: What is the role of Zane, the new member of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Zane is a comfort dog providing aid during critical incidents, peer support, and community outreach.


Q: What was the result of the investigation into gang activity in Pittsburgh's southern neighborhoods?
A: Nine arrests were made, including four people charged with the 2014 murder of Omar Hodges.


Q: What was the crime rate trend in Pittsburgh during the first quarter of the year?
A: Crime rates dropped by 7% compared to the same time last year and 12% compared to the five-year average.


Q: What significant event is scheduled to occur at Heinz Field, as mentioned in the text?
A: A Garth Brooks concert expected to be the largest event in Heinz Field history.


Q: What was the purpose of the grand jury convened in 2018 regarding the gang activity investigation?
A: The grand jury was convened to assure the protection of key witnesses from ongoing retaliatory violence.


Q: How many people are expected to participate in the Pittsburgh Marathon events?
A: More than 35,000 people will participate in the marathon events.


Q: What are the consequences for cars not moved along the Pittsburgh Marathon route?
A: Cars not moved along the route will be towed.

Q: What agencies were involved in ensuring safety at Heinz Field during the event?
A: The Pennsylvania State Police, Liquor Control Enforcement, Port Authority Police, Heinz Field Security, and county agencies were involved.


Q: What types of disorderly conduct were officers prepared to address at Heinz Field?
A: Officers were prepared to address fighting, public intoxication, underage drinking, and any other illegal behavior.


Q: What specialty units were present at Heinz Field for the event?
A: Mounted units from Pittsburgh Police and State Police, a fire boat, river rescue, K-9 units, and traffic officers on motorcycles were present.


Q: When did the parking lots at Heinz Field open for the event?
A: The parking lots opened at 2 p.m.


Q: What was the weather forecast for the event at Heinz Field?
A: The weather was forecast to be warm with temperatures near 80 degrees and possible thunderstorms in the afternoon.


Q: How many EMS personnel were working inside Heinz Field for the concert?
A: There were 32 EMS personnel working inside the stadium.

A: The decals were placed to show support for Pride Month and celebrate the LGBTQIA+ community.

A: It is mandatory for all members to go through LGBTQIA+ training.

A: Pittsburgh Pride celebrations will be held June 7-9 in areas throughout downtown and the North Side.


Q: What is the significance of the Mid-Atlantic Police Motorcycle Rodeo held in Pittsburgh?
A: The rodeo builds skills and working relationships between motorcycle officers and supports the Special Olympics of Pennsylvania.


Q: How many officers were promoted to sergeant during the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police promotion ceremony?
A: Five officers were promoted to sergeant.


Q: What changes were announced for the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police command staff?
A: Four commanders were moved to new positions within the bureau, effective July 8, 2019.


Q: What are the restrictions on fireworks in Point State Park during the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: Fireworks are not allowed in Point State Park, and city law prohibits the use of any fireworks within 150 feet of any structure.


Q: How many new officers graduated from the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police training academy?
A: Twenty-four new officers graduated.


Q: What incident did Pittsburgh police respond to on a playground on June 25, 2019?
A: Police responded to an altercation involving an adult male and a juvenile male on a playground.

Q: Who was charged with simple assault and criminal mischief?
A: Thomas D’Andrea, a city of Pittsburgh firefighter, was charged with simple assault and criminal mischief.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police post online as part of their commitment to transparency?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police posted their 2018 annual report online.


Q: What significant reductions in crime statistics were reported in the 2018 annual report?
A: The report detailed a 19 percent reduction in non-fatal shootings and a 5 percent reduction in homicides.

A: Chief Scott Schubert highlighted the community and public safety coming together during the synagogue attack.

A: Camerin Caldwell faces charges of criminal attempt homicide, aggravated assault, reckless endangerment, and firearms violations.

A: Marvin Balk, Elliott Brown, Austin Hsin, Sean McGrath, Nicholas Okwiya, and John Saliba were sworn in as the newest paramedics.


Q: What was Officer Calvin Hall's role in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was a 2-year veteran of the bureau, assigned to the Northview Heights Public Safety Center.


Q: What happened to Officer Calvin Hall on July 14, 2019?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was shot three times in the back and later passed away due to his injuries.


Q: What did the family of Officer Calvin Hall express gratitude for?
A: The family expressed gratitude to the doctors, nurses, and staff at UPMC Presbyterian, as well as the support from the police department and community.


Q: What advisory did the City of Pittsburgh issue ahead of a heat wave?
A: The City of Pittsburgh issued a heat advisory from noon on Friday until 8 p.m. Saturday evening.

Q: Who held a news conference to provide information on heat safety in Pittsburgh?
A: Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS Chief Ron Romano, Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire Chief Darryl Jones, Parks and Recreation Director Ross Chapman, and Dr. Donald Yealy, Chairman of UPMC’s Emergency Medicine Department.


Q: What did Public Safety Director Hissrich say would be aggressively prosecuted?
A: Leaving animals or children in vehicles during the heat event.


Q: What are some early warning signs of heat stress mentioned by Dr. Donald Yealy?
A: Not feeling quite right, upset stomach, or feeling a little sweaty.


Q: What did EMS Chief Ron Romano advise city residents to do during the heat event?
A: Drink plenty of fluids and stay indoors, especially those with underlying medical conditions.


Q: What did Fire Chief Jones warn against as a method to cool down?
A: Opening neighborhood fire hydrants.


Q: What alternatives did Parks and Recreation Director Ross Chapman suggest for cooling down?
A: Using the city’s 18 public pools, eight spray parks, and three cooling centers.


Q: When and where will the end of watch ceremony for Officer Calvin Hall take place?
A: On Saturday, July 20, at 8 p.m. on the 1500 block of Brighton Road.


Q: What temporary road closures will occur for Officer Hall's funeral?
A: Fifth Avenue and other roads near Soldiers & Sailors Memorial Hall and Homewood Cemetery.


Q: What initiative did the Pittsburgh Police Bureau launch in honor of Officer Calvin Hall?
A: A month-long blood drive in partnership with Vitalant.


Q: How can the public participate in the blood drive honoring Officer Calvin Hall?
A: By donating blood at any Vitalant location and mentioning his name or using the group code Z0021100.

A: James Wyatt was arrested on charges of criminal homicide and aggravated assault.

A: A two-week enforcement campaign focusing on school zone safety and traffic violations.

A: The station will close for repairs, and personnel and vehicles will be relocated to other stations.

A: Fire Station 8 will not function as a working fire house during repairs.

A: Violent crimes are more likely to occur between 4 p.m. and 10 p.m.

Q: What is the purpose of the "Scentsational" tracking program launched by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: To create a safety net for those who might get lost and have trouble finding their way home using a bloodhound tracking program.

Q: What is the ScentSational Tracking Program and where was it launched?
A: The ScentSational Tracking Program is a scent tracking initiative using bloodhounds, officially launched at Point State Park.


Q: Who is the current bloodhound and handler involved in the ScentSational Tracking Program?
A: The current bloodhound is Cappy, and his handler is Officer Kevin Merkel.


Q: What organization donated containers and equipment for the ScentSational Tracking Program?
A: Allegheny General Hospital donated the containers and equipment for the program.


Q: How can residents participate in the ScentSational Tracking Program?
A: Residents can participate by attending community outreach events, having scents collected at regular appointments, or contacting their local police zone.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of EMS received the 2019 Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.

A: The target time is less than 90 minutes, and they achieved it in about 80% of cases in 2018.

A: They are used to control bleeding and prevent infection in trauma wounds.

A: They were instructed to self-quarantine at home.

A: The officer is in self-isolation at home.

Q: Why was the 28-person recruit class temporarily suspended?
A: The class was suspended to identify who among them might have been exposed to a firearms instructor who tested positive for COVID-19.

A: The potential exposure occurred at the outdoor police firing range in Zone 5.


Q: What measures were taken for recruits who might have been exposed to COVID-19?

A: They received recognition for achieving expert level pediatric care from the Pennsylvania Emergency Health Services Council.

A: Six police officials tested positive for COVID-19.


Q: What is the purpose of the masks issued to Pittsburgh city staff?
A: The masks are issued to reduce the amount of potentially infectious droplets expelled by the wearer, thereby protecting others.


Q: What did Pittsburgh Police Chief Scott Schubert say about the death of George Floyd?
A: He stated that the actions of the involved officers were incomprehensible and that excessive force is unacceptable.


Q: What task force was created in response to the protests in Pittsburgh?
A: The Damage Assessment & Accountability Task Force (DAAT) was created to investigate crimes related to the protests.


Q: What is the role of the Damage Assessment & Accountability Task Force (DAAT)?
A: The DAAT investigates individuals involved in crimes during protests, such as attacking journalists, looting, and causing property damage.


Q: What happened to the firefighter who tested positive for COVID-19 in Pittsburgh?
A: The firefighter recovered from the virus and returned to work.


Q: What did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's 2019 Annual Report highlight?
A: It highlighted a 36% drop in homicides and ongoing efforts like group violence intervention and homeless empathy training.


Q: Who was arrested in connection with the protests in Pittsburgh?
A: Matthew Michanowicz was arrested after police found a backpack with homemade explosives.

Q: What is the DAAT?
A: DAAT is a multi-agency team comprised of local, state, and federal law enforcement partners, including the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, Allegheny County District Attorney’s Office, and others.


Q: How can the public help with the investigation of crimes related to protests?
A: The public can share videos, photographs, or information with DAAT by emailing daat@pittsburghpa.gov or calling (412) 323-7800.


Q: What was the increase in fireworks complaint calls in Pittsburgh from June 1 to June 21, 2020?
A: There was a 389 percent increase in fireworks complaint calls, with 137 calls received compared to 28 calls the previous year.


Q: What is the penalty for violating fireworks laws in Pittsburgh?
A: Violators are subject to a $100 fine and possible seizure of their fireworks.


Q: What safety measures are being emphasized for the Fourth of July in Pittsburgh?
A: Safety measures include not using fireworks illegally, not firing guns in the air, practicing water safety, following pandemic guidelines, preparing for heat, and not drinking and driving.

A: Changes to incident command are being implemented to keep citizens safe and improve police-community relations.

A: Nine officers were positive for COVID-19.

A: Venues were closed, large gatherings were prohibited, fireworks were canceled, and the event was transformed into a made-for-TV-only event.

Q: What is the Fireworks Task Force's initiative beginning June 22?
A: The task force will enforce fireworks regulations in all zones from 7 p.m. until 2 a.m. every night until July 5.


Q: What is illegal regarding fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: It is illegal to discharge fireworks within 150 feet of a structure and in any city park, ball field, or city-owned property.


Q: What will Pittsburgh Police conduct on June 23 in Homewood?
A: A blitz on abandoned vehicles.


Q: How many homicides were reported in Pittsburgh year-to-date compared to the same time in 2020?
A: There have been 31 homicides compared to 20 at the same time in 2020.


Q: What percentage of firearms recovered in Pittsburgh were purchased in Pennsylvania?
A: Approximately 75% of the firearms.


Q: What is the ATF's new initiative in Pittsburgh?
A: The ATF is creating a firearms trafficking unit and assigning two agents to work with Pittsburgh Police.


Q: What event is Pittsburgh set to host on July 4, 2021?
A: The city's Independence Day celebration with a fireworks display at Point State Park.

Q: What measures are being taken by Pittsburgh police for safety during the Fourth of July celebrations?
A: Pittsburgh police will increase lighting, ensure crowd movement for emergency access, and conduct light bag screenings at park entrances.


Q: Which locations will have increased lighting during the Fourth of July celebrations in Pittsburgh?
A: Key locations downtown will have increased lighting.


Q: What is the role of the Pennsylvania state police during the fireworks display?
A: They will monitor traffic on the Fort Pitt and Fort Duquesne bridges to ensure it keeps flowing.


Q: What medical resources will be available during the Fourth of July celebrations in Pittsburgh?
A: Motorcycle medics and traditional medic units will be stationed at various points to treat patients.


Q: What weather conditions are expected on Independence Day in Pittsburgh?
A: Temperatures in the high 70s with high humidity and a 40% chance of precipitation.


Q: What advice does Dr. Donald Yealy give regarding heat-related ailments?
A: To avoid dehydration by drinking enough fluids and avoiding alcohol, which dehydrates quickly.


Q: What safety reminder does Public Safety Director Wendell Hissrich give regarding children and vehicles?
A: He warns against leaving children in hot vehicles as temperatures can rise quickly, posing a risk of heat stroke or death.


Q: What will the fireworks task force be doing until July 5?
A: Patrolling city neighborhoods and responding to complaints of illegal fireworks use.


Q: What is the public safety warning regarding consumer-grade fireworks?
A: They pose a risk of blast injuries, heat injuries, and ocular injuries, especially when used with impaired judgment.


Q: What COVID-19 precautions does Dr. Yealy recommend for those not vaccinated?
A: Wear a mask during the celebrations as the virus still poses a risk.

A: Forgetting children in the back of hot vehicles.


Q: How quickly can temperatures inside a vehicle rise, even with a window open?
A: Temperatures can rise by 20 degrees within 10 minutes.

A: They are strongly encouraged to wear a mask.

A: They visited the school, and children explored Officer Rosato’s cruiser.

A: Joshua Kuzma.


Q: What adjustments are being made to traffic on E. Carson Street in Pittsburgh?
A: Vehicle traffic will be outbound only between S.10th and S.18th streets from 7 p.m. to 4 a.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.


Q: What type of vehicles are allowed to travel in both directions on E. Carson Street?
A: Only emergency vehicles and Port Authority buses.


Q: What is prohibited on E. Carson Street between 7 p.m. and 4 a.m. during the traffic adjustments?
A: Parking and deliveries.

A: Lillie Leonardi founded Books Bridge Hope and its "Box of Goodness" initiative.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police officers distribute the "Boxes of Goodness" to those in need.


Q: What changes were made to the South Side traffic pilot project in Pittsburgh?
A: The start time for converting East Carson Street to one-way traffic was changed from 7:00 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays.


Q: Why was the South Side traffic pilot project temporarily paused?
A: The project was paused due to a partial building collapse on East Carson Street.


Q: When did East Carson Street fully reopen after the building collapse?
A: East Carson Street fully reopened on August 19, 2021.

A: The city has placed high-resolution cameras at known dumping sites and prioritized enforcement of illegal dumping.

A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police increased patrols with assistance from various units and placed temporary light towers in busy areas.


Q: What procedural changes did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police announce following the death of Jim Rogers?
A: Changes include requiring a supervisor on scene for any use of force incident, mandatory EMS assessment for taser deployments, retraining personnel, and expediting organizational reviews of use of force.

Q: What is the OneCOP program, and who is it intended to benefit?
A: The OneCOP program is a national initiative to strengthen ties between police and communities through partnerships with diverse congregations, aiming to improve relationships and trust.

Q: What is the purpose of the OneCOP initiative in Pittsburgh?
A: The OneCOP initiative aims to address grievances and negative perceptions civilians have about law enforcement by fostering collaborations between police agencies and local groups, especially faith-based organizations, to create safer and more engaged neighborhoods.

A: Over 21 years.

Q: What unique feature does Pittsburgh's emergency medical services (EMS) system have?
A: Pittsburgh's EMS system involves physicians working side-by-side with paramedics and EMTs both in the field on emergency calls and during training and protocol development.

Q: What system has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police transitioned to for crime data collection?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police has transitioned to the National Incident Based Reporting System (NIBRS).


Q: What is a key difference between the NIBRS and the old UCR crime reporting methods?
A: NIBRS documents "crimes against society," such as drug offenses and weapons law violations, which were not included in the UCR system.

Q: Who headed the team working on the new records management and reporting system for Pittsburgh police?
A: Acting Commander of Administration Patrick Fosnaught.


Q: What is the purpose of the new records management system for Pittsburgh police?
A: To provide better data collection, upgraded functionality, improved performance, and enhanced search and investigative capabilities.

A: Saturday, November 18.

A: Allegheny County Sheriff's Office, Allegheny County Police, Pennsylvania State Police, Port Authority Police, and State Park Rangers.


Q: What special arrangements are made for safety during the Highmark Light Up Night?
A: Uniformed and plainclothes officers, temporary light towers, extra medic units, and river rescue crews.


Q: Who was Therese Rocco and what was her notable achievement?
A: Therese Rocco was Pittsburgh's first female assistant chief of police and a nationally renowned expert in missing persons.


Q: What is the significance of the Therese Rocco Media Room at Pittsburgh police headquarters?
A: It is named in honor of Therese Rocco's contributions to law enforcement.

A: Richard Fashion received the Academic Achievement Award and Hunter Reed earned the Physical Fitness Award.


Q: What improvements have Pittsburgh police made following the death of Jim Rogers?
A: Assigning officers to monitor prisoners during hospital transfers, summoning EMS after taser use, retraining on tactics, and reviewing body camera footage after use of force.


Q: Why is the City of Pittsburgh pausing the spay and neuter program?
A: Due to inappropriate use of services and the need to evaluate and adapt the program for sustainability and equity.

A: Thirteen personnel were promoted.

A: Officers were promoted to the ranks of sergeant, lieutenant, commander, and assistant chief.

A: The new schedule is four 10-hour shifts each week with three consecutive days off.


Q: What new division was formed within the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police to reduce violent crime?
A: The Violent Crime Division was formed.


Q: What changes are being made to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's night shift?
A: Centralized deployment with strategically placed units and multiple supervisors, including a night watch commander.

A: To provide a direct line to 9-1-1 between 3 a.m. and 7 a.m.

A: Designated drivers, rideshare platforms, or public transit.


Q: What program was launched by the City of Pittsburgh's Office of Community Health and Safety?
A: The Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program.

Q: What is the main goal of the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program in Pittsburgh?
A: The main goal of the LEAD program is to improve public safety and public order while reducing unnecessary justice system involvement for participants.


Q: When is the LEAD program in Pittsburgh scheduled to launch?
A: The LEAD program in Pittsburgh is scheduled to launch in spring 2024.


Q: In which police zones will the Pittsburgh LEAD program initially be implemented?
A: The Pittsburgh LEAD program will initially be implemented in police zones 1 and 2.


Q: What types of offenses is the LEAD program in Pittsburgh targeting?
A: The LEAD program targets low-level offenses such as retail theft, simple possession, possession of paraphernalia, prostitution, and disorderly conduct.


Q: What change is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police implementing regarding burglar alarm responses?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police will only prioritize verified alarms and certain high-risk locations, while unverified alarms will receive a lower priority response.


Q: How many police staff hours were spent on responding to burglar alarms in Pittsburgh in 2023?
A: 4,166 police staff hours were spent responding to burglar alarms in Pittsburgh in 2023.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarm calls in Pittsburgh in 2023 resulted in verified incidents?
A: 0.43% of burglar alarm calls in 2023 resulted in verified incidents.


Q: What will happen under the new burglar alarm response model after the fifth false alarm in a calendar year?
A: After the fifth false alarm, Pittsburgh police supervisors are permitted to disregard the call.


Q: What is the penalty for repeated false burglar alarms in Pittsburgh?
A: Permit holders will be required to pay a fee for repeated false alarms after the second false response in a calendar year.


Q: What are the qualifications required to apply for a school crossing guard position in Pittsburgh?
A: Applicants must be at least 18 years old, possess a valid Class C Pennsylvania driver’s license, pass a background check, and be city residents.

A: Tylor O’Connell was charged with 19 counts of criminal mischief for graffiti tags.

Q: What scam alert did the Pittsburgh police issue on April 19, 2018?
A: A scam alert for Duquesne Light customers about fraudulent calls demanding payment with threats of immediate power shutoff.

Q: Does Duquesne Light perform shutoffs on weekends?
A: No, Duquesne Light does not perform shutoffs on weekends.


Q: What should you do if a scammer comes to your door claiming to be from Duquesne Light?
A: Always ask to see employee identification, look for a company logo on the uniform and vehicle, and call the utility company to verify the person's identification.


Q: Where can you report if you fall prey to a scam related to Duquesne Light?
A: Report it to your local police zone, the Federal Trade Commission at ftc.gov, and the FBI’s Internet Crime Complaint Center at www.ic3.gov.

A: It supports the dog-on-leash initiative throughout city parks.

Q: What is the purpose of the National Prescription Drug Take Back Day?
A: To provide a safe, convenient, and responsible means of disposing prescription drugs while educating the public about medication-abuse potential.

A: 610 pounds.


Q: Where can prescription drugs be dropped off year-round in Pittsburgh?
A: At police headquarters (1203 Western Ave, 15233) and Zone 6 (312 South Main St, 15220).

A: Pet owners are not permitted to leave dogs outside for more than 30 minutes when the temperature is above 90 degrees.

A: The city of Pittsburgh averaged 19 ethnic intimidation incidents per year over a ten-year period.

A: Racial animus, primarily targeting African Americans, is the most common contributor to ethnic intimidation charges.

Q: Who was Officer Calvin Hall and when did he pass away?
A: Officer Calvin Hall was a Pittsburgh police officer who passed away on July 17, 2019.


Q: What is the purpose of the Damage Assessment & Accountability Taskforce (DAAT)?
A: To investigate individuals causing destruction during protests, including attacks on journalists, looting, and property damage.


Q: What evidence is DAAT analyzing for their investigations?
A: Digital evidence from police body-worn cameras, city cameras, and private CCTV footage.


Q: How can the public contribute to the DAAT investigations?
A: By sharing videos, photographs, or information via email to daat@pittsburghpa.gov, with contributors remaining anonymous.


Q: Who was arrested in connection to the DAAT investigations and why?
A: Matthew Michanowicz was arrested for placing a backpack with homemade explosives.


Q: What is the stance of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police on peaceful protests?
A: They believe all people have a fundamental right to protest peacefully, as guaranteed by the First Amendment.


Q: What is the composition of the DAAT team?
A: It includes local, state, and federal law enforcement partners such as the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, FBI Pittsburgh, and others.


Q: What recent increase in complaints did Pittsburgh police experience regarding fireworks?
A: A 389 percent increase in fireworks complaint calls from June 1 to June 21 compared to the previous year.


Q: What are the legal restrictions on fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be used within 150 feet of any structure, in parks, or on private property without consent.


Q: What safety reminder did Fire Prevention Officer Lisa Epps-Cuda provide about sparklers?
A: Sparklers burn at 1,200 degrees and are not safe, especially for children.


Q: What changes are expected for the Fourth of July celebrations in Pittsburgh due to the pandemic?
A: No city-sponsored fireworks, no mass gatherings, and enforcement of physical distancing and mask-wearing.


Q: What is the potential consequence for violating Pittsburgh's fireworks laws?
A: A $100 fine and possible seizure of fireworks.

Q: What is the Pittsburgh police's response to gunfire in public areas?
A: Pittsburgh police will respond to ShotSpotter activations and arrest anyone caught firing a gun in public.


Q: How are Pittsburgh authorities addressing water safety during pool closures?
A: River Rescue, the fire boat, and the Coast Guard will enforce boating laws and teach water safety on the city's three rivers.


Q: What measures are recommended to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in Allegheny County?
A: Maintain physical distancing, wear a mask, wash hands for at least 20 seconds, avoid large crowds, and stay home if unwell.


Q: What are the guidelines for fireworks use in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks are prohibited within 150 feet of any structure, in parks, public spaces, and on private property without landowner consent.


Q: What is the penalty for violating fireworks laws in Pittsburgh?
A: Violators are subject to a $100 fine and possible seizure of their fireworks.


Q: What is the illegal status of sky lanterns in Pittsburgh?
A: The release of sky lanterns is illegal in Pittsburgh.

A: The American Heart Association’s 2020 Mission: Lifeline EMS Gold Plus Performance Achievement Award.

A: It completed training to become recognized as a Type-3A Swift Water and Flood Response Team.

A: The Civil Affairs Unit ensured well-trained, experienced, and compassionate police officers served as liaisons with activists and other stakeholders during First Amendment-protected activities.


Q: What did Schubert do to increase transparency regarding Pittsburgh police policies?
A: Schubert made all Pittsburgh police policies and procedures readily available on the City of Pittsburgh website.

A: Sergeant Carla Kearns graduated as a member of the 284th session, a program attended by fewer than one percent of officers, known for its advanced training.


Q: When and where was the Pittsburgh Bureau of Emergency Medical Services ceremony held?
A: The ceremony was held on December 7, 2022, in the Pittsburgh Police Special Deployment Division building.


Q: What is the main focus of the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust's "First Night" celebrations?
A: The event is a longstanding tradition to kick off the New Year in downtown Pittsburgh, drawing tens of thousands of people.


Q: What changes occurred regarding the Office of Special Events in Pittsburgh in 2023?
A: The Office of Special Events was reinstated to the Department of Parks & Recreation (Citiparks) after being part of the Public Safety Administration.

A: General inquiries can be sent to ofem@pittsburghpa.gov.

A: Media inquiries should be sent to pio@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What was the response of Tennessee law enforcement regarding the incident involving Tyre Nichols?
A: Tennessee law enforcement swiftly investigated and charged the officers involved.


Q: Does the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police have a unit similar to the Memphis "Scorpion Unit"?
A: No, the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police does not have a unit similar to the "Scorpion Unit."


Q: What is the purpose of the Axon My90 survey program in Pittsburgh?
A: The Axon My90 survey program aims to bridge the gap between officers and the neighborhoods they serve through community feedback.

A: Residents receive a text link for a survey following designated calls for service or police interaction.

A: Mathew Davis was sworn in as the new assistant chief.

A: The weather is forecast to be moderately chilly with temperatures in the low 40s, dropping into the 30s, with a chance of rain or snow showers.


Q: Who were the two paramedics sworn in during the Pittsburgh Bureau of Emergency Medical Services ceremony?
A: Alex Cappellini and Adam Croci were sworn in as paramedics.


Q: What is the focus of Pittsburgh's new community paramedicine program?
A: The program focuses on addressing the needs of the most vulnerable residents and reducing reliance on the 9-1-1 system.


Q: What collaboration is involved in Pittsburgh's community paramedicine program?
A: The program involves collaboration between EMS personnel and OCH&S social workers.


Q: What type of health conditions does the community paramedicine program aim to address?
A: The program aims to address chronic health conditions such as obstructive lung diseases, diabetes, seizure disorders, and heart disease.

A: Sergeant Andrew Baker was promoted to the rank of lieutenant.

A: TSAP is part of a public health-informed care program collaboration with the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police.

A: More than 30,000 people participated in the Pittsburgh Marathon.

A: Pittsburgh EMS did not have any employees admitted to the hospital or pass away during the pandemic.

A: March 28, 2023, was declared Chief Ronald Romano Day in Pittsburgh.

A: The Pittsburgh Marathon, three Pittsburgh Pirates games, Cinco de Mayo celebrations, and various concerts and shows took place.


Q: What safety measures are in place for the Juneteenth celebrations in Pittsburgh?
A: Bag checks will be conducted at Point State Park's entry points, and certain items are prohibited.

A: The parade route includes Crawford Street, Centre Avenue, Sixth Avenue, Fifth Avenue, and Liberty Avenue.

A: The fireworks will take place on June 19, 2023, at 9:35 p.m. in Point State Park.

Q: When does entry to VIP gates 1 & 2 begin on concert days at Acrisure Stadium?
A: Entry to VIP gates 1 & 2 begins at 3:30 p.m.


Q: What time do all gates open at Acrisure Stadium on concert days?
A: All gates open at 4:30 p.m.


Q: What is the start time for music at Acrisure Stadium on concert days?
A: The music starts at 6:30 p.m.


Q: What type of ticket is accepted at Acrisure Stadium?
A: Only mobile tickets are accepted.


Q: How is payment handled at Acrisure Stadium?
A: Acrisure Stadium is a cashless venue; only debit, credit, and digital wallet payments are accepted.


Q: What transportation options are encouraged for concert attendees at Acrisure Stadium?
A: Public transit, ride share platforms, or alternate means like the Gateway Clipper are encouraged.


Q: What is prohibited in terms of parking on concert days at the North Shore?
A: There is no street parking available on the North Shore on concert days.


Q: What is the policy regarding bags at Acrisure Stadium?
A: Acrisure's clear bag policy is in effect.


Q: What should non-ticket holders do regarding visiting Acrisure Stadium on concert days?
A: Non-ticket holders are strongly discouraged from coming down to the stadium and the North Shore.


Q: What safety measures are in place for Juneteenth events and concerts in Pittsburgh?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police and other agencies will have a visible presence, and there will be safety perimeters and traffic restrictions.


Q: What are the rules regarding fireworks usage in Pittsburgh?
A: Fireworks cannot be discharged on public or private property without permission, within 150 feet of a building or vehicle, in parks, or while under the influence.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's response to fireworks misuse?
A: The Fireworks Task Force can issue warnings, citations, arrests, and confiscate fireworks.


Q: What are the scheduled times for fireworks during Pittsburgh's Independence Day celebration?
A: Fireworks are scheduled from 9:35 - 10:00 p.m. on July 4th.


Q: What are the parking restrictions during Pittsburgh's Independence Day celebration?
A: Parking restrictions will be in place on Liberty Avenue, Boulevard of the Allies, and Commonwealth Place.


Q: Who was Earl Buford Jr. and what was his role in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Earl Buford Jr. was the police chief from 1992 to 1995 and the second minority to hold the position.

Q: What event is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire coordinating with the Pennsylvania Helicopter Aquatic Rescue Team (PA-HART)?
A: A planned exercise on August 22 simulating a real-world rescue using approximately four Blackhawk helicopters.


Q: What was the outcome of the standoff in Pittsburgh's Garfield neighborhood on August 23, 2023?
A: The subject was pronounced deceased at the scene by Pittsburgh EMS after nearly a six-and-a-half-hour standoff.


Q: Who will investigate the incident in the Garfield neighborhood involving shots fired during an eviction notice?
A: The Pennsylvania State Police will be the investigative agency for this incident.


Q: What was the cause of Lieutenant Randolph “Randy” Meyer II’s death?
A: He passed away after a battle with appendiceal cancer.


Q: What is the purpose of the new publicly-available dashboard announced by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: To provide a general overview of criminal activity across the city and enhance transparency.


Q: When will the nationwide test of the emergency alert system and wireless emergency alerts take place?
A: At approximately 2:20 p.m. Eastern Time on October 4, with a backup date of October 11.


Q: What is the purpose of the emergency alert system test conducted by the FCC and FEMA?
A: To warn the public about emergencies, particularly on a national scale, and ensure system effectiveness.


Q: What major events are scheduled in Pittsburgh over Labor Day weekend?
A: The Soulful Taste of the Burgh festival, Labor Day parade, Acrisure Stadium Kickoff and Rib Festival, University of Pittsburgh football game, and the Steelers 5K footrace.

A: To replace the signs on the top of the Federated Tower building.


Q: What type of crimes are excluded from the data set on the Pittsburgh police data portal?
A: Violent crimes of a sexual nature.

Q: What event did the Pittsburgh Department of Public Safety celebrate regarding Dr. Ronald Roth?
A: The Pittsburgh Department of Public Safety celebrated Dr. Ronald Roth's long career at a proclamation ceremony.


Q: How long did Dr. Ronald Roth serve as the medical director for the Pittsburgh Department of Public Safety?
A: Dr. Ronald Roth served as the medical director for over 21 years.


Q: Where did Dr. Ronald Roth complete his EMT training?
A: Dr. Ronald Roth completed his EMT training at Penn State University in 1977.


Q: What degree did Dr. Ronald Roth earn from the University of Pittsburgh in 1982?
A: Dr. Ronald Roth earned his medical degree from the University of Pittsburgh in 1982.


Q: What role did Dr. Ronald Roth have during his residency?
A: During his residency, Dr. Ronald Roth staffed a 24/7 physician emergency response vehicle and served as a flight physician on a medical helicopter.


Q: How long has Dr. Ronald Roth worked at the UPMC Presbyterian Emergency Department?
A: Dr. Ronald Roth has worked at the UPMC Presbyterian Emergency Department for over 30 years.


Q: What was Dr. Ronald Roth's role during the COVID-19 pandemic?
A: Dr. Ronald Roth guided the city of Pittsburgh through the COVID-19 pandemic by staying abreast of national guidelines and best practices.


Q: Who is Dr. Ronald Roth's successor as the medical director for the city of Pittsburgh?
A: Dr. Lenny Weiss is Dr. Ronald Roth's successor as the medical director.


Q: What is unique about Pittsburgh's EMS system?
A: Pittsburgh's EMS system is unique because physicians work side-by-side with paramedics and EMTs both in the field and during training and protocol development.


Q: What new positions were created during the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's promotions ceremony?
A: Eight firefighters were promoted to lieutenant, five lieutenants to captain, and one captain to battalion chief.


Q: Who was promoted to the rank of battalion chief in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire?
A: Damian Szuch was promoted to the rank of battalion chief.


Q: How many commanders were promoted in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police swearing-in ceremony?
A: Five lieutenants were promoted to the rank of commander.


Q: Who were promoted to the rank of sergeant in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Joshua Haupt, Emily Myers, and Erin Palchak were promoted to the rank of sergeant.


Q: What significant first was achieved during the Pittsburgh EMS promotions ceremony?
A: Jennifer McDermott-Grubb became the first female division chief in the history of Pittsburgh EMS.


Q: What are the valid hours for Halloween block party permits in Pittsburgh?
A: Halloween block party permits are valid from 5:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.


Q: What is the fee for a Halloween block party permit in Pittsburgh?
A: The fee for a Halloween block party permit is $25.


Q: What reporting system did the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police switch to on November 14, 2023?
A: The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police switched to the National Incident Based Reporting System (NIBRS).


Q: What is a key difference between NIBRS and the previous UCR system?
A: NIBRS collects data on "crimes against society" and allows data collection on up to 10 criminal offenses per incident, unlike the UCR system.

Q: What is the most serious offense reported under the UCR system when multiple crimes occur at the same scene?
A: Homicide, if it occurs, is the most serious offense reported under the UCR system.


Q: How does the NIBRS system differ from the UCR system in terms of crime reporting?
A: NIBRS includes every offense in one report, provided they are separate and distinct crimes.


Q: What are the two groups of offenses under the NIBRS system?
A: Group A and Group B offenses.


Q: Who is leading the Pittsburgh Police's transition to the new records management and reporting system?
A: Acting Commander of Administration, Patrick Fosnaught.


Q: What is the purpose of the Highmark Light Up Night in Pittsburgh?
A: It marks the start of the holiday season in Pittsburgh.


Q: What precautionary measures will Pittsburgh public safety take for the Highmark Light Up Night?
A: Uniformed and plainclothes officers, temporary light towers, extra medic units, and river rescue crews will be in place.


Q: Who was Therese Rocco, and what was her significance in Pittsburgh's law enforcement history?
A: Therese Rocco was the first woman to become assistant chief of police in Pittsburgh and the country, known for her expertise in missing persons cases.


Q: What was the main focus of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's recent policy improvements following the Jim Rogers incident?
A: Ensuring individuals in police custody are treated with care and respect, including monitoring prisoners and summoning EMS after taser use.


Q: Why has the Pittsburgh Bureau of Animal Care and Control paused the spay and neuter program?
A: Due to misuse of the program by individuals bringing animals from outside city limits using city addresses.

Q: What is the primary goal of the Bureau of Animal Care and Control's program?
A: The primary goal is to assist resident pet owners with the cost of altering their animals and control the community cat population.


Q: What change is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police implementing starting February 26, 2024?
A: They are transitioning to four 10-hour shifts each week with three consecutive days off.


Q: What is the purpose of the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police's new work schedule?
A: To enhance officer wellness and contribute to recruiting and retaining new officers.


Q: Who was promoted to the position of assistant chief in the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: Christopher Ragland, Martin Devine, and Richard Ford.


Q: What new division is being formed by the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police?
A: The Violent Crime Division, which includes homicide, narcotics, intelligence, and the violence prevention unit.


Q: What event is expected to attract up to 200,000 spectators in Pittsburgh?
A: The annual St. Patrick's Day parade.


Q: What new facility will the Pittsburgh police have on Mary Street?
A: A substation open from 7 p.m. to 5 a.m. Wednesdays through Sundays.


Q: What is the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire's role for newly promoted officers?
A: To facilitate connection between firefighters and the community they serve.


Q: What program did the Department of Public Safety’s Office of Community Health and Safety and Mayor Ed Gainey launch?
A: The Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) program.


Q: What will the Pittsburgh Police Cares Portal provide?
A: A one-stop online resource for police/community engagement events, safety alerts, monthly crime statistics, and zone/neighborhood-centered news.

Q: What is the primary goal of the Pittsburgh diversion program?
A: The primary goal is to improve public safety and order while reducing unnecessary justice system involvement for individuals with substance use disorder and mental and behavioral health challenges.


Q: When is the Pittsburgh diversion program expected to launch?
A: The program is expected to launch in spring 2024.


Q: Which police zones will the Pittsburgh diversion program initially focus on?
A: The program will initially focus on police zones 1 and 2.


Q: What types of offenses will the Pittsburgh diversion program address?
A: The program will address low-level offenses such as retail theft, simple possession, prostitution, public intoxication, and disorderly conduct.


Q: What organizations are involved in supporting the Pittsburgh diversion program?
A: Organizations involved include the Allegheny County Health Department, Department of Human Services, District Attorney’s Office, Public Defender’s Office, and the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police.


Q: How many calls for service for burglar alarms were there in Pittsburgh in 2023?
A: There were 9,097 calls for service for burglar alarms.


Q: What percentage of burglar alarm calls in Pittsburgh resulted in police reports in 2023?
A: 0.43% of the burglar alarm calls resulted in police reports.


Q: What new procedure will Pittsburgh police follow for unverified burglar alarms starting April 15, 2024?
A: Unverified burglar alarms will be dispatched with the same level of response as other non-priority calls and placed in a queue.


Q: What will happen after the fifth documented false alarm activation in a calendar year in Pittsburgh?
A: Pittsburgh police supervisors are permitted to disregard the call.


Q: How many police staff hours were spent on burglar alarm responses in Pittsburgh in 2023?
A: 4,166 police staff hours were spent on burglar alarm responses.

Q: When will the city of Pittsburgh resume construction activity?
A: Construction activity in Pittsburgh will resume on Friday.


Q: What did the city of Pittsburgh announce regarding social gatherings?
A: The city of Pittsburgh banned gatherings of 50 or more people.


Q: What assistance program did Welcoming Pittsburgh secure funding for?
A: Welcoming Pittsburgh secured a $500,000 grant for a COVID-19 cash assistance program to serve vulnerable immigrant communities.


Q: What operational level did Pittsburgh move to in response to COVID-19?
A: Pittsburgh moved to Level 2 emergency operations in response to COVID-19.


Q: When will meals be distributed to registered seniors in Pittsburgh?
A: Meals will be distributed to registered seniors starting Friday, March 20.


Q: What did the city of Pittsburgh amend in response to COVID-19?
A: The city amended the schoolchildren meal distribution schedule and extended the income tax payment deadline.


Q: What partnership did the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) form to provide financial assistance?
A: The URA partnered with the city and Urban League of Greater Pittsburgh to provide short-term rent/mortgage/utility financial assistance to city residents.


Q: What resources are available for those affected by homelessness in Pittsburgh?
A: The BigBurgh mobile app and Allegheny County Department of Human Services provide resources for those affected by homelessness.


Q: What hotline can be called for COVID-19 related community resources in Allegheny County?
A: The Allegheny County and United Way of Southwest PA's COVID-19 hotline can be called at 1-888-856-2774 or 211.


Q: What organization provides a virtual family assistance center for those who lost loved ones to COVID-19?
A: The Red Cross provides a virtual family assistance center for those who lost loved ones to COVID-19.

Q: What organization is tracking and reporting COVID-19 tests and confirmed cases daily in Pittsburgh?
A: The Allegheny County Health Department.

A: The PA Department of Health hotline at 1-877-PA-HEALTH (724-3258).

A: The BigBurgh mobile app helps neighbors without homes.

A: It helps households struggling to pay for internet service during the pandemic.

Q: What services does the Bureau of Animal Care & Control provide?
A: The Bureau provides care, control, and resolution for situations involving domestic animals and wildlife, enforces city and state codes, issues citations, assists in pet/owner recovery, resolves neighbor disputes, and more.


Q: What is the responsibility of an animal owner in Pittsburgh?
A: An owner is responsible for the care, behavior, and welfare of an animal they possess, including proper feeding, shelter, and adherence to laws protecting animals and the community.


Q: How many dogs and cats are picked up yearly by Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh?
A: Over 1,300 dogs and cats are picked up yearly.


Q: What are the office hours for Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh?
A: Monday through Friday from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m., with operations continuing until 11 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., and holidays from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m.


Q: What is required for every dog living in Pittsburgh?
A: A license is required for every dog aged three months and older.


Q: What program does Pittsburgh offer for community cats?
A: Pittsburgh offers a spay & neuter program for community cats, accepting applications for up to five cats per household.


Q: What should residents do if they encounter a stray animal in their neighborhood?
A: Residents should contact Animal Control.


Q: What is the purpose of the rodent baiting program in Pittsburgh?
A: The program allows residents to utilize rodent baiting services for free up to two times per year.


Q: What wildlife can residents of Pittsburgh expect to share common areas with?
A: Skunks, raccoons, groundhogs, foxes, coyotes, deer, turkeys, etc.


Q: What is the after-hours contact number for Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh?
A: The after-hours number is 412-255-2935.

Q: What is the primary role of the Bureau of Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh?
A: The Bureau of Animal Care & Control provides care, control, and resolution to situations dealing with domestic animals and wildlife.


Q: What services does the Bureau of Animal Care & Control offer to the city of Pittsburgh?
A: The bureau captures stray animals, assists in pet/owner recovery, resolves neighbor disputes over animals, helps the elderly and physically-challenged with animal concerns, and removes nuisance wildlife.


Q: How many dogs and cats are picked up yearly by Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh?
A: Over 1,300 dogs and cats are picked up yearly.


Q: What is required for every dog over three months old living in Pittsburgh?
A: A dog license is required for every dog over three months old.


Q: What is the purpose of dog licenses and registration tags in Pittsburgh?
A: Dog licenses and registration tags help to assist in finding lost pets.


Q: What program does Pittsburgh offer for community cats?
A: Pittsburgh offers a spay & neuter program for community cats, accepting applications for up to five cats per household as a temporary extension of the 2023 contract.


Q: What is the definition of "nuisance wildlife" according to the Bureau of Animal Care & Control?
A: Nuisance wildlife is defined as wildlife that causes, or is about to cause, property damage or presents a threat to health or safety by means of disease transmission or direct attacks.


Q: What are the office hours for the Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh?
A: Office hours are Monday through Friday, 7 a.m. to 3 p.m., with operations continuing from 3 p.m. to 11 p.m. on weekdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. on weekends, and 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. on holidays.


Q: How can residents of Pittsburgh contact Animal Care & Control for emergencies after hours?
A: Residents can call the after-hours number at 412-255-2935 for emergencies.


Q: What does the Bureau of Animal Care & Control do in collaboration with the Pennsylvania Game Commission?
A: The bureau assists in tracking the rabies virus.


Q: What is the responsibility of a pet "owner" in Pittsburgh?
A: An owner is responsible for the care, behavior, and welfare of the animal, whether they own it or not, if it is on their property.

Q: What is the role of the Bureau of Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh?
A: The Bureau of Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh provides care, control, and resolution to situations involving domestic animals and wildlife, enforces city and state animal codes, issues citations, captures stray animals, assists in pet/owner recovery, resolves neighbor disputes over animals, and assists in the removal of nuisance wildlife.


Q: How does the Bureau of Animal Care & Control define nuisance wildlife?
A: Nuisance wildlife is defined as wildlife that causes, or is about to cause, property damage or that presents a threat to the health or safety of the community by means of disease transmission or direct attacks.


Q: How many dogs and cats are picked up yearly by Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh?
A: Over 1,300 dogs and cats are picked up yearly by Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh.


Q: What are the office hours for the Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh?
A: The office hours for Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh are Monday through Friday, 7 a.m. to 3 p.m., with operations continuing from 3 p.m. to 11 p.m. Monday through Friday. On Saturdays and Sundays, operations are from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., and on holidays, from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m.


Q: What is required for dog ownership in Pittsburgh?
A: A license is required for every dog, age three-months and older, living in the city of Pittsburgh.


Q: What program does Pittsburgh offer for community cats?
A: Pittsburgh offers a spay & neuter program for community cats, accepting applications for up to five cats per household as a temporary extension of the 2023 contract.


Q: How can residents of Pittsburgh deal with stray animals?
A: Residents of Pittsburgh should contact Animal Control if there is a stray animal in their neighborhood.


Q: What is the contact number for after-hours animal emergencies in Pittsburgh?
A: The contact number for after-hours animal emergencies in Pittsburgh is 412-255-2935.


Q: What is required for keeping bees or farm animals in Pittsburgh?
A: Information regarding regulations and permits is required for keeping bees or farm animals in Pittsburgh.


Q: What does the term "owner" include according to the Bureau of Animal Care & Control?
A: "Owner" includes every person who keeps or shelters an animal and every person who allows an animal to be on their property.

Q: What are the office hours for the Animal Care & Control in Pittsburgh from Monday to Friday?
A: The office hours are from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m., with operations continuing from 3 p.m. to 11 p.m.


Q: When are the Animal Care & Control operations available on weekends and holidays?
A: Saturdays and Sundays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., and on holidays from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m.
