Q: What is the date and time for the City Council public hearing on the institutional master plan for Central Catholic High School?
A: February 5, 2025, at 1:30 pm


Q: What is the purpose of the City Council public hearing on February 5, 2025?
A: To discuss an institutional master plan for Central Catholic High School and a zoning map amendment for the North Oakland neighborhood.


Q: Where can you find contact information for registered community organizations in the city?
A: On the City Planning's "Who's My RCO" webpage.

Q: When will the City Council hold a public hearing on an institutional master plan for Central Catholic High School?
A: February 5, 2025, at 1:30 pm.


Q: What is the purpose of the City Council public hearing scheduled for February 5, 2025?
A: To discuss an institutional master plan for Central Catholic High School and a zoning map amendment for the North Oakland neighborhood.


Q: What is the council bill number associated with the institutional master plan for Central Catholic High School?
A: Council Bill 2024-1303.


Q: What is the council resolution number for the public hearing on February 5, 2025?
A: Council Resolution 2024-1343.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: To promote quality of life in Pittsburgh by providing voluntary design assistance and reviewing selected higher profile projects.


Q: How often does the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP) meet?
A: Every other Tuesday, alternating with the Planning Commission.


Q: Who are some of the members of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: Members include Eric Booth, Bruce Chan, Ryan Indovina, Greg Laforest, Cassandra Osterman, Peter Quintanilla, Bob Reppe, and Claudia Saladin.


Q: What types of projects might be reviewed by the CDAP?
A: Projects ranging from building additions to multi-parcel developments.


Q: What is the purpose of the City Council's public hearing on a zoning map amendment?
A: To discuss changes to the zoning map for the North Oakland neighborhood.


Q: Where can archived meeting material for the Historic Review Commission and other commissions be found?
A: On City Planning's YouTube channel.


Q: What are some core considerations of the CDAP when reviewing development proposals?
A: Successful design, public space enhancement, context sensitivity, and sustainable urbanism.

Q: What is the purpose of the Historic Review Commission (HRC)?
A: The HRC provides guidance for exterior work on historic buildings and controls new construction or demolition within historic districts and landmarks.


Q: When does the Historic Review Commission meet?
A: The HRC meets on the first Wednesday of each month at 1:00 pm.


Q: Who appoints the members of the Historic Review Commission?
A: The members are appointed by the mayor.


Q: What is the requirement for naming or renaming a public property for a person according to the Naming Commission?
A: The person must have been deceased for at least three years.


Q: How often does the Planning Commission meet?
A: The Planning Commission meets every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: What types of projects does the Planning Commission review?
A: The Planning Commission reviews major development proposals, zoning changes, master plans, and historic nominations, among others.


Q: Who is the chairwoman of the Planning Commission?
A: Lashawn Burton-Falk is the chairwoman.


Q: What does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD) do?
A: The PACD reviews and approves the aesthetics of public art and civic structures in public spaces.


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission meet?
A: The PACD meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess.


Q: What is the role of the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA)?
A: The ZBA reviews land use proposals according to the zoning code in public evidentiary hearings.


Q: How long does the ZBA have to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision following a hearing.


Q: What must applicants provide at a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must provide a site plan, evidence justifying the request, and documentation of authorization if not the property owner.


Q: How can someone contact the Historic Review Commission via email?
A: By emailing historicreview@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the role of the Naming Commission?
A: The Naming Commission creates guidelines for naming or renaming public properties and facilities.


Q: How can someone apply to the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: Applications are submitted on the EngagePGH page, following the application guidelines.

Q: What is the expiration period for a ZBA decision?
A: A ZBA decision expires one year after it is issued.


Q: How can an applicant request an extension for a ZBA decision?
A: An applicant can request a one-year extension by contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov with a brief explanation of why an extension is needed.


Q: Who can appeal a ZBA decision and where should the appeal be filed?
A: Any affected party can appeal a ZBA decision to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 calendar days of the decision's issue date.


Q: Where can transcripts of ZBA hearings be requested?
A: Transcripts can be ordered from Network Deposition Services by calling 412-281-7908.


Q: Are ZBA meetings open to the public?
A: Yes, ZBA meetings are open to the public and are held virtually via Zoom or in-person.


Q: How can one receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: To receive ZBA agendas via email, contact zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: CDAP promotes quality of life in Pittsburgh by providing design guidance on selected, higher profile projects impacting the public realm.


Q: How often does the Historic Review Commission meet?
A: The Historic Review Commission meets on the first Wednesday of each month.


Q: What is a requirement for naming or renaming a public property after a person?
A: The person must have been deceased for at least three years.


Q: What types of projects does the Planning Commission review?
A: The Planning Commission reviews new construction, renovations, zoning ordinance changes, major developments, and historic nominations, among others.


Q: How can past meeting materials for the Planning Commission be accessed?
A: Past meeting materials can be accessed on City Planning's YouTube channel or the public notices and meeting calendar.


Q: What is the composition of the Planning Commission?
A: The Planning Commission is a nine-member panel appointed by the mayor for six-year, staggered terms.

Q: What is the purpose of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD) in Pittsburgh?
A: The PACD empowers the development of art and culture in public spaces and promotes the design of public spaces and civic structures that positively impact the city's public realm.


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission meet?
A: The PACD meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess, starting at 2:00 pm.


Q: How can someone receive commissions and board agendas via email for the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: By emailing pacd@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the role of the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA) in Pittsburgh?
A: The ZBA reviews land use proposals in accordance with the zoning code and conducts public evidentiary hearings.


Q: How often does the Zoning Board of Adjustment meet?
A: The ZBA meets on the first three Thursdays of each month, starting at 9:00 am.


Q: What is the minimum notice period required before a ZBA hearing?
A: A minimum 21-day posted notice period is required before a ZBA hearing.


Q: How long does the ZBA have to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision after a hearing.


Q: How can someone appeal a ZBA decision?
A: Affected parties can appeal a ZBA decision to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 calendar days of the decision's issue date.


Q: What is the process for obtaining a ZBA hearing transcript?
A: A transcript can be ordered by calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908, and a fee will be charged.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP) in Pittsburgh?
A: The CDAP promotes quality of life by providing design guidance on higher profile projects impacting the public realm, advising the Department of City Planning.


Q: How often does the Contextual Design Advisory Panel meet?
A: CDAP meets every other Tuesday, alternating with the Planning Commission.


Q: What is the over-the-counter (OTC) review process?
A: OTC review is conducted by staff for low-impact projects that meet certain eligibility criteria and have minimal impact on the public realm.

Q: What is the initial phase of the design review process in city planning?
A: The initial phase is the staff design review, where city planning staff develop urban design targets tailored to the development proposal.


Q: What is the purpose of the CDAP review in the design process?
A: The CDAP review is voluntary but highly recommended to provide additional feedback and recommendations for certain projects.


Q: What are some criteria considered for CDAP review?
A: Criteria include the size of the project, complexity of the design context, and impact on the public realm.


Q: What type of projects does the CDAP generally review?
A: CDAP reviews project development plans, final land development plans, and projects undergoing site plan review.


Q: What is the format of a typical CDAP meeting?
A: The format includes a project introduction by city planning staff (5 minutes), project presentation by the representative (10-15 minutes), and a general panel discussion (30-40 minutes).


Q: How can one contact the CDAP?
A: By emailing pacd@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: When does the Historic Review Commission (HRC) meet?
A: The HRC meets on the first Wednesday of each month at 1:00 pm.


Q: Who are the members of the Historic Review Commission?
A: Members include an architect, a preservationist, a realtor, a building inspector, and a planner.


Q: How long must a person be deceased before a public property can be named after them, according to the Naming Commission?
A: A person must be deceased for at least three years.


Q: What is the role of the Planning Commission?
A: The Planning Commission guides land use and land development and makes recommendations concerning the zoning ordinance and zoning maps.


Q: When does the Planning Commission meet?
A: The Planning Commission meets every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: What is the responsibility of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD)?
A: The PACD empowers the development of art and culture in public spaces and promotes the design of public spaces and civic structures.


Q: What type of projects are eligible for Over-the-Counter (OTC) review?
A: Projects that will have a minimal impact on the public realm, such as replacements and negligible changes.


Q: How often does the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA) meet?
A: The ZBA meets on the first three Thursdays of each month.


Q: What is the decision timeframe for the ZBA after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision following a hearing.

Q: What is required for a ZDR application that needs a ZBA hearing?
A: The applicant will be contacted to schedule a hearing date, and a $400 ZBA fee is assessed in addition to base zoning review fees.


Q: How can ZDR application fees be paid?
A: Fees can be paid via credit card or e-check through the OneStopPGH portal.


Q: How are ZBA agendas made available to the public?
A: ZBA agendas are posted online on the city planning's public meetings calendar and sent via email.


Q: How are neighbors notified about ZBA hearings?
A: The Department of City Planning mails notice letters to abutting property owners and recommends applicants contact neighbors and local community organizations.


Q: What materials must applicants provide at a ZBA hearing?
A: A site plan, evidence justifying the request, and documentation of authorization if the applicant is not the property owner.


Q: When will the ZBA issue a decision after a hearing?
A: Within 45 days after the record for a hearing is closed.


Q: What happens after a ZBA decision is issued?
A: The Department of City Planning reviews the application for zoning code compliance and issues a Record of Zoning Approval (ROZA) if compliant.


Q: How long is a ZBA decision valid?
A: One year after issuance, during which substantial construction or occupancy should begin.


Q: How can a ZBA decision be appealed?
A: By appealing to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 calendar days of the decision.


Q: Where can transcripts of ZBA hearings be requested?
A: By calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908.


Q: Are ZBA meetings open to the public?
A: Yes, they are held virtually via Zoom or in-person and are open to the public.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: CDAP provides voluntary design assistance to maximize the value of new development projects impacting the public realm.


Q: When does the Historic Review Commission (HRC) meet?
A: On the first Wednesday of each month at 1:00 pm.


Q: How can past meeting presentations of the Historic Review Commission be accessed?
A: By visiting the City Planning's YouTube page or ordering a transcript from Network Deposition Services.

Q: What are the guidelines for naming or renaming public property or facilities?
A: A facility or public property can only be named or renamed for a person after that person has been deceased for at least three years.


Q: Who are the members of the Naming Commission?
A: The members are Jamil Bey (Director of City Planning), Kim Lucas (Director of Mobility and Infrastructure), Chris Hornstein (Director, Department of Public Works Facilities), and Kathryn Vargas (Director, Parks and Recreation).


Q: When does the Planning Commission meet?
A: The Planning Commission meets every other Tuesday, with an August recess, starting at 1:00 pm.


Q: What is the role of the Planning Commission in the city?
A: The Planning Commission guides land use and land development, makes recommendations to city council concerning the zoning ordinance and zoning maps, and reviews major development proposals, among other responsibilities.


Q: Who is the chairwoman of the Planning Commission?
A: LaShawn Burton-Falk is the chairwoman of the Planning Commission.


Q: What types of projects are reviewed by the Planning Commission?
A: The Planning Commission reviews new construction and renovations, zoning map changes, institutional master plans, lot consolidations, conditional uses, historic nominations, demolitions, and more.


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission meet?
A: The Public Art & Civic Design Commission meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess, starting at 2:00 pm.


Q: What is the purpose of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: The commission empowers the development of art and culture in public spaces and promotes the design of public spaces and civic structures.


Q: How is a Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA) hearing scheduled?
A: Applicants must file a zoning and development review application online through the OneStopPGH portal, after which the Department of City Planning schedules a hearing date.


Q: What is the fee for a ZBA hearing, and is it refundable?
A: The ZBA fee is $400, assessed in addition to base zoning review fees, and it is non-refundable.


Q: How long does the ZBA have to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision after a hearing.


Q: Can ZBA decisions be appealed?
A: Yes, any affected party may appeal a ZBA decision to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 calendar days of the decision’s issue date.

Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP) in Pittsburgh?
A: CDAP promotes quality of life by providing voluntary design assistance to maximize the value of new development projects, advising the Department of City Planning on design issues.


Q: How often does the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP) meet?
A: CDAP meets every other Tuesday, alternating with the Planning Commission.


Q: What is the composition of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: CDAP is comprised of eight members with expertise in the physical development of the city.


Q: What type of projects does the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP) review?
A: CDAP reviews project development plans, final land development plans, and projects undergoing site plan review, among others.


Q: What is the purpose of the Historic Review Commission (HRC) in Pittsburgh?
A: The HRC provides guidance for exterior work on historic buildings and controls proposed new construction or demolition within historic districts.


Q: How often does the Historic Review Commission (HRC) meet?
A: The HRC meets on the first Wednesday of each month at 1:00 pm.


Q: What is a requirement for naming or renaming public property by the Naming Commission?
A: A facility or public property can only be named or renamed for a person who has been deceased for at least three years.


Q: What is the role of the Planning Commission in Pittsburgh?
A: The Planning Commission guides land use and development, makes zoning recommendations, and reviews major development proposals.


Q: How often does the Planning Commission meet?
A: The Planning Commission meets every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: What is the responsibility of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD)?
A: PACD empowers art and culture development in public spaces and reviews the aesthetics of designs on city-owned property.


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD) meet?
A: The PACD meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess.


Q: What is the function of the over-the-counter (OTC) review by the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: OTC review is for low-impact projects that meet certain eligibility criteria, involving minimal changes to the public realm.

Q: What is considered a "minor change" according to the text?
A: A minor change is a change or addition that will not affect the general aesthetic of the site, would go unnoticed by a large portion of visitors, or would be assumed by most viewers to be a standard element of city infrastructure.


Q: How can one access past meeting minutes and agendas for city planning?
A: Current year meeting agendas, presentations, and minutes are available on the city planning public notices and meeting calendar, while previous years' presentations can be found on city planning's YouTube page.


Q: How can one order a transcript of a city planning meeting?
A: You can order a transcript by calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908, and there will be a fee to access the transcript.


Q: How often does the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA) meet?
A: The ZBA meets on the first three Thursdays of each month.


Q: What is required to schedule a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must file a zoning and development review (ZDR) application online through the OneStopPGH portal, and after review, the department will contact the applicant to schedule a hearing date.


Q: What is the fee for a ZBA hearing?
A: The ZBA fee is $400, assessed in addition to the base zoning review fees.


Q: What is the public notification process for ZBA hearings?
A: ZBA agendas are posted online and sent via email, and notice letters are mailed to abutting property owners. Applicants are also encouraged to contact neighbors and community organizations.


Q: How long does it take for the ZBA to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA will issue a decision within 45 days after a hearing.


Q: What happens if additional time is needed after a ZBA decision is issued?
A: An applicant may request a one-year extension by contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov with a brief explanation.


Q: How can one appeal a ZBA decision?
A: A ZBA decision can be appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 calendar days of the decision's issue date.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: CDAP promotes quality of life by providing design guidance on selected projects, focusing on successful design, public space enhancement, and sustainable urbanism.


Q: What materials are needed for a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must provide a site plan, evidence justifying the request, and documentation of authorization if they are not the property owner.


Q: How can one access ZBA agendas and decisions?
A: ZBA agendas are posted online on the city planning public meetings calendar, and decisions can be requested by contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: What is the purpose of the CDAP's second meeting?
A: The second meeting allows the project representative to present changes since the last meeting and provide additional visuals as the design has developed.


Q: How often does the Historic Review Commission (HRC) meet?
A: The HRC meets on the first Wednesday of each month at 1:00 pm.


Q: Who appoints the members of the Historic Review Commission?
A: The members are appointed by the mayor.


Q: What is required for a facility or public property to be named after a person?
A: The person must have been deceased for at least three years.


Q: When does the Planning Commission meet?
A: Every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: What types of projects does the Planning Commission review?
A: New construction and renovations within seven districts, zoning ordinance changes, master plans, and historic nominations.


Q: What is the role of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: To review and approve the aesthetics of the designed environment on or over city-owned property.


Q: How often does the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA) meet?
A: On the first three Thursdays of each month.


Q: What is the ZBA's decision issuance timeline after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision.


Q: What is the fee for a ZBA hearing application?
A: A $400 fee is assessed in addition to base zoning review fees.


Q: How are neighbors notified about a ZBA hearing?
A: The Department of City Planning mails notice letters to abutting property owners.


Q: What evidence might applicants present at a ZBA hearing?
A: Photographs, site plans, business plans, and evidence demonstrating compliance with zoning code approval criteria.

Q: When does a ZBA decision expire?
A: A ZBA decision expires one year after it is issued.


Q: How can an applicant request an extension for a ZBA decision?
A: An applicant can request a one-year extension by contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov and providing a brief explanation of why an extension is needed.


Q: How long does an affected party have to appeal a ZBA decision?
A: An affected party may appeal a ZBA decision within 30 calendar days of the decision’s issue date.


Q: Where does the appeal process for a ZBA decision start?
A: The appeal process starts at the Department of Court Records located on the main floor of the City-County Building, 414 Grant Street.


Q: How can transcripts of ZBA hearings be requested?
A: Transcripts can be requested by calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908.


Q: Are ZBA meetings open to the public?
A: Yes, ZBA meetings are open to the public and are held virtually via Zoom or in-person.


Q: How can someone receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: To receive ZBA agendas via email, contact zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: Where can past ZBA decisions be requested?
A: Past ZBA decisions can be requested by contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: CDAP provides voluntary design assistance to promote quality of life through professional peer critique for new development projects.


Q: How often does the Contextual Design Advisory Panel meet?
A: CDAP meets every other Tuesday, alternating with the Planning Commission.


Q: What is the mission of the Historic Review Commission (HRC)?
A: The HRC provides guidance for exterior work on historic buildings and controls new construction or demolition within historic districts.


Q: When does the Historic Review Commission meet?
A: The HRC meets on the first Wednesday of each month at 1:00 pm.


Q: What are the guidelines for naming or renaming public properties according to the Naming Commission?
A: A property can only be named or renamed for a person after they have been deceased for at least three years.


Q: How often does the Planning Commission meet?
A: The Planning Commission meets every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: What types of projects does the Planning Commission review?
A: The Planning Commission reviews major development proposals, zoning ordinance changes, and historic nominations, among others.

Q: How can one obtain a transcript of a meeting?
A: You can order a transcript by calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908. A fee will be charged, and you need the meeting date available.


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD) meet?
A: The PACD meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a recess in December, starting at 2:00 pm.


Q: What are the two committees within the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: The Public Art Review Committee and the Civic Design Review Committee.


Q: Who is the chair of the Public Art Committee?
A: Mikael Owunna is the chair of the Public Art Committee.


Q: What is the purpose of the Over-the-Counter (OTC) review?
A: OTC review is for low-impact projects that meet certain eligibility criteria, having minimal impact on the public realm.


Q: How can one receive commissions and board agendas via email?
A: Email planningcommission@pittsburghpa.gov or pacd@pittsburghpa.gov to receive agendas via email.


Q: When does the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA) meet?
A: The ZBA meets on the first three Thursdays of each month, starting at 9:00 am.


Q: What is required for a ZBA hearing to be scheduled?
A: Applicants must file a Zoning and Development Review (ZDR) application online through the OneStopPGH portal.


Q: How long does the ZBA have to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision after a hearing.


Q: What happens if a ZBA decision is not acted upon within a year?
A: The decision expires one year after issuance unless a one-year extension is requested.


Q: Can ZBA decisions be appealed?
A: Yes, they can be appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 days of the decision's issue date.


Q: How can one receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: Email zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov to receive ZBA agendas via email.


Q: Are ZBA meetings open to the public?
A: Yes, ZBA meetings are public and can be attended virtually via Zoom or in-person.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: CDAP provides professional design guidance to maximize the value of new development projects impacting the public realm.

Q: What is the purpose of the staff design review phase?
A: The purpose of the staff design review phase is to develop urban design targets tailored to the development proposal, site conditions, and neighborhood context, and to address design-related zoning requirements.


Q: What is CDAP review and is it mandatory?
A: CDAP review is a voluntary, but highly recommended, process where projects are reviewed for urban design targets and staff comments.


Q: What types of projects does CDAP review?
A: CDAP reviews project development plans, final land development plans, and projects undergoing site plan review.


Q: What does the CDAP meeting format typically include?
A: The CDAP meeting format includes a project introduction by city planning staff, a project presentation by the representative, and a general panel discussion.


Q: What is the role of the Historic Review Commission (HRC)?
A: The HRC provides guidance for exterior work on historic buildings and controls new construction or demolition within historic districts.


Q: What is required to start an application with the Historic Review Commission?
A: To start an application, one must visit the city planning's historic preservation page.


Q: How often does the Naming Commission meet?
A: The Naming Commission meets quarterly.


Q: What is a key condition for naming or renaming public property after a person?
A: A person must have been deceased for at least three years before public property can be named or renamed after them.


Q: When does the Planning Commission meet?
A: The Planning Commission meets every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: What is the role of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD)?
A: The PACD Commission reviews and approves the aesthetics of public art and civic structures on city-owned property.


Q: What is the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA) responsible for?
A: The ZBA reviews land use proposals in accordance with the zoning code through public evidentiary hearings.


Q: How long does the ZBA have to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision following a hearing.

Q: What is the fee for a ZBA application in addition to the base zoning review fees?
A: The ZBA fee is $400.


Q: Are the zoning and ZBA fees refundable?
A: No, the fees are non-refundable regardless of the ZBA request outcome.


Q: How can ZBA fees be paid?
A: Fees can be paid via credit card or e-check through the OneStopPGH portal.


Q: How are ZBA agendas made available to the public?
A: ZBA agendas are posted online on the city planning's public meetings calendar and sent via email.


Q: How are neighbors notified about a ZBA hearing?
A: The Department of City Planning mails notice letters to abutting property owners.


Q: What is required if a project is in an area with a registered community organization (RCO)?
A: A development activities meeting with the RCO may be required at least 30 days before the ZBA hearing.


Q: What materials must applicants provide at a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must provide a site plan, evidence justifying the request, and authorization if they are not the property owner.


Q: When will the ZBA issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA will issue a decision within 45 days after the record for a hearing is closed.


Q: What must happen within one year of a ZBA decision being issued?
A: A permit should be obtained and substantial construction or occupancy should begin.


Q: Can a ZBA decision be appealed?
A: Yes, any affected party may appeal a ZBA decision to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 days.


Q: Where can transcripts of ZBA hearings be requested?
A: Transcripts can be ordered from Network Deposition Services by calling 412-281-7908.


Q: Are ZBA meetings open to the public?
A: Yes, ZBA meetings are open to the public and can be attended virtually via Zoom or in-person.


Q: How can someone receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: By emailing zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: CDAP provides design guidance on selected, higher-profile projects in Pittsburgh.


Q: How often does the Historic Review Commission meet?
A: The Historic Review Commission meets on the first Wednesday of each month.

Q: What is the minimum period a person must be deceased before a public facility can be named or renamed after them?
A: A person must be deceased for at least three years before a public facility can be named or renamed after them.


Q: Who is the chair of the Naming Commission?
A: Jamil Bey is the chair of the Naming Commission.


Q: How often does the Planning Commission meet?
A: The Planning Commission meets every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: What is the term length for members of the Planning Commission?
A: Members of the Planning Commission are appointed for six-year, staggered terms.


Q: What types of projects does the Planning Commission review?
A: The Planning Commission reviews new construction, renovations, zoning changes, master plans, historic nominations, and demolitions, among others.


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission meet?
A: The Public Art & Civic Design Commission meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess.


Q: What are the responsibilities of the Public Art Review Committee?
A: The Public Art Review Committee reviews and approves the addition, modification, relocation, and removal of public art items.


Q: What is the role of the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA)?
A: The ZBA reviews land use proposals in accordance with the zoning code and conducts public evidentiary hearings.


Q: How long does the ZBA have to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision following a hearing.


Q: What is required for scheduling a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must file a zoning and development review (ZDR) application through the OneStopPGH portal.


Q: How can one receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: To receive ZBA agendas via email, contact zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What happens if additional time is needed after a ZBA decision is issued?
A: An applicant may request a one-year extension by contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov with an explanation.


Q: Can ZBA decisions be appealed?
A: Yes, ZBA decisions can be appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 calendar days of the decision's issue date.


Q: Where are ZBA meetings held?
A: ZBA meetings are held virtually via Zoom or in-person in the lower level hearing room at 412 Boulevard of the Allies.

Q: What is the mission of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: The mission of CDAP is to promote quality of life in the city of Pittsburgh through professional, voluntary design assistance to maximize the economic, civic, contextual, and aesthetic value of new development projects impacting the public realm.


Q: How often does the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP) meet?
A: CDAP meets every other Tuesday, alternating with the Planning Commission.


Q: What are the core considerations for projects reviewed by CDAP?
A: Core considerations include successful design, public space enhancement, context sensitivity, sustainable urbanism, and ensuring well-designed buildings and landscapes.


Q: Who are some members of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: Members include Eric Booth, Bruce Chan, Ryan Indovina, Greg LaForest, Cassandra Osterman, Peter Quintanilla, Bob Reppe, and Claudia Saladin.


Q: What is the role of the Historic Review Commission (HRC)?
A: The HRC provides guidance for exterior work on historic buildings and has control over new construction or demolition within historic districts and exterior work to historic landmarks.


Q: When does the Historic Review Commission meet?
A: The Historic Review Commission meets on the first Wednesday of each month at 1:00 pm.


Q: What are the requirements for naming or renaming public property by the Naming Commission?
A: A facility or public property can only be named or renamed for a person after that person has been deceased for at least three years.


Q: How often does the Planning Commission meet?
A: The Planning Commission meets every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: What types of projects does the Planning Commission review?
A: The Planning Commission reviews new construction and renovations, zoning map and code changes, institutional master plans, lot consolidations, subdivisions, and historic nominations.


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD) meet?
A: The PACD Commission meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess.


Q: What is the purpose of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: The commission empowers the development of art and culture in public spaces and promotes the design of public spaces and civic structures that positively impact the city’s public realm.


Q: How can someone receive commissions and board agendas via email?
A: By emailing the respective commission or board, such as historicreview@pittsburghpa.gov for the Historic Review Commission or pacd@pittsburghpa.gov for the Public Art & Civic Design Commission.

Q: What is the purpose of the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA)?
A: The ZBA reviews land use proposals in accordance with the zoning code and holds public evidentiary hearings.


Q: How often does the Zoning Board of Adjustment meet?
A: The ZBA meets on the first three Thursdays of each month, starting at 9:00 pm.


Q: What is required for a ZBA hearing to be scheduled?
A: Applicants must file a zoning and development review (ZDR) application online through the onestoppgh portal.


Q: How long does the ZBA have to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision after a hearing.


Q: What happens if a ZBA decision is not acted upon within a year?
A: A ZBA decision expires one year after it is issued unless an extension is requested.


Q: How can someone appeal a ZBA decision?
A: An appeal can be filed with the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 days of the decision’s issue date.


Q: Where can past ZBA meeting materials and decisions be accessed?
A: Past meeting materials and decisions can be accessed on the city planning's public notices and meeting calendar or the city planning's YouTube page.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: CDAP provides design guidance to enhance the economic, civic, contextual, and aesthetic value of new development projects.


Q: How are CDAP meetings structured?
A: CDAP meetings include a project introduction, a project presentation, and a general panel discussion.


Q: What materials must applicants provide for a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must provide a site plan, evidence justifying the request, and authorization documentation if they are not the property owner.


Q: How can one receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: By emailing zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What are some examples of approved citywide standards by the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: Fixit bike repair station standards, greenway standards, and small cell aesthetic guidelines.

Q: What is the purpose of the CDAP second meeting?
A: The second CDAP meeting allows the project representative to present changes since the last meeting and provide additional visuals as the design has developed.


Q: When does the Historic Review Commission (HRC) meet?
A: The Historic Review Commission meets on the first Wednesday of each month at 1:00 pm.


Q: Who appoints the members of the Historic Review Commission?
A: The members of the Historic Review Commission are appointed by the mayor.


Q: What is required to start an application with the Historic Review Commission?
A: To start an application with the Historic Review Commission, visit the city planning's historic preservation page.


Q: What is the primary role of the Naming Commission?
A: The Naming Commission creates guidelines and specifications for naming or changing the name of public property or facilities.


Q: How often does the Naming Commission meet?
A: The Naming Commission meets quarterly and is held virtually.


Q: What is a requirement for naming or renaming a public property after a person?
A: A public property can only be named or renamed for a person after that person has been deceased for at least three years.


Q: Who is the chair of the Planning Commission?
A: Lashawn Burton-Falk is the chairwoman of the Planning Commission.


Q: What types of projects does the Planning Commission review?
A: The Planning Commission reviews new construction, renovations, zoning map changes, lot consolidations, subdivisions, conditional uses, and historic nominations.


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD) meet?
A: The Public Art & Civic Design Commission meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess, starting at 2:00 pm.


Q: What are the two committees within the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: The two committees are the Public Art Review Committee and the Civic Design Review Committee.


Q: What is the role of the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA)?
A: The Zoning Board of Adjustment reviews land use proposals in accordance with the zoning code requirements.


Q: How long does the ZBA have to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision after a hearing.


Q: What is required for a ZBA hearing to be scheduled?
A: A ZBA hearing is scheduled after filing a zoning and development review (ZDR) application and being contacted by the Department of City Planning.


Q: How are neighbors notified about a ZBA hearing?
A: Neighbors are notified by mailed notice letters from the Department of City Planning to abutting property owners.

Q: When does a ZBA decision expire?
A: A ZBA decision expires one year after it is issued.


Q: How can an applicant request an extension for a ZBA decision?
A: An applicant can request a one-year extension by contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov and providing a brief explanation of why an extension is needed.


Q: Who can appeal a ZBA decision, and within what timeframe?
A: Any affected party may appeal a ZBA decision to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 calendar days of the decision’s issue date.


Q: Where can a transcript of a ZBA hearing be ordered?
A: A transcript of a ZBA hearing can be ordered by calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908.


Q: Are ZBA meetings open to the public?
A: Yes, ZBA meetings are open to the public and held virtually via Zoom or in-person.


Q: How can one receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: To receive ZBA agendas via email, contact zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: Where can past ZBA decisions be requested?
A: Past ZBA decisions can be requested by contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the role of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: CDAP provides professional, voluntary design assistance to promote quality of life in Pittsburgh and advises the Department of City Planning by reviewing and providing design guidance on selected projects.


Q: How often does the Historic Review Commission meet?
A: The Historic Review Commission meets on the first Wednesday of each month.


Q: What is the primary function of the Naming Commission?
A: The Naming Commission creates guidelines and specifications for naming or changing the name of public property or facilities.


Q: When does the Planning Commission meet?
A: The Planning Commission meets every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: What types of projects does the Planning Commission review?
A: The Planning Commission reviews major development proposals, master plans, conditional uses, lot consolidations, subdivisions, and historic nominations.

Q: How can one order a transcript of a city planning meeting?
A: By calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908, with a fee charged.


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD) meet?
A: The PACD meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess.


Q: Who is the chair of the Public Art Committee?
A: Mikael Owunna is the chair of the Public Art Committee.


Q: What is the purpose of the Over-the-Counter (OTC) review?
A: The OTC review is for low-impact projects that meet certain eligibility criteria and have minimal impact on the public realm.


Q: How long does the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA) have to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision following a hearing.


Q: What must applicants provide at a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must provide a site plan, evidence justifying the request, and documentation of authorization if not the property owner.


Q: How can one receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: By emailing zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What happens if a ZBA decision is not acted upon within a year?
A: The decision expires, but an applicant may request a one-year extension.


Q: How can one appeal a ZBA decision?
A: By appealing to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 days of the decision's issue date.


Q: What is the fee for a ZBA hearing application?
A: The fee is $400, in addition to base zoning review fees.


Q: Where are past meeting minutes for city planning commissions available?
A: On the city planning's YouTube page and through links to PDF documents for each year.


Q: What is the role of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: To empower art and culture development in public spaces and promote positive design of public spaces and civic structures.

Q: What is the mission of the Contextual Design Advisory Panel (CDAP)?
A: The mission of CDAP is to promote quality of life in the City of Pittsburgh through professional, voluntary design assistance that maximizes the economic, civic, contextual, and aesthetic value of new development projects impacting the public realm.


Q: How many members comprise the CDAP?
A: CDAP is comprised of eight members.


Q: What role does CDAP play in the city planning design review process?
A: CDAP advises the Department of City Planning by reviewing and providing design guidance on selected, higher-profile projects throughout the city.


Q: Is CDAP a commission?
A: No, CDAP is an advisory panel, not a commission.


Q: What are some core considerations for CDAP when reviewing development proposals?
A: Core considerations include successful design, public space enhancement, context sensitivity, sustainable urbanism, well-designed buildings and landscapes, and appropriate connections to adjacent sites and neighborhoods.


Q: How often does CDAP meet?
A: CDAP meets every other Tuesday, alternating with the Planning Commission.


Q: What types of projects may CDAP review?
A: CDAP may review project development plans, final land development plans, and projects undergoing site plan review.


Q: What is the format of a typical CDAP meeting?
A: A typical CDAP meeting includes a project introduction by city planning staff, a project presentation by the project representative, and a general panel discussion.


Q: What happens after a CDAP meeting?
A: After the meeting, city planning staff send a summary of the comments to the applicant, who then updates the design accordingly.


Q: Can projects be reviewed more than once by CDAP?
A: Yes, projects can be reviewed twice if necessary, with the second meeting focusing on changes and additional visuals since the last meeting.


Q: What is the purpose of CDAP workshops?
A: Workshops are collaborative meetings where the project representative brings their goals and current design to the panel for guidance to help create successful urban spaces.


Q: How can someone contact CDAP?
A: CDAP can be contacted via email at pacd@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: What is the purpose of updating the design before the CDAP meeting?
A: To address urban design targets and incorporate staff's comments.


Q: What types of projects may be reviewed by the CDAP?
A: Projects ranging from building additions to multi-parcel developments.


Q: What criteria are considered to determine if a CDAP review is beneficial?
A: The size of the project, complexity of the design context, and impact on the public realm.


Q: What is the typical format of a CDAP meeting?
A: A project introduction by city planning staff, a project presentation by the project representative, and a general panel discussion.


Q: How long is the project presentation by the project representative in a CDAP meeting?
A: 10-15 minutes.


Q: What happens after a CDAP meeting?
A: City planning staff sends a summary of the comments to the applicant, who then updates the design accordingly.


Q: When might a project be reviewed twice by CDAP?
A: If the project does not meet design objectives in the first full CDAP meeting.


Q: What is the purpose of CDAP workshops?
A: To provide a collaborative meeting where project representatives receive design guidance to meet their objectives and create successful urban spaces.


Q: How can someone contact CDAP via email?
A: By emailing pacd@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: When does the Historic Review Commission (HRC) meet?
A: On the first Wednesday of each month at 1:00 pm.


Q: What is the composition requirement for the Historic Review Commission?
A: The commission must include an architect, a preservationist, a realtor, a building inspector, and a planner.


Q: What control does the Historic Review Commission have?
A: Control over any proposed new construction or demolition within a historic district and exterior work to a historic landmark.


Q: Who is the chairperson of the Historic Review Commission?
A: Lucia M. Aguirre.


Q: Where can one find past meeting minutes and agendas for the Historic Review Commission?
A: On the city planning public notices and meeting calendar.


Q: How can one order a transcript of a Historic Review Commission meeting?
A: By calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908, with a fee charged.

Q: How can one obtain a transcript of a city planning meeting?
A: By calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908, with a fee charged for access.


Q: What is the email address to receive commissions and board agendas for historic preservation?
A: historicreview@pittsburghpa.gov


Q: How often does the Naming Commission meet?
A: Quarterly, and the meetings are held virtually.


Q: What is a requirement for naming or renaming a public property after a person?
A: The person must have been deceased for at least three years.


Q: Who is the chair of the Naming Commission?
A: Jamil Bey, Director of City Planning.


Q: What is the role of the Planning Commission?
A: Guiding land use and land development within the city and making recommendations to city council on zoning matters.


Q: When does the Planning Commission meet?
A: Every other Tuesday, with an August recess.


Q: How many members are on the Planning Commission?
A: Nine members.


Q: What is the email address to receive Planning Commission agendas?
A: planningcommission@pittsburghpa.gov


Q: When does the Public Art & Civic Design Commission meet?
A: On the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess.


Q: What is the main purpose of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission?
A: To empower art and culture development in public spaces and promote positive design impacts on the city's public realm.


Q: Who is the chair of the Public Art Committee within the PACD Commission?
A: Mikael Owunna.

Q: What is the purpose of the Over-the-Counter (OTC) review?
A: The OTC review is conducted by staff for low-impact projects that meet certain eligibility criteria, with minimal impact on the public realm.


Q: What types of projects are eligible for OTC approval?
A: Projects eligible for OTC approval include replacements, negligible changes, projects fitting city standards, and modifications of previously approved designs.


Q: What are the criteria for replacements in OTC reviews?
A: Replacements must repair, improve, or update existing elements or fixtures, either in kind or by updating content while maintaining the same overall aesthetic.


Q: What constitutes a "negligible change" in OTC reviews?
A: Negligible changes are those with minimal to no impact on the public realm, including low visibility changes and minor changes that do not affect the site's general aesthetic.


Q: How can one learn more about the OTC process?
A: By downloading the OTC process guide via the link provided in the section.


Q: What are the roles of the Public Art & Civic Design Commission (PACD)?
A: The PACD empowers the development of art and culture in public spaces and reviews and approves the aesthetics of designed environments on city-owned property.


Q: When does the PACD commission meet?
A: The PACD commission meets on the fourth Wednesday of each month, with a December recess.


Q: Who are the members of the Public Art Committee?
A: The Public Art Committee includes Mikael Owunna (chair/commission president), Christine Bethea, Anneliese Martinez, and Shaunda McDill.


Q: Who are the members of the Civic Design Committee?
A: The Civic Design Committee includes Megan Ziegler (chair/commission vice-president), Ali Abdullah, Lisa Carver, and Gerrod Winston.


Q: How can one access past meeting minutes of the PACD?
A: Past meeting minutes are available in PDF format on the city planning public notices and meeting calendar, and previous year's presentations are on city planning's YouTube page.


Q: How can one order a transcript of a PACD meeting?
A: By calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908, noting that a fee will be charged and the meeting date is required.

Q: Where can previous year's meeting presentations be accessed?
A: Previous year's meeting presentations can be accessed on City Planning's YouTube page.


Q: How can someone order a transcript of a meeting?
A: To order a transcript of a meeting, call Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908.


Q: What is the fee for accessing a transcript from Network Deposition Services?
A: Network Deposition Services will charge a fee to access the transcript.


Q: What is the Zoning Board of Adjustment (ZBA)?
A: The ZBA is an adjudicative body that reviews land use proposals according to the zoning code.


Q: When does the ZBA meet?
A: The ZBA meets on the first three Thursdays of each month at 9:00 PM.


Q: How long does it take for the ZBA to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision after a hearing.


Q: How is a ZBA hearing scheduled?
A: A ZBA hearing is scheduled after submitting a Zoning and Development Review (ZDR) application through the OneStopPGH portal.


Q: What is the fee for a ZBA hearing?
A: The ZBA fee is $400, assessed in addition to base zoning review fees.


Q: How are ZBA agendas made available to the public?
A: ZBA agendas are posted online on City Planning's public meetings calendar and sent via email.


Q: How are neighbors notified about a ZBA hearing?
A: The Department of City Planning mails notice letters to abutting property owners.


Q: What materials must applicants provide at a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must provide a site plan, evidence justifying the request, and authorization documentation if not the property owner.


Q: Can ZBA decisions be appealed?
A: Yes, ZBA decisions can be appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 calendar days.


Q: How can someone request a ZBA decision transcript?
A: To request a ZBA decision transcript, contact Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908.


Q: What happens if a ZBA decision is not acted upon within one year?
A: A ZBA decision expires one year after issuance; a permit should be obtained and construction or occupancy should begin within that time.


Q: What is required for public notification of a ZBA hearing?
A: ZBA agendas must be posted online and notice letters mailed to abutting property owners.


Q: How can someone receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: To receive ZBA agendas via email, contact zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: How can a transcript of a ZBA hearing be requested?
A: You can order a transcript by calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908.


Q: Are ZBA agendas available online?
A: Yes, ZBA agendas are posted online on City Planning's public meetings calendar.


Q: How can one receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: To receive agendas via email, contact zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: Are ZBA meetings open to the public?
A: Yes, ZBA meetings are open to the public and held virtually via Zoom or in-person.


Q: How long does it take for the ZBA to issue a decision after a hearing?
A: The ZBA has 45 days to issue a decision following a hearing.


Q: What is required to schedule a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must file a Zoning and Development Review (ZDR) application online through the OneStopPGH portal.


Q: What is the fee for a ZBA hearing?
A: The ZBA fee is $400, in addition to base zoning review fees.


Q: How are neighbors notified about ZBA hearings?
A: The Department of City Planning mails notice letters to abutting property owners.


Q: What materials must applicants provide at a ZBA hearing?
A: Applicants must provide a site plan, evidence justifying the request, and documentation of authorization if not the property owner.


Q: When does a ZBA decision expire?
A: A ZBA decision expires one year after it is issued.


Q: Can a ZBA decision be appealed?
A: Yes, any affected party may appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 days of the decision's issue date.


Q: What happens if additional time is needed after a ZBA decision?
A: An applicant may request a one-year extension by contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: How long after a hearing does the ZBA issue a decision?
A: The ZBA issues a decision within 45 days after the record for a hearing is closed.


Q: What must happen after a ZBA decision is issued for further compliance?
A: The Department of City Planning will review the application for compliance with the zoning code and issue a Record of Zoning Approval (ROZA) if compliant.


Q: When do ZBA decisions expire?
A: A ZBA decision expires one year after it is issued.


Q: Can a ZBA decision be appealed?
A: Yes, any affected party may appeal a ZBA decision to the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County within 30 calendar days of the decision’s issue date.


Q: How can one request a transcript of a ZBA hearing?
A: By calling Network Deposition Services at 412-281-7908 with the case number and hearing date available.


Q: Are ZBA meetings open to the public?
A: Yes, ZBA meetings are open to the public and held virtually via Zoom or in-person.


Q: How can one receive ZBA agendas via email?
A: By emailing zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: Where can past ZBA decisions be requested?
A: By contacting zoningboard@pittsburghpa.gov with the ZBA case number for reference.


Q: What is the role of neighborhood planners in city planning?
A: Neighborhood planners act as liaisons between city government and the community for most planning processes.


Q: What is the purpose of the planning education series?
A: To build up knowledge for the upcoming neighborhood plan process, focusing on different topic areas.


Q: What is the Registered Community Organization (RCO) program?
A: It establishes a set of standards for community-based organizations to create neighborhood plans that may be adopted by the planning commission.


Q: What is the Public Engagement Guide designed to do?
A: It outlines a framework for conducting engagement efforts throughout the comprehensive planning process to increase engagement.

Q: What is the purpose of the Neighborhood Plan Guide in Pittsburgh?
A: The Neighborhood Plan Guide establishes a framework for creating high-quality and consistent neighborhood plans that can be adopted by the planning commission.


Q: Who can initiate the neighborhood planning process in Pittsburgh?
A: The City of Pittsburgh or registered community organizations can initiate the neighborhood planning process.


Q: What role do neighborhood planners play in Pittsburgh?
A: Neighborhood planners act as liaisons between city government and the community, participating in and often coordinating community plans.


Q: What is the purpose of the Public Engagement Guide?
A: The Public Engagement Guide outlines a framework for conducting engagement efforts and establishes guidelines for improving engagement in the comprehensive planning process.


Q: What current neighborhood plans are mentioned in the text?
A: The EcoInnovation District, the Manchester Chateau Neighborhood Plan, the Greater Hazelwood Neighborhood Plan, the Homewood Community Plan, and the Oakland Plan.


Q: What is the purpose of the Planning Education Series?
A: The Planning Education Series consists of informational sessions to build knowledge for the upcoming neighborhood plan process.


Q: What is the Registered Community Organization (RCO) program?
A: The RCO program establishes standards for community-based organizations to create neighborhood plans that may be adopted by the planning commission.


Q: How does the City of Pittsburgh use the Neighborhood Plan Guide?
A: The city uses the Neighborhood Plan Guide to guide its work in initiating planning processes and ensuring plans meet set standards.

Q: What is the purpose of the Neighborhood Plan Guide developed by city planning?
A: The Neighborhood Plan Guide establishes a framework for creating high-quality and consistent neighborhood plans that can be adopted by the planning commission.


Q: Who can initiate the neighborhood planning process according to the guide?
A: The city of Pittsburgh will initiate these planning processes in most instances, but registered community organizations can also initiate the neighborhood planning process.


Q: What role do neighborhood planners serve in the planning process?
A: Neighborhood planners act as liaisons between city government and the community, participating in and often coordinating community plans, and explaining zoning, development, transportation, and other planning-related matters.


Q: What is the goal of the Public Engagement Guide?
A: The Public Engagement Guide outlines a framework for conducting engagement efforts throughout the comprehensive planning process and establishes guidelines for improving engagement.


Q: What is the Registered Community Organization (RCO) program?
A: The RCO program establishes standards for community-based organizations to follow in order to create a neighborhood plan that may be adopted by the planning commission.


Q: What is the Planning Education Series?
A: It is a series of informational sessions coordinated by DCP to build knowledge for the upcoming neighborhood plan process, focusing on different topic areas.


Q: Name one of the current neighborhood plans mentioned in the text.
A: The EcoInnovation District is one of the current neighborhood plans mentioned.

Q: What is the purpose of the Neighborhood Plan Guide developed by city planning?
A: The Neighborhood Plan Guide establishes a framework for creating high-quality and consistent neighborhood plans that can be adopted by the planning commission.


Q: Who can initiate the neighborhood planning process in Pittsburgh?
A: The City of Pittsburgh or registered community organizations can initiate the neighborhood planning process.


Q: Can you name some of the current neighborhood plans mentioned in the text?
A: EcoInnovation District, Manchester Chateau Neighborhood Plan, Greater Hazelwood Neighborhood Plan, Homewood Community Plan, and The Oakland Plan.


Q: What are some planning projects mentioned in the text?
A: Riverbank Conditions Assessment and Best Practices Study, Broadway Avenue Public Realm Project, Carrick Artistic Intersection, and Hays Woods.


Q: What is the role of public agencies in the neighborhood planning process?
A: Public agencies collaborate with city planning and community planning partners to follow standards and adopt neighborhood plans.


Q: What does the city planning section include information about?
A: City planning includes information about meeting calendars, public notices, commissions and boards, neighborhood planning, and planning projects.


Q: What are some aspects covered under planning programs?
A: Historic preservation program, public art process guides, mobility and infrastructure, permits, licenses, and inspections.


Q: What is one of the master plans mentioned in the text?
A: The Greater Hill District Master Plan is one of the master plans mentioned.

Q: What is the purpose of the PreservePGH plan?
A: The PreservePGH plan aims to preserve Pittsburgh's distinct character and culture in ways that contribute to a high quality of life.


Q: What is required for doing exterior work on a property in a city-designated historic district in Pittsburgh?
A: Approval by the Historic Review Commission is required for development review.


Q: What types of projects require development review in Pittsburgh's historic districts?
A: Projects requiring development review include in-kind repair or restoration, HVAC replacement, fencing replacement, signage replacement, roofing replacement, painting, new construction, exterior alterations, additions, and demolition of buildings.


Q: What are some of the planning programs mentioned in the text?
A: Planning programs mentioned include Adopt-a-Lot, Greenways, Building Benchmarking Compliance, and Registered Community Organizations.


Q: What is the focus of Pittsburgh's historic preservation work?
A: Pittsburgh's historic preservation work focuses on preserving the city's cultural heritage, which includes its people, neighborhoods, buildings, landscapes, and stories.


Q: What is the vision statement of PreservePGH?
A: The vision statement of PreservePGH emphasizes preserving Pittsburgh's distinct character and culture while balancing tradition and innovation, and environmental sensitivity with resource use.


Q: What are some of the planning projects listed in the text?
A: Planning projects listed include the Riverbank Conditions Assessment and Best Practices Study, Broadway Avenue Public Realm Project, Carrick Artistic Intersection, Hays Woods, and various neighborhood plans.


Q: What is the significance of cultural and historic resources in Pittsburgh?
A: Cultural and historic resources significantly impact Pittsburgh's character and contribute to a unique and distinct sense of place.

Q: What is the first step in applying for work on a historic property in Pittsburgh?
A: The first step is completing a building & development application (BDA) online at onestoppgh and paying the appropriate filing fee.


Q: What additional application is required alongside the BDA application?
A: An application for a certificate of appropriateness (COA) is required.


Q: How many business days in advance must applications be received before the next HRC hearing date?
A: Applications must be received at least 13 business days prior to the next available HRC hearing date.


Q: What materials must be uploaded for project review in the onestoppgh application?
A: A full design narrative, photographs, drawings & renderings, proposed exterior materials information, and a site plan/survey.


Q: Who should be emailed to verify if your application has been received and included on the agenda?
A: Email historicreview@pittsburghpa.gov to verify application receipt and agenda inclusion.


Q: What types of work require development review by the Historic Review Commission?
A: Development review is required for in-kind repairs, new construction, exterior alterations, additions, demolition, and alterations of materials, windows, doors, roofing, light fixtures, HVAC, fencing, walls, gates, and signage.


Q: Are development reviews required for interior alterations?
A: No, development reviews are not required for interior alterations unless the interior is designated for gardening or landscaping.


Q: What is PreservePGH?
A: PreservePGH is the Pittsburgh cultural heritage plan completed in 2012, guiding the city's historic preservation work.


Q: What is the vision statement of PreservePGH?
A: Pittsburgh's distinct character and culture will be preserved in ways that contribute to a high quality of life, balancing tradition and innovation, preservation and new construction, environmental sensitivity, and continued use of resources.

Q: What is required for in-kind repair or restoration of HVAC replacement, fencing replacement, signage replacement, roofing replacement, and painting in a city-designated historic district in Pittsburgh?
A: A development review is required.


Q: What types of projects require a development review in Pittsburgh's historic districts?
A: New construction, exterior alterations, additions, demolition of buildings, and repair, removal, replacement, or alteration of materials, windows, doors, roofing, light fixtures, HVAC, fencing, walls, gates, and non-conforming signage.


Q: Are development reviews required for interior alterations in Pittsburgh's historic districts?
A: No, unless the interior is designated for gardening or landscaping.


Q: What is the first step in applying for work on a historic property in Pittsburgh?
A: Completing a building & development application (BDA) online at onestoppgh and paying the appropriate filing fee.


Q: What additional application must be submitted as part of the onestoppgh BDA application?
A: An application for a certificate of appropriateness (COA).


Q: What materials are required for a project review in Pittsburgh's historic districts?
A: A full design narrative, photographs, drawings & renderings, proposed exterior materials information, and a site plan/survey.


Q: How far in advance must applications be received before the next available HRC hearing date?
A: At least 13 business days prior.


Q: How can you confirm that your project is on the agenda for the HRC hearing in Pittsburgh?
A: By verifying your application has been received via email to historicreview@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What document guides the city planning's historic preservation work in Pittsburgh?
A: PreservePGH, the Pittsburgh cultural heritage plan completed in 2012.


Q: What is the vision statement of PreservePGH?
A: Pittsburgh's distinct character and culture will be preserved in ways that contribute to a high quality of life, offering a balance of tradition and innovation, preservation and new construction, environmental sensitivity, and continued use of resources.

Q: What is required for doing exterior work on a property in a city-designated historic district in Pittsburgh?
A: Approval by the Historic Review Commission is required.


Q: What is the process called for getting approval for exterior work on historic properties in Pittsburgh?
A: The process is called development review.


Q: What types of work require development review in Pittsburgh's historic districts?
A: In-kind repair or restoration, HVAC replacement, fencing replacement, signage replacement, roofing replacement, painting, new construction, exterior alterations, additions, demolition, and alteration of materials, windows, doors, roofing, light fixtures, HVAC, fencing, walls, gates, and non-conforming signage.


Q: What types of work do not require development review in Pittsburgh's historic districts?
A: Interior alterations (unless the interior is designated) and gardening or landscaping.


Q: What is the first step to apply for work on a historic property in Pittsburgh?
A: Completing a Building & Development Application (BDA) online at OneStopPGH and paying the filing fee.


Q: What additional application is required along with the BDA for historic property work?
A: An application for a Certificate of Appropriateness (COA).


Q: How many business days prior to the next Historic Review Commission hearing must applications be received?
A: At least 13 business days.


Q: Where should applicants verify their application has been received for historic property work in Pittsburgh?
A: By emailing historicreview@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What materials are required to be uploaded with the OneStopPGH application for project review?
A: A full design narrative, photographs, drawings & renderings, proposed exterior materials information, and a site plan/survey.


Q: What document guides historic preservation work in Pittsburgh?
A: PreservePGH, the Pittsburgh Cultural Heritage Plan.


Q: What is the vision statement of PreservePGH?
A: Pittsburgh's distinct character and culture will be preserved in ways that contribute to a high quality of life, balancing tradition and innovation, preservation and new construction, environmental sensitivity, and continued use of resources.

Q: Where can you apply for a Building & Development Application (BDA) in Pittsburgh?
A: You can apply for a Building & Development Application (BDA) online at onestoppgh.


Q: What additional application must be submitted with the BDA for work on a historic property?
A: An application for a Certificate of Appropriateness (COA) must be submitted with the BDA.


Q: How far in advance must applications be received before the next HRC hearing date?
A: Applications must be received at least 13 business days prior to the next available HRC hearing date.


Q: What materials are required for project review in a historic district?
A: A full design narrative, photographs, drawings & renderings, proposed exterior materials information, and a site plan/survey are required.


Q: What types of work require a development review in a city-designated historic district?
A: Development review is required for in-kind repair or restoration, new construction, exterior alterations, additions, demolition, and repair or alteration of materials, windows, doors, roofing, light fixtures, HVAC, fencing, walls, gates, and signage.


Q: What types of work do not require a development review in a historic district?
A: Interior alterations (unless designated) and gardening or landscaping do not require a development review.


Q: How can you confirm that your project is on the HRC agenda?
A: Verify your application has been received by emailing historicreview@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What should you do if your application is incomplete?
A: Staff will note which specific items are required to continue the project review.

A: Resources for historic preservation can be found through the city's historic preservation program and related links.

A: Public Art & Design is responsible for maintaining and preserving the city's collection of monuments, memorials, and works of historical and modern art.

Q: What resources are available to help with the City of Pittsburgh's zoning and development review process?
A: Several easy-to-use guides are available to help with the process.


Q: What is the purpose of the performance points process guides?
A: They encourage new developments to embrace innovation and contribute to neighborhood livability by incorporating city priorities such as affordable housing, public art, and energy-efficient design.

A: The presentation can be viewed in a PDF format (3MB).

A: The process is detailed in the Administrator Exception PDF (245KB).
