A: The Construction Management Plans PDF (163KB) outlines the requirements.


Q: How can someone learn about the zoning approval process for child care uses?
A: By referring to the Child Care and Zoning PDF (103KB).


Q: What is the purpose of the site plan requirements guide?
A: It outlines what information is necessary for a site plan to show the location of a project.


Q: What is included in the public art collection management policy document?
A: The policy document is available in PDF format (475KB).

Q: What department should you work with if planning to build in the City of Pittsburgh?
A: You should work with the Department of City Planning Zoning & Development Review Division.


Q: What is the purpose of the process guides provided by the City of Pittsburgh's Department of City Planning?
A: The process guides are designed to make the building process easier and help get projects moving.


Q: What is OneStopPGH in relation to the City of Pittsburgh’s planning process?
A: OneStopPGH is an online filing system that the process guides are being updated to coordinate with.


Q: What is included in the "Approved Street Trees" document?
A: It lists the approved species of trees and how frequently each may be planted.


Q: What does the "Administrator Exception" document detail?
A: It details the process to follow when a project requires an administrator exception per the zoning code.


Q: What information does the "Child Care and Zoning" document provide?
A: It provides information on types of child care uses and the process for zoning approval.


Q: What is the purpose of the "Construction Management Plans" document?
A: It outlines the process for construction management plans when required in the development review process.


Q: What do the "Design Review Process" and "Design Review Submission" documents cover?
A: They cover the process to follow for design review and the submission requirements for design review.


Q: What is the focus of the "Floodplain Overlay" document?
A: It focuses on FEMA floodplain requirements and property development.


Q: What does the "Geotechnical Reports" document explain?
A: It explains why geotechnical reports are required, who needs to do them, and how they are reviewed.


Q: What is the "Neighborhood Gateway Signage" document about?
A: It details what signage is allowed and where it can be placed.


Q: What does the "Occupancy History" document provide?
A: It provides the process for users that established on a property prior to 1958.


Q: What is the purpose of the "Lot Consolidation and Subdivisions" document?
A: It explains why lot consolidation and subdivisions are required, how to file for them, and what to do after approval.


Q: What do "Performance Points Process Guides" encourage?
A: They encourage new developments to embrace innovation and contribute to neighborhood livability by incorporating city and community priorities.


Q: What information does the "Planning Commission Process" document contain?
A: It contains information on what projects the commission reviews, how hearings are conducted, and what to expect.


Q: What are "Site Plan Requirements" necessary for?
A: They are necessary for everything that gets built to show its location and to determine what information is necessary for a project.


Q: What does the "Residential Accessory Structure Setback Requirements" document illustrate?
A: It illustrates the types of setbacks to consider when building an accessory structure.


Q: What is the focus of the "Site Plan Review Process" document?
A: It provides a more detailed review for medium-sized projects and helps determine whether a project requires it.


Q: What does the "Zoning Board of Adjustment" document outline?
A: It outlines the process to follow when a project needs a variance or special exception to the zoning code.

Q: What is the purpose of the performance points process guides in Pittsburgh's city planning?
A: They encourage new developments to embrace innovation and contribute to neighborhood livability by incorporating city and community priorities such as affordable housing, public art, and energy-efficient design.


Q: What do site plan requirements entail according to Pittsburgh's city planning guides?
A: Everything that gets built needs a site plan to show its location, and the guide helps determine what information is necessary for a project.


Q: What is the role of the zoning board of adjustment in Pittsburgh?
A: The zoning board of adjustment handles the process for projects needing a variance or special exception to the zoning code, including application requirements.


Q: What is the mission of Pittsburgh's Department of Mobility and Infrastructure?
A: To provide the physical mobility necessary to support the social and economic mobility of Pittsburgh residents through management, design, improvement, and operation of the public right-of-way.


Q: What is the purpose of Pittsburgh's approved street trees list?
A: It shares the approved species of trees and how frequently each may be planted.


Q: What does the floodplain overlay guide include?
A: FEMA flood plain requirements and property development information.


Q: What is the focus of the transportation development review in Pittsburgh?
A: Managing safe transportation for all, including site plan reviews, impact studies, and right-of-way permits to shape Pittsburgh's multimodal network.


Q: What are the residential accessory structure setback requirements?
A: A diagram illustrating the types of setbacks to consider when building an accessory structure like a pool or shed.

Q: What is the mission of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure in Pittsburgh?
A: To provide the physical mobility necessary to support the social and economic mobility of the people of Pittsburgh through the management, design, improvement, and operation of the public right of way.


Q: What areas does the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure manage in Pittsburgh?
A: The department is responsible for the transportation of people and goods throughout the city and for managing the operation of and access to the public right-of-way, including sidewalks, curbs, streets, and bridges.


Q: What is one of the city's mobility principles regarding household access to fresh produce?
A: Every household in Pittsburgh can access fresh fruits and vegetables within 20 minutes travel of home, without the requirement of a private vehicle.


Q: What percentage of household income should not be exceeded for basic needs according to Pittsburgh's mobility principles?
A: No household must spend more than 45% of household income to satisfy basic housing, transportation, and energy needs.


Q: How does the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure aim to influence economic success?
A: By providing access to transportation, which is the factor most likely to influence household economic success.

Q: What are some responsibilities of the planning group mentioned in the text?
A: Oversight, development, and collaboration of system plans, multimodal networks, and implementation; development of conceptual design of transportation facilities; collection and analysis of data on the condition and use of the mobility system; coordination with county and regional organizations to plan transportation infrastructure improvements; serving as the initial point of contact for public stakeholders and partners for general mobility concerns; tracking the development of the regional transportation improvement program (TIP); development of the department's submission to the city's capital improvement plan; pursuit of grants and other resources to support implementation of the transportation program.

A: DOMI provides review of transportation impact studies (TIS) as part of the development approval process.

Q: What is the purpose of a Transportation Impact Study (TIS)?
A: To assess the impact of a development on the adjacent roadway network and determine necessary mitigations.

Q: What is required for improvements within the public right-of-way that alter its existing geometry, composition, or operation?
A: A ROW (Right-of-Way) improvement plan is required.


Q: Who should be contacted for questions about the webpage mentioned in the text?
A: Angie Martinez at angela.martinez@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What is the responsibility of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure (DOMI) in Pittsburgh?
A: DOMI is responsible for the safe transportation of people and goods throughout the city and for managing the planning, operations, and improvement of the public rights-of-way.


Q: What actions does DOMI evaluate to achieve its mission?
A: DOMI evaluates the impact of certain development actions on the city’s multimodal transportation network.


Q: What is a Transportation Impact Study (TIS) and when is it required?
A: A TIS is required when a development is anticipated to impact the adjacent roadway network, affecting network capacity, and requiring mitigations to support the proposed development.


Q: What is the goal of Transportation Demand Management (TDM)?
A: The goal of TDM is to reduce single occupancy vehicle trips by making it easier and more attractive for travelers to use transit, biking, walking, and other efficient travel options.


Q: What must be obtained before work can begin within the public right-of-way?
A: The appropriate permit(s) from the applicable DOMI permit office must be obtained.


Q: What does the level of transportation review for a land development project depend on?
A: It is tailored to the scale, use, context, and unique features of the proposed site and runs concurrent with the Department of City Planning (DCP) zoning review.

Q: What is the responsibility of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure (DOMI) in Pittsburgh?
A: DOMI is responsible for the safe transportation of people and goods throughout the city of Pittsburgh and for managing the planning, operations, and improvement of the public rights-of-way (ROW).


Q: What actions does DOMI evaluate to achieve its mission?
A: DOMI evaluates the impact of certain development actions on the city’s multimodal transportation network, including site plan review, transportation impact study, transportation demand management, ROW permits, and ROW improvement plans.


Q: When is a Transportation Impact Study (TIS) required?
A: A TIS is required when a development is anticipated to impact the adjacent roadway network in a manner where network capacity impacts are expected and mitigations are necessary to support the proposed development.


Q: What is the goal of Transportation Demand Management (TDM)?
A: The goal of TDM is to reduce single occupancy vehicle trips by making it easier and more attractive for travelers to utilize transit, biking, walking, and other efficient travel options.


Q: What must be obtained before work can begin within the public right-of-way?
A: The appropriate permit(s) must be obtained from the applicable DOMI permit office before work can begin within the public right-of-way.


Q: What requires a ROW Improvement Plan?
A: Improvements within the public ROW that alter the existing geometry, composition, or operation of the right(s)-of-way require a ROW Improvement Plan.


Q: Who should be contacted for questions about the webpage?
A: Questions about the webpage should be directed to Angie Martinez at angela.martinez@pittsburghpa.gov.

Q: What is the primary responsibility of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure (DOMI) in Pittsburgh?
A: DOMI is responsible for the safe transportation of people and goods throughout the city of Pittsburgh and for managing the planning, operations, and improvement of the public rights-of-way (ROW).


Q: What types of review actions does DOMI evaluate for land development projects?
A: DOMI evaluates site plan review, transportation impact study, transportation demand management, ROW permits, ROW improvement plans, and curb cuts.


Q: When is a Transportation Impact Study (TIS) required?
A: A TIS is required when a development is anticipated to impact the adjacent roadway network in a way that affects network capacity and requires mitigations.


Q: What is the goal of Transportation Demand Management (TDM)?
A: The goal of TDM is to reduce single occupancy vehicle trips by making it easier and more attractive for travelers to use transit, biking, walking, and other efficient travel options.


Q: What must be obtained before work within a public right-of-way can begin?
A: The appropriate permit(s) must be obtained from the applicable DOMI permit office.


Q: What is required for improvements within the public right-of-way that alter its existing geometry or operation?
A: A ROW improvement plan is required for such improvements.


Q: Where can residents, businesses, and contractors apply for and receive permits online in Pittsburgh?
A: They can use the OneStopPGH public portal to apply for and receive permits online.


Q: How can questions about the DOMI webpage be directed?
A: Questions should be directed to Angie Martinez at angela.martinez@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What are the customer service hours for DOMI's in-person and remote services?
A: Monday – Friday from 9 am to 3 pm via their counter, permit phone line, and the OneStopPGH portal chat.


Q: What types of DOMI permits are available online?
A: Online permits include construction staging (barricade, demolition dumpster, machinery, materials staging, scaffolding), curb cut, moving, opening, pole, sidewalk repair, banner, valet, outdoor dining & retail, tree, and small cell wireless facility permits.

Q: What must all opening, pole, and construction staging (barricade) permits include on the application?
A: They must list a general contractor.


Q: Where can general contractors register to verify insurance and tax compliance?
A: With the City of Pittsburgh.


Q: How can one apply for a general contractor license in Pittsburgh?
A: Online through onestoppgh.

A: domi.streets@pittsburghpa.gov.

A: jennifer.massacci@pittsburghpa.gov.

A: On the onestoppgh public portal.

A: Monday – Friday from 9am to 3pm.


Q: Which email can be used for general questions regarding permits in Pittsburgh?
A: domipermits@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What types of permits are available through DOMI online?
A: Banner, construction staging, curb cut, moving, opening, pole, sidewalk repair, valet, outdoor dining & retail, tree, and small cell wireless facility permits.


Q: What should be reviewed before applying for permits on onestoppgh?
A: User-friendly documents on the applicant guidance page, including the ROW fee schedule and information sheets.


Q: What type of instructional videos are available for new users of onestoppgh?
A: Videos created for the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections.

Q: What types of permits are available online through DOMI?
A: Permits available online include banner, construction staging (barricade, demolition dumpster, machinery, materials staging, scaffolding), curb cut, moving, opening, pole, sidewalk repair, valet, outdoor dining & retail, tree, and small cell wireless facility.


Q: What must be listed on all opening, pole, and construction staging (barricade) permits?
A: A general contractor must be listed on the permit application.


Q: What is required of general contractors in Pittsburgh regarding permits?
A: General contractors must register with the city of Pittsburgh to verify insurance and tax compliance.


Q: How can one apply for a general contractor license in Pittsburgh?
A: You can apply for the general contractor license online through onestoppgh.

A: Questions about ROW improvement plans can be emailed to domi.streets@pittsburghpa.gov.

A: Plan reviews available online include minor encroachment, major encroachment, ROW improvement plan (new construction and minor), street vacation, street dedication, annual bridge, annual dumpster, annual machinery, annual valet, and annual ROW use agreement.


Q: What is onestoppgh?
A: Onestoppgh is a single online location where residents, businesses, contractors, and others can apply, pay for, and receive permits online.

A: DOMI's in-person and remote customer service hours are Monday – Friday from 9 am to 3 pm.

A: It is the central hub for Pittsburgh residents to apply, pay for, and receive business licenses, permits, and track violation notices.

A: domi.streets@pittsburghpa.gov


Q: How are permit costs calculated in Pittsburgh?
A: Based on the total construction value of the project.


Q: Under which act is construction in Pittsburgh regulated?
A: Pennsylvania Construction Code Act or PA Act No. 45 of 1999 (Uniform Construction Code).


Q: How must all appeal applications be made in Pittsburgh?
A: Electronically through the online OneStopPGH system.

Q: What is the purpose of the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections (PLI) code enforcement?
A: To protect the health, safety, and welfare in existing buildings and structures.


Q: How is the cost of a permit calculated by PLI?
A: Based on the total construction value of the project.


Q: What act regulates construction in Pennsylvania, including Pittsburgh?
A: The Pennsylvania Construction Code Act or PA Act No. 45 of 1999, also known as the Uniform Construction Code (UCC).


Q: How must all appeal applications be submitted to PLI?
A: Electronically through the online OneStopPGH system.


Q: What is OneStopPGH?
A: The central hub for Pittsburgh residents to apply, pay for, and receive business licenses, permits, and track violation notices.


Q: What happens when a structure is declared a public safety hazard by PLI?
A: PLI will condemn the building.


Q: What do PLI bulletins provide?
A: An overview of PLI construction procedures, guidance on code-related topics, and code interpretations.

A: Two types, although the specific types are not detailed in the text.

A: Online.

A: The International Code Council’s (ICC) I-Codes.

A: The UCC adopts, in whole or part, the International Code Council’s (ICC) I-Codes.

A: All appeal applications must be made electronically through the online OneStopPGH system.

A: Pittsburgh residents can apply for permits and licenses through OneStopPGH.

A: The purpose is to protect the health, safety, and welfare in existing buildings and structures.

A: It allows residents to apply, pay for, and receive business licenses, permits, and track violation notices.

A: It is also known as PA Act No. 45 of 1999 or the Uniform Construction Code (UCC).

A: Bulletins provide an overview of PLI construction procedures, guidance on code-related topics, and code interpretations.

A: The UCC adopts, in whole or part, the International Code Council’s (ICC) I-Codes.

A: The Pennsylvania Construction Code Act or PA Act No. 45 of 1999, also known as the Uniform Construction Code (UCC).

A: All appeal applications must be made electronically through the online OneStopPGH system.

A: Inquiries should be directed to supervisors individually or through the shared email address to ensure timely responses.


Q: What is the purpose of the OneStopPGH system?
A: The OneStopPGH system is a one-stop shop for residents to apply for, pay for, and obtain business and trade licenses, development, right-of-way, and fire code permits, and planning applications.


Q: Where can residents go for in-person services related to permits and licenses?
A: Residents can visit the OneStopPGH counter at 412 Boulevard of the Allies, opening on November 18, 2024.


Q: What types of payments are accepted at the OneStopPGH counter?
A: The counter accepts credit card, check, and money order payments, but not cash.


Q: What are the OneStopPGH customer service hours?
A: Monday - Friday from 9 am to 3 pm.


Q: What are some holidays when OneStopPGH customer service is unavailable?
A: New Year's Day, Martin Luther King Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, Juneteenth, Independence Day, Labor Day, Veterans Day, Thanksgiving Day, Day after Thanksgiving, and Christmas Day.

Q: What is the OneStopPGH portal designed for?
A: The OneStopPGH portal is designed as a one-stop shop for residents to apply for, pay for, and obtain business and trade licenses, development, right-of-way, and fire code permits, as well as planning applications.


Q: Which departments collaborate on the OneStopPGH system?
A: The OneStopPGH system is a collaborative effort of the departments of city planning (DCP), mobility and infrastructure (DOMI), permits, licenses, and inspections (PLI), and the Pittsburgh Bureau of Fire (PBF).

A: The OneStopPGH in-person counter will open on November 18, 2024.

Q: What types of work require a PLI permit?
A: Constructing, enlarging, altering, repairing, moving, demolishing, or changing the occupancy of a building, structure, and facility, and erecting, installing, enlarging, altering, repairing, removing, converting, or replacing any electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system.


Q: What is the size limit for hard copy submissions at the OneStopPGH counter?
A: Documents up to 11” x 17” in size.

Q: What is the International Residential Code applicable to?  
A: It is applicable to structures accessory to the dwelling and detached two-family dwellings that are 3 stories or less in height.


Q: When is the International Residential Code not applicable?  
A: It is not applicable if other uses beyond the dwelling unit are present in the structure.


Q: What does the International Building Code apply to?  
A: It applies to structures regulated by the code, including attached and detached single-family and two-family dwellings more than 3 stories in height, mixed-use structures, and non-residential uses.


Q: What are the general work types defined in the text?  
A: New construction, addition/alteration, and minor alteration.


Q: What is required for minor alterations to existing buildings?  
A: A valid certificate of occupancy is required.


Q: What is the first step in the permit process?  
A: Application submission.


Q: What entity is responsible for plumbing permits?  
A: The Allegheny County Health Department Plumbing Division.


Q: What types of work require a permit according to the text?  
A: Constructing, enlarging, altering, repairing, moving, demolishing, or changing the occupancy of a building or structure, and altering electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing systems.


Q: What is not required for single-family dwellings and townhouses?  
A: Certificates of occupancy are not required.


Q: What might a demolition require in addition to a regular permit?  
A: A permit from the Allegheny County Health Department for asbestos abatement.

Q: What types of buildings do not require a certificate of occupancy?
A: Single-family dwellings and townhouses do not require certificates of occupancy.


Q: What are the steps in the permit process?
A: The steps are application submission, application review, permit issuance, permit inspections, and permit completion.


Q: Which department is responsible for plumbing permits?
A: The Allegheny County Health Department plumbing division is responsible for plumbing permits.


Q: What types of work require a permit according to the text?
A: Constructing, enlarging, altering, repairing, moving, demolishing, or changing the occupancy of a building, structure, and facility; and erecting, installing, enlarging, altering, repairing, removing, converting, or replacing any electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system.


Q: What is the maximum fine for not obtaining a permit for asbestos abatement?
A: The maximum fine is up to $25,000.


Q: What types of permits does PLI issue that do not include construction?
A: Occupancy only and occupant load placard permits.


Q: What is the permit type configuration based on?
A: Permit type, structure type, work type, and work scope.


Q: What is applicable to detached single-family dwellings and townhouses under three stories?
A: They are regulated by the International Residential Code and applicable to structures accessory to the dwelling.


Q: What code regulates commercial structures?
A: The International Building Code.


Q: What is required for demolition work?
A: A permit from the Allegheny County Health Department for asbestos abatement may be required.

Q: What is required for customers applying for a new or renewal general contractor license?
A: Customers must provide their firm's EPA lead, renovation, repair, and painting (RRP) certification, which is valid for 5 years.


Q: What types of work require a permit?
A: Constructing, enlarging, altering, repairing, moving, demolishing, or changing the occupancy of a building, structure, and facility; erecting, installing, enlarging, altering, repairing, removing, converting, or replacing any electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system.


Q: What are the steps in the permit process?
A: Application submission, application review, permit issuance, permit inspections, and permit completion.


Q: Do single-family dwellings and townhouses require certificates of occupancy?
A: No, single-family dwellings and townhouses do not require certificates of occupancy.


Q: What is the penalty for not obtaining a permit for asbestos abatement from the Allegheny County Health Department?
A: Fines of up to $25,000.


Q: What continuing education requirement exists for trade license holders?
A: Trade license holders are required to obtain eight (8) continuing education units (CEUs) annually for renewal.


Q: What happens if a license holder allows their license to expire?
A: They will be charged a late fee after the date of expiration.


Q: Where should the address in the certificate holder field be for certificates of insurance?
A: City of Pittsburgh, 412 Blvd of the Allies, PLI, Floor 3, Pittsburgh, PA 15219.


Q: How can one contact the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections?
A: By emailing pliapptech@pittsburghpa.gov or calling 412-255-2175.


Q: What must the format of all required certificates of insurance documents include?
A: The name insured should be the owner’s name, and the business/operating name should be shown under "dba," if applicable.

Q: What types of licenses does the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections issue?
A: The department issues licenses for contractor licenses, trade licenses, and business licenses.


Q: What must customers provide when applying for a new or renewal general contractor license?
A: Customers must provide their firm's EPA lead, renovation, repair, and painting (RRP) certification.


Q: How long is the RRP certification valid?
A: The RRP certification is valid for 5 years.


Q: How many continuing education units (CEUs) are required annually for trade license renewal?
A: Trade license holders are required to obtain eight (8) CEUs annually for renewal.


Q: When did PLI adopt the licensing rules and regulations?
A: PLI adopted the licensing rules and regulations on November 15th, 2018.


Q: What happens if a license holder allows their license to expire?
A: License holders who allow their license to expire will be charged a late fee.

A: The address should read: City of Pittsburgh, 412 Blvd of the Allies, PLI, Floor 3, Pittsburgh, PA 15219.

A: Trade license holders are required to obtain eight (8) continuing education units (CEUs) annually.

Q: Where can many of the records most commonly requested from PLI be accessed?
A: PLI's website and the Western Pennsylvania Regional Data Center’s datasets website.


Q: Since when does the code violations summary report include all PLI issued code violations?
A: Since Oct. 15, 2015


Q: What type of resources are mentioned as continuously growing and available for updates?
A: PLI resources


Q: What type of forums does PLI hold monthly to address frequently asked questions?
A: Monthly community forums


Q: What kind of newsletter has PLI started?
A: A monthly newsletter to communicate changes occurring at PLI.

Q: What is the purpose of the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections (PLI) code enforcement?
A: The purpose is to protect the health, safety, and welfare in existing buildings and structures.


Q: What code does PLI enforce for property maintenance?
A: PLI enforces the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC) as adopted by the City of Pittsburgh Code of Ordinances Title 10 Chapter 1004.


Q: How can someone file a complaint with PLI?
A: By calling the 311 response center or filing an electronic complaint form.


Q: Where can the public access records commonly requested from PLI?
A: On PLI’s website and the Western Pennsylvania Regional Data Center’s datasets website.


Q: What should property owners do if they receive a request for compliance from PLI?
A: Contact the inspector using the direct number on the request, discuss the issue, and arrange an appointment or follow-up inspection.


Q: What happens if a property owner does not fix a violation by the deadline in the second request from PLI?
A: A third inspection is conducted, and if the violation persists, a criminal court complaint is filed with the local magisterial district judge.


Q: How can someone determine the owner of a property?
A: By using the Allegheny County real estate website to find the owner of record.


Q: What actions can PLI take against vacant properties owned by the URA or the city?
A: They will send a notice of violation and take steps to raze or clean and secure the building as applicable.


Q: How can someone appeal an initial notice of violation from PLI?
A: File the appeal with the Board of License and Inspection Review (LIR Board) if the notice is for violations of the city's licensing code or IPMC.


Q: What resources does PLI offer to community members and business owners?
A: PLI offers newsletters, community forums, and various online resources to learn more about their services.

Q: What should a property owner do if a city tree is uplifting the sidewalk in front of their property?
A: The property owner is responsible for fixing the sidewalk but must contact the Department of Public Works' Forestry Division for root pruning and the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure for a sidewalk repair permit.


Q: How can a property owner appeal a notice of violation related to the city's licensing code or the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC)?
A: They would file the appeal with the Board of License and Inspection Review (LIR Board).


Q: What is the purpose of the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections (PLI) Code Enforcement?
A: To protect the health, safety, and welfare in existing buildings and structures.


Q: What code does PLI enforce as adopted by the City of Pittsburgh Code of Ordinances Title 10 Chapter 1004?
A: The International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC).


Q: How can someone file a complaint about a property violation?
A: By calling the 311 response center or filing an electronic complaint form.


Q: What types of violations does PLI enforce?
A: PLI enforces violations such as weeds and/or debris on property, abandoned vehicles on private property, sidewalks that are a tripping hazard, electrical violations, building violations, and zoning violations.


Q: What happens if a property owner does not respond to a request for compliance and fix the violation?
A: The inspector will conduct a second inspection, send a second request, and if still unresolved, a third inspection will lead to a criminal court complaint.


Q: Who should be contacted for root pruning if a city tree is involved in uplifting a sidewalk?
A: The Department of Public Works' Forestry Division.


Q: What is required before planting, removing, or trimming a city tree?
A: A permit from the Forestry Division.


Q: How can someone determine the owner of a property?
A: By using the Allegheny County real estate website to find the owner of record.

Q: What happens if a property violation is not fixed by the deadline in the second request?
A: The inspector will conduct a third and final inspection, and if the violation persists, a criminal court complaint will be filed with the local magisterial district judge.


Q: What can the judge do if you are found guilty of a violation at the hearing?
A: The judge can impose a fine, and if the fine is not paid, the judge can find you in contempt and send you to jail.


Q: How can you file a complaint about a property violation?
A: Call the 311 response center at 311 or 412-255-2621 if outside the city, or file an electronic complaint form.


Q: Where can you find the owner of record for a property?
A: Use the Allegheny County real estate website.


Q: What types of violations does PLI enforce?
A: PLI enforces violations related to weeds and/or debris, abandoned vehicles on private property, sidewalk tripping hazards, electrical violations, building violations, and zoning violations.


Q: How can you appeal an initial notice of violation for the city's licensing code or IPMC?
A: File the appeal with the Board of License and Inspection Review (LIR Board).

A: Contact the Department of Public Works' Forestry Division for root pruning and the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure for a sidewalk repair permit.


Q: What is the purpose of the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections (PLI) code enforcement?
A: To protect the health, safety, and welfare in existing buildings and structures.


Q: How are most inspections initiated?
A: Through requests called, texted, tweeted, or electronically submitted to the 311 response center.


Q: What should you do if you receive a request for compliance and want to talk to the inspector?
A: Call the inspector's direct number provided on the request.

A: The property owner is responsible for fixing the sidewalk.

A: Contact the Department of Public Works' Forestry Division for root pruning and the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure for a sidewalk repair permit.

A: 412-665-3625

A: 412-255-8850


Q: Are property owners allowed to plant, remove, or trim a city tree without a permit?
A: No, a permit from the Forestry Division is required.


Q: What code does the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections (PLI) enforce to protect health, safety, and welfare in buildings?
A: The International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC) as adopted by the City of Pittsburgh Code of Ordinances Title 10 Chapter 1004.


Q: What should a property owner do if they receive a request for compliance?
A: Call the inspector's direct number on the request to discuss the issue or schedule an appointment.


Q: What happens if a property owner does not respond to a request for compliance?
A: A second inspection is conducted, and a second request is sent. If still not addressed, a third inspection leads to a criminal court complaint.


Q: How can a complaint be filed regarding property issues?
A: By calling the 311 response center or filing an electronic complaint form.


Q: How can someone determine the owner of a property?
A: By using the Allegheny County real estate website.


Q: What action does PLI take regarding vacant properties owned by the URA or the city?
A: They send a notice of violation and take steps to raze or clean and secure the building if applicable.


Q: Where can appeals for violations of the city's licensing code or IPMC be filed?
A: With the Board of License and Inspection Review (LIR Board).


Q: What violations does the PLI enforce?
A: Violations such as weeds and/or debris on property, abandoned vehicles on private property, sidewalks that are a tripping hazard, and electrical, building, and zoning violations.

Q: What can happen if you are found guilty at a hearing for a violation?
A: The judge can impose a fine, and if you do not pay the fine, the judge can find you in contempt and send you to jail.


Q: What does PLI encourage property owners to do to avoid fines or jail?
A: PLI encourages property owners to work with their inspector and fix the violations.

A: You can call the 311 response center at 311 or 412-255-2621 if outside the city, or file an electronic complaint form.


Q: What types of violations does PLI enforce?
A: PLI enforces violations such as weeds and/or debris on a property, abandoned vehicles on private property, sidewalks that are a tripping hazard, electrical violations, building violations, and zoning violations.

A: You can use the Allegheny County real estate website to find the owner of record for a property.

A: File the appeal with the Board of License and Inspection Review (LIR Board) for violations of the city's licensing code or IPMC, or with the Board of Appeals (BOA) for violations of the Uniform Construction Code (UCC).

A: To protect the health, safety, and welfare in existing buildings and structures.

Q: What action does PLI take for vacant properties with ordinance violations owned by the URA or the city?
A: PLI sends a notice of violation, and steps are taken to raze or clean and secure the building.


Q: What is the role of the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections (PLI) in code enforcement?
A: PLI enforces the International Property Maintenance Code and the zoning code to protect health, safety, and welfare.


Q: What happens if a property owner does not respond to a request for compliance?
A: The inspector conducts a second inspection, and if the violation persists, a third inspection is done, potentially leading to a criminal court complaint.


Q: What types of violations does PLI enforce?
A: PLI enforces violations like weeds or debris on property, abandoned vehicles on private property, tripping hazards on sidewalks, electrical violations, building violations, and zoning violations.

Q: What is required for a structure to be considered for a city-funded demolition?
A: The structure must be considered an imminent danger.


Q: How does the International Property Maintenance Code define "imminent danger"?
A: A condition which could cause serious or life-threatening injury or death at any time.


Q: What are some reasons a building may be condemned according to the text?
A: Unsafe structures, unsafe equipment, unfit for human occupancy, unlawful structure, and imminent danger.


Q: What is one potential remedy for a property owner of a condemned structure?
A: Obtaining a private demolition permit or repairing the structure to remove code violations.


Q: What section of the International Property Maintenance Code addresses imminent danger?
A: Section 109.1.


Q: What does the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections (PLI) do routinely?
A: Inspects structures to assess building integrity.


Q: What is one of the sections mentioned that relates to the closing of a vacant structure?
A: Section 108.2.


Q: What type of documents should be reviewed for specific properties in the categories of razed, condemned, and under contract?
A: Razed, condemned, and under contract documents.


Q: What must happen before PLI considers a city-funded demolition for a condemned structure?
A: The structure may be condemned for a number of years.

Q: What department is responsible for inspecting structures to assess building integrity in Pittsburgh?
A: The Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections (PLI) is responsible for inspecting structures to assess building integrity.


Q: What are some reasons a building may be condemned according to the text?
A: A building may be condemned for unsafe structures, unsafe equipment, being unfit for human occupancy, being an unlawful structure, closing of vacant structures, imminent danger, and vacant structure and land.


Q: What is the definition of "imminent danger" according to the International Property Maintenance Code?
A: "Imminent danger" is defined as a condition which could cause serious or life-threatening injury or death at any time.


Q: What are some remedies available for a property owner of a condemned structure?
A: Remedies include obtaining a private demolition permit or repairing the structure to remove code violations.


Q: How is the cost of a permit calculated according to the PLI fee schedule?
A: The cost of a permit is calculated based on the total construction value of the project.


Q: What types of permit types are eligible for expedited plan review services?
A: Expedited plan review services are only offered for fire alarm and fire suppression permit types.


Q: What change occurred to the fees collected for the Pennsylvania Code Official Training Fund in 2017?
A: The fees increased from $4.00 to $4.50, authorized by Act 37 of 2017.


Q: When did the fee increase for the Pennsylvania Code Official Training Fund become effective?
A: The fee increase became effective on October 25, 2017.


Q: What should applicants do if the construction value changes between application and permit issuance?
A: If the construction value changes, the total cost of the permit may also change, and applicants should adjust accordingly.

Q: How is the cost of a permit calculated?
A: The cost of a permit is calculated based on the total construction value of the project.


Q: What happens if the construction value changes between application and permit issuance?
A: The total cost of the permit may change if the construction value changes between application and permit issuance.


Q: What types of permits currently offer expedited review services?
A: Expedited review services are currently offered only for fire alarm and fire suppression permit types.


Q: When did the fees for the Pennsylvania Code Official Training Fund increase, and by how much?
A: The fees increased from $4.00 to $4.50 effective October 25, 2017.


Q: What legislation authorized the increase in fees collected by municipalities for construction or building permits?
A: Governor Wolf signed Act 37 of 2017 authorizing the increase.


Q: Under which code is construction in Pennsylvania, including Pittsburgh, regulated?
A: Construction is regulated under the Pennsylvania Construction Code Act, also known as the Uniform Construction Code (UCC).


Q: Which codes are currently adopted under the PCCA/UCC?
A: The 2018 base and 2018 accessibility codes are currently adopted.


Q: Where can one find information about the Pittsburgh amendments to the UCC?
A: Information is documented under section 1002 of the Pittsburgh City Code.


Q: Which department should be consulted for plumbing code permits and regulations in Pittsburgh?
A: The Allegheny County Health Department’s plumbing program should be consulted.


Q: What resources offer free access to codes and standards?
A: The International Code Council (ICC) and the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) offer free access to their codes and standards.

Q: What act regulates construction in Pennsylvania, including the city of Pittsburgh?
A: The Pennsylvania Construction Code Act or PA Act No. 45 of 1999 regulates construction in Pennsylvania, including the city of Pittsburgh.


Q: What codes are currently adopted under the PCCA/UCC?
A: The 2018 base and 2018 accessibility codes are currently adopted under the PCCA/UCC.


Q: Where is the City of Pittsburgh's adoption and amendment of the UCC documented?
A: It is documented under section 1002 of the Pittsburgh City Code.


Q: Does the PLI enforce the plumbing code provisions of the UCC?
A: No, the PLI does not enforce the plumbing code provisions of the UCC.


Q: Where can one find information on plumbing code permits and regulations in Pittsburgh?
A: Information can be found through the Allegheny County Health Department’s Plumbing Program.


Q: Which organizations provide free access to codes and standards?
A: The International Code Council (ICC) and the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) provide free access to codes and standards.


Q: What does the UCC adopt in whole or part?
A: The UCC adopts the International Code Council’s (ICC) I-Codes in whole or part.


Q: How are local amendments to the UCC in Pittsburgh enforced?
A: They are enforced by PLI based on the code provision and/or topic.

Q: How must all appeal applications be submitted according to the text?
A: All appeal applications must be made electronically through the online OneStopPGH system.

A: You should create a OneStopPGH account if you do not have one.


Q: Who should be contacted to obtain a PIN number for connecting to legacy permit or license information?
A: You should contact pliapptech@pittsburghpa.gov to obtain a PIN number.


Q: What are the three reasons the Board of Appeals accepts variance requests?
A: The true intent of the uniform construction code was incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of the uniform construction code do not apply, and an equivalent form of construction is to be used.


Q: What is the purpose of the Board of License and Inspection Review (LIR)?
A: The LIR Board ensures independent oversight of license and property maintenance inspection determinations made by the PLI's license officer and code officials.


Q: What actions can the LIR Board take after hearing an appeal?
A: The LIR Board can affirm, modify, reverse, vacate, or revoke the notice, order, or action from which an appeal is taken.

A: Appeals for zoning violations should go through the Zoning Board of Adjustment.

A: PLI is the enforcement arm for the zoning and development review division of city planning.

A: Appeals for zoning violations should be directed to the Zoning Board of Adjustment.

A: All appeal applications must be submitted electronically through the online OneStopPGH system.

A: If you do not have a OneStopPGH account, you should create one.


Q: For what reasons can a variance request be filed with the Board of Appeals?
A: A variance request can be filed if the true intent of the uniform construction code was incorrectly interpreted, the provisions do not apply, or an equivalent form of construction is to be used.


Q: What is the purpose of the Board of License and Inspection Review (LIR)?
A: The purpose of the LIR Board is to ensure independent oversight of the license and property maintenance inspection determinations.

A: Customers can connect to legacy permit or license information by contacting pliapptech@pittsburghpa.gov to obtain a PIN number.


Q: What does the Board of License and Inspection Review (LIR) adjudicate?
A: The LIR Board adjudicates appeals of orders, decisions, or determinations related to business licensing and the International Property Maintenance Code of the Pittsburgh City Code.

A: The PLI acts as the enforcement arm for the zoning and development review division of city planning.

A: A PIN number obtained by contacting pliapptech@pittsburghpa.gov is required to create a OneStopPGH portal account.

Q: What is the purpose of the Board of License and Inspection Review (LIR Board)?
A: The LIR Board ensures independent oversight of license and property maintenance inspection determinations made by PLI's license officer and code officials.


Q: What does the LIR Board adjudicate?
A: The LIR Board adjudicates appeals of orders, decisions, or determinations related to Title VII, business licensing, and Title X, Building, Chapter 1004, International Property Maintenance Code of the Pittsburgh City Code.


Q: What actions can the LIR Board take after hearing an appeal?
A: The LIR Board can affirm, modify, reverse, vacate, or revoke the notice, order, or action from which an appeal is taken.


Q: Where should appeals for zoning violations be directed?
A: Appeals for zoning violations should go through the Zoning Board of Adjustment.


Q: What change is happening to the building and development application process starting June 12th, 2024?
A: The new Building & Development Application will replace the current zoning development review application and building permit application, consolidating them into a single, unified application.


Q: What are some benefits of the new Building & Development Application (BDA)?
A: Benefits include simplified prompts requiring no expertise in construction, inter-agency review and coordination, and the ability to add multiple co-applicants.


Q: What happened to the zoning development review (ZDR) application with the introduction of the BDA?
A: The ZDR application reviews are now incorporated into the BDA, eliminating the need to apply twice for the same scope.


Q: What improvements are included in the new customer portal upgrade announced on April 26th, 2024?
A: Improvements include modern design standards, better hosting for faster loading and stability, multi-device support, and upcoming automatic language translation.


Q: When did the customer portal upgrade go live?
A: The customer portal upgrade went live on Monday, March 25th.


Q: What will the new tutorials for the upgraded customer portal provide?
A: The new tutorials will provide guidance on using the upgraded customer portal.

Q: When did the new Building & Development Application replace the current zoning development review and building permit applications?
A: June 12th, 2024.


Q: What does the new Building & Development Application consolidate?
A: It consolidates the building permit and zoning application into a single, unified application.


Q: What are some benefits of the new Building & Development Application (BDA)?
A: It requires no expertise in the construction process, uses simplified prompts, includes inter-agency review and coordination, allows co-applicants, and eliminates the need for a separate zoning development review application.

A: A new customer portal upgrade.

A: Modern design standards for accessibility, better hosting for faster loading and stability, multi-device support, and upcoming automatic language translation.


Q: What does the ability to add co-applicants to the Building & Development Application allow?
A: It allows anyone to respond to requests for more information or provide revisions.

A: The BDA is designed to replace the current zoning development review application and building permit application.


Q: When did the Building & Development Application (BDA) go into effect?
A: The BDA went into effect on June 12th, 2024.

A: Benefits include no expertise needed in the construction process, inter-agency review and coordination, and the ability to add multiple co-applicants.

A: The reviews associated with the ZDR are now incorporated into the BDA, removing the need to apply twice for the same scope.

A: The customer portal upgrade was announced on April 26th, 2024.


Q: What are some features of the upgraded OneStopPGH customer portal?
A: Features include modern design standards, better hosting for faster loading, multi-device support, and upcoming automatic language translation.

Q: What is the Pittsburgh Digital Equity Coalition (PDEC)?
A: PDEC is a working group announced in October 2022 to promote digital equity in Pittsburgh.


Q: What are the four areas of need identified by the PDEC for digital equity programming?
A: High-quality, affordable broadband internet services; computing devices that meet needs; internet skills, knowledge, and literacy; and accessible technical support.


Q: What percentage of Pittsburgh households have a broadband subscription according to the 2022 American Community Survey data?
A: 86.5% of households have a broadband subscription.


Q: What is a major reason households do not subscribe to broadband, according to surveys?
A: Affordability is the biggest reason households do not subscribe to broadband.


Q: What is the percentage of senior households in Pittsburgh with a broadband subscription?
A: 70.8% of senior households have a broadband subscription.


Q: What percentage of Pittsburgh households do not have a laptop, desktop, or tablet computer?
A: 17.6% of households do not have a laptop, desktop, or tablet computer.


Q: What report highlighted the disproportionate disconnection of certain groups in Pittsburgh?
A: A 2022 Southwestern Pennsylvania Commission report on equitable broadband access.

Q: Who announced the Pittsburgh Digital Equity Coalition (PDEC) in October 2022?
A: City of Pittsburgh Mayor Ed Gainey and County Executive Rich Fitzgerald announced the Pittsburgh Digital Equity Coalition (PDEC).


Q: What are the four areas of greatest need identified by PDEC for digital equity programming?
A: High quality, affordable broadband internet services; computing devices that meet their needs; internet skills, knowledge, and literacy; and accessible technical support.


Q: What percentage of Pittsburgh households had a broadband subscription as of 2022?
A: 86.5% of households in Pittsburgh had a broadband subscription.


Q: What percentage of senior households in Pittsburgh had a broadband subscription according to 2022 data?
A: 70.8% of senior households (over 65 years old) had a broadband subscription.


Q: What percentage of Pittsburgh households making less than $20,000 annually had a broadband subscription as of 2022?
A: 71.1% of households making less than $20,000 annually had a broadband subscription.


Q: What percentage of Pittsburgh households do not have a laptop, desktop, or tablet computer?
A: 17.6% of households in Pittsburgh do not have a laptop, desktop, or tablet computer.


Q: Which groups are disproportionately disconnected from broadband access according to a 2022 report?
A: Seniors, families with k-12 students, and black citizens are disproportionately disconnected.


Q: What is identified as the biggest reason households do not subscribe to broadband?
A: Affordability is identified as the biggest reason households do not subscribe to broadband.


Q: What major contributing factor affects computer usage according to the text?
A: A lack of understanding for how to use a computer is a major contributing factor.


Q: What does the Pittsburgh Digital Equity Coalition plan to address in their strategic plan?
A: The plan addresses gaps in digital skills, low-cost high-speed internet services, access to devices, and technical assistance.

Q: What is the biggest reason households do not subscribe to broadband?
A: Affordability is the biggest reason households do not subscribe to broadband.


Q: What major contributing factor affects broadband subscription aside from affordability?
A: A lack of understanding of how to use a computer is a major contributing factor.


Q: Which populations are disproportionately disconnected from broadband according to the 2022 Southwestern Pennsylvania Commission report?
A: Seniors, families with K-12 students, and black citizens are disproportionately disconnected.


Q: What percentage of households in Pittsburgh have a broadband subscription as of 2022?
A: 86.5% of households in Pittsburgh have a broadband subscription.


Q: What percentage of senior households in Pittsburgh have a broadband subscription?
A: Only 70.8% of senior households (over 65 years old) have a broadband subscription.


Q: What percentage of Pittsburgh households making less than $20,000 annually have a broadband subscription?
A: Only 71.1% of households making less than $20,000 annually have a broadband subscription.


Q: What percentage of households in Pittsburgh do not have a laptop, desktop, or tablet computer?
A: 17.6% of households in Pittsburgh do not have a laptop, desktop, or tablet computer.


Q: Who announced the Pittsburgh Digital Equity Coalition (PDEC) in October 2022?
A: City of Pittsburgh Mayor Ed Gainey and County Executive Rich Fitzgerald announced the PDEC.


Q: What are the four areas of greatest need identified by the PDEC for digital equity programming?
A: High-quality, affordable broadband internet services; computing devices that meet their needs; internet skills, knowledge, and literacy; accessible technical support.


Q: What is the role of the Pittsburgh Digital Equity Coalition (PDEC)?
A: The PDEC is a working group of anchor organizations and community groups promoting digital equity and addressing community needs.

A: To assist residents and maintain high standards of service excellence.

Q: What is the mission of the Department of Public Works?
A: The mission is to operate and maintain infrastructure while providing essential services for everyday life, regional economic growth, and environmental sustainability.


Q: What services does the Department of Public Works provide to preserve the city's infrastructure?
A: The department maintains city streets, preserves park facilities, and rehabilitates public facilities.


Q: How does the Department of Public Works address the environmental needs of Pittsburgh?
A: By collecting residential refuse and recyclables, managing an anti-litter division, and monitoring illegal dumpsites.


Q: What division of the Department of Public Works is responsible for arboricultural services?
A: The Forestry Division.


Q: How does the Department of Public Works ensure the safety of residents and city visitors?
A: By responding to emergencies such as flooding, land subsidence, snow/ice storms, and other weather-related catastrophes.

Q: What is the mission of Pittsburgh's Environmental Services?  
A: The mission is to establish and maintain a refuse and recycling system that promotes a safe, litter-free, and environmentally friendly city.


Q: What services does the Public Works department provide in Pittsburgh?  
A: Public Works maintains city streets, preserves park facilities, rehabilitates public facilities, collects residential refuse and recyclables, and responds to emergencies.


Q: How does Pittsburgh's Public Works department address illegal dumping?  
A: They tackle illegal dumping through prevention, education, abatement, and enforcement.


Q: What requirement is there for special events in Pittsburgh regarding recycling?  
A: Organizers of special events expecting 200 or more individuals per day must separate recyclables from municipal waste.


Q: What does the forestry division of Public Works in Pittsburgh do?  
A: They provide prompt, efficient, and safe delivery of arboricultural services.


Q: How does Pittsburgh's Environmental Services aim to promote an environmentally friendly city?  
A: By providing residential pick-up, drop-off resources, and commercial recycling services.

A: Residents can access a collection schedule, recycling tips, a landlord letter, a recycling decal download, and a waste and recycling fact sheet.


Q: What emergencies does the Public Works department respond to in Pittsburgh?  
A: They respond to emergencies such as flooding, land subsidence, snow/ice storms, and other weather-related catastrophes.

Q: What is the mission of Pittsburgh's Environmental Services?
A: The mission is to establish and maintain a refuse and recycling system that promotes a safe, litter-free, and environmentally friendly city for all residents and customers.


Q: What are the main strategies used by Environmental Services to achieve their goals?
A: The strategies include residential pick-up, drop-off resources, commercial recycling, and enforcement of recycling requirements.


Q: What requirement is there for organizers of special events in Pittsburgh?
A: Organizers of special events expecting 200 or more individuals per day are required to separate recyclables from municipal waste.

A: Resources include a collection schedule, landlord waste and recycling fact sheet, recycling FAQs, and downloadable recycling decals.

Q: What is the primary role of the Zoning Division in Pittsburgh?
A: The primary role of the Zoning Division is to administer the city of Pittsburgh zoning code and historic preservation code.


Q: What does the Zoning Division regulate in Pittsburgh?
A: The Zoning Division regulates land use, interior/exterior renovations, additions/expansions, new construction, zone changes, zoning code text amendments, public realm design, local historic designations, consolidations, and subdivisions.


Q: What is the intent of the zoning regulations in Pittsburgh?
A: The intent of zoning regulations is to allow property owners the reasonable use of their property insofar as the use is not detrimental to abutting properties or the neighborhood.


Q: Where can the Pittsburgh zoning code and historic preservation code be found?
A: The Pittsburgh zoning code (Title 9) and historic preservation code (Title 11) are hosted by General Code.

Q: What are the three levels of zoning review in Pittsburgh?
A: Basic zoning review, site plan review, and zoning review with planning commission.


Q: What typically falls under basic zoning review?
A: Small projects like chicken coops, most single-family dwellings, signs (excluding high wall and public destination facility signs), exterior HVAC equipment, generators, ground-mounted solar panels, and sidewalk cafes.


Q: What types of projects typically require site plan review?
A: Mid-sized projects and projects in environmentally sensitive areas such as single-family dwellings in parks or hillside zoning districts, multi-family dwellings, non-residential and some residential projects in neighborhood business districts, and parking lots.


Q: What types of projects typically require planning commission review?
A: Large projects and projects in high visibility areas such as new construction, significant exterior renovations in certain zoning districts, high wall signs, public destination facility signs, and developments impacting steep slopes.


Q: What document do projects typically receive after successfully completing the zoning review process?
A: The Record of Zoning Approval (ROZA).


Q: Where can zoning and development review applications be submitted in Pittsburgh?
A: Through the OneStopPGH online portal.


Q: What is required if the project location in Pittsburgh does not have a valid address?
A: An address request application must be successfully completed and an address verification letter issued.

Q: What determines if a project requires a professionally stamped plan?
A: The survey requirements website is used to determine if a project requires a professionally stamped plan.


Q: What type of projects typically require a site plan review?
A: Mid-sized projects and projects in environmentally sensitive areas, such as single-family dwellings in parks or hillside zoning districts, multi-family dwellings, and non-residential projects in neighborhood business districts.


Q: Which zoning districts require planning commission review for new construction and significant exterior renovations?
A: The GT (Golden Triangle), OPR (Oakland Public Realm), GPR (Grandview Public Realm), UPR (Uptown Public Realm), EMI (Educational/Medical Institution), RIV (Riverfront), and SP (Specially Planned) zoning districts.

A: A zoning and development review application is required for all development review projects.

A: Applications can be submitted through the OneStopPGH online portal or at the OneStopPGH counter in Pittsburgh, PA.


Q: What happens if a project location does not have a valid address?
A: Final approval will not be issued until an address request application has been successfully completed and an address verification letter has been issued.

A: The Record of Zoning Approval (ROZA) is typically received.

A: Basic zoning review, site plan review, and zoning review with planning commission.


Q: What type of projects typically require basic zoning review?
A: Small projects such as chicken coops, most single-family dwellings in residential zoning districts, signs (excluding high wall and public destination facility signs), exterior HVAC equipment, and sidewalk cafes.


Q: What additional reviews might be required beyond zoning review?
A: Additional reviews may include construction management plan review, design review, historic staff review, floodplain review, geotechnical review, stormwater management review, transportation review, and others.


Q: What fees are associated with planning commission review?
A: Planning commission review, hearing, and notice fees apply.


Q: What is necessary to apply for appropriate permits after zoning review approval?
A: The Record of Zoning Approval (ROZA) and any other required documentation must be submitted to the Department of Permits, Licenses, and Inspections.

A: All development review projects, including signs, require a zoning and development review application, which can be submitted through the OneStopPGH online portal.


Q: Where can hard copy applications and checks be submitted for zoning reviews?
A: Hard copy applications and checks can be mailed or dropped off at the OneStopPGH counter, 412 Boulevard of the Allies, Pittsburgh, PA 15219.


Q: What are the three levels of zoning review?
A: The three levels of zoning review are basic zoning review, site plan review, and zoning review with planning commission.


Q: What types of projects typically require site plan review?
A: Site plan review typically applies to mid-sized projects and projects in environmentally sensitive areas such as single-family dwellings in parks or hillside zoning districts, multi-family dwellings, non-residential and some residential projects in neighborhood business districts, and parking lots.


Q: What is the significance of the planning commission review?
A: Planning commission review is typically required for large projects and projects in high visibility areas, including new construction, additions, and significant exterior renovations in specific zoning districts, high wall signs, and developments impacting natural steep slopes.


Q: What document is typically received upon successful completion of the zoning review process?
A: Projects that successfully complete the zoning review process typically receive at least one approval document called the Record of Zoning Approval (ROZA).


Q: What additional reviews might be required for zoning development review applications?
A: Additional reviews may include construction management plan review, design review, historic staff review, floodplain review, geotechnical review, stormwater management review, and transportation review.

A: If a project location does not have a valid address, final approval will not be issued until an address request application has been successfully completed and an address verification letter has been issued.

Q: What types of projects typically require a basic zoning review?
A: Basic zoning review is typically required for small projects such as chicken coops, most single-family dwellings in residential zoning districts, signs (excluding high wall and public destination facility signs), exterior HVAC equipment or generators, some non-residential change of use with no exterior renovations, ground-mounted solar panels, and sidewalk cafes.


Q: What types of projects typically require a site plan review?
A: Site plan review is typically required for mid-sized projects and projects in environmentally sensitive areas, including single-family dwellings in parks or hillside zoning districts, multi-family dwellings, non-residential and some residential projects in neighborhood business districts, and parking lots.


Q: What types of projects typically require a planning commission review?
A: Planning commission review is typically required for large projects and projects in high visibility areas, such as new construction, additions, and significant exterior renovations in specific zoning districts, high wall signs, public destination facility signs, any development impacting a natural steep slope, and all project development plans and final land development plans.

A: After successfully completing the zoning review process, projects typically receive a Record of Zoning Approval (ROZA).

Q: What types of projects fall under basic zoning review?

Q: What is the inclusionary zoning ordinance?
A: A policy that ties the construction of affordable housing to market-rate housing in new or major renovation projects with 20 or more residential units.


Q: In which Pittsburgh neighborhoods is the inclusionary zoning ordinance applicable?
A: Lawrenceville, Bloomfield, Polish Hill, and Oakland (excluding the EMI zoning district).


Q: What percentage of units must be priced affordably under the inclusionary zoning ordinance?
A: 10% of the units.


Q: What is the maximum rent for a two-bedroom unit under the inclusionary zoning standards?
A: No more than $855.


Q: What is the maximum sale price for a two-bedroom home under the inclusionary zoning standards?
A: No more than $128,000.


Q: What is the purpose of inclusionary zoning according to the City of Pittsburgh?
A: To promote, produce, and preserve affordable housing options throughout the city.

Q: What does "affordable" mean in the context of inclusionary zoning?
A: "Affordable" means rent or sale prices are based on certain percentages of the area median income (AMI), set by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, and vary by household size.


Q: What percentage of AMI is used for for-rent inclusionary units?
A: For-rent inclusionary units are set aside for households earning no more than 50% of AMI.


Q: What percentage of AMI is used for for-sale inclusionary units?
A: For-sale inclusionary units are set aside for households earning no more than 80% of AMI.


Q: What is the maximum price for a two-bedroom unit under the inclusionary zoning standards?
A: A two-bedroom unit would rent for no more than $855, and a two-bedroom home would be listed for sale at no more than $128,000.


Q: Where is the inclusionary zoning ordinance currently applicable?
A: The inclusionary zoning ordinance is currently applicable in Lawrenceville, Bloomfield, Polish Hill, and Oakland (excluding the EMI zoning district).


Q: What is the purpose of inclusionary zoning (IZ)?
A: Inclusionary zoning ensures neighborhoods can offer new housing units by tying the construction of affordable housing to market-rate housing.


Q: What is the threshold for projects to apply inclusionary zoning?
A: Inclusionary zoning applies to new construction or major renovation projects that include 20 or more residential units.


Q: What percentage of units must be priced affordably in projects that meet the inclusionary zoning size threshold?
A: Projects must price 10% of units affordably, rounding up if necessary.

Q: What is the purpose of inclusionary zoning in Pittsburgh?
A: Inclusionary zoning in Pittsburgh ties the construction of affordable housing to that of market-rate housing to ensure neighborhoods offer new housing units.


Q: What percentage of units must be priced affordably in projects with inclusionary zoning?
A: Projects meeting the size threshold must price 10% of units affordably.


Q: What areas currently have the inclusionary zoning ordinance in Pittsburgh?
A: The inclusionary zoning ordinance is applicable in Lawrenceville, Bloomfield, Polish Hill, and Oakland (excluding the EMI zoning district).


Q: How are "affordable" rent or sale prices determined in Pittsburgh's inclusionary zoning?
A: Prices are based on certain percentages of the Area Median Income (AMI), defined by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.


Q: What is the maximum rent for a two-bedroom unit under Pittsburgh's inclusionary zoning standards?
A: A two-bedroom unit would rent for no more than $855.


Q: What is the maximum sale price for a two-bedroom home under Pittsburgh's inclusionary zoning standards?
A: A two-bedroom home would be listed for sale at no more than $128,000.


Q: What income level must households not exceed to qualify for for-rent inclusionary units in Pittsburgh?
A: Households must earn no more than 50% of the Area Median Income (AMI).


Q: What income level must households not exceed to qualify for for-sale inclusionary units in Pittsburgh?
A: Households must earn no more than 80% of the Area Median Income (AMI).


Q: What document outlines Pittsburgh's housing needs as of 2022?
A: The City of Pittsburgh Housing Needs Assessment (2022).


Q: What is the role of the GIS division in Pittsburgh's Department of Innovation and Performance?
A: The GIS division provides data and analysis services and maintains interactive web applications for data sharing and standardized use.


Q: What is the maximum rent for a studio/efficiency unit at 30% of AMI according to HUD's 2023 adjusted home income limits?
A: The maximum rent for a studio/efficiency unit at 30% of AMI is $528.

Q: What must be obtained from the city's GIS team before any permit application can be reviewed or issued in Pittsburgh?
A: An address must be obtained from the city's GIS team.


Q: What services does the GIS division of the Department of Innovation and Performance provide?
A: The GIS division provides data and analysis services to city departments and authorities.


Q: How is GIS data provided to users?
A: GIS data is provided to internal and external users through an easy-to-use interface via interactive web applications.


Q: What does the GIS team incorporate into their workflow for better data sharing?
A: The GIS team incorporates open data into their workflow.


Q: What is the focus of the GIS team's collaboration with outside agencies?
A: The focus is on establishing critical authoritative data with greater accuracy.


Q: What type of maps and data can be viewed through GIS resources?
A: GIS open data and historic 200 scale maps can be viewed.


Q: What kind of links and resources are accessible through GIS?
A: A variety of links and resources, including regional and census data, are accessible.


Q: What tools has the GIS team created to serve Pittsburgh residents?
A: The GIS team has created mapping tools.


Q: Where can information about submitting a new street name request be obtained?
A: Information about submitting a new street name request can be obtained from the GIS team.

Q: What types of maps are available for download from the GIS section?
A: The available downloadable maps include 1984 200 scale lot and block maps (zip, 63mb) and 1984 200 scale topography maps (zip, 65mb).


Q: Which department's GIS team created mapping tools for Pittsburgh residents?
A: The GIS team of the Department of Innovation & Performance created mapping tools for Pittsburgh residents.


Q: What should users do regarding interactive map URLs?
A: Users should update their bookmarks because the interactive map URLs have been upgraded to a new server.


Q: What types of administrative maps are included in the interactive tools?
A: Administrative maps include the City of Pittsburgh index map, zoning & parcel maps, neighborhoods, wards & voting districts, city council districts, and Pittsburgh public school board districts.


Q: What transportation-related maps are available in the interactive tools?
A: Transportation-related maps include DOMI road obstructions, residential permit parking, parking meters, and street ownership maps.


Q: What community-related information can be found in the interactive maps?
A: Community-related information includes Pittsburgh historic maps, neighborhood planners, city steps, and community development block grant eligible areas.


Q: Which institutions provide GIS links and resources mentioned in the text?
A: GIS links and resources are provided by the Allegheny County GIS Division, Western Pennsylvania Regional Data Center, Pennsylvania Spatial Data Access, and University of Pittsburgh's digital historic maps.

Q: What type of maps has the GIS team of the Department of Innovation & Performance created for Pittsburgh residents?
A: The GIS team created administrative, transportation, community, and environment maps.

A: Users should acknowledge the City of Pittsburgh as a source when using the data in reports, papers, publications, maps, and other products.

A: No, the databases should not be redistributed to any other parties to ensure appropriate documentation and data limitations are provided.

Q: What must be obtained before any permit application can be reviewed or issued in Pittsburgh?
A: An address must be obtained from the city's GIS team.


Q: How long does it typically take for an address assignment in Pittsburgh?
A: Address assignment may take anywhere from one day to two weeks.


Q: What is the formula used for address assignment in Pittsburgh?
A: One address per 11 linear feet, or the closest number of feet to 11 if insufficient footage is available.


Q: Who should be contacted for address assignments in Pittsburgh?
A: The City GIS Department of Innovation and Performance at 604 City-County Building, 414 Grant St., Pittsburgh, PA 15219.

A: The entire review time takes an average of three months.

Q: What happens after a new street name request is reviewed in Pittsburgh?
A: Legislation is drawn up and sent to City Council for approval, and final approval is obtained from the Mayor’s Office.

A: (412) 255-2431

A: The applicant submits a new street name request to the GIS team.

A: Street application instructions (PDF, 306KB) and a street application (PDF, 389KB, a fillable form).

A: The GIS team reviews the request.


Q: What happens after the GIS team completes the review and verification process for a new street name?
A: Legislation is drawn up and sent to the city council for approval.


Q: Where is the final approval for a new street name obtained from?
A: The mayor’s office.


Q: How long does the entire review process for a new street name request typically take?
A: An average of three months.
