Q: What are household hazardous wastes (HHW)?
A: Wastes produced in households that are hazardous in nature but not regulated as hazardous waste under federal and state laws.

Q: What does the City of Pittsburgh do with used Christmas trees?
A: The City of Pittsburgh recycles used Christmas trees into free, natural, and environmentally friendly pine mulch for all city residents.


Q: How many Christmas trees were recycled in Pittsburgh during the 2023/2024 season?
A: Over 2,308 trees were recycled.


Q: What are the dates for mulch pick-up at the Pittsburgh Zoo overflow parking lot in 2024?
A: Saturday, April 19th, and Saturday, April 26th.


Q: What are residents required to bring when picking up mulch at the Pittsburgh Zoo drop-off location?
A: Residents must bring their own buckets, gloves, and shovels.


Q: When can residents drop off their Christmas trees for recycling in Pittsburgh?
A: From December 26th through January 26th.


Q: Name three drop-off locations for Christmas tree recycling in Pittsburgh.
A: Sue Murray Swimming Pool Parking Lot, Jack Stack Swimming Pool, and Brookline Recreation Center.


Q: What should be removed from Christmas trees before dropping them off for recycling?
A: All decorations, plastic bags, and tree stands.


Q: What happens if Christmas trees are left at the curb in Pittsburgh?
A: They will be sent to the landfill.


Q: Which organizations offer a curbside pickup service for Christmas tree recycling in Pittsburgh?
A: Girl Scout troops and two BSA troops.


Q: What do the BSA troops do with the Christmas trees they collect?
A: They deliver the trees to Garfield to be used for goat food.

Q: Where is the mulch pick-up location for the Pittsburgh Zoo Christmas tree recycling program?
A: The mulch pick-up location is the Pittsburgh Zoo overflow parking lot (parking area to the right) at 7370 Baker Street, Pittsburgh, PA 15206.


Q: On which dates can residents pick up mulch at the Pittsburgh Zoo location?
A: Residents can pick up mulch on Saturday, April 19th, and Saturday, April 26th, from dawn until dusk or while supplies last.


Q: What should participants bring when picking up mulch at the Pittsburgh Zoo location?
A: Participants should bring their own buckets, gloves, and shovels.


Q: During which dates does the Christmas tree recycling event run?
A: The event runs from December 26th through January 26th.


Q: What is the purpose of recycling Christmas trees in Pittsburgh?
A: The purpose is to recycle them into free, natural, and environmentally friendly pine mulch for city residents.


Q: How many trees were recycled in the 2023/2024 season in Pittsburgh?
A: Over 2,308 trees were recycled.


Q: What should be removed from Christmas trees before dropping them off for recycling?
A: All decorations, plastic bags, and tree stands should be removed.


Q: What will happen to trees left at the curb?
A: Trees left at the curb will be sent to the landfill.


Q: Which organizations are involved in the Christmas tree recycling curbside pickup service in Pittsburgh?
A: Girl Scout troops and two BSA troops are involved in the service.


Q: What is the use of trees collected by BSA troops from Stanton Heights, Garfield, and Bloomfield?
A: The trees will be delivered to Garfield to be used for goat food.


Q: What guide is available for making holiday plans more sustainable?
A: The PRC's Holiday Greening Guide (PDF, 7MB) is available for more information.

Q: What should be removed from Christmas trees before recycling them in Pittsburgh?
A: All decorations, plastic bags, and tree stands should be removed.


Q: What happens if you leave your Christmas tree at the curb in Pittsburgh?
A: It will be sent to the landfill.


Q: Which neighborhoods are included in the Girl Scout Christmas tree recycling pickup in Pittsburgh?
A: Morningside, Highland Park, Larimer, East Liberty, Friendship, Shadyside, Point Breeze, Point Breeze North, Squirrel Hill North, Squirrel Hill South, and Greenfield.


Q: What is the purpose of the Christmas tree recycling organized by Girl Scout troops in Pittsburgh?
A: To take trees to designated drop-off centers where they will be mulched and not end up in the landfill.


Q: How many Christmas trees were recycled in Pittsburgh during the 2023/2024 season?
A: Over 2,308 trees.


Q: Where can residents of Pittsburgh pick up mulch from recycled Christmas trees?
A: At the Pittsburgh Zoo overflow parking lot, 7370 Baker Street, Pittsburgh, PA 15206.


Q: What are the dates for mulch pickup at the Pittsburgh Zoo location?
A: Saturday, April 19th, and Saturday, April 26th.


Q: What is the timeframe for the Christmas tree recycling event in Pittsburgh?
A: From December 26th through January 26th.


Q: What is the location for Christmas tree drop-off in Highland Park, Pittsburgh?
A: Highland Park Zoo, 7370 Baker Street.


Q: What is the goal of the plastic bag ban and paper bag fee in Pittsburgh?
A: To foster a clean and sustainable community by reducing waste and litter.


Q: What is the minimum charge for paper bags under Pittsburgh's ordinance?
A: At least 10¢.


Q: Who does the plastic bag ban and paper bag fee apply to in Pittsburgh?
A: All businesses located within Pittsburgh city limits that sell or distribute food and/or other products to the public.

Q: What types of businesses does the plastic bag ban and paper bag fee apply to?
A: The ban and fee apply to businesses within Pittsburgh city limits that sell or distribute food and/or other products to the public, including supermarkets, convenience stores, gas stations, department stores, dollar stores, clothing stores, restaurants, food trucks, farmers’ markets, festivals, and cafeterias.


Q: What must businesses do to comply with the plastic bag ordinance?
A: Businesses must discontinue distributing plastic carryout bags, charge at least 10¢ for paper bags, educate staff on the ban and fee, inform customers with signs, and ensure receipts list bag charges as a separate line item.


Q: Are any types of plastic bags exempt from the ordinance?
A: Yes, the ordinance does not apply to bags used solely for unwrapped prepared food or bakery goods, uncooked meats or fish, flowers, potted plants, dry cleaning, medication, or loose bulk items like fruits and vegetables.


Q: What happens if a business violates the ordinance?
A: An inspector will issue a warning, return after 30 days to check for compliance, and if necessary, give an additional 30 days before a final inspection. Fines of $100 for initial violations and $250 for subsequent violations may be imposed.


Q: What is the purpose of the mandatory paper bag fee?
A: The fee helps businesses offset the cost of paper bags, encourages customers to bring their own bags, and creates consistency in customer expectations and practices.


Q: Can businesses provide paper bags for free?
A: Yes, paper bags can be provided for free to customers paying with WIC, SNAP, or another type of EBT card.


Q: What are the requirements for compliant paper bags?
A: Compliant paper bags must contain no old-growth fiber and be made from at least 40% post-consumer recycled content.


Q: How can customers avoid the paper bag fee?
A: Customers can avoid the fee by bringing their own bags or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: What should businesses do with leftover plastic bags?
A: Businesses should consider donating leftover plastic bags to organizations or businesses outside Pittsburgh city limits, such as food banks or nonprofit reuse stores.


Q: How can customers report a non-compliant business?
A: Customers can report non-compliant businesses by contacting the City of Pittsburgh 311 Response Center or filing an online request form under the "plastic bag ban compliance" request type.

Q: What types of bags can businesses provide under the ordinance?
A: Businesses can provide reusable bags and compliant paper bags containing at least 40% post-consumer recycled content and no old-growth fiber, with a 10¢ fee per bag.


Q: What is the fee for providing paper bags to customers?
A: A 10¢ fee must be charged for each paper bag provided to customers.


Q: Are businesses required to provide bags to customers?
A: No, businesses are not required to provide bags and may rely on customers to bring their own.


Q: Are compostable or biodegradable plastic bags allowed under the ordinance?
A: No, plastic bags labeled “compostable,” “biodegradable,” or "made from plants" are not allowed.


Q: What should businesses do with leftover plastic bags?
A: Businesses should consider donating leftover plastic bags to organizations or businesses outside of Pittsburgh city limits.


Q: What actions will inspectors take if a business violates the ordinance?
A: Inspectors will issue a warning, provide guidance, and offer assistance, then return after 30 days to check for corrections. If violations persist, a citation will be filed.


Q: What fines can be imposed for violations of the ordinance?
A: Fines are $100 for an initial violation and $250 for each subsequent violation, with each day of continued violation considered a separate offense.


Q: How can customers report a non-compliant business?
A: Customers can report non-compliant businesses by contacting the Pittsburgh 311 response center or filing an online request form under "plastic bag ban compliance."


Q: Where does the paper bag fee go?
A: Businesses keep the paper bag fee to help recoup additional costs associated with providing paper bags.


Q: How can customers avoid paying the paper bag fee?
A: Customers can avoid the fee by bringing their own bags or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: What is the purpose of the mandatory paper bag fee?
A: The fee helps offset costs for businesses, encourages customers to bring their own bags, and creates consistency in customer expectations.


Q: Who does the plastic bag ban and paper bag fee apply to?
A: The ordinance applies to all businesses within Pittsburgh city limits that sell or distribute food and/or other products to the public.

Q: Are retailers required to provide bags to customers?
A: No, retailers are not required to provide any bags and may rely on customers to bring their own or offer repurposed cardboard boxes.


Q: Are bags used to carry out leftovers at restaurants subject to the ordinance?
A: Yes, bags given to customers for carrying out packaged leftovers are subject to the policy.


Q: Are small carryout bags subject to the ordinance?
A: Yes, any bag not included on the exempt bags list is subject to the policy, regardless of size.


Q: Are compostable or biodegradable plastic bags allowed under the ordinance?
A: No, there is no exception for plastic bags labeled “compostable,” “biodegradable,” or "made from plants."


Q: What should businesses do with existing stock of plastic bags?
A: Businesses should consider donating leftover plastic bags to organizations or businesses outside of Pittsburgh city limits.


Q: Where does the paper bag fee go?
A: Businesses keep the fee to help recoup costs associated with providing paper bags.


Q: How can customers avoid the paper bag fee?
A: Customers can avoid the fee by bringing their own bag or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: Is it safe to use reusable bags?
A: Yes, reusable bags can be used safely with basic cleaning practices.


Q: How can a customer report a non-compliant business?
A: Customers can report non-compliance by contacting the Pittsburgh 311 response center or filing an online request form.


Q: Why did Pittsburgh ban plastic bags and mandate a fee for paper bags?
A: The ordinance aims to foster a clean and sustainable community by reducing waste and litter.


Q: What are the fines for violating the plastic bag ordinance?
A: Fines are $100 for an initial violation and $250 for each subsequent violation. Each day a violation continues may be considered another violation.

Q: What is the primary reason for banning plastic bags in Pittsburgh?
A: Plastic bags are banned because they are made from non-renewable resources, often used just once, hard to recycle, do not biodegrade, and contribute to litter and pollution.


Q: What fee must be charged for paper bags in Pittsburgh?
A: A fee of at least 10¢ must be charged for each paper bag provided to customers.


Q: To whom does the plastic bag ban and paper bag fee ordinance apply?
A: The ordinance applies to businesses within Pittsburgh city limits that sell or distribute food and/or other products to the public.


Q: Are businesses required to provide bags under the ordinance?
A: No, retailers are not required to provide any bags and may choose to rely on customers to bring their own.


Q: What should businesses do if they have leftover plastic bags?
A: Businesses are encouraged to donate leftover plastic bags to organizations or stores outside of Pittsburgh city limits.


Q: What actions should businesses take to comply with the ordinance?
A: Businesses should discontinue plastic bags, charge for paper bags, update point-of-sale systems, educate staff, and inform customers about the changes.


Q: What are the consequences for businesses not complying with the ordinance?
A: Non-compliant businesses may receive a warning, followed by fines of $100 for the initial violation and $250 for subsequent violations.


Q: Are there any exceptions to the plastic bag ban?
A: Yes, bags used solely for unwrapped prepared food, bakery goods, uncooked meats, fish, flowers, potted plants, dry cleaning, medication, or loose bulk items are exempt.


Q: Can businesses provide paper bags for free to certain customers?
A: Yes, paper bags can be provided for free to customers paying with WIC, SNAP, or another type of EBT card.


Q: How can customers avoid the paper bag fee?
A: Customers can avoid the fee by bringing their own bags or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: What should be included on receipts regarding the paper bag fee?
A: Receipts must list the paper bag fee as a separate line item, labeled as “carry-out bag charge” or similar wording.


Q: How can customers report a business that is not complying with the ordinance?
A: Customers can report non-compliance to the City of Pittsburgh 311 response center or file an online request form.

Q: What types of bags are exempt from the plastic bag ban and paper bag fee?
A: Bags used solely to contain unwrapped prepared food, bakery goods, uncooked meats or fish, flowers, potted plants, dry cleaning, medication, and loose bulk items like fruit, vegetables, grains, nuts, and candy are exempt.


Q: What is the penalty for an initial violation of the plastic bag ordinance?
A: $100 for the initial violation.


Q: How often can violations of the ordinance be considered separate offenses?
A: Every day violations continue may be considered another violation.


Q: What must businesses do to comply with the paper bag fee requirement?
A: Businesses must charge at least 10¢ for each paper bag provided.


Q: What must businesses include on receipts regarding the paper bag fee?
A: The charges for paper bags must be listed as a separate line item on receipts.


Q: Who keeps the paper bag fee collected by businesses?
A: Businesses keep the fee to help recoup costs associated with providing paper bags.


Q: Are retailers required to provide bags to customers?
A: No, retailers are not required to provide any bags and may choose to rely on customers to bring their own.


Q: Can plastic bags labeled "compostable" or "biodegradable" be used under the ordinance?
A: No, there is no exception for plastic bags labeled “compostable” or “biodegradable.”


Q: How can customers avoid paying the paper bag fee?
A: Customers can avoid the fee by bringing their own bags or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: What should businesses do with leftover plastic bags?
A: Businesses should consider donating leftover plastic bags to organizations or businesses outside of Pittsburgh city limits.


Q: How can customers report a non-compliant business?
A: Customers can report a non-compliant business by contacting the City of Pittsburgh 311 response center or filing an online request form.


Q: What is the purpose of the mandatory paper bag fees?
A: The fees help businesses offset costs, encourage customers to bring their own bags, and create consistency for businesses and customers.

Q: What happens if a business continues to operate out of compliance with the ordinance after the third inspection?
A: Inspectors will file a citation and the following fines can be applied: $100 for an initial violation and $250 for each subsequent violation.


Q: What types of bags can businesses provide under the ordinance?
A: Businesses can provide reusable bags and compliant paper bags, which must contain no old-growth fiber and be made from at least 40% post-consumer recycled content.


Q: Are businesses required to provide bags to customers?
A: No, businesses are not required to provide bags and may choose to rely on customers to bring their own bags or offer alternatives like repurposed cardboard boxes.


Q: Are bags labeled “compostable” or “biodegradable” allowed under the ordinance?
A: No, there is no exception for plastic bags labeled “compostable,” “biodegradable,” or "made from plants."


Q: How can customers avoid the paper bag fee?
A: Customers can avoid the fee by bringing their own bag to the store or restaurant or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: Where does the paper bag fee go?
A: Businesses keep the fee to help recoup additional costs associated with providing paper bags; some may choose to donate the fee to a local non-profit.


Q: What should businesses do with leftover plastic bags?
A: Businesses should consider donating leftover plastic bags to organizations outside of Pittsburgh city limits, such as food banks or nonprofit reuse stores.


Q: How can customers report a non-compliant business?
A: Customers can report non-compliant businesses by contacting the City of Pittsburgh 311 response center and filing an online request form under the "plastic bag ban compliance" request type.


Q: What is the purpose of the paper bag fee?
A: The paper bag fee helps businesses offset the cost of paper bags, encourages customers to bring their own bags, and creates consistency for businesses and customers.


Q: What are the fines for violations of the ordinance?
A: The fines are $100 for an initial violation and $250 for each subsequent violation, with each day a violation continues considered a separate offense.

Q: What ordinance did the Pittsburgh City Council pass in April 2022?
A: The ordinance banning plastic bags and requiring at least a 10¢ charge for paper bags.


Q: Why are plastic bags considered problematic?
A: They are made from non-renewable resources, often used just once, hard to recycle, do not biodegrade, and they litter and clog storm drains and recycling machinery.


Q: What must businesses in Pittsburgh do to comply with the plastic bag ban?
A: Discontinue plastic carryout bags, charge at least 10¢ for paper bags, educate staff and customers, and update point-of-sale systems.


Q: What are businesses required to do with paper bags under the ordinance?
A: Charge at least 10¢ for each paper bag provided and ensure this charge is listed as a separate line item on receipts.


Q: Are there any exceptions to the plastic bag ban for certain types of bags?
A: Yes, the ban does not apply to bags used solely for unwrapped prepared food, uncooked meats or fish, flowers, potted plants, dry cleaning, medication, or loose bulk items.


Q: What happens if a business is found to be out of compliance with the ordinance?
A: An inspector will issue a warning, return after 30 days for re-inspection, and if non-compliance continues, file a citation with fines starting at $100.


Q: How can customers avoid the paper bag fee?
A: By bringing their own bags to the store or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: What should businesses do with leftover plastic bags?
A: Consider donating them to organizations or businesses outside of Pittsburgh city limits.


Q: What is the purpose of the paper bag fee?
A: To offset the cost of paper bags for businesses, encourage customers to bring their own bags, and create consistency for businesses and customers.


Q: How can someone report a non-compliant business regarding the plastic bag ban?
A: By contacting the City of Pittsburgh 311 response center or filing an online request form under the "plastic bag ban compliance" request type.


Q: What are the requirements for compliant paper bags?
A: They must contain no old-growth fiber and be made from at least 40% post-consumer recycled content.

Q: What types of businesses does the plastic bag ban and paper bag fee apply to in Pittsburgh?
A: It applies to businesses located within Pittsburgh city limits that sell or distribute food and/or other products to the public, including supermarkets, convenience stores, gas stations, department stores, dollar stores, clothing stores, restaurants, food trucks, farmers’ markets, festivals, and cafeterias.


Q: What actions must businesses take to comply with the ordinance?
A: Businesses must discontinue the distribution of plastic carryout bags, charge at least 10¢ for paper bags, educate staff, post informative signs, and ensure receipts include bag charges as a separate line item.


Q: What are the requirements for paper bags under this ordinance?
A: Paper bags must contain no old-growth fiber, be made from at least 40% post-consumer recycled content, and a 10¢ fee must be charged for each bag.


Q: Are there any exceptions to the plastic bag ban?
A: Yes, the ban does not apply to bags used solely to contain unwrapped prepared food, bakery goods, uncooked meats, fish, flowers, potted plants, dry cleaning, medication, or loose bulk items.


Q: What are the penalties for non-compliance with the ordinance?
A: Inspectors will issue a warning for initial violations, followed by a $100 fine for the first violation and $250 for subsequent violations. Each day a violation continues may be considered another violation.


Q: How can businesses ensure they are compliant with the ordinance?
A: Businesses can review the webpage for more information, use available guides, and contact bagban@pittsburghpa.gov for assistance.


Q: What should a business do with leftover plastic bags?
A: Businesses should consider donating their remaining stock to organizations or businesses outside of Pittsburgh city limits.


Q: How can customers avoid the paper bag fee?
A: Customers can avoid the fee by bringing their own bag or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: What resources are available to help businesses comply with the ordinance?
A: Available resources include a retailer compliance guide, a compliant bag supplier guide, and various signage templates.


Q: Who can customers contact to report a non-compliant business?
A: Customers can contact the City of Pittsburgh 311 response center or file an online request form under the "plastic bag ban compliance" request type.

Q: What types of bags can businesses provide under the ordinance?
A: Businesses can provide reusable bags and compliant paper bags containing at least 40% post-consumer recycled content and no old-growth fiber.


Q: What is the minimum fee that must be charged for paper bags?
A: A 10¢ fee must be charged for each paper bag provided to customers.


Q: Are businesses required to provide bags to customers?
A: No, retailers are not required to provide any bags and may rely on customers bringing their own bags.


Q: What is the purpose of the paper bag fee?
A: The paper bag fee helps businesses offset the cost of paper bags, encourages customers to bring their own bags, and creates consistency for businesses and customers.


Q: What types of bags are banned under the ordinance?
A: Plastic carryout bags, including those labeled "compostable" or "biodegradable," are banned.


Q: Are there any exceptions to the plastic bag ban?
A: The ban does not apply to bags used solely for containing unwrapped prepared food, bakery goods, uncooked meats, fish, flowers, potted plants, dry cleaning, medication, or loose bulk items.


Q: What steps must businesses take to comply with the ordinance?
A: Businesses must discontinue plastic bags, charge a fee for paper bags, educate staff and customers, and update point-of-sale systems to reflect the bag fee.


Q: What happens if a business violates the ordinance?
A: An inspector will issue a warning and provide guidance. If violations persist after 30 days, fines starting at $100 for the initial violation and $250 for subsequent violations may be imposed.


Q: How can customers avoid the paper bag fee?
A: Customers can avoid the fee by bringing their own bags or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: Where does the paper bag fee go?
A: The fee is kept by businesses to help cover the cost of providing paper bags.


Q: How can a non-compliant business be reported?
A: Customers can report non-compliant businesses to the Pittsburgh 311 Response Center or by calling 311 or 412-255-2621.


Q: Who does the ordinance apply to?
A: The ordinance applies to all businesses within Pittsburgh city limits that sell or distribute food and/or other products to the public.

Q: What is the minimum fee that must be charged for every paper bag provided to customers?
A: At least 10¢.


Q: Are businesses required to charge a paper bag fee to customers paying with WIC, SNAP, or EBT cards?
A: No, paper bags may be provided for free to these customers.


Q: What are the three main purposes of the mandatory paper bag fees?
A: To help offset the cost of paper bags, encourage customers to bring their own bags, and create consistency for businesses and customers.


Q: What types of bags does the plastic bag ban and paper bag fee not apply to?
A: Bags used solely to contain unwrapped prepared food or bakery goods, uncooked meats or fish, flowers, potted plants, dry cleaning, medication, or loose bulk items.


Q: What is the initial fine for a business violation of the ordinance?
A: $100.


Q: How long do businesses have to correct violations after the initial warning?
A: 30 days after the first inspection, and an additional 30 days if necessary after the second inspection.


Q: What types of plastic bags are included in the ban?
A: Plastic bags made from corn or other plant sources and labeled biodegradable or compostable.


Q: What resource is available to help businesses comply with the ordinance?
A: The Retailer Compliance Guide (pdf, 466kb).


Q: How are bag fees supposed to be handled on receipts?
A: Bag fees must be separately itemized on receipts.


Q: What is the penalty for subsequent violations after the initial fine?
A: $250 for subsequent violations.


Q: Where can businesses find vendors for compliant reusable or paper bags?
A: The Compliant Bag Supplier Guide (pdf, 183kb).

Q: What is the penalty for an initial violation of the ordinance?
A: $100 for an initial violation.


Q: How much is the fine for each subsequent violation?
A: $250 for each subsequent violation.


Q: Can each day a violation continues be considered a separate offense?
A: Yes, every day a violation continues may be considered a separate offense.


Q: What kinds of bags can businesses provide?
A: Businesses can provide reusable bags and compliant paper bags.


Q: What makes a paper bag compliant?
A: A paper bag is compliant if it contains no old-growth fiber and is made from at least 40% post-consumer recycled content.


Q: Is there a fee for providing paper bags?
A: Yes, a 10¢ fee must be charged for each paper bag.


Q: Are there any signage requirements for businesses regarding the ordinance?
A: There are no longer any requirements to post signage, but businesses are encouraged to inform customers that plastic bags cannot be provided and a 10¢ fee will be charged for each paper bag.


Q: Are retailers required to provide bags to customers?
A: No, retailers are not required to provide any bags and may rely on customers to bring their own or provide repurposed cardboard boxes.


Q: Are bags for carrying out leftovers at restaurants subject to the ordinance?
A: Yes, bags for carrying out packaged leftovers are subject to the policy.


Q: Are small carryout bags subject to the ordinance?
A: Yes, any bag not on the exempt bags list is subject to the policy, regardless of size.


Q: Are bags labeled "compostable" or "biodegradable" allowed under the ordinance?
A: No, there is no exception for plastic bags labeled "compostable," "biodegradable," or "made from plants."


Q: What should businesses do with existing stock of plastic bags?
A: Businesses should consider donating leftover plastic bags to organizations or businesses outside of Pittsburgh city limits.


Q: Where can additional questions about the ordinance be directed?
A: Additional questions can be directed to bagban@pittsburghpa.gov or (412) 514-4261.


Q: Where does the paper bag fee collected by businesses go?
A: Businesses keep the fee to recoup additional costs associated with providing paper bags; some may donate the fee to a local non-profit.


Q: How can customers avoid the paper bag fee?
A: Customers can avoid the fee by bringing their own bag or opting not to receive a bag.


Q: Is it safe to use reusable bags?
A: Yes, reusable bags can be used safely with basic cleaning practices, such as washing them to prevent bacteria accumulation.


Q: How can a non-compliant business be reported?
A: Customers can report non-compliance to the City of Pittsburgh 311 Response Center or file an online request form under the "plastic bag ban compliance" request type.


Q: What is illegal dumping?
A: Illegal dumping is the improper and criminal act of disposing of municipal waste at unauthorized locations to avoid proper waste disposal responsibilities.


Q: How can illegal dumping be reported?
A: If illegal dumping is currently happening, call 911. If discovered after the fact, call 311.

Q: What is illegal dumping?
A: Illegal dumping is the improper and criminal act of disposing or abandoning municipal waste, such as household waste, construction waste, tires, furniture, and electronic waste, at unauthorized places like roadsides, open areas, and private property.


Q: How does illegal dumping affect the community?
A: Illegal dumping is a costly crime that negatively impacts local residents and taxpayers, costing $600 per ton to clean up, and it poses risks to public health, pollutes the environment, and reduces property values.


Q: What is the penalty for illegal dumping?
A: Illegal dumping can result in fines of up to $10,000.


Q: How can I report illegal dumping?
A: If you see illegal dumping happening, call 911. If you find illegal dumping after it occurred, call 311.


Q: Can I remove a "We Buy Houses" sign from a utility pole?
A: Yes, these are considered illegal bandit signs and can be removed by anyone. If unable to do so safely, report it to 311 for removal.


Q: How can I request a public trash can placement in my area?
A: You can request a trash can placement through the 311 service request system, though placement is subject to factors like safety and serviceability.


Q: How can I volunteer to install a public amenity in Pittsburgh?
A: Contact volunteer@pittsburghpa.gov with details of the work you want to perform, as public amenities require multiple approvals.


Q: What can I do to help keep Pittsburgh litter-free?
A: You can volunteer for clean-ups, organize clean-ups, or assist neighborhoods by coordinating or providing refreshments for volunteers.


Q: How should waste be disposed of to avoid illegal dumping?
A: Bulky waste not maintained by environmental services should be taken to an approved contracted transfer station as per the Allegheny County Municipal Solid Waste Management Plan.


Q: Can the city provide a specialist to talk with organizations about litter?
A: Yes, contact volunteer@pittsburghpa.gov to arrange a meeting with an anti-litter specialist, recycling specialist, or environmental enforcement coordinator.

Q: What should you do if you see illegal dumping happening?
A: Call 911.


Q: What should you do if you find illegal dumping after it has occurred?
A: Call 311.


Q: What information is important to report when you see illegal dumping?
A: License plate number, make and model of vehicle, description of materials dumped, location, and time and date of occurrence.


Q: Are you allowed to remove a "we buy houses" sign from a utility pole?
A: Yes, these signs are considered "litter on a stick" and can be taken down by anybody.


Q: How can you request a public trash can placement in your area?
A: Request through the 311 service request system.


Q: What is the cost difference between properly disposing of waste and cleaning up illegal dumping?
A: Proper disposal costs $60 per ton, while cleanup costs $600 per ton.


Q: What is the penalty for illegal dumping?
A: Fines of up to $10,000.


Q: How can you volunteer to help keep Pittsburgh litter-free?
A: Organize a clean-up and the Department of Public Works will provide supplies and pick up collected refuse.


Q: What constitutes illegal dumping?
A: The improper disposal or abandonment of municipal waste at unauthorized locations.


Q: How can you volunteer to install a public amenity in Pittsburgh?
A: Contact volunteer@pittsburghpa.gov with details of the work you want to perform.


Q: What should be done with bulky waste not maintained by environmental services?
A: It must be taken to a contracted transfer station approved by the Allegheny County Municipal Solid Waste Management Plan.


Q: Can the city provide a specialist to talk with organizations about litter issues?
A: Yes, contact volunteer@pittsburghpa.gov to arrange a meeting with a specialist.

Q: How should you report illegal dumping if it is happening currently?
A: Call 911.


Q: What should you do if you find illegal dumping after it has occurred?
A: Call 311.


Q: What information is helpful to report illegal dumping?
A: License plate number, vehicle make and model, description of dumped materials, location, and time and date of occurrence.


Q: Can you remove a "We Buy Houses" sign from a utility pole?
A: Yes, these are considered illegal bandit signs and can be taken down by anybody.


Q: How can you request a public trash can placement in your area?
A: Through the 311 service request system.


Q: How can you volunteer to install a public amenity like a garden or benches?
A: Contact volunteer@pittsburghpa.gov with details of the work you want to perform.


Q: What is the average cost of cleaning up a dump site compared to proper waste disposal?
A: Cleaning up a dump site costs on average $600 per ton, while proper disposal costs $60 per ton.


Q: What is the penalty for illegal dumping?
A: Fines of up to $10,000.


Q: How can you help keep Pittsburgh litter-free?
A: Volunteer for clean-ups or support neighborhood clean-ups through coordination or providing refreshments.


Q: What constitutes illegal dumping?
A: Improperly disposing of municipal waste like household waste, construction waste, or electronic waste at unauthorized locations.


Q: How can an organization arrange for a specialist to talk about litter and recycling?
A: Contact volunteer@pittsburghpa.gov to arrange a meeting with a specialist.


Q: How should bulky waste be disposed of to avoid illegal dumping?
A: Take it to a contracted transfer station approved by the Allegheny County Municipal Solid Waste Management Plan.

Q: How can individuals help keep Pittsburgh litter-free?
A: Individuals can volunteer to help clean up, organize clean-ups, or provide refreshments to volunteers. The Department of Public Works will provide supplies and pick up collected refuse.


Q: What is illegal dumping?
A: Illegal dumping is the improper disposal of municipal waste, such as household waste, construction waste, and electronic waste, in unauthorized areas like roadsides and vacant lots.


Q: How can waste be properly disposed of to avoid illegal dumping?
A: Bulky waste not maintained by environmental services should be taken to a contracted transfer station approved by the Allegheny County Municipal Solid Waste Management Plan.


Q: How should illegal dumping be reported?
A: If illegal dumping is happening currently, call 911. If discovered after the fact, call 311.


Q: Can the city provide a specialist for organizations wanting to address litter issues?
A: Yes, organizations can contact volunteer@pittsburghpa.gov to arrange a meeting with an anti-litter specialist, recycling specialist, or environmental enforcement coordinator.


Q: What is the penalty for illegal dumping in Pittsburgh?
A: Illegal dumping can result in fines of up to $10,000.


Q: Can individuals remove "We Buy Houses" signs from utility poles?
A: Yes, these are considered illegal bandit signs and can be taken down by anybody.


Q: How can someone request a public trash can placement?
A: Requests can be made through the 311 service request system, but placement depends on factors like safety and serviceability.


Q: How can someone volunteer to install public amenities in Pittsburgh?
A: Contact volunteer@pittsburghpa.gov with details of the project. Public amenities require multiple levels of approval.


Q: How does illegal dumping affect the community?
A: It is costly, negatively impacts taxpayers, risks public health, pollutes the environment, and reduces property values.

Q: What effect does litter on the ground have on people's behavior?
A: Studies have shown that having litter on the ground prompts more people to throw litter down than they would in an area with no litter.


Q: What support does the Department of Public Works offer for clean-up events in Pittsburgh?
A: The Department of Public Works provides supplies and pick-up of all collected refuse for clean-up events organized within the city of Pittsburgh.


Q: What is illegal dumping?
A: Illegal dumping is the improper and criminal act of disposing or abandoning municipal waste at unauthorized locations to avoid proper waste disposal responsibilities.

A: Organizations can contact volunteer@pittsburghpa.gov to arrange a meeting with an anti-litter specialist, recycling specialist, or environmental enforcement coordinator.

A: Bulky waste not maintained by environmental services must be taken to a contracted transfer station approved by the Allegheny County Municipal Solid Waste Management Plan.

A: If illegal dumping is happening currently, call 911.

A: If illegal dumping is discovered after it has occurred, call 311.

A: Yes, these signs are considered illegal bandit signs and can be removed by anyone.

A: Cleaning up illegal dump sites costs on average $600 per ton, compared to $60 per ton for proper disposal, affecting local resources and taxpayers.

Q: What is the policy of the City of Pittsburgh regarding discrimination on the basis of disability?
A: The City of Pittsburgh does not discriminate against individuals with disabilities in its services, programs, or activities, in accordance with Title II of the ADA.


Q: Who should be contacted for ADA accommodations in Pittsburgh?
A: Michelle Walker, the ADA Coordinator at the Mayor's Office of Equal Protection, should be contacted for ADA accommodations.


Q: What is the contact information for the ADA Coordinator in Pittsburgh?
A: The ADA Coordinator, Michelle Walker, can be reached at ada@pittsburghpa.gov.


Q: What should be done if there is disagreement with the outcome of an ADA accommodations request in Pittsburgh?
A: A grievance form should be completed to initiate a grievance with the City of Pittsburgh, which will be addressed within 15 days.

Q: Who should be contacted for ADA accommodations in Pittsburgh?
A: The City ADA Coordinator, Michelle Walker, should be contacted.


Q: What is the deadline for requesting ADA accommodations for an event in Pittsburgh?
A: Requests should be made as soon as possible, but no later than two business days before the event.


Q: Does the City of Pittsburgh discriminate on the basis of disability in employment?
A: No, the City of Pittsburgh does not discriminate on the basis of disability in its hiring or employment practices.


Q: What does the City of Pittsburgh provide to ensure effective communication for persons with disabilities?
A: The city will generally provide appropriate aids and services upon request.


Q: Will the City of Pittsburgh place a surcharge on individuals with disabilities for auxiliary aids or modifications?
A: No, the city will not place a surcharge on individuals with disabilities for these services.


Q: Where is the ADA Coordinator's office located in Pittsburgh?
A: Mayor's Office of Equal Protection, 414 Grant Street, 5th Floor, Pittsburgh, PA 15219.


Q: How long does the City of Pittsburgh take to address an ADA grievance?
A: The grievance will be addressed within 15 days.


Q: What should be included when contacting the ADA Coordinator for accommodations?
A: A completed ADA accommodations request form should be included.


Q: What act does the City of Pittsburgh comply with to prevent discrimination based on disability?
A: The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Title II.


Q: What does the City of Pittsburgh strive to ensure for all people in its programs and services?
A: The city strives to be inclusive of all people.

Q: Who should be contacted for accommodations related to effective communication or policy modifications in Pittsburgh?
A: The City ADA Coordinator, Michelle Walker, should be contacted.


Q: What is the email address for the City ADA Coordinator in Pittsburgh?
A: ada@pittsburghpa.gov


Q: Where is the office of the City ADA Coordinator located?
A: Mayor's Office of Equal Protection, 414 Grant Street, 5th Floor, Pittsburgh, PA 15219.


Q: How soon should one contact the City ADA Coordinator before an event requiring accommodations?
A: As soon as possible, but no later than two business days before the event.


Q: What should be included when contacting the City ADA Coordinator for accommodations?
A: A completed ADA Accommodations Request Form.


Q: How does the City of Pittsburgh handle grievances related to ADA accommodations?
A: By completing the ADA grievance form, which will be addressed within 15 days.


Q: What is the City of Pittsburgh's policy on surcharges for auxiliary aids/services or policy modifications for individuals with disabilities?
A: The city will not place a surcharge on individuals with disabilities to cover these costs.


Q: Does the City of Pittsburgh discriminate on the basis of disability in employment practices?
A: No, it complies with all regulations under the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission under Title I of the ADA.


Q: What does the City of Pittsburgh strive to provide for persons with disabilities?
A: Effective communication aids and services for equal participation in programs, services, and activities.


Q: What does the City of Pittsburgh's non-discrimination policy comply with?
A: Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).

Q: What is the purpose of the City of Pittsburgh's ADA accommodation policy?
A: To establish guidelines for making reasonable accommodations for qualified applicants and employees with disabilities, allowing them to perform essential job functions or enjoy equal employment opportunities.


Q: What does the City of Pittsburgh's ADA policy comply with?
A: The mandate of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA), which prohibits employment discrimination on the basis of disability.


Q: Who makes determinations on employee requests for ADA accommodations in Pittsburgh?
A: The ADA Accommodation Review Board.


Q: What is considered a "qualified applicant or employee" under Pittsburgh's ADA policy?
A: An individual with a disability who meets the requisite skill, experience, education, and other job-related requirements of a position and can perform essential functions with or without reasonable accommodation.


Q: What is defined as a "disability" under the ADA policy?
A: A physical, medical, mental, or psychological impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities, a history or record of such an impairment, or being regarded as having such an impairment.


Q: What constitutes "essential functions" of a job according to the policy?
A: The fundamental job duties of the employment position that an individual with a disability holds.


Q: What is "undue hardship" in the context of ADA accommodations?
A: An action that results in significant difficulty or expense to the employer, taking into account factors like employer size, resources, and operation nature.


Q: What are examples of "reasonable accommodation" as per the policy?
A: Adjustments to job duties, work environment, or performance methods, such as making facilities accessible, job restructuring, modified work schedules, or providing interpreters.


Q: How should documentation regarding an employee's medical condition be handled?
A: It must be collected on separate forms and maintained in separate medical files, treated as confidential medical records.


Q: What is the City of Pittsburgh-Allegheny County Task Force on Disabilities?
A: An advisory body established to advise on policies impacting citizens with disabilities, promote integration and employment, and address state and federal issues affecting people with disabilities.


Q: How many members are on the City-County Task Force on Disabilities, and how are they appointed?
A: Thirteen members; six appointed by the Allegheny County Chief Executive and six by the Mayor of Pittsburgh, each for a four-year term.

Q: How many members are initially appointed to the task force?
A: Twelve members are initially appointed.


Q: Who appoints the thirteenth member of the task force?
A: The twelve appointed members select the thirteenth member.


Q: What is the term length for the thirteenth member of the task force?
A: The term length is four years.


Q: Who has the authority to remove members from the task force?
A: The Allegheny County Chief Executive and the Mayor of Pittsburgh.


Q: What must the appointments to the task force represent?
A: A wide variety of disability groups, with geographic and ethnic balance.


Q: What majority is required among the task force members?
A: A majority must be individuals with disabilities.


Q: Are members of the task force financially compensated for their service?
A: No, members do not receive financial reimbursement other than costs associated with participation in meetings.


Q: What conditions can cause a task force member position to become vacant?
A: Withdrawal of application, failure to meet qualifications, voluntary resignation, or inability to serve.


Q: Who must a task force member notify to resign?
A: The chair or task force staff.


Q: How can a task force member be removed?
A: By the Mayor of Pittsburgh or Allegheny County Chief Executive.


Q: Who appoints a replacement if a member appointed by the Mayor resigns?
A: The Mayor of Pittsburgh.


Q: Who appoints a replacement if a member appointed by the Allegheny County Chief Executive resigns?
A: The Allegheny County Chief Executive.


Q: Can the task force petition for expansion?
A: Yes, they can petition the Mayor and the Allegheny County Chief Executive.


Q: How often must the task force meet annually?
A: At least four times per year.


Q: What act must all task force meetings comply with?
A: The State of Pennsylvania Sunshine Act.


Q: What is required for a quorum at a task force meeting?
A: The presence of the chairperson or co-chairperson.


Q: What are the officer positions within the task force?
A: Chairperson, Co-chairperson, Treasurer, and Board Member At-large.


Q: What is the term length for task force officers?
A: Two years.


Q: Who serves as the staff to the task force?
A: The ADA Coordinator, City of Pittsburgh.


Q: What must the task force keep detailed records of?
A: All income and expenditures.


Q: When does the street sweeping program in Pittsburgh begin and end?
A: Begins April 1 and ends November 30.


Q: How often are streets in heavily developed commercial business districts swept?
A: At least twice per week.


Q: Under what conditions is it required to clear sidewalks of ice and snow in Pittsburgh?
A: Within 24 hours after the fall of snow or accumulation of ice.


Q: What was the city's response to the 2010 blizzard regarding sidewalk snow removal citations?
A: A moratorium on issuing citations was placed during the state of emergency.

Q: What is the goal of Pittsburgh's street sweeping program?
A: The goal is to maintain Pittsburgh's streets on a regular basis by either machine sweeping, hand cleaning, or flushing.


Q: When does the street sweeping schedule begin and end in Pittsburgh?
A: The schedule begins on April 1 and ends on November 30.


Q: How are business districts in Pittsburgh cleaned to avoid disruption?
A: They are normally cleaned at night to avoid disrupting normal business activity and to take advantage of parking restrictions.


Q: What are the hours for neighborhood and residential street sweeping in Pittsburgh?
A: Neighborhood and residential street sweeping begins after 8 am and ends approximately at 2:30 pm.


Q: How often are streets in heavily developed commercial business districts cleaned?
A: Streets in these areas are swept and flushed at least twice per week.


Q: What is the cleaning frequency for neighborhood business districts and main streets?
A: These streets are swept or flushed once per week.


Q: How often are residential areas with limited traffic swept?
A: They are swept once or twice per month.


Q: How frequently are neighborhood streets used for local purposes swept?
A: These streets are swept or flushed two to four times per year.


Q: Who monitors the effectiveness of the street sweeping program in Pittsburgh?
A: The Public Works Administration staff closely monitors the program's effectiveness.

Q: When does the Department of Public Works' street sweeping program in Pittsburgh begin and end?
A: The street sweeping program begins on April 1 and ends on November 30.


Q: How are business districts in Pittsburgh typically cleaned under the street sweeping program?
A: Business districts are normally cleaned at night.


Q: What is the schedule for neighborhood and residential street sweeping in Pittsburgh?
A: Neighborhood and residential street sweeping begins after 8 am and ends approximately at 2:30 pm.


Q: How often are streets in Level 1 areas swept in Pittsburgh's street sweeping program?
A: Streets in Level 1 areas are swept and flushed at least twice per week.


Q: What level of service is provided to neighborhood business districts and main streets in Pittsburgh's street sweeping program?
A: Level 2 service, where streets are swept or flushed once per week.


Q: How frequently are residential areas with limited traffic swept in Pittsburgh's street sweeping program?
A: Residential areas in Level 3 are swept once or twice per month.


Q: What disaster events is Pittsburgh prone to?
A: Pittsburgh is prone to floods, severe winter storms, drought, tornadoes, windstorms, landslides, ground subsidence, and rare earthquakes.


Q: What role does the Department of Public Works play during disasters in Pittsburgh?
A: The Department of Public Works serves as the response crew for disaster situations.


Q: Are the leaders of the Department of Public Works in Pittsburgh trained for emergencies?
A: Yes, department leaders are certified in emergency preparedness.

Q: What is the purpose of the Pittsburgh paving program?
A: The program is to resurface streets all over the city during the 2023 paving season.


Q: How is the yearly paving list created in Pittsburgh?
A: It is based on criteria such as the street overall condition index (OCI), street use categories, and equity.


Q: What are the street use categories considered for paving in Pittsburgh?
A: Streets are categorized into primary, secondary, and tertiary.


Q: How can residents report street or road issues in Pittsburgh?
A: By filling out an online form at the 311 response center or calling 3-1-1 within Pittsburgh, or 412-255-2621 outside Pittsburgh.


Q: When is the paving scheduled for Council District 1 in 2024?
A: April 15th.


Q: What is the contact number for the City of Pittsburgh Geographic Information Systems?
A: (412) 255-2152.


Q: What is the role of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure (DOMI) in Pittsburgh?
A: DOMI works with community groups and council members to identify street surface issues and create the yearly paving list.


Q: What is the significance of the street overall condition index (OCI) in Pittsburgh's paving program?
A: It determines the priority for streets to be included in the yearly paving list based on their physical condition.


Q: What is the equity criterion used for in Pittsburgh's paving list?
A: To ensure tax dollars are applied fairly so that streets in neighborhoods with higher needs receive higher OCI scores.


Q: What is the schedule for paving in Council District 9 in 2024?
A: May 5th.

Q: When are calls to the 311 response center in Pittsburgh answered by a live operator?
A: Calls to the 311 response center are answered by a live operator from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.


Q: What is the paving schedule for Council District 1 in 2024?
A: April 15th.


Q: How can one report a street or road-related issue in Pittsburgh?
A: By filling out the online form on the 311 response center or calling 3-1-1 within Pittsburgh, or 412-255-2621 outside of Pittsburgh.


Q: What criteria are used by the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure to create the yearly paving list?
A: Street Overall Condition Index (OCI), street use (primary, secondary, tertiary), and equity.


Q: What is the date for the paving schedule in Council District 9 in 2024?
A: May 5th.


Q: Where can one view the map of roads repaved in Pittsburgh between 2019 and 2023?
A: At https://pittsburghpa.maps.arcgis.com/apps/dashboards/b7fd705ad59c40e0b08fbf4ac1323c7c


Q: What is the paving schedule for Council District 7 in 2024?
A: May 20th.


Q: How does the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure ensure equity in the paving schedule?
A: By applying an equity metric to ensure tax dollars are applied fairly, giving higher OCI scores to streets in neighborhoods with a higher need.

Q: How is the yearly paving list in Pittsburgh created?
A: The yearly paving list is created by the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure (DOMI) using criteria such as the Street Overall Condition Index (OCI), street use categories (primary, secondary, tertiary), and equity considerations.


Q: What is the Street Overall Condition Index (OCI)?
A: The OCI is a score given to every street in Pittsburgh based on its physical condition, which helps determine its priority on the yearly paving list.


Q: How are streets categorized for paving priorities?
A: Streets are categorized into primary, secondary, and tertiary, with primary roads receiving the most use and thus having their OCI scores drop more quickly.


Q: How can someone report a street or road-related issue in Pittsburgh?
A: Issues can be reported by filling out an online form at the 311 response center or by calling 3-1-1 within Pittsburgh or 412-255-2621 outside the city.


Q: What is the phone number to contact Pittsburgh's 311 response center from outside the city?
A: The phone number is 412-255-2621.


Q: When is Council District 1 scheduled for paving in 2024?
A: Council District 1 is scheduled for paving on April 15th, 2024.

A: The 5-year paving map can be viewed at https://pittsburghpa.maps.arcgis.com/apps/dashboards/b7fd705ad59c40e0b08fbf4ac1323c7c.


Q: What are the operating hours for Pittsburgh's 311 live operator service?
A: The operating hours are from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.

Q: What does PWSA stand for in the context of the paving schedule?
A: PWSA stands for Pittsburgh Water & Sewer Authority.


Q: Where can additional information about the PWSA paving schedule be found if a browser does not support inline frames?
A: Additional information can be found by visiting the PWSA restoration page.


Q: How can someone inquire further about the PWSA paving schedule?
A: They can email domitraffic@pittsburghpa.gov for further questions.


Q: What should residents look for on their streets regarding the PWSA paving schedule?
A: Residents should look for "no parking" signs and follow the day and time restrictions on the signs.


Q: What factors might cause the PWSA paving schedule to change?
A: The schedule might change or be postponed based on the weather and other factors.


Q: What is one of the main topics covered in the document alongside the PWSA paving schedule?
A: The document covers topics such as trash & recycling, ADA & disability rights, and road maintenance.


Q: Where can one find the curb ramp schedule if their browser does not support inline frames?
A: The curb ramp schedule can be accessed via a Google Sheets link provided in the document.

Q: What is the purpose of DOMI's neighborhood traffic calming program?
A: The program aims to increase the safety and comfort of people traveling by all modes through a neighborhood by reducing excessive motorist speeds on residential streets.


Q: What types of physical safety improvements are common in traffic calming measures?
A: Common improvements include speed humps, speed cushions, speed tables, raised crosswalks, pedestrian islands, traffic circles, changes to lane widths, and chicanes.


Q: What is not included in the neighborhood traffic calming program?
A: The program does not include larger-scale solutions to traffic congestion or speeding on higher-volume arterial streets, nor the use of stop signs as traffic calming measures.


Q: What are the eligibility criteria for a street to be considered for the traffic calming program?
A: The street must be owned by the City of Pittsburgh, have a maximum of two travel lanes if two-way and one lane if one-way, and be a local street or collector.


Q: How is a street evaluated for inclusion in the traffic calming program after passing the initial eligibility screen?
A: It is evaluated based on speed and volume of traffic, crash history, pedestrian generators, and presence of sidewalks, among other criteria.


Q: What data is used to evaluate traffic calming projects?
A: Data includes motorized vehicular volumes and speeds, number of reported crashes over a 3-year period, number of pedestrian generators, presence of sidewalks, and neighborhood equity score.


Q: What are the measures of success for the traffic calming program?
A: Success is measured by reductions in reported crashes, vehicular volume, and vehicular speeds (85th percentile).


Q: How can residents request traffic calming measures as of September 2023?
A: Requests can be made through a new map-based request portal that integrates eligibility requirements and provides status updates.


Q: What happens if a street is selected for a traffic calming project?
A: The resident who submitted the application and their council district will be notified before traffic calming elements are installed.


Q: What should be done if there are traffic-related or pedestrian safety issues at a particular intersection?
A: These concerns are best communicated with DOMI through the city’s 311 system.

Q: What types of projects typically do not affect on-street parking?
A: Projects that include speed humps or tables typically do not affect on-street parking.


Q: Can stop signs be used for traffic calming or speed reduction according to the MUTCD?
A: No, stop signs shall not be used as a means of traffic calming/speed reductions according to the MUTCD.


Q: How do speed humps, tables, or cushions affect emergency services and transit?
A: They cause minimal degradation of response time, usually measured in seconds, for EMS and transit vehicles.


Q: What should be done if vehicles are parked on the sidewalk?
A: Report the infraction to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police or the Pittsburgh Parking Authority, as it is a ticketable offense.


Q: What is the purpose of DOMI's Neighborhood Traffic Calming Program?
A: To increase the safety and comfort of people traveling by reducing excessive motorist speeds on residential neighborhood streets.


Q: What types of traffic calming measures are commonly used?
A: Speed humps, speed cushions, speed tables, raised crosswalks, pedestrian islands, traffic circles, changes to lane widths, and chicanes.


Q: What criteria must a street meet to be eligible for the Neighborhood Traffic Calming Program?
A: The street must be owned by the City of Pittsburgh, have a maximum of two travel lanes if two-way, one travel lane if one-way, and be a local street or collector.


Q: What data is used for traffic calming evaluations?
A: Motorized vehicular volumes and speeds, number of reported crashes in a 3-year period, number of pedestrian generators within 1-2 blocks, presence of sidewalks, and neighborhood equity score.


Q: What are the measures of success for the traffic calming program?
A: Reduction in reported crashes, reduction in volume, and reduction in vehicular speeds (85th percentile).


Q: How can requests for traffic calming be made as of September 2023?
A: Through a new request portal with a map-based system that integrates eligibility requirements and provides status updates.


Q: What happens if a street passes the eligibility screen for traffic calming?
A: Staff will collect speed and volume data, and the street will be placed on the eligible list if it meets the speed threshold.


Q: Why might there not be a public meeting for a traffic calming project?
A: The city reserves the right to make necessary safety improvements beneficial to the greater good without public input unless the project scope changes parking or traffic operations.

Q: Can drivers park on top of speed humps or tables?
A: Yes, drivers may park on top of speed humps or tables.


Q: Is it possible to install a stop sign to slow down traffic?
A: No, stop signs are not used for traffic calming or speed reduction; they are used to designate right-of-way.


Q: How do speed humps/tables/cushions affect emergency services and transit?
A: They cause minimal degradation of response time, usually measured in seconds.


Q: What should be done if vehicles are parked on sidewalks?
A: Report the infraction to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police or the Pittsburgh Parking Authority, as city code prohibits parking on sidewalks.


Q: What is the purpose of DOMI’s neighborhood traffic calming program?
A: To increase safety and comfort by reducing excessive motorist speeds on residential neighborhood streets.


Q: What types of physical safety improvements are part of traffic calming measures?
A: Speed humps, speed cushions, speed tables, raised crosswalks, pedestrian islands, traffic circles, changes to lane widths, and chicanes.


Q: What criteria must a street meet to be eligible for the neighborhood traffic calming program?
A: The street must be owned by the City of Pittsburgh, have a maximum of two travel lanes if two-way and one lane if one-way, and be a local street or collector.


Q: What data is used for traffic calming evaluations?
A: Motorized vehicular volumes and speeds, number of reported crashes in a 3-year period, number of pedestrian generators, presence of sidewalks, and neighborhood equity score.


Q: What measures of success are used for the traffic calming program?
A: Reduction in reported crashes, reduction in volume, and reduction in vehicular speeds (85th percentile).


Q: How are requests for traffic calming made as of September 2023?
A: Through a new request portal that integrates eligibility requirements and provides status updates.


Q: What happens if a street meets all eligibility criteria for traffic calming but is not selected?
A: The street remains on the list of potential projects for the following year due to limited funding.


Q: Why might there not be a public meeting for a traffic calming project?
A: The city reserves the right to make necessary safety improvements without public input unless the project scope changes parking or traffic operations.

Q: How do speed humps, tables, and cushions affect emergency services and transit?
A: They cause minimal degradation of response time, usually measured in seconds, and are coordinated with public safety and Pittsburgh Regional Transit.


Q: What is the purpose of speed tables on primary emergency response routes?
A: Speed tables are deployed for speed control measures on primary emergency response routes identified by public safety.


Q: What should be done if vehicles are parked on the sidewalk?
A: Report the infraction to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police or the Pittsburgh Parking Authority, as city code prohibits parking on sidewalks.


Q: What is the goal of DOMI's neighborhood traffic calming program?
A: To increase safety and comfort by reducing excessive motorist speeds on residential neighborhood streets.


Q: What types of physical safety improvements are used in traffic calming?
A: Speed humps, speed cushions, speed tables, raised crosswalks, pedestrian islands, traffic circles, lane width changes, and chicanes.


Q: What types of streets are eligible for the neighborhood traffic calming program?
A: Streets owned by the City of Pittsburgh, with a maximum of two travel lanes if two-way or one travel lane if one-way, and must be a local street or collector.


Q: What criteria are used to evaluate traffic calming project applications?
A: Speed, volume, crash history, pedestrian generators, presence of sidewalks, and the DOMI equity index.


Q: How can residents request traffic calming measures?
A: Through a new request portal available as of September 2023, which integrates eligibility requirements and provides status updates.


Q: Why are stop signs not used for traffic calming?
A: Because the MUTCD states stop signs should not be used for speed reductions but to designate right-of-way.


Q: What are the measures of success for the traffic calming program?
A: Reduction in reported crashes, reduction in volume, and reduction in vehicular speeds (85th percentile).


Q: Can traffic calming projects affect on-street parking?
A: Yes, reductions in on-street parking are possible depending on the project scope, but typically speed humps or tables do not change parking. Temporary no parking signs may be installed during construction.

Q: What are speed tables and how do they function in traffic calming?
A: Speed tables are similar to speed humps but have a modified flat top that raises the entire wheelbase of a vehicle to reduce its speed, creating a more undulating traffic calming measure.


Q: What should be done if people are parking on the sidewalk?
A: City code prohibits vehicles from parking or stopping on sidewalks, and these infractions are ticket-able offenses that should be reported to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police or the Pittsburgh Parking Authority.


Q: What is the aim of the DOMI's Neighborhood Traffic Calming Program?
A: The program aims to increase the safety and comfort of people traveling by all modes through a neighborhood by reducing excessive motorist speeds on residential neighborhood streets.


Q: What types of streets are eligible for the Neighborhood Traffic Calming Program?
A: Eligible streets must be owned by the City of Pittsburgh, have a maximum of two travel lanes if two-way or one travel lane if one-way, and be a local street or collector.


Q: What criteria are used to evaluate streets for traffic calming projects?
A: Criteria include speed, volume, crash history, pedestrian generators, presence of sidewalks, and the DOMI equity index.


Q: What measures are typically not included in the traffic calming program?
A: The program does not include larger-scale solutions to traffic congestion or speeding on higher-volume arterial streets, nor does it include regulatory measures like stop signs for traffic calming.


Q: How can residents request traffic calming measures as of September 2023?
A: Requests can be made through a new map-based request portal that integrates eligibility requirements and provides status updates.


Q: What data is used for traffic calming evaluations?
A: Data includes motorized vehicular volumes and speeds, number of reported crashes in a 3-year period, number of pedestrian generators within 1-2 blocks, presence of sidewalks, neighborhood equity score, and connection to existing plans.


Q: Why might there not be a public meeting for a traffic calming project?
A: Public meetings usually occur if the project scope makes changes to parking or traffic operations, but the city reserves the right to make necessary safety improvements without public input.


Q: Can stop signs be used as a means of traffic calming?
A: No, the MUTCD states that stop signs shall not be used for traffic calming or speed reductions; they are intended to designate right-of-way.

Q: What is the purpose of stop signs according to the text?
A: Stop signs are used to designate right-of-way for drivers at intersections.


Q: How do speed humps/tables/cushions affect emergency services and transit?
A: They cause a minimal degradation of response time for EMS and transit vehicles.


Q: What is the difference between speed humps and speed tables?
A: Speed tables have a modified flat top that raises the entire wheelbase of a vehicle to reduce its speed.

A: Report the infraction to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police or the Pittsburgh Parking Authority, as it is a ticketable offense.

A: To increase safety and comfort by reducing excessive motorist speeds on residential streets.

Q: What are the measures of success for the traffic calming program?
A: Reduction in reported crashes, reduction in volume, and reduction in vehicular speeds (85th percentile).

A: No, stop signs are not used for traffic calming or speed reduction.


Q: What data is used for traffic calming evaluations?
A: Motorized vehicular volumes and speeds, number of reported crashes in a 3-year period, number of pedestrian generators, presence of sidewalks, and neighborhood equity score.

Q: What data is used for traffic calming evaluations?
A: Traffic calming evaluations use data on motorized vehicular volumes and speeds (mph), number of reported crashes in a 3-year period, number of pedestrian generators within 1-2 blocks, presence of sidewalks, neighborhood equity score, and connection to existing plans.


Q: What are the measures of success for the traffic calming program?
A: The measures of success include reduction in reported crashes, reduction in volume, and reduction in vehicular speeds (85th percentile).


Q: Why wasn't there a public meeting for the traffic calming project?
A: Public meetings are not required for all projects. The city reserves the right to make necessary safety improvements without public input unless the project scope changes parking or traffic operations.


Q: Will the traffic calming project affect parking?
A: Reductions in on-street parking are possible depending on the project scope, but for projects with speed humps or tables, there will usually be no changes to parking.


Q: Can a stop sign be installed to slow down traffic?
A: No, the MUTCD states that stop signs shall not be used as a means of traffic calming or speed reduction.


Q: How do speed humps/tables affect emergency services and transit?
A: There is minimal degradation of response time for EMS and transit vehicles, and the department coordinates projects with public safety and Pittsburgh Regional Transit.


Q: What can be done about vehicles parking on sidewalks?
A: Parking on sidewalks is prohibited by city code and is a ticket-able offense, which should be reported to the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police or the Pittsburgh Parking Authority.


Q: What is an autonomous vehicle?
A: An autonomous vehicle is capable of sensing its environment and moving safely with little or no human input, with current testers in Pittsburgh using Level 4 autonomous driving systems.


Q: What is the purpose of the Pennsylvania Safety Transportation and Research Track (PennSTART)?
A: PennSTART aims to provide a facility focused on modernizing and enhancing training for first responders and testing autonomous technologies.


Q: Who are the current autonomous vehicle testers in the Pittsburgh region?
A: Current testers include Aurora Innovation, Inc., Carnegie Mellon University AV Center, and Motional.


Q: What are Personal Delivery Devices (PDDs)?
A: PDDs are ground delivery devices operated autonomously or remotely, weighing less than 550 pounds without cargo, and can operate on sidewalks, shoulders, and bicycle lanes.


Q: What was the purpose of Pittsburgh's pilot program with PDD operator Kiwibot?
A: The pilot aimed to provide experience with PDDs to create informed local policies before widespread deployment.

Q: What is an autonomous vehicle (AV)?
A: An autonomous vehicle is a vehicle capable of sensing its environment and moving safely with little or no human input.


Q: What level of autonomous driving systems are being tested in Pittsburgh?
A: All AV testers in Pittsburgh are testing level 4 autonomous driving systems, which can perform all driving functions under certain conditions.


Q: Which company in Pittsburgh has shifted focus to autonomous trucking?
A: Aurora Innovation, Inc. has shifted focus to develop autonomous trucking.


Q: What did House Bill 2398 establish in Pennsylvania in 2022?
A: House Bill 2398 established Pennsylvania's regulatory framework for autonomous vehicles and moved authority over autonomous technologies to the state level.


Q: What is the purpose of the Pennsylvania Safety Transportation and Research Track (PennSTART)?
A: PennSTART aims to provide a facility for modernizing and enhancing training for first responders and for testing and refining autonomous technologies.


Q: Where is the PennSTART facility located?
A: The PennSTART facility is located adjacent to RIDC Westmoreland’s site in Mount Pleasant, Pennsylvania.


Q: What are personal delivery devices (PDDs) under state law?
A: PDDs are ground delivery devices for transporting cargo or goods, operated remotely or autonomously, and weighing less than 550 pounds without cargo.


Q: What requirement must companies meet to operate PDDs in Pittsburgh?
A: Companies must submit an application to PennDOT and receive authorization to operate PDDs in Pittsburgh.


Q: Which organization supported a pilot program with PDD operator Kiwibot in Bloomfield?
A: The Knight Foundation supported the pilot program with Kiwibot.


Q: What is the goal of Pittsburgh's initiative with the Knight Foundation regarding autonomous mobility?
A: The goal is to engage local residents around new mobility technologies to ensure they reflect community input and meet local needs.


Q: Which institutions are current autonomous vehicle testers in the Pittsburgh region?
A: Aurora Innovation, Inc., Carnegie Mellon University AV Center, and Motional are current AV testers in the Pittsburgh region.

Q: What is the purpose of Pittsburgh's initiative with the Knight Foundation from 2018 to 2023?
A: The initiative aimed to support autonomous mobility pilot projects and engage local residents around new mobility technologies to ensure they reflect community input and meet local needs.


Q: What level of autonomous driving systems are being tested in Pittsburgh?
A: Level 4 autonomous driving systems, as defined by the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE).


Q: What is the role of PennDOT regarding autonomous vehicles in Pennsylvania?
A: PennDOT is the authority managing issues related to autonomous vehicles in Pennsylvania, following the establishment of the regulatory framework by House Bill 2398 in 2022.


Q: What facility is being developed by PennDOT in southwestern Pennsylvania?
A: The Pennsylvania Safety Transportation and Research Track (PennSTART), focused on modernizing and enhancing training for first responders and providing a space for testing and refining autonomous technologies.


Q: Which companies are current autonomous vehicle testers in the Pittsburgh region?
A: Aurora Innovation, Inc. (Aurora), Carnegie Mellon University (CMU AV Center), and Motional.


Q: What is a Personal Delivery Device (PDD) according to state law?
A: A ground delivery device manufactured for transporting cargo or goods, operated by a remote or autonomous system, and weighing less than 550 pounds without cargo.


Q: What was the purpose of the pilot program with PDD operator Kiwibot in Bloomfield?
A: To provide city staff and residents with experience with personal delivery devices and to create informed local policies before widespread PDD deployment.

A: The facility focuses on transportation safety, research, and operational needs, emphasizing traffic incident management, connected and autonomous vehicles, tolling, traffic signals, work zones, commercial vehicles, and transit vehicles.


Q: What is a Personal Delivery Device (PDD) according to state law?
A: A PDD is a ground delivery device for transporting cargo or goods, operated by a remote or autonomous system, weighing less than 550 pounds without cargo, and may operate on sidewalks, shoulders, and bicycle lanes.

A: Aurora Innovation, Inc. (Aurora), Carnegie Mellon University AV Center, and Motional.

A: To provide city staff and residents experience with PDDs to create informed local policies before widespread deployment.


Q: What is the focus of Pittsburgh's shared and autonomous mobility principles?
A: To shape the development of autonomous technology and policy to achieve mobility goals and avoid unintended consequences like sprawl and congestion.

A: Level 4 autonomous driving systems, capable of performing all driving functions under certain conditions.

A: It set up Pennsylvania’s regulatory framework around autonomous vehicles and moved authority over autonomous technologies to the state level, with PennDOT managing related issues.

A: To support autonomous mobility pilot projects and engage local residents around new mobility technologies to ensure they reflect community input and meet local needs.

A: A facility in southwestern Pennsylvania focused on modernizing training for first responders and providing a space for testing and refining autonomous technologies.


Q: What is a Personal Delivery Device (PDD) according to state law?
A: A ground delivery device manufactured for transporting cargo or goods, operated by a driving system allowing remote or autonomous operation, and weighing less than 550 pounds without cargo.


Q: Which companies are current autonomous vehicle testers in the Pittsburgh region?
A: Aurora - Aurora Innovation, Inc., Carnegie Mellon University - CMU AV Center, and Motional.

A: To provide city staff and residents experience with personal delivery devices (PDDs) and create informed local policies before widespread deployment.


Q: What regulatory changes occurred in 2022 regarding autonomous vehicles in Pennsylvania?
A: House Bill 2398 set up Pennsylvania's regulatory framework around autonomous vehicles, moving authority over autonomous technologies to the state level with PennDOT now managing related issues.

Q: What authority does PennDOT have regarding personal delivery devices in Pennsylvania?
A: State law gives PennDOT the authority to authorize a personal delivery device provider to operate in the state.

A: A company must submit an application to PennDOT and receive authorization.

A: The pilot was intended to provide city staff and residents experience with personal delivery devices to create informed local policies before widespread deployment.
